PRESIDENCY OF THE PRESIDENT 4 One of the Court's main objectives and part of its mission to promote transparency and accountability is to bring the European Court of Auditors closer to EU citizens.
It is therefore a great pleasure for me to welcome you as a reader of the first annual activity report of the European Court of Auditors.
The report aims to provide an overall view of the Court and to report on its activities in 2007, the year in which it celebrates its 30th anniversary as an external auditor of the European Union, which, according to its mission, contributes to improving EU financial management and acts as an independent guardian of the financial interests of the Union's citizens.
The Court makes its main contribution through its audits and reports, which enable the audited body to improve its financial management, and assist the discharge authority (European Parliament and Council) in its monitoring of the implementation of the EU budget.
This report provides an overview of the audit reports published in 2007 and highlights the main conclusions regarding the implementation of the 2006 EU budget and the sound financial management of EU funds.
The Court not only reports on the financial management of past years, but also actively participates in the establishment of an EU financial control framework.
2007 was a very important year for EU financial management.
The section entitled "The Court's position" outlines the Court's view on important developments related to Member States' accountability and the Court's contribution to the public consultation on budgetary reform launched by the European Commission.
None of the Court's 2007 results would be conceivable without the commitment, know-how and competence of its 850 staff.
Staff are the main capital of a future-oriented authority which strives for constant improvement.
This first annual activity report contains details of the Court's reform process, which was launched in 2006 with a self-assessment.
Progress has been made in implementing the resulting Action Plan in 2007 and a peer review process was launched at the end of the year, led by a group of auditors from Canada, Austria, Norway and Portugal's national audit offices.
The first result of this reform process was the following statement on the Court's mission, mission statement, values and strategic objectives, which will guide the future activities on which the Court will report in due course.
I wish you much pleasure in reading the first Annual Activity Report and I hope it will be of benefit to you.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5
6 TERMS, GUIDELINE, VALUES AND STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES TERMS OF TRANSFER The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, he contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
7 VALUES Independence, integrity & impartiality Professionalism Added value Excellence & efficiency Independence, integrity and impartiality for the body, its members and employees.
provide its addressee with appropriate test results, rejecting any form of influence by instructions or pressure from the outside.
Maintaining a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
To draw up relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and supporting documents, taking into account the concerns of its addressees and containing important and indicative statements.
To contribute to an effective improvement in the management of the EU budget and to strengthening accountability for the management of EU financial resources.
Promote team spirit through effective communication.
STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES In order to fulfil its mandate, the European Court of Auditors has stated its commitment to the following strategic objectives: Professionalism Output Target group Development & Growth Consolidated audit methods, appropriate audit strategy, further development of audit practices in the public sector, development of common audit standards and comparable audit benchmarks for EU funds, cooperation with the EU-ORCB, effective ‘Community control framework', selection of relevant audit topics, timeliness, clarity and legibility of reports, quality of economic audits, increasing the impact of reports Deeper relations with audited bodies in order to promote a better understanding of the audit process and to achieve wider acceptance of audit results; strengthening contacts with the European Parliament and the Council as budgetary and discharge authority; effective communication with EU citizens taking advantage of experience with the peer review process in order to strengthen and develop methods, results and maximise efficiency; pursuing an effective and dynamic staff policy; quality of vocational training; modernising infrastructure; implementing IT strategies
8 ROLE AND WORK OF THE HOF WHAT ROLE HAS THE HOF?
The European Union's budget amounts to around EUR 120 billion, representing about 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States.
This represents a small share compared to national budgets.
For some Member States, however, EU funds play an important role in financing public activities. For example, the overall budget volume is close to the GNI of some countries, such as Romania.
The composition of the budget has changed over time, with agriculture and cohesion policy being the main areas of expenditure (see Box 1).
The budget shall be established annually, on the basis of the seven-year financial framework, by the Council, i.e. representatives of the Member States, and by the directly elected European Parliament on a proposal from the European Commission.
The Commission is responsible for the budget itself, but shares a significant share of the administrative tasks with the Member States, particularly with regard to expenditure on agricultural and cohesion policy.
Depending on the expenditure regime, national authorities may be responsible for defining spending strategies, selecting beneficiaries and projects and making payments.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on applications from beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union.
9 BOX 1 – HOW DOES THE EU DISCRIMINATE?
The EU budget is largely used for uses other than national budgets, partly because of the different areas of responsibility.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually account for a large part of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which usually takes the form of payments to farmers throughout the Union, has been the main part of budgetary expenditure, albeit at present with a decreasing trend.
In 2008, a little less than half of the budget is earmarked for the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development.
Since the 1980s, a significant part of the expenditure has been devoted to cohesion – i.e. regional and social development – to co-finance a wide range of projects, from road construction in Slovakia to training courses for the unemployed in Denmark.
In 2008, expenditure on sustainable growth, of which the lion's share of cohesion, was estimated at 38% of the budget.
This heading also covers a large part of the EU's research funding.
About 6% of the budget is spent on the administration of the Community institutions.
EU expenditure Citizenship, freedom, security and justice 1% The European Union as a global player 6% Administration 6% Cohesion – Sustainable growth 38% Agriculture – Conservation and management of natural resources 49%
Democratic societies need complete and accurate publicly available information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both with a view to improving financial management and ensuring accountability.
In its role as external auditor of the EU, the European Court of Auditors ensures that the EU funds have been properly accounted for, irrespective of their place of use, and spent in accordance with the legislation, taking due account of the optimum use of funds.
The Court's audit results are used by the Commission, Parliament and the Council as well as by Member States to improve EU financial management.
In addition to the Court's work, many national control authorities are examining EU funds if they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
Overview of internal and external control of EU budget EU level 10 Commission (DG, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing Bodies European Court of Auditors National control authorities National level External control Internal control
What are the audit findings of the Court? The Court applies three different types of audits 1: auditing of the accounts, compliance audit (compliance with legal requirements) and auditing of the accounts, depending on which of the three following questions is the starting point of the audit: 11 • • • Does the annual accounts provide a true and fair view of the financial situation, results and cash flows for the year in accordance with the accounting framework in force?
Under the EC Treaty, the Court is obliged to make such a statement – or a judgment on the audit – on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The annual Statement of Assurance is generally known under the French acronym DAS (Déclaration d'Assurance).
1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
The Court shall carry out its audit of the annual accounts of the EU in accordance with International Audit Principles (ISAs), which shall apply in both the public and the private sectors.
The Court, together with the national control authorities, actively participates in the further development of international audit standards, which was promoted by the standardisation bodies (Intosai, IFAC).
In order to ensure that payments are consistent with the legislation and frameworks, the Court is based on the results of both its examination of the monitoring and control systems to prevent, detect and correct errors in legality and regularity and a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Where systems are reviewed and found to be reliable, the number of transactions to be audited by the Court will be reduced in order to arrive at a sound conclusion as to their legality and regularity.
When selecting issues for its economic impact assessments, the Court strives to identify areas where the greatest impact is to be expected in terms of the potential for improvement identified in terms of the economy, cost-effectiveness and effectiveness of EU expenditure.
12 2 Intosai (International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions) International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions – IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) International Association of Accountants.
13 BOX 2 – THE COURT'S PRE-ROUND TESTS RELATING TO PAYMENTS RELATING TO THE EU BUDGET The Court does not have the necessary resources to examine in detail all the operations of the EU budget.
The Court shall monitor these operations until the final beneficiary of the aid, such as a farmer in southern Germany.
The Court will then carry out on-the-spot checks, such as the measurement of the size of the agricultural area, to determine whether the relevant information in the aid application corresponds to the actual circumstances.
The population of all agricultural payments By being a statistical sample, the results can be extrapolated to the relevant population, i.e. a specific area of revenue or expenditure, and together with information resulting from the system evaluation can serve as the basis for an overall audit opinion.
This graph shows how the Court proceeds to identify operations for the purposes of the in-depth review.
In practice, the Court's sampling procedures are more complex, e.g. a two-stage sampling procedure is used to improve the efficiency of the audit work.

14 PREPARATION STRUCTURE AND ORGANISATION BUILDING THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body of 27 members, each with one member per Member State.
As the Organigram shows (see page 17), there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas (preserving and managing natural resources – structural policies, transport, research and energy – external policies – own resources, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies).
The fifth audit group (CEAD or coordination, communication, evaluation, quality assurance and development) is responsible for "horizontal issues such as coordination in the field of statement of assurance, quality assurance, the development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, a Management Committee composed of members of all audit groups shall be responsible for preparing all administrative matters requiring a formal Court decision.
MEMBERS The members of the Court shall be appointed by the Council, after consulting the European Parliament, for a term of six years in accordance with the proposals made by each Member State and shall be eligible for re-election.
In addition to its role within the College, which is responsible for final decision-making on audits and opinions, as well as on further strategic and administrative issues, each Member is primarily responsible for his or her specific tasks in the audit area.
The member shall then present the report to the audit group or to the Court and, after its adoption by the European Parliament, the Council and other interested third parties.
With the accession of Bulgaria and Romania on 1 January 2007, the Court welcomed two new members, Ms Nadeschda Sandolova and Mr Ovidiu Ispir.
One year later, on 1 January 2008, the Court accepted three other new members, Mr Michel Cretin (France), Mr Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) and Mr Harald Noack (Germany), as the term of office of its predecessors had expired.
The Council also extended the term of office of four members (Greece, the Netherlands, Austria and the United Kingdom) for a further six years.

16 THE PRESIDENT The European Court of Auditors is headed by the President, who is elected by the members from among them for a period of three years, with re-election allowed.
The role of the President is that of a Primus inter Pares.
The President shall represent the Court in all its external relations, in particular in its relations with the discharge authority, with the other institutions of the European Union and with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States and beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, the Portuguese Member, was elected 11th President of the Court.
THE DIRECTORATE-GENERAL SECRETARY The Secretary-General is the highest-ranking member of the institution and is appointed by the Court for a period of six years, and may be re-elected.
The Secretary-General shall be responsible for the staff and administration of the Court, including professional training and the Translation Directorate, each with one unit per official language (22), excluding Gaelic.
The Secretary-General is also under the responsibility of the General Secretariat.
The term of office of the current Secretary-General of the Court, Mr Michel Hervé, was extended on 1 July 2007.
THE HOFES PERSON The staff of the European Court of Auditors is approximately 850 staff (836 on 31 December 2007) and includes auditors (484), translators (162) and administrative staff.
The Court's auditors have a wide range of training profiles and relevant professional experience in both the public and private sectors, in particular in the fields of accounting, financial management, internal and external audit, and law and economics.
Like the other EU institutions, the Court employs nationals from all Member States.
18 OVERVIEW OF THE AUDIT REPORTS AND 3 OPINIONS OF THE COURT The results of the Court's audits of the accounts and compliance audits are mostly incorporated into annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds (EDFs), as well as in the special annual reports on the Union agencies and bodies.
The results of the audits will be published in the course of the year in the form of special reports.
The Court also publishes opinions on draft legislative acts affecting financial management.
ANNUAL REPORTS ON THE FINANCIAL YEAR 2006 ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET As the Court has repeatedly stated in its annual reports on the implementation of the EU's general budget, adequate and appropriate internal control systems set up by the Commission and the Member States are essential to ensuring proper EU budget management.
In recent years, the Court has recognised the Commission's efforts to promote and apply improved internal control and administrative procedures, both with regard to the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the operations recorded therein.
The 2006 Annual Report continued this tradition by identifying areas where there is – sometimes considerable – need for improvement, as well as identifying large areas of expenditure where the situation remains unsatisfactory.
The Court concluded that the ‘final accounts of the European Communities, which show the implementation of the EU budget for 2006, give a true and fair view of the financial situation and results of the Communities, except for the designation of excessive amounts in accounting liabilities and pre-financing in the balance sheet.
Further improvements are therefore considered necessary in order to ensure that the newly introduced accrual accounting function fully satisfactorily and that its potential as a reliable management and control tool can be fully exploited.
3 This section is intended to introduce the Court's reports and opinions rather than its summary.
More detailed information can be found in the full text of the Court documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
As regards the expenditure areas identified in the ‘Final accounts of the European Communities', in which most payments are made – agriculture [mainly agricultural expenditure not subject to the Integrated Administration and Control System (IPCoS), structural measures, internal policies and large parts of external policies – the Court makes a negative assessment of the legality and regularity of these expenditure areas and concludes that they continue to be significantly affected by errors.
In the case of payments in these areas, the monitoring and control systems could only partially limit the risk of errors of legality and regularity in the transactions.
The Court stresses that complicated or unclear eligibility criteria or complex legislation have had a significant impact on the legality and regularity of transactions.
However, the Court noted a significant decrease in the estimated total error rate in agricultural operations and concluded that, where properly applied, the IACS is an effective system to reduce the risk of irregular expenditure.
Moreover, the Court noted that the operations underlying commitments and revenue had no significant errors, including payments related to administrative expenditure, the bulk of the pre-accession strategy and parts of external policies (see Box 3). 19

The systems are classified as "partly satisfactory" if some control arrangements have been found to work properly while others have not.
As a result, they may not be able, overall, to limit the errors in the underlying transactions to a tolerable level.
The report highlights a number of shortcomings in the "functioning of monitoring and control systems".
The table only highlights the key statements, but the details cannot be fully presented.

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE EUROPEAN DEVELOPMENT FUND (EDF) In 2007, the Court also published an annual report on the European Development Funds (EDF).
While the Court was able to give an unqualified opinion on the reliability of the accounts of the EDFs, the audit opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying payments authorised under the responsibility of delegations in the beneficiary countries was limited in view of the substantial error rate in these transactions.
OTHER ANNUAL REPORTS In addition, a further 28 special annual reports on the European agencies and other decentralised bodies and an annual report on the audit of the efficiency of the management of the European Central Bank were published in 2007. 21
SPECIAL REPORTS PUBLISHED IN 2007 The Court published nine special reports in 2007.
The reports covered studies of financial management issues in many different fields, ranging from VAT cooperation (No 8/2007) to capacity building in countries as far away as Angola and Vietnam (No 6/2007).
The Court's tests revealed problems of various kinds with various consequences.
The weaknesses identified by the Court in relation to the EU institutions' expenditure on buildings (No 2/2007) show that not all EU funds have been used properly in this area.
The shortcomings identified in the report on the monitoring, inspection and sanctioning systems concerning the rules for the conservation of Community fisheries resources (No 7/2007) could have serious consequences not only for aquatic resources but also for the future of the fisheries industry.
Despite the different ways in which funds are used in the various areas of the EU budget, the Court reports identify several common issues which can be defined as follows: 22 • • • While the use of funds should be both swift and efficient, efforts to achieve these two goals at the same time can create a tension.
This is the subject of the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (No 1/2007) and the report on the Commission's management of the CARDS programme in the countries of the Western Balkans (No 5/2007).
Although planning does not guarantee effectiveness, it is of major importance.
Issues relating to strategic and long-term planning were raised in the reports on the EU institutions' expenditure on buildings (No 2/2007) and on the evaluation of the EU framework programmes for research and technological development (RTD) (No 9/2007) as well as in two reports relating to external assistance, one relating to the CARDS programme (No 5/2007) and the other to the effectiveness of technical assistance in the context of capacity-building (No 6/2007).
The Commission's evaluations are a key element of its performance management system when it comes to assessing performance and, where necessary, identifying the need for improvement.
If evaluations take place at an early stage of the programming cycle, this means that progress is insufficient and that insufficient relevant data are available for evaluation purposes.
On the other hand, the possibility of making timely changes during the current period and improvements before the start of the next one may be reduced if evaluations are carried out at a later date.
The issue of the correct timing of evaluations was addressed both in the report on the mid-term processes of the Structural Funds (N° 1/2007) and in the report on RTD evaluation (N° 9/2007).
23 • • evaluations as well as audits are more difficult to carry out if the objectives of the spending programmes are unclear; this was another topic discussed in the latter two reports.
The management and control of EU expenditure is subject to complex regulations, which must be clearly and unambiguously formulated in order to ensure that the funds are used for the intended purposes.
The existence of clear definitions and rules is crucial if funds are to be collected or used as planned.
This was covered in the reports on the European Refugee Fund (No. 3/2007) and on checks on goods and substitution of Member States when exporting agricultural products (No. 4/2007).
The lack of common definitions is one of the factors which may affect the completeness, comparability and reliability of data collected from the different Member States.
This can have consequences if the data is the basis for decisions such as the allocation of funds.

OPINIONS PUBLISHED IN 2007 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management by delivering opinions on proposals or budgetary management issues.
These opinions are required as part of the adoption procedure of financial regulations 4 or may be submitted at the request of one of the other Community institutions 5. In addition, the Court may submit opinions on its own initiative.
The Court's opinions may address questions relating to specific areas of expenditure, such as the two opinions of 2007 concerning new Regulations for the European Development Funds (Nos 2/2007 and 9/2007).
They may also cover broader issues of EU financial management, such as the Court's opinion on annual summaries, national declarations and the audit work of national audit bodies (No 6/2007).
Opinions are based on the Court's expertise on EU financial management over the course of the years in the course of its audits and, in some cases, reference is made to certain audits.
For example, in the opinion on ensuring the proper application of customs and agricultural rules (No 3/2007), the Court refers to a recommendation in an earlier special report that the Commission should take measures to improve the reliability of sources of information on fraud.
The need for simplification is a recurring issue in the Court's opinions (see, for example, Opinion No 7/2007 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities).
In a 2007 opinion (No 6/2007), the Court presented its position on the annual summaries as well as on the national declarations submitted voluntarily by some Member States on their own initiative.
This opinion is dealt with in more detail in the section entitled 'The Court's position'.
Article 279 of the Treaty.
Article 248(4).
Most of the Court's opinions have been published in the Official Journal of the European Union and are available on the Court's website.
26 CONTINUING AND EFFECTIVENESS Public financial control plays a key role in modern democratic societies from the point of view of efficient financial management.
The audit activities shall be held accountable to the addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, whether their taxpayers' money is spent in a proper and appropriate manner.
From this perspective, public financial control is a key element of accountability and a useful basis for public discussion.
In this respect, the Court's work has considerable potential for impact.
The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned, primarily in the European context of the Commission, the Parliament, the Council and the Member States.
On the basis of this information, they may take measures with or without reference to the examination conclusions.
Although the Court's audit activities have their main effect on its published reports, they have already had some effect throughout the course of the audit itself.
In particular, all the audits result in the submission of detailed audit findings to the audited body in order to confirm the accuracy of the Court's observations.
The final text of the report is also subject to a 'contradictory procedure'.
The responses of the audited body, namely the Commission, will be published together with the reports.
In the replies, the audited body often acknowledges the problems identified by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to remedy them.
After completion of the audit work and publication of a report, the audit results will be evaluated and used by Parliament and the Council to carry out their political task of monitoring the use of the budget.
In the framework of the annual discharge procedure, the Court reports form a basis for the Council's recommendation and Parliament's decision in this regard.
In the 2006 discharge procedure, particular attention was paid to the conclusions put forward by the Court in the field of structural policies.
In its 2006 discharge resolution, Parliament directly referred to an action plan proposed by the Commission as a direct consequence of the conclusions of the Court's annual report and called for quarterly reports on the state of its implementation.
Parliament also called for better insight into the corrective measures taken to address the errors and weaknesses.
The special reports will also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, given the fact that they are published throughout the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on them have usually taken place at an earlier stage at the meetings of Parliament and the Council.
A good example of a possible follow-up is provided by the recent special report on building expenditure (No. 2/2007).
Indeed, Parliament had already entrusted its administration with the preparation of a report examining whether it would be feasible to create a European Construction Office to be responsible for the construction and maintenance of buildings of the institutions and bodies of the European Union.
The Court's audit report on checks carried out by the Member States on the export of agricultural products (No 4/2007) can be given as a further example.
The Council and the Commission responded without delay to the Court's recommendations by amending existing legislation.
The impact of the audit reports can be increased by their thematicity in the relevant media, which provides greater attention and stimulates public debate.
The media are the most immediate source of information for citizens.
As a rule, media coverage for the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive, but some special reports have also been followed with interest by the press.
For example, the fisheries report (No 7/2007) has received a lot of media attention.
An extraordinary Fisheries Council was convened to discuss the Court's report and the Commission launched a procedure which may lead to amendments to the legislation to remedy the shortcomings identified.
This is an example of a report that has made a particularly valuable contribution to the decision-making process because of its relevance and timeliness.
This section provided some guidance on the impact of the Court reports published in 2007.
Further details on the follow-up to previous observations of the Court are given in the respective chapters of its annual report.
The Court's most frequently commented in its last annual report is that, despite the measures taken, the shortcomings identified in the previous year have only been partially remedied.
The opinion should also be considered when considering the impact of the Court's work.
The Court's intention is to analyse increasingly the long-term impact of its work – both audits and opinions.
This can be illustrated by the example set out in Box 4.
27 BOX 4 – THE OPINION OF THE COURT ON ‘Single audit' Over the years, the Court has published a number of opinions on how to develop the general internal control system for the EU budget.
The opinion on the ‘Single audit' (No 2/2004) in 2004 has made a significant contribution to this end.
In this opinion, the Court proposes to integrate the definition and implementation of all internal control into a single Integrated Control Framework, which includes common principles and objectives and ensures that costs and benefits are proportionate.
The opinion on the "Unique Audit" developed into a reference document for the Commission, but also for the Court, for example in 2007 in its comments on the definition of effective and efficient internal control in the updated implementing rules of the Financial Regulation (Opinion No 1/2007).
The integrated audit approach is reflected in the Commission's 2006 Integrated Internal Control Framework Action Plan.
The Commission has taken steps to emphasise the role and responsibilities of the Member States in the field of internal control, including the new obligation to submit annual summaries of the audit opinions, declarations and audits carried out in accordance with the regulations applicable to each area of expenditure.
28 OF THE POSITION OF THE HOFES NATIONAL SUMMARY AND DECLARATIONS The Commission and Member States have launched initiatives to enhance the involvement of Member States in the accountability cycle for EU funds.
In part, the aim is to resolve the problem of significant error rates with regard to the legality and regularity of the main expenditure areas of the budget, especially in those areas in which the Commission and the Member States share management.
Significant recent developments include the obligation for Member States to submit annual summaries of available audit results and declarations, the voluntary initiatives of some Member States to make national declarations, and the decision of some national control authorities to draw up audit reports on the management of EU funds.
In its opinion No 6/2007, the Court considers that, where properly implemented, all these elements could improve the management and control of EU funds.
The opinion sets out the conditions under which these elements are of added value and can be used by the Court in compliance with international audit principles.
As annual summaries form an integral part of the internal control system, the Court will assess the extent to which they improve the functioning of internal control in the context of its usual audit procedures.
Annual summaries can lead to better overall control of EU funds in areas with shared management insofar as they highlight strengths and weaknesses.
National declarations are based on voluntary initiatives by certain Member States and are made at the highest level and submitted to national parliaments.
Although they do not, on their own, constitute conclusive audit evidence, they can be seen as a novel element of internal control and provide valuable information on the implementation of the EU budget.
The Court recognises the potential benefits of national declarations and audit work in raising awareness among Member States of the importance of internal control of EU funds.
The audit work carried out by the national control authorities (national audit reports) in relation to the legality and regularity of EU expenditure or national declarations could provide audit evidence to the Court if it is able to verify the suitability and quality of the audit work in accordance with international audit principles.
In this case, the Court will take into account the operating reports issued by national control authorities when planning and carrying out its own audits.
National declarations and national audit reports contain statements on control systems.
National declarations may also contain certain examination judgments on the legality and regularity of transactions.
Experience shows that the main risk to the legality and regularity of the transactions lies in the reliability of the information provided by the beneficiaries when applying for EU funds, rather than in the way in which it is processed by the Member States and the Commission.
The declaration that systems work as required in the EU regulations cannot on its own guarantee the legality and regularity of the transactions concerned.
Recognising the need for a stronger role for national control authorities in the overall context of accountability of EU expenditure, the EU's Contact Committee of Supreme Audit Institutions has set up a working group on the harmonisation of audit standards and standards specifically tailored to the EU context.
Joint audit approaches and methods will increase the Court's ability to rely on the work of the national control authorities, provided that the quality of the work is directly demonstrated.
EU BUDGET REVIEW In September 2007, the Commission published a consultation paper to launch an open debate on EU finances as part of a far-reaching budgetary review.
In early April 2008, the Court presented its contribution to the debate, in which it outlined the main principles to be taken into account in the design of new programmes, so that they provide European added value in terms of clarity of objectives, the pursuit of simplification, the sense of reality, transparency and accountability.
Among other things, the Court recommended that the following aspects be taken into account: • • • orientation of expenditure programmes not after input but after output; better use of the concept of acceptable risk in the design and adoption of expenditure programmes; degree of discretion to be given to national or regional authorities in the management of expenditure programmes and their accounting; whether VAT own resources still form a useful part of the own resources system, with a view to reviewing all the balancing mechanisms that are based on the guiding principles of the own resources system – justice, transparency, cost-effectiveness, simplicity and contribution capacity of each Member State. 29
30 THE WORK OF THE COURT IN 2007 AND IN HINAUS IN 2007 The Court shall present its future audit work annually in a work programme submitted to the Committee on Budgetary Control of the European Parliament and available to the public on the Court's website.
The Court monitors the implementation of the work programme as a basis for improvements in subsequent years.
In 2007, the number of adopted special annual reports on European agencies and other decentralised bodies increased significantly.
The number of special reports and opinions was similar to those in previous years.
The annual reports on the general budget and the European Development Funds have been published as planned.
Results (number) 2004 2005 2006 2007 Special reports 10 6 11 9 Annual reports (including EDFs) 1 1 1 1 Special annual reports 23 20 23 29 Opinions 2 11 8 9 In 2007 the Court first applied its new assurance model (a model of audit security) in the field of audit of accounts and compliance (assessment of compliance) in order to obtain sufficiently robust results in the most efficient way possible.
The Court also decided to provide more detailed information on the results of its Statement of Assurance, in particular on the results of the audit of individual operations.
The Court considers that this will provide useful information for monitoring purposes, together with a schematic presentation of the results of the system evaluations, to measure progress in the area of financial management.
ACTION PLAN AND PEER-REVIEW PROCEDURE The Court constantly strives to improve all aspects of its work.
In 2005, the Court decided to submit to a peer review procedure.
In doing so, senior staff of a small number of Supreme Audit Institutions assess the organisation or results of a sister institution by means of professional standards and against the background of their respective professional experience.
Since all Supreme Audit Institutions have similar tasks, peer review procedures can make a very valuable contribution to improving audit bodies.
In the course of the preparation for the peer review procedure, the Court carried out a self-assessment in 2006 under which the institution was given the opportunity to explore its strengths and weaknesses.
In 2007, the Court adopted an action plan to address the weaknesses identified.
The plan comprised a total of 23 measures, six of which were the subject of task forces involving members of the Court and staff from different areas and hierarchy levels of the institution: 31 1. Mission statement, mandate, strategic objectives and planning 2. Management structure (management), structure and organisation 3. Internal performance indicators 4. Employees and internal communication 5. External stakeholders and communication approaches, external communication strategy 6. Improving reporting quality The results of these task forces presented in 2007 included new declarations on mission, mission statement and values, as well as strategic objectives for the Court, a new strategy and guidelines for internal communication and a report on ways to improve reporting quality.
QUANTITATIVE AND QUALITATIVE IMPROVEMENT OF THE AUDIT WORK Several of the strategic objectives adopted concern the output of the institution.
The Court strives to make the impact of its audits more visible by selecting relevant topics, by selecting timeliness, and by making its reports clearer and more readable.
It has also begun to increase the number of its impact assessments and improve their quality.
In 2007, considerable efforts were made to develop the methodological basis of the Court's work as an essential prerequisite for high-quality audit work.
A new manual for auditing accounting and compliance audits has been developed with great effort, which is due to be completed in 2008.
The Court's new audit manual was adopted at the end of 2006 and was therefore available to the auditors for the first time in 2007.
To further improve the quality of the Court's work in the field of economic audit, additional guidelines have been developed and several seminars and training sessions have been held.
The Court also set new ambitious targets for the use of information technologies.
In the new IT strategy adopted in 2007 the Court stated its intention to expand its capacity to carry out IT audits and to make the use of computer assisted audit techniques (CAATs) as a common practice in accounting and audit audits.
It is important that the quantity and quality of the output of the farm can be properly evaluated.
The Court is developing performance indicators which should enable it to provide a wide range of performance data in future annual activity reports.
For the future, the Court plans to develop a methodology for assessing the cost-effectiveness of the institution. 32
33 30th anniversary of the Court In 2007, the European Court of Auditors celebrated its 30th anniversary as an external audit body of the European Union.
The celebrations started with an increased presence of the Court (seminars, information stands, etc.) in most capitals of the European Union as part of the activities of the 2007 European Day.
On 17 October 2007, an exhibition entitled "30 Years of Court of Auditors" was also opened, which included a series of thematic display panels, a sound picture show with more than 150 photos and video excerpts as well as numerous documents.
The Luxembourg Central Bank issued a silver commemorative coin on this occasion.
On 18 October 2007, the European Court of Auditors held a seminar entitled "The Future of Public Financial Control in the EU", attended by a number of high-level experts from EU circles and the organ's executives.
IMPROVING NON-audit ASPECTS AT THE HOF Many of the tasks set out in the Action Plan concern communication, to which increased efforts were devoted in 2007.
Among other things, a new website was put into operation and information material on the annual report was published in a more accessible format and the Court agreed to a new procedure for presenting its special reports to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control.
Other developments, mostly directly or partly related to the Action Plan, concerned the modernisation of the Court's accounting system and new policy documents in the areas of staff and IT.
The Court also began to modernise its information systems in the areas of audit, translation, knowledge and communication, management information and staff.
In addition, in 2007 the Court made progress in its preparations for a second extension of its main building, which is necessary due to the recent and planned increase in staff.
Audit work to be carried out in 2008 7 As in previous years, the Court will present, in addition to its annual report on the general budget of the EU, an annual report on the European Development Funds and special annual reports on European agencies and other bodies.
Expenditure under the EU's general budget is planned in seven-year cycles, so-called financial frameworks.
2007 was the first year of the new financial framework, focusing on the implementation of policies.
The Court takes this opportunity to elaborate on an earlier innovation, namely the Commission's conversion to activity-related budgeting and activity-related management, as well as the breakdown of the budget into 31 policy areas with some 220 activities.
The annual report for the financial year 2007 is broken down into groups of policy areas which are largely, but not entirely, in line with the new headings of the financial framework.

36 INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION COOPERATION WITH THE EU's NATIONAL ACCOUNTING INSTITUTIONS Pursuant to the EC Treaty, the European Court of Auditors has carried out its audit in connection with the Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCBs), while the Treaty of Amsterdam has subsequently added: "The Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies are working together with confidence, while maintaining their independence.
The ongoing contacts are maintained by liaison officers appointed by the individual SAIs.
Working groups have been set up to assist in the development of common positions and practices.
In 2007, a delegation from the Court took part in the annual meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the European Union SAIs held in Helsinki on 3 and 4 December by the Finnish Court of Auditors.
The meeting focused on "Risk management, acceptable risk and integrated internal control system in the management of EU funds" and was devoted to discussing the role of SAIs in this area.
The Court will host the next meeting of the Contact Committee on 1 and 2 December 2008.
Two liaison officers meetings were held in 2007 to prepare the Contact Committee meeting.
The first meeting was held in The Hague on 23 and 24 April and the second on 11 and 12 October in Luxembourg, chaired by the European Court of Auditors.
In both meetings, recent developments in the area of EU financial management were discussed and the work of the Task Force "Cooperation" was examined, dealing with the Contact Committee itself, its working methods and possibilities for improvement; in this context, proposals were put forward for a more efficient management of the work processes.
The meeting also covered the activities of the various working and expert groups set up by the Contact Committee to deal with specific issues of common interest.
The Court attended meetings of the Network of Candidate Countries and Candidate Countries "in speИ (Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and Turkey).
The Presidents of the SAIs of the candidate countries and candidate countries "in spe" and of the European Court of Auditors met in Skopje (former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia) on 11 and 12 June 2007.
An important aspect of all efforts to improve practical cooperation in the audit of EU funds concerns the audit principles used.
Against this background, the Contact Committee decided in 2006 to set up a working group chaired by one of the members of the Court, Mr Josef Bonnici, to "develop common auditing standards and comparable auditing standards based on internationally recognised auditing principles and adapted to the EU context".
The first meetings of the European Court of Auditors were held in Luxembourg in 2007.
In December 2007, a progress report was submitted to the Helsinki Contact Committee and a resolution was adopted.
OTHER INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international audit principles through its membership of European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, namely Eurosai and Intosai.
Within the framework of the Eurosai, the Court is represented in the environmental working group and in the IT working group and participates in the Eurosai Training Committee.
The Court hosted a seminar on "Analysis of the SAI's most common IT problems in Luxembourg on 17 and 18 April 2007 as well as a seminar entitled "Economic Audit – Where do we stand?" from 4 to 6 December 2007.
Since the Court became a full member of Intosai in 2004, it has been actively involved in the Subcommittee for Guidelines for Auditing Accounting (FAS), the Subcommittee for Auditing Compliance with Legal Standards (CAS) and the Subcommittee for Economic Audits (PAS).
The Court took part in all FAS meetings held in 2007 and provided active contributions to the published and discussed guidelines.
The FAS named the ERA representative (Mr Jesús Lázaro Cuenca) as one of the FAS representatives for the project of the Steering Committee of the Committee on Technical Standards on Quality of Examination. In addition, the Court took part in the CAS meeting in January 2007 in New Delhi.
In addition, the Court's Translation Directorate provided resources for the linguistic revision of a document in Spanish and German.
The Court also took part in the XIX Intosai Congress (Incosai) in Mexico from 5 to 10 November 2007, where two main themes were discussed: "State debt, its administration, accountability and audit," and "Evaluation systems of economic efficiency based on generally accepted key indicators – targets and performance indicators."
In 2008, the Court will continue its active participation in the working groups, seminars and meetings of Eurosai and Intosai.

38 PERSONAL PERSONAL POLICY The Court's most important capital is its staff.
They have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
In its recent modernisation of personnel policy, the Court set priorities in the areas of recruitment, training, career development and improvement of working conditions.

The visits are normally carried out by central and local authorities involved in granting, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as by the respective final beneficiaries.
The audit teams usually consist of two to three examiners and the length of an examination trip may be up to two weeks depending on the type of examination and the distance.
In 2007, travel expenses related to audit trips amounted to EUR 0.49 million (compared to EUR 0.43 million in 2006).
This represents a significant investment to ensure a sufficient audit coverage of all levels and locations of EU funds management.

43 BOX 6 – THE FISHERIES REPORT – RESULT OF A REFERRED TEAM PERFORMANCE The Court's 2007 report on monitoring, inspection and sanctioning systems in the area of fisheries resources (Special Report No 7/2007) attracted considerable attention both among policy-makers and in the media.
Articles in numerous newspapers, as well as the rapid reactions to both the Commission and the Council, demonstrated the relevance and topicality of the report.
The starting point of this success was a team of a dozen court auditors who worked closely with the rapporteur member, Mr Kikis Kazamias, and his cabinet.
Mr Emmanuel Rauch, a French examiner who has been working at the Court for several years, and his Spanish colleague Mr Alejandro Ballester were the team leaders during the preparatory phase in autumn 2005.
The audit covered trips to six Member States, from Denmark to Italy, both to central administrative authorities to gain insight into the control systems, and to the main ports to assess how the systems work in practice.
Insofar as the language skills of the team members were not sufficient, translators from the Court's language service provided assistance.
The audit team is very proud to have contributed to the gradual recognition by policy-makers of the serious consequences of the way in which the Community fisheries policy is implemented.
Other audit authorities have also shown interest in the audit, as it provides suggestions and know-how, for example, for an upcoming audit on a similar subject in the Baltic Sea countries.

44 FINANCIAL INFORMATION BUDGET The Court's budget accounts for about 0.1% of the EU's total budget and 1.8% of the administrative appropriations of the EU institutions and bodies.
Over the past three years, there has been an increase of 17%.
This increase is primarily linked to the consequences of EU enlargements in 2004 and 2007.
A further significant increase can be observed in the Court's budget for construction measures (the budget for buildings practically doubled between 2006 and 2008), because future, newly recruited employees will be accommodated in a second extension building (K3 building), whose completion is scheduled for 2013.
Some 72% of the total budget in 2007 was allocated to staff.

SERVICE INTERNE REVISION The Internal Audit Service of the Court is intended to assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives by means of a systematic, methodological evaluation of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
In addition, the Internal Audit Service makes proposals to increase the efficiency of the Court.
In general, it is a matter of assessing the performance of individual services in the implementation of strategies, programmes and measures with the aim of continuous improvement.
In 2007, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused on auditing the Court's accounts (including support for the Court's external auditor's work), audit of ex ante audit, implementation of internal control standards, the Court's latest extension (the so-called K2 building) and the Court's recruitment procedures.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee, composed of three members of the Court and one external expert, shall monitor the work of the Internal Auditor and ensure his independence.
It shall also examine and approve the work programme and the internal auditor's reports and, where appropriate, entrust them with specific audit tasks.
The Committee met eight times in 2007.
The Court's opinion of 28 September 2007 on the Court's external auditor for the financial year 2006 states: "We believe that the annual accounts give a true and fair view of the financial and financial situation of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2006 and of the economic results for the financial year ending that financial year in accordance with Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 of 25 June 2002 and its implementing rules, the generally accepted accounting principles and the internal rules of the European Court of Auditors.

PRESIDENCY OF THE PRESIDENT The Court of Auditors, as an independent audit body of the EU, makes a unique contribution to improving EU financial management and promoting transparency and accountability by providing audit services and acting as a role model.
For the Court, 2008 was marked by a significant number of significant progress and important developments in the area of EU financial management, which will be discussed in more detail in this Annual Activity Report.
A defining event was the European Court of Auditors' peer review, which led to a positive conclusion on the usefulness of the Court's audit management framework and on the independence and objectivity of its work.
In its annual report on the 2007 financial year, published in November 2008, the Court issued for the first time an unqualified audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's accounts.
As in previous years, however, it found too high a rate of error of legality and regularity in the areas of the EU budget, which accounts for most of the expenditure.
In 2008, the Court also recognised developments launched at EU and national level, which are likely to lead to significant improvements in EU financial management in the future.
Two examples set out in this Annual Activity Report relate to the ongoing process of reviewing the EU budget to which the Court has made an active contribution and to the Commission's communication on the tolerable risk of error.
In the field of international relations, the Court was responsible for organising the discussions of the European Union's Chief Audit Institutions' Contact Committee (ORCB) on EU budget reform and the revised Lisbon Strategy, as well as for hosting a recent workshop on the role of the EU's ORCB in the context of action to address the current financial crisis.
As its audit environment is undergoing rapid change, the Court considers that internal reforms should be adapted in order to better fulfil its obligations under the Treaty and to fulfil its mandate effectively.
A significant step taken by the Court in 2008 to implement its mission and mission was the development of an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012.
The audit strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of the audits and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will be decisive for the Court's work programmes over that period, as well as its efforts to continuously improve and exploit the key challenges and opportunities identified in the peer review process in terms of exploiting potential for improvement.
Thanks to its competence and commitment, the Court's staff play a central role in carrying out the audit work carried out by the Court as an independent guardian of the financial interests of citizens with a view to improving financial management.
On behalf of the Court and on my own behalf, I would like to thank all the staff for their commitment and professional work last year.
Special thanks are due to our former Secretary General, Mr Michel Hervé, who resigned at the end of 2008.
I wish you a pleasant read of this Annual Activity Report, which provides an insight into the Court and an overview of the activities carried out in 2008.
Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira President 5
PROCUREMENT, GUIDELINES AND VALUES PROCUREMENT The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
GUIDELINE An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, characterised by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact of its work, and providing valuable support to its audience for improving EU financial management.
value independence, integrity and impartiality independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and staff.
Professionalism Respect a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
Added value Creation of relevant, timely, high-quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the interests of its addressees and containing important and forward-looking statements.
Excellence and efficiency Recognition of the value of the individual, support in the further development of special skills and reward of performance.
ROLE AND WORK OF THE HOFE EXPENDITURE OF THE HOFE'S WORK IS THE EU'S BUDGET The budget of the European Union amounts to around EUR 120 billion, representing about 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in the financing of public activities, with the total budget almost equivalent to the GNI of some Member States.
The European Union's revenue consists mainly of contributions from Member States derived from their gross national income (GNI – 65.4%) or based on VAT collected by Member States (VAT – 16.9%).
Customs duties and agricultural duties (the so-called traditional own resources – 16.5%) also constitute a substantial part of revenue.
The composition of the budget has changed over time, with agricultural and cohesion policy being the main areas of expenditure (see Box 1).
BOX 1 已 HOW DOES THE EU MAKE YOUR COUNTRY?
The EU budget is financed by financial contributions from Member States (mainly on the basis of national GNI) as well as by customs duties and agricultural duties.
The EU budget is largely used for purposes other than national budgets, partly because of the different areas of responsibility.
For example, the Union is not responsible for social security systems, which usually account for a substantial part of national expenditure.
Since the 1960s, agricultural expenditure, which is usually paid in the form of payments to farmers across the Union, has been the main component of budgetary expenditure, albeit at present with a decreasing trend.
In 2009, 45.3% of the budget for the conservation and management of natural resources, mainly for agriculture and rural development, is earmarked.
Since the 1980s, a significant proportion of the expenditure on cohesion measures, i.e. regional and social development, has been devoted to co-financing a wide range of projects, from road construction projects in Poland to training for the unemployed in Spain.
In 2009, the budget for sustainable growth will amount to 39.6% of the budget, of which the lion's share will be cohesion measures.
This budget also covers most of the EU's research funding.
In addition, EU funds will be channelled at a significant level into development aid and humanitarian aid, as well as countries that have close relations with the Union or are candidate countries.
6,7% of the budget will be spent on the management of the Community institutions.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice The European Union as a global player Administration Agriculture – conservation and management of natural resources 45.3% 1.2 % 7.2 % 6.7% EU expenditure Cohesion – sustainable growth Source: general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2009 (OJ L 69, 13.3.2009). 39.6%
The budget is adopted annually by the Council, i.e. by representatives of the Member States, and by the directly elected European Parliament on a proposal from the European Commission, on the basis of a seven-year financial framework.
The Commission shall draw up the budget and shall also be responsible for its implementation.
Most of the budget, in particular in the area of expenditure on agricultural and cohesion policy, will be implemented in cooperation with the Member States.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on applications by beneficiaries themselves, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union. 8
Democratic societies need complete and correct publicly available information as a basis for discussion and decision-making, both with a view to improving financial management and ensuring accountability.
The EU and its Member States have an external audit body, which has the role of independent guardian of the financial interests of citizens.
In its role as external auditor of the EU, the European Court of Auditors ensures that the EU funds have been correctly recorded regardless of their place of use and spent in accordance with the legislation, taking due account of the optimum use of funds.
The results of the Court's audit work will be used by the Parliament, the Council and the Commission as well as by Member States to improve EU financial management.
The Court's work forms an important basis for the annual discharge procedure, during which Parliament, acting on the basis of Council recommendations, decides whether the Commission has fulfilled its responsibilities for the implementation of the budget in the previous year.
In spite of its name, the Court has no judicial powers.
In the shared management budgetary areas, Member States shall cooperate with the Commission in the establishment of monitoring and control systems, i.e. internal control, to ensure that the funds are used correctly and correctly.
Internal control thus has a European as well as a national dimension.
In addition to the Court's work, many national control authorities are examining EU funds, provided they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
9 OVERVIEW OF THE INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL CONTROLS OF THE EU BUDGET EU level Internal control External control Commission (DGs, Internal Audit Service) European Court of Auditors Member States Implementing Bodies National control authorities National level
(Economic Audit) HOW does the COURT REPORT ON ITS RESULTS?
The Court shall publish the results of its audit work in the following types of reports: annual reports – with the results of the audit of the accounts in the form of a statement of assurance on the implementation of the general budget2 and on activities under the European Development Funds3.
Special annual reports – with the results of the audit of the accounts of the agencies and bodies of the Communities.
Special reports – with the results of selected cost-effectiveness or compliance audits.
10 1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
2 Under the EC Treaty, the Court is obliged to make such a statement – or an audit opinion – on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
In this context, the underlying transactions are usually payments to final beneficiaries to the EU budget.
The annual Statement of Assurance is generally known under the French acronym DAS (Déclaration d'Assurance).
In contrast to practice in the Member States, the Court makes such a statement on the EU budget as a whole.
3 The European Development Funds (EDF) are based on international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States)
The Court shall carry out its audit of the annual accounts of the EU in accordance with International Audit Principles (ISAs), which shall be valid in both the public and the private sectors.
However, the existing international auditing principles do not fully cover the Court's compliance audit.
The Court, together with national control authorities, actively participates in the further development of international audit standards promoted by the standardisation bodies (INTOSAI, IFAC)4.
In order to ensure that payments are consistent with legislation and framework rules, the Court builds on the results of both its study of monitoring and control systems to prevent, detect and correct errors in legality and regularity and of a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Where systems are reviewed and found to be reliable, the number of operations which the Court is required to examine in order to arrive at a sound conclusion as to their legality and regularity shall be reduced accordingly.
Other sources, such as the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions.
In the case of financial audits, the Court uses a variety of audit methods to assess management and monitoring systems and to evaluate performance data on the basis of the criteria derived from the legislation with regard to the principles of sound financial management.
In selecting issues for its business audits, the Court seeks to identify areas where the greatest impact is to be expected in terms of the demonstrated potential for improvement in terms of the economy, economic efficiency and effectiveness of EU expenditure. 11 were concluded, as well as decisions by the Council on the association of overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP States, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see External Relations, Development and Enlargement) and partly through delegations in the beneficiary countries.
The EDF investment facilities are managed by the European Investment Bank (EIB) and are not subject to the Court's audit mandate.
4 INTOSAI (International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions) International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions – IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) International Association of Accountants.
12 BOX 2 我 THE PRESIDERATION OF THE HOFE IN RESPECT OF PAYMENTS RELATING TO EU BUDGET The Court does not have the resources to examine in detail all the operations financed by the EU budget.
In connection with the preparation of the DAS, it therefore uses statistical sampling methods to obtain a result representative of the population as a whole.
The sample selection shall be carried out by random selection of a representative sample of underlying operations from all areas of the Union budget, such as agriculture, for detailed examination.
The Court shall monitor these operations until the final beneficiary of the aid, such as a farmer in France.
The Court then carries out on-the-spot checks, e.g. measuring the size of the agricultural area, to determine whether the relevant information in the aid application corresponds to the actual circumstances.
As a result of the statistical sample, the results can be extrapolated to the population concerned, i.e. a specific area of revenue or expenditure, and together with information resulting from the system evaluation can serve as the basis for an overall audit opinion.
In practice, the Court compares the results of its checks on statistical samples with a certain upper limit, which it considers to be acceptable – the so-called materiality threshold.

BREAKDOWN STRUCTURE AND ORGANIZATION BUILDING THE EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body composed of 27 members, each with one member per Member State.
All audit reports and opinions shall be adopted by the College.
The Court is divided into five audit groups to which individual members are assigned.
As can be seen from the organisational chart (see page 17), there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas (preserving and managing natural resources – structural policies, transport, research and energy – external policies – revenue, banking activities, administrative expenditure, Community institutions and bodies and internal policies).
The fifth audit group (CEAD or Coordination, Communication, Evaluation, Quality Assurance and Development) is responsible for "horizontal issues such as the coordination in the field of the Statement of Assurance, Quality Assurance, the development of the Court's audit methodology and the general dissemination of the Court's audit results and reports.
In addition, a Management Committee shall be responsible for the preparatory treatment of all administrative matters requiring a formal decision by the Court.
MEMBERS The members of the Court shall be appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament for a term of six years, in accordance with the proposals of each Member State, and may be re-elected.
Members shall perform their duties in full independence for the general good of the European Union.
In addition to its role within the College, which is responsible for final decision-making on audits and opinions, as well as on wider strategic and administrative issues, each member is primarily responsible for his or her specific tasks in the audit area.
The actual examination work is usually the task of the examiners in the individual examination departments and is coordinated by the relevant member with the support of his cabinet.
The member shall then present the report to the audit group or to the Court and, after its adoption in the European Parliament, the Council and other interested third parties.
On 1 January 2008, three new members – Mr Michel Cretin (France), Mr Harald Noack (Germany) and Mr Henri Grethen (Luxembourg) – replaced their respective predecessors at the end of their term of office.
The Council also extended the mandate of four members – Mr Hubert Weber (Austria), Mr Maarten B. Engwirda (Netherlands), Mr David Bostock (United Kingdom) and Mr Ioannis Sarmas (Greece) – for a period of six years.
THE PRESIDENT The European Court of Auditors is headed by the President, who is elected by the members from among them for a term of three years, with the right of re-election.
The President shall represent the Court in all its external relations, in particular in its relations with the discharge authority, with the other institutions of the European Union and with the supreme audit authorities of the Member States and beneficiary countries.
On 16 January 2008, the Portuguese member, Mr Vítor Manuel da Silva Caldeira, was elected tenth President of the Court. 14
THE SECRETARY-GENERAL The Secretary-General is the highest-ranking member of the institution and is appointed by the Court for a period of six years; re-election is permitted.
The Secretary-General shall be responsible for the staff and material management of the Court, including professional training and the Translation Directorate, each with one unit per official language (22), except for Irish.
The Secretary-General is also responsible for the Court's secretariat.
The former Secretary General, Mr Michel Hervé, left the Court on 31 October 2008.
On 9 October 2008, Mr John Speed was appointed Secretary General m.d.W.d.G.b.
On 10 March 2009, the Court appointed Mr Eduardo Ruiz García as the new Secretary-General with effect from 16 March 2009. THE HOFES PERSONAL OF THE HOFES The budget for the financial year 2008 provides for 858 posts for the European Court of Auditors (as at 31 December 2008).
The Court's auditors have a wide range of training profiles and relevant professional experience in both the public and private sectors, in particular in the fields of accounting, financial management, internal and external audit and legal and economic sciences.
Like the other EU institutions, the Court employs nationals from all Member States. Personnel are subject to the EU Staff Regulations.______________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

OVERVIEW OF AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS5 ANNUAL REPORTS ON THE 2007 FINANCIAL YEAR ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET The annual accounts give a true picture of the financial situation and the results of the EU on all main points.
The restrictions set out in last year's annual report on the reliability of the accounts for the financial year 2006 are no longer valid because of the improvements which have been made for 2007.
The Court gives full judgements on the legality and regularity of certain areas, such as Union administrative expenditure.
However, the Court cannot give an unrestricted opinion on most areas of expenditure.
Although most of the Court's audited payments have been made in accordance with the legislation, the Court still considers the error rate in payments to final beneficiaries, such as farmers and promoters of EU funded projects, to be too high.
With the exception of cohesion measures with an error rate of at least 11%, the Court's estimate of error rate in these themes ranges from 2% to 5%.
In some areas of expenditure, especially those previously covered by internal and external policies, the estimated error rate has fallen but not so much that this would change the overall picture.
The result does not mean that these infringements of legislation are due to fraud or that most operations in these areas are illegal and/or illegal.
THE SITUATION IN CERTAIN AREAS In three areas – administrative and other expenditure, economy and finance, and revenue – the Court's audits of representative samples of operations have revealed low estimated error rates.
In the Union's largest expenditure area – agriculture and natural resources – the estimated overall error rate remains essential.
Rural development, with its often complex rules, accounts for a disproportionate proportion of this error rate.
For the expenditure of the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the value of the error rate estimated by the Court is just below the materiality threshold of 2 %.
As in previous years, cohesion measures, which account for more than one third of the budget volume, are the most flawed area.
In view of the random estimate made by the Court of the proportion of the errorful transactions, at least 11 % of the total amount of the refunds should not have been made.
5 This section is intended to introduce the Court's reports and opinions rather than its summary.
For more information, see the full text of the Court documents published on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) after their adoption.
19 BREAKDOWN OF MONITORING AND CONTROL The high error rate in areas such as cohesion is partly due to the inherent risk of the high number of beneficiaries applying for EU funding under complex regulations and legislation.
The shortcomings in the design and functioning of the systems also contribute to the shortcomings identified.
Most programmes financed by EU funds include provisions on corrective measures which provide for the recovery of funds unduly disbursed due to errors on a multiannual basis.
However, there is no information on the impact of these measures.
This means that it is not possible to establish in concrete terms whether they effectively reduce the proportion of illegal and/or irregular expenditure.
The Commission has been working since 2000 on a reform programme to improve the management of the EU budget, which includes an action plan from 2006.
By the end of 2007, the Commission had implemented two thirds of the sub-measures under the Action Plan.
However, it is still too early to assess the impact of these measures.
Improved high-level controls – such as the Commission's monitoring of Member States' control activities – make it impossible to compensate for inadequate controls at a lower level, such as on-the-spot checks.
However, the benefits of increased on-the-spot checks must be weighed against costs.
The Court recommends that the Union's political authorities define the appropriate level of risk of error.
In order to reduce the error rate in EU payments, the Court recommends simplifying rules and legislation, streamlining internal control measures and improving monitoring and reporting.

21 QUEST 4  ▁Rücksendung INTERPRETATION OF THE AUDIT CASES An auditor may issue the following types of audit opinions: • full audit opinion if it is proven that the accounting is reliable or that the underlying transactions, i.e. payments, are legal and correct in all essential respects; • negative audit opinion if the error rate in the underlying transactions is material and comprehensive or the accounting is not reliable; • refusal of audit opinion if the auditor cannot obtain sufficient and adequate audit evidence to support his audit opinion and the possible effects are both material and comprehensive; • limited audit opinion if an unqualified audit opinion cannot be delivered but the effects of disagreements or limitations of the scope of the audit are not so material or comprehensive as to require a negative audit opinion or refusal of the audit opinion.
