OPINIONS PUBLISHED IN 2008 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management by delivering opinions on proposals or budgetary management issues.
These opinions are required as part of the adoption procedure of financial rules7 or may be submitted at the request of one of the other institutions of the Community8.
The Court may also submit opinions on its own initiative.
The Court's opinions may address issues relating to certain areas of expenditure in the EU, such as the amendment of the Financial Regulation of the European Aviation Safety Agency (No 1/2008), or issues relating to EU revenue, such as the amendment of the Regulation on the Community's own resources system (No 2/2008).
Opinions are based on the Court's expert knowledge on EU financial management which has been acquired over the years in the course of its audits, and in some cases reference is made to certain audits or opinions.
For example, the Court's opinion on the new financial regulation of the European Joint Undertaking for ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor) refers to its annual report on the 2006 financial year, which already drew attention to high risks regarding the legality and regularity of payments for research aid.

CONTINUING DEVELOPMENT AND EFFECTIVENESS Public financial control plays a central role in promoting accountability and makes a useful contribution to public debate.
The audit activities shall be held accountable to the addressees at the end of the information chain, in this case to European citizens, whether their taxpayers' money is spent in a proper and appropriate manner.
The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned, primarily the Parliament, the Council, the Commission and the Member States, in the European context.
On the basis of that information, they may take measures with or without reference to the examination conclusions.
Although the Court's audit activity has its main effect on the published reports, it itself has some effect throughout the course of the audit.
In the replies, the audited body often acknowledges the problems encountered by the Court and sets out the steps it intends to take to remedy them.
After completion of the audit work and publication of a report, the audit results will be evaluated and used by Parliament and the Council to carry out their political task of monitoring the use of the budget.
In the context of the annual discharge procedure, the Court's reports form a basis for the Council's recommendation on this subject and for Parliament's decision.
29 Examples of this can be found in the 2007 discharge procedure, in which the European Parliament calls on the Commission and the Member States to make efforts to simplify and further clarify the rules in order to reduce the risks of error, streamline controls and reduce costs.
This applies both to areas of shared management – such as expenditure on agricultural and cohesion measures – and to areas of direct management – such as expenditure on research or on culture and education.
The special reports will also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
However, due to the fact that they are published during the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on them have usually taken place at an earlier stage in the meetings of Parliament and the Council.
The impact of the audit reports can be enhanced by their thematicity in the relevant media, which gives greater attention and stimulates public debate.
As a rule, media coverage for the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive, but some special reports have also been followed with interest by the press.
An example of this is the special report on cross compliance (No 8/2008), which is currently being published on the adoption of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP) health check.
Given the importance of cross-compliance and its central role within the CAP, and the timing of its publication, the report received a broad response from the various media: television, newspapers, specialised press, Internet publications (press, agricultural associations, MEP websites, web blogs, etc.).
The report was also discussed in detail in the European Parliament and almost all the Court's recommendations were taken up in the draft discharge report.
Further information on the follow-up to previous Court observations is given in the respective chapters of its annual report.
The Court's most frequently stated remark in its last annual report is that, despite the measures taken, the shortcomings identified in the previous year have only been partially remedied.
It is the intention of the Court to analyse to an increasing extent the long-term impact of its work – audits as well as opinions.
As an example, the Court uses a Commission database of follow-up to its audit recommendations as a basis for assessing the impact of its audit.
The assessment may lead to separate in-depth audits leading to further findings and recommendations.
These may be incorporated into a subsequent Special Report on the area concerned or may be included in a Report on the follow-up and impact of recommendations on financial management.
VIEW OF THE COURT THE CONCEPT OF THE TOLERABLE FEDERAL RISK In the context of the development of a Community internal control framework, the Court held in its Opinion No. 2/2004 that it is for the political authorities to decide on the level of risk they are prepared to accept when approving EU spending regimes.
The Court proposed that Parliament and the Council agree on an appropriate balance between the costs and benefits of controls, in other words the tolerable residual risk of expenditure errors.
The costs of controls should be proportional to the benefits they provide in monetary and political terms.
Since the publication of this opinion, both the European Parliament and the Council have expressed their desire in their discharge resolutions to pursue the issue and to achieve a common understanding of the tolerable level of risk.
At the end of 2008, the Commission issued a Communication entitled ‘Towards a common understanding of the concept of tolerable risk of error'.
The Court welcomed this communication and sent a response to the Commission, in which it identified certain limits and outlined the main aspects to be considered in the future follow-up to this issue.
In its Communication, the Commission states that any decision on a tolerable risk of error should be based, inter alia, on the potential for further simplifications.
The Court also highlights the importance and benefits of further simplifications and the potential impact on the reduction of errors or irregularities.
The concept of "tolerable risk of error" should be clearly separated from the concept of the materiality threshold as defined and applied by the Court, which is the responsibility of the external auditor10.
The Court considers that the cost-benefit analysis of spending programmes could provide information not only for discussions on the tolerable risk, but also for the review of the regulatory framework and management structure of the programmes concerned.
In this context, the relevant question may not be whether there is a tolerable risk of error, but whether the risk of error is so high that the scheme or programme in question should be abolished/set up or fundamentally modified.
The concept of tolerable risk should also be specifically considered when designing expenditure (and revenue) schemes or programmes.
It would be useful for expenditure programmes to have sufficient information on the risks involved at the time of their adoption, as well as the costs of the checks envisaged to reduce these risks to an acceptable level.
This would make decisions in the knowledge of the facts and take explicit account of the risks and costs involved.
The budgetary reform process may provide an opportunity to reflect on this issue, as suggested by the Court in its response to the Commission communication entitled "Reforming the budget, changing Europe"11.
31 10 The term "essentiality" is defined in the international audit principle ISA 320 as follows: "Information is essential if its omission or incorrect presentation could affect the economic decisions taken by financial addressees on the basis of a financial statement.
Materiality depends on the size of the item or the error resulting from the special circumstances of omission or incorrect representation.
Therefore, materiality is more a threshold or a limit and less a primary qualitative requirement, which must have information to be useful.

AUDIT STRATEGY The audit strategy is based on the Court's strategic objectives.
33 STRATEGIC OBJECTIVES Professionalism Output Addressees Further development and growth Consolidated audit methods, adequate audit strategy, further development of audit practice in the public sector, development of common audit standards and comparable audit standards for EU funds, cooperation with the EU-ORKB, effective ‘Community control framework', selection of relevant audit topics, timeliness, clarity and legibility of reports, quality of economic assessments, increasing the impact of reports Deepening relations with the audited bodies, in order to provide a better understanding of the audit process and to achieve a wider acceptance of the audit results.
The Court's audits and reports aim to contribute to improving EU financial management and protecting the EU's financial interests for EU citizens.
The following key aspects are taken into account in formulating the strategy relevant to the Court's activities: EFFICIENCY EFFICIENCY REPORTS Audit work Work Programme In 2008, the Court developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 to implement its mission and mission statement.
A summary of this document is available on the Court's website.
The Court's strategy is based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of audits and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will have a significant impact on the Court's work programmes during that period as well as on its efforts to improve continuously.
The Court aims to maximise the overall impact of its audits over the period concerned by: • selecting and designing audits focused on issues from risk areas and of utmost interest to the Court's audience; • continuing to present sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement and monitoring whether these proposals are being implemented; • carrying out a wider range of audits and presenting new types of audit products that complement the current annual and special reports; • producing a larger number of special reports and improving their timeliness and ease of use; • further developing its relations with its main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public.
These include: • improved management; • effective and dynamic staffing policies; • rationalisation of audit tasks; • improvement of IT tools; • enhancement of expertise; • strengthening relations with audited bodies. 34
AUDIT WORK TO BE IMPLEMENTED IN 200912 As in previous years, the 2009 work programme includes the preparation of annual reports setting out the results of audits of the accounts to be carried out by the Court in accordance with the EC Treaty and other EU legislation.
For 2009, the Court identified a number of audit issues relating to policy developments and EU financial management issues.
As regards developments in EU policies, the following topics were selected: • growth and employment; • climate change and sustainable development; • Europe as a global partner; • better regulation.
In addition, the Court highlights the following issues in the area of EU financial management, which it believes deserve particular attention: • Completion of expenditure programmes for the period 2000-2006, in particular in the area of the Structural Funds; • Accountability and reform of the EU; • Progress of the Commission's Action Plan for an Integrated Internal Control Framework, taking into account the concept of tolerable risk; • Administrative and control measures at Member State level.
The Court's objective is to address these issues from 2009 onwards in the framework of its annual reports, special reports and some new types of reports (see comments below).
The Court intends to publish a series of special reports and related novel reports, drawn up on the basis of the audit tasks it has selected.
The planning and implementation of these selected audit tasks as well as the reporting in this respect are generally over a period of more than one year.
Therefore, most of the reports published in a given year are based on audit work initiated in previous years.
Box 5 contains the selected audit tasks, which are completed or are pending completion, and the results of which are therefore expected to be published in special reports in 2009 or early 2010.
35 12 A more complete and detailed overview of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's 2009 Work Programme, which is available on its website (www.eca.europa.eu).
Follow-up to the recommendations is an important tool for the Court to actively contribute to improving financial management.
The report will include an analysis of the extent to which our recommendations have been followed and, if necessary, an assessment of the effectiveness of the measures taken.
It is expected to be published approximately at the same time as the annual report. — The other new type of report the Court intends to present is a report on high risk areas in the context of EU financial management.
The report is addressed to the new Commission, which will start work towards the end of the year, and will serve as a guide.
Further development and improvement of action plan and peer-reviewing procedures In 2006 the Court carried out a self-assessment in which its strengths and weaknesses were identified.
An action plan to address the weaknesses was subsequently drawn up.
The Action Plan included a number of measures followed by the Court • defined its mission, mission, strategic objectives and strategic planning; • developed internal performance indicators, which will be gradually introduced (see section below); • adopted an internal communication strategy, which is already being implemented and has opened up new channels for better dissemination of information within the institution; • adopted various measures to improve the quality of its reports, for example through a new graphic design to improve readability and external assessments; • adopted a progressive strategy to improve the Court's relations with its addressees, the press and the general public.
As part of its efforts to improve, the Court will seek to take up in 2009 the comments and recommendations of the International Peer Review Report on the European Court of Auditors, published in December 2008, which constitutes an important stage in the Court's ongoing reform process.
The peer review was carried out by representatives of the national control authorities of Canada, Norway, Austria and Portugal.
The peers carried out their work in 2008 and in this context also contacted the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control.The final report was presented at the end of 2008.
The purpose of the peer review procedure was to assess the conception and functioning of the framework set by the Court for audits.
The review covered the following areas: • planning and audit procedures for audits of accounts and auditing of accounts; • reporting on audit results; • services to assist the Court in achieving its objectives.
The peer review team concluded that the design of the audit framework set by the Court is in line with international audit principles and good practice for Supreme Audit Institutions.
Furthermore, the peers noted that • the Court carries out its activities independently and objectively; • the Court's audit reports were based on sufficient and appropriate audit evidence, as provided for in the international audit principles; • the interested parties put high trust in the Court's reports and generally considered them fair, objective and objective.
The Court welcomes the constructive comments and recommendations made by peers, which identify ways of further strengthening their role as the Supreme Audit Authority and highlight the challenges involved.
These include the need to develop a culture that focuses on the Court's uniform approach as an audit body; • strengthen quality assurance and quality control activities with a view to the consistent interpretation and application of its audit strategies and methods; • develop risk-oriented audit strategies to best use resources in view of the different needs of those addressed.
The peer review report acknowledges that most of the recommendations have already been anticipated in the pre-procedure action plan.
The Court intends to include the other recommendations in its 2009-2012 audit strategy after an exchange with its staff and addressees and will endeavour to implement them during that period.

CENTRAL SERVICE INDICATORS In 2008, the Court decided to introduce a system of key performance indicators (CLIs) for its audit-related and non-audit-related activities in order to measure performance in achieving the Court's strategic objectives and objectives set out in the Annual Work Programme.
ZLI will strengthen internal and external accountability and enhance work efficiency and quality. ZLI will be gradually introduced in 2009 and 2010.
• to inform management of the success of the Court as an institution in implementing what it has undertaken; • to support the decision-making process by paying attention to efficiency issues and promoting improvements; • to provide information to the audience on relevant aspects related to the Court's performance.
They are intended to provide information about the performance of the Court as a "company" and become an integral part of the Court's management system.
The amount and quality of audit work can also be improved by considering the impact of the Court's reports and opinions on financial management.
Four key performance indicators (1 to 4) are used to measure the impact of the Court's work.
They will be developed with a view to their inclusion in the Court's annual work programme for 2010.
The Court has measured the performance in 2008 on the basis of the ZLI 5 and 6.
ZLI 5 – Number of reports adopted compared to the number of reports planned In 2008, the Court adopted 79% of the planned number of reports.
The annual report and most special annual reports were adopted as planned.
Of the planned 20 special reports, only twelve were adopted.
The remaining eight special reports were still in the drafting phase as at 31 December 2008.
ZLI 6 – Number of reports adopted on time In 2008, the Court adopted 73% of its reports on time.
The annual report and all the specific annual reports were adopted on time, while further efforts are needed to improve compliance with the deadlines for the adoption of the special reports.
ZLI 7, which will measure the number of key audit notifications issued on time, will provide useful performance information and will be prepared in 2009.
A CLI (8) covers aspects relating to the Court's financial management.
Two ZLI (9 and 10) will contribute to improving staff satisfaction and optimise the use of vocational training as an instrument to update on-going knowledge of the latest testing methods and techniques.

INTERNATIONAL CO-OPERATION CO-OPERATION WITH THE EU'S NATIONAL INSTITUTIONS OF ACCOUNTS Pursuant to the EC Treaty, the ERH carried out its audit in "Connection with the Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCBs), while in the Treaty of Amsterdam it was later added: "The Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies are working together with confidence while maintaining their independence. However, in the Treaty of Nice this regulation was extended by the fact that in the 18th declaration of the Final Act, the Court of Auditors was expressly requested to set up a Committee for contacts with the national audit bodies in which all Presidents of the SAIs and the Court meet each year to discuss matters of common interest.
In December 2008, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the Contact Committee of the Presidents of the EU-ORKB.
The meeting focused on the reform of the EU budget and the revised Lisbon Strategy for the period 2008-2011.
The Contact Committee shall seek to strengthen cooperation among its members with a view to improving external audit and accountability in the EU.
The role of the Contact Committee has developed over the years in parallel with European integration.
In addition to facilitating the exchange of information between the SAIs and the ERA, this body has made significant progress in effective cooperation between the various control authorities.
At its meeting in Helsinki in 2007, the Contact Committee recognised the need to tackle emerging or new issues in a timely manner and agreed to provide a permanent agenda item for dealing with such topical issues.
Accordingly, at its 2008 meeting, the Contact Committee discussed the economic and financial crisis and agreed to organise a workshop on the role of the EU ORCB in the context of the crisis.
A network to promote cooperation on audits related to the Lisbon Strategy and EU crisis management measures was set up.
The Court took part in meetings of the Network of SAIs of Candidate Countries and Candidate Countries ‘in speiven' (Turkey, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Albania, Bosnia-Herzegovina and Montenegro).
These meetings were held at the same time as liaison officers' meetings in May and October.
A delegation from the Court also participated in a workshop organised by the Network on 8 and 9 July in Ankara, Turkey, to examine/evaluate systems of internal control of public finances.
Throughout 2008, the Court actively participated in the various working groups set up by the Contact Committee.
The Working Group on Common Audit Standards, whose objective is to develop common audit standards tailored to the EU environment and comparable audit standards based on internationally recognised audit standards, met four times in 2008 under the chairmanship of the Court.
With effect from December 2008, the Court took over the (rotating) chair of the Working Group on Value Added Tax, and the agricultural expert network resumed its work under the chairmanship of a member of the Court.
OTHER INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international audit principles and procedures through its membership of European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, namely EUROSAI and INTOSAI.
A delegation from the Court attended the VII EUROSAI Congress, which took place in Krakow (Poland) from 2 to 5 June.
The main topics discussed included the introduction of audit-related quality management systems in an SAIs, the examination of social programmes in the field of training and the vocational integration of disabled people.
The President of the Court presented a contribution to the role of management in the introduction of a quality management system for auditing.
Within the framework of EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the environmental working group and in the IT working group and participates in the EUROSAI Training Committee.
It also participates in the working group set up at the VII EUROSAI Congress to draw up a guide to best practice in achieving quality in SAIs.
The Court is also a member of the EUROSAI Task Force on Disaster Relief. 42
At the EUROSAI Congress, the European Court of Auditors, together with the Supreme Audit Authority of the Slovak Republic, was appointed as auditor for the period 2009-2011.
Since the Court became a full member of INTOSAI in 2004, it has actively participated in the Subcommittee for Guidelines for Auditing Accounting (FAS), the Subcommittee for Auditing Compliance with Legal Standards (CAS) and the Subcommittee for Economic Audits (PAS).
The Court contributed to the Subcommittee to promote best practices and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews.
Since 2008, the Court has been chairing the Working Group on the Accountability and Audit of Disaster Relief (subsequent INTOSAI Task Force Tsunami).
A first meeting of this working group was organised by the Court as host from 30 June to 2 July 2008.
The draft work programme for the period 2008-2010 was discussed and adopted at this meeting.
The main objective is to develop guidelines for accountability and audit in this field, with all stakeholders to be achieved through the relevant certification body.
In addition to its coordinating role, the Court has assumed responsibility for a number of tasks, two of which are in cooperation with the Norwegian Court of Auditors.
The chairmanship of this working group also requires the Court to be represented in the meetings of the INTOSAI Bureau. 43

They have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
As a key performance indicator (ZLI 9) for human resources, the Court established the assessment of the level of satisfaction of the Court's staff.
To this end, a satisfaction survey has been carried out to provide information on this issue and to support the decision-making process in this area.

TRANSLATION Translation is an important administrative task that enables the Court to achieve its communication objectives and fulfil its legal obligation to publish in 22 languages.
The volume of translation increased by 17% in 2008, mainly due to the adoption of a higher number of special reports.
The vast majority of translations are done internally, and in peak times when the normal capacity of the translation departments is exceeded, translation contracts are awarded to the Translation Centre (CTOU) or to external translation agencies.
In addition, the translators participate in examination trips and support the examiners before, during and after examination trips, including in the subsequent stages of drafting audit reports.
The translators shall provide constant support in the ongoing updating of the contents of the intranet and the website in English and French.
They also support INTOSAI working groups and meet other specific needs in relation to the Court's activities.
The Court's Translation Directorate is actively involved in the work of the Interinstitutional Translation and Interpretation Committee (CITI), is a member of international committees and participates in international conferences related to the development of electronic translation and documentation tools.
ATTACHMENTS In the course of the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to Member States and other recipient countries from EU funds in order to obtain appropriate audit evidence.
The visits are normally carried out by central and local authorities involved in granting, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as by their final beneficiaries.
The audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors and the length of an examination trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and the distance.
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member State visited, which provide useful logistical and practical support. 47
In 2008 expenses of 3.29 million euros were incurred in connection with audit trips.
This substantial investment is needed to ensure adequate audit coverage of all levels and locations of the management of EU funds.
The graphs below provide an overview of the number of audit missions carried out by the Court in 2008 in the EU Member States and outside the Union.

VOCATIONAL TRAINING The occupation of the examiner requires continuous training.
In 2008, the Court's employees completed an average of ten days of professional training.
The number of specialist training activities increased considerably compared to 2007.
In 2008, the Court increased its support for the participation of its staff in ongoing programmes to acquire or maintain professional qualifications and qualifications in the areas of external audit, internal audit and IT audit.
Language courses accounted for 48% of the total number of training days in 2008 (compared to 52% in 2007).
Without taking into account the language courses, the examiners completed seven days of professional training in 2008.
On the basis of the long-term strategic objective "Continuing development and growth" and the 2008-2011 training framework and the continuing training pathways adopted in 2008, the Professional Training Unit has improved the content of the training activities and developed new training courses in line with the priorities agreed by the Court.
In addition, cooperation with the other institutions and interinstitutional bodies such as the European School of Administration has been successfully continued.

During the duration of the programme, relatively high administrative costs (for the Commission, the Agency and the participants) were incurred – about the same amount as the amount paid to participants during the same period.
The creation of the Executive Agency had improved the satisfaction of the participants with the programme.

4 PREFACE OF THE PRESIDENT 4 Welcome to read the Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors for 2009.
The purpose of this report is to provide readers with an overview of the main findings and progress made by the Court during this year and to inform them of the main developments in its audit environment and internal organisation.
2009 was an important year of renewal for the EU, marked by the election of a new European Parliament, the entry into force of the Lisbon Treaty and the launch of the process of selecting a new European Commission.
The new Treaty confirms the role and mandate of the Court and its status as an EU institution and introduces changes to the management and control of EU funds, strengthening the role of the European Parliament and emphasising the responsibility of Member States for the implementation of the budget.
The Court expects these developments to provide good opportunities to improve EU financial management.
The section entitled ‘The Court's point of view' provides a summary of our opinion on the risks and challenges that the new Commission will face.
The quality of EU spending is given a high priority.
During this year, we have made considerable progress in implementing our 2009-2012 audit strategy and on the road to achieving our objectives – increasing the impact of our work and improving the use of our resources.
A decisive step was our decision to submit to the Council of the European Union a new Rules of Procedure for approval to streamline our procedures for the adoption of reports and opinions.
In addition, the number of reports prepared by the Court increased from 42 in 2008 to 57 in 2009.
I am also pleased to report that our core product, the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, once again received a positive reception from our main institutional addressees, who agreed with many of our recommendations.
During 2009, the Court continued its active cooperation with Member States' Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCBs) to develop common approaches for assessing EU funds and to consider how SAIs can help governments to cope with the financial and economic crisis.
The Court's achievements depend on the competence and motivation of its 880 employees.
Their satisfaction is a key factor in the Court's success and is first quantified in this report.
I would like to thank the Court's staff for their tireless and dedicated work, which enables the Court to carry out its mission.

As an external auditor of the EU, he contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.

8 ROLE AND WORK OF THE HOF 8 CAPITAL OF THE HOF IS THE EU BUDGET The European Union's budget (2010) amounts to around EUR 123 billion, representing about 1% of the gross national income (GNI) of its 27 Member States.
However, for some Member States, EU funds play an important role in the financing of public activities, and the overall budget is considerable compared to the GNI of several Member States.
The European Union's revenue consists mainly of contributions from Member States derived from their gross national income (GNI – 76%), customs duties and agricultural duties (the so-called traditional own resources – 12%) and a contribution based on VAT collected by Member States (VAT – 11%).
BOX 1 – WHAT IS THE EU TAKEN OUT OF THE EU?
The EU budget is financed by Member States' financial contributions (mainly on the basis of national GNI), customs duties and agricultural duties, and VAT contributions.
The EU budget is largely used for purposes other than national budgets, partly due to different areas of responsibility.
Citizenship, freedom, security and justice 1, 1 % Conservation and management of natural resources (mainly agriculture) 47,3 % The EU's largest single area of expenditure is agriculture and rural development, mainly in the form of payments to farmers, accounting for almost half of the budget expenditure.
Cohesion measures – regional and social development – also make up a large proportion of these, which co-finances a wide range of projects, from road construction projects in Latvia to training for the unemployed in the Netherlands.
This sector accounts for about one third of the budget expenditure.
The European Union as a global player EU expenditure Source: General budget of the European Union for the financial year 2010. Administration 6.4% 6.3 % Sustainable growth (mainly cohesion) 38.8%
The budget is established annually, on the basis of the seven-year financial framework, by the Council, i.e. by representatives of the Member States, and by the directly elected European Parliament.
The European Commission shall draw up the budget and shall also be responsible for its implementation.
The bulk of the budget, in particular in the area of expenditure on agricultural and cohesion policy, is implemented in cooperation with the Member States.
A particular feature of Community expenditure is the high percentage of payments based on the beneficiary's own applications, whether farmers or project managers throughout the Union. 9
10 WHAT ROLE HAS THE HOF?
Democratic societies need correct, publicly available information as a basis for discussion and decision-making both in terms of improving financial management and ensuring accountability.
In its role as external auditor of the EU, the European Court of Auditors ensures that EU funds have been correctly accounted for regardless of their place of use and spent in accordance with the relevant legislation and taking due account of the need for optimal use of funds.
The Court's audit results are used by the Commission, Parliament and the Council, as well as by Member States to improve EU financial management.
In addition to the Court's work, many national control authorities are examining EU funds, provided they are managed and spent by public authorities in the Member States.
OVERVIEW OF INTERNAL AND EXTERNAL CONTROL OF EU BUDGET Commission (DGs, Internal Audit Service) Member States Implementing Bodies European Court of Auditors National control authorities National level Internal control External control
(ACCOUNT OF ACCOUNTS) 2. Are financial operations in all essential respects consistent with the relevant legal and other regulatory framework?
(COMPLIANCE VERIFICATION) 3. Is the financial management sound, i.e. has the use of resources been kept to a minimum (sparability), has the results been achieved with the lowest possible use of resources (economic efficiency) and has the desired objectives been achieved (effectiveness)?
The Court shall publish the results of its audit work in the following types of reports: Annual reports – with the results of the audit of the accounts in the form of a statement of assurance on the implementation of the general budget2 and on the activities of the European Development Funds3.
Special annual reports – with the results of the audit of the accounts of the Union's agencies and decentralised bodies.
11 1 For more information on the Court's audit methods, see the manuals available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
2 In accordance with the TFEU, the Court is obliged to make such a statement – or an audit opinion – on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The annual Statement of Assurance is generally known under the French acronym DAS (Déclaration d敘Assurance).
12 HOW DOES THE HOF PRESENT IN HIS TESTS?
The Court shall carry out its audit of the EU's annual accounts in accordance with international audit principles, which shall apply in both the public and private sectors.
However, the existing international auditing principles do not cover the audit carried out by the Court.
The Court, together with the national control authorities, actively participates in the further development of international audit principles promoted by the standard-setting organisations (INTOSAI, IFAC)4.
In order to ensure that payments are consistent with the legal and other regulatory frameworks, the Court relies on the results of both its investigation of monitoring and control systems to prevent or to detect and correct errors of legality and regularity, as well as a sample of individual transactions (payments) (see Box 2).
Other sources, such as statements by the management of the audited bodies in the form of the Annual Activity Reports of the Directors-General of the Commission and the work of other auditors, are also used to support the Court's conclusions.
In the case of economic audits, the Court uses a large number of audit methods to assess the administrative and monitoring systems and to assess performance data on the basis of the criteria derived from the legislation and with a view to the principles of sound financial management.
When selecting issues for its business audits, the Court seeks to identify areas where the greatest impact is to be expected in terms of the potential for improvement identified in terms of economy, efficiency and effectiveness of EU expenditure.
3 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are based on international agreements concluded between the Community and its Member States and certain African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) as well as on Council decisions on the association of overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
The Commission manages most of the expenditure related to the ACP countries, partly through the EuropeAid Cooperation Office (see External Relations, Development and Enlargement) and partly through delegations in the beneficiary countries.
4 INTOSAI (International Organisation of Supreme Audit Institutions) – International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions; IFAC (International Federation of Accountants) – International Auditing Association.
BOX 2 – EXAMINATION OF A SAMPLE OF PAYMENTS FROM THE EU BUDGET BY THE HOF 13 The Court does not have the necessary resources to examine in detail all transactions relating to the EU budget.
It therefore uses statistical sampling techniques to provide a representative result for the populations concerned.
The Court follows these processes up to the final beneficiary of the grant, for example a promoter in Italy.
The Court then checks – often on the spot – whether the application is in line with the actual circumstances.
By being a representative sample, the results may be extrapolated to the population concerned, i.e. a specific area of revenue or expenditure, and will serve as a basis for an overall audit opinion, together with information resulting from the assessment of management and control systems and other sources.
SELECTION OF A SAMPLE OF PROPOSALS Random selection of a representative sample Population of cohesion payments Payment to a promoter in Italy
14 TASKS AND RESPONSIBILITIES5 14 GUIDANCE STRUCTURE AND ORGANISATION The Court of Auditors acts as a collegial body of 27 members, each with one member per Member State, appointed by the Council after consulting the European Parliament for a term of six years.
Members shall elect a President from among their number for a period of three years, with the possibility of re-election as well.
Five audit groups to which individual members of the Court are assigned prepare the reports and opinions for adoption by the Court.
The organization chart shows that there are four thematic audit groups covering different budgetary areas, as well as another audit group dealing with 'horizontal' issues.
In addition, a Management Committee made up of members of the Court is responsible for preparing the Court's administrative decisions.
At the end of 2009, the Court sent the Council a proposal to amend its Rules of Procedure in order to allow certain categories of Court opinions and reports to be adopted instead of the entire College of Chambers.
These amendments will streamline and make the Court's decision-making process more efficient, including by reducing the time needed to adopt decisions.
Each Chamber has two areas of competence: the first is the adoption of special reports, special annual reports and opinions, the second is the preparation of draft comments on the annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds and draft opinions on the adoption by the College.
As with the Court, decisions are taken by a majority of the members of the Board.
Members may attend meetings of all chambers, but shall be entitled to vote only in the chamber to which they have been assigned by the Court.
Of course, the whole College will continue to meet to discuss and adopt those documents for which the Court alone is responsible, such as the annual reports on the EU's general budget and the European Development Funds.
The role of the Management Committee will be strengthened.
The Committee shall be composed of the President of the Court holding the chair and the Doyens of the Chambers.
Administrative matters requiring a Court decision, as well as decisions on procedural, policy or strategic issues, shall be prepared by the Committee before being submitted to the Court for adoption.
The Member shall then present the report to the audit group and to the Court and, after adoption of the report, shall also present it to the European Parliament, to the Council and to other interested third parties.
5 Further details are available on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu).
THE HOFE'S PERSONNEL The budget for the financial year 2009 provides for 880 posts for the European Court of Auditors (as at 31 December 2009).
The Court's staff in the audit area shall be responsible for the planning and carrying out of audits and the preparation of the resulting draft reports.
The auditors work in teams of different sizes: For some specific audits, a team consists of four or five auditors, while some of the Court's broader audits (e.g. audits of accounting/compliance audits in the area of agricultural and cohesion expenditure with a view to drawing up the annual statement of assurance) involve 20 or more auditors.
As a rule, auditors must obtain audit evidence in the course of an audit by means of different procedures: by examining files in Luxembourg, visits to the European Commission, and ‘on-the-spot' audit visits to the Member States, where the revenue accruing to the EU budget is created and the actions financed from the EU budget are carried out.
The Court's reports and opinions must be accessible to readers throughout the Union and, as part of its audit work, the Court must maintain contacts with authorities and other bodies throughout the Union.
This would not be possible without the Court's translators translating his (in almost all cases in English or French) reports and opinions into 22 of the official languages of the Union.
They shall also translate correspondence between the Court and other bodies, as appropriate, and in some cases assist examiners in carrying out verification visits in the Member States.
The Court's administrative staff are responsible for a large number of support tasks that arise in a multinational body operating in the EU context.
This concerns the areas of finance, accounting, budget, buildings, information technologies, transport, security, etc. The Secretary-General is the highest-ranking staff of the Court and is responsible for staff management and the management of the Court. 15

ANNUAL REPORT ON THE IMPLEMENTATION OF THE EU BUDGET: SIX KERN ASSESSMENTS • The annual accounts of the European Union give a true picture of the financial situation and the results. • As regards the legality and regularity of the transactions, the overall results for 2008 reflect the improvements in budgetary management achieved in recent years. • The overall progress achieved in 2008 is mainly due to the better results in the main theme, "Agriculture and natural resources".
In rural development, the estimated error rate is lower than in previous years, but still essential.
For the first time, the Court does not give a negative opinion on agriculture and natural resources as a whole. • The second, cohesion, which accounts for nearly one third of the budget, remains a problem as the most flawed budgetary area.
According to the Court's estimate, at least 11% of the total amount of the reimbursements should not have been paid. • The recommendations made by the Court in the past to improve monitoring and control systems will continue to be valid.
They should be seen as part of an ongoing process in which the relevant measures can only be considered effective after some time. • In addition, particular attention should be paid to those areas of expenditure in which the Court continues to object to a high error rate.
In many cases, mistakes are a result of excessively complex regulations and regulations.
That is why simplification remains a priority objective. 19
20 Unrestricted audit opinion on the reliability of the accounts The Court concluded that the 2008 annual accounts of the European Communities provide a true and fair view of the financial situation of the European Communities and of the results of its operations and cash flows.
Unrestricted audit opinions In 2008, the Court issued full audit opinions on ‘Revenues', commitments in all areas and payments in the themes ‘Education and citizenship' and ‘Administrative and other expenditure'.
A limited audit opinion Payments in the "Agriculture and natural resources" theme, with the exception of rural development, were lawful and correct in all essential respects.
Payments in the theme 'Economy and finance', with the exception of expenditure on the Sixth Framework Programme for Research and Technological Development (FP6) covered by this theme, were legal and correct in all essential respects.
Negative opinions The Court issued negative opinions on the subjects of cohesion, research, energy and transport, as well as external aid, development and enlargement.
Payments in these themes were largely, albeit at different levels, flawed.
Increasing the need for monitoring and control systems Monitoring and control systems in the themes "Research, energy and transport", "External assistance, development and enlargement", as well as "Education and citizenship" have been of limited effectiveness in preventing or detecting and correcting the reimbursement of excessive or non-refundable costs.
In the case of the ‘Agriculture and natural resources' area, the Court also concluded that the monitoring and control systems were of limited effectiveness.
However, it pointed out that the Integrated Management and Control System (IPCS) remains an effective control system in general.
However, improvements are needed in some areas, in particular rural development, where shortcomings exist.
In the case of the theme 'Economy and finance', the monitoring and control systems have been found to be effective in two of the three areas examined.
In the third area, "Companies", the systems were only considered to be conditionally effective, mainly due to shortcomings in FP6.
In the case of the ‘Cohesion' theme, the Court found that the Member States' systems dedicated to the correction of errors detected in national controls have, in most cases, been at least partially effective.
The Commission, the Member States and other beneficiary countries need to make further efforts to implement the necessary improvements in these themes in order to adequately manage the risk of illegal expenditure.
BOX 3 – INTERPRETATION OF AUDIT CASES 21 An auditor may issue the following types of audit opinions: • full audit opinion if it is proven that the accounting is reliable or that the underlying transactions, i.e. payments, are lawful and correct on all essential points; • negative audit opinion if the error rate in the underlying transactions is material and comprehensive or the accounting is not reliable; • refusal of the audit opinion if the auditor cannot obtain sufficient and adequate audit evidence to support his audit opinion and the possible effects are both material and comprehensive; limited audit opinion if no full audit opinion can be given, but the effects of differences or limitations on the scope of the audit are not so significant or comprehensive that they require a negative audit opinion or refusal of the audit opinion.

THE 2008 AUDIT AUTHORITY TO THE EDF The Court concluded that the 2008 EDF financial statements give an accurate picture of the financial situation of the EDFs in all essential respects.
As regards the legality and regularity of operations, the Court gave a full audit opinion on EDF revenue and commitments.

SPECIAL ANNUAL REPORTS A further 37 special annual reports on the agencies and other decentralised bodies of the European Union for the financial year 2008 were adopted in 2009.
The Union agencies shall perform a wide range of tasks at different locations within the Union.
Each agency has a specific mission and manages its own budget.
The audits of the Union agencies and other decentralised bodies shall be the subject of specific annual reports, which shall be published separately.
With the exception of the European Police College, the Court issued full audit opinions for all agencies on the reliability of the accounts and on the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions. 23
24 SPECIAL REPORTS7 The selection of topics for economic and compliance audits and their design is based on criteria such as the risk to the profitability of certain revenue and expenditures or their compliance with legislation, expenditure volume, timing of the latest audit, upcoming developments in the regulatory or operational framework, as well as political and public interest.
Since cost-effectiveness and compliance checks are complex and require a lot of detail work, their full implementation from the preliminary study to the final reporting usually takes more than a year.
The Court adopted a total of 18 special reports in 2009.
The special reports are available directly on the Court's website (www.eca.europa.eu) and a reference to their publication appears in the Official Journal.
As in previous years, the reports related to investigations into financial management issues in many different areas, ranging, for example, from EU food aid for the most deprived (No 6/2009) to cash management at the Commission (No 5/2009).
In addition to the 18 special reports, the Court analysed the use of EU funds in 2009 with a view to turning the Chernobyl site into environmentally safe conditions.
Recommendations on how to improve the management of EU funds made available through the EBRD were sent to the President of the Commission in a (unpublished) letter from the President of the Court.
The special reports adopted by the Court in 2009 are listed below by thematic area.
In order to illustrate the nature of the issues addressed and the conclusions drawn, a brief report will be presented on each topic.
7 special reports are available on the Court's website or can be obtained with an electronic order form from the EU Bookshop.
SUSTAINABLE GROWTH • No 3/2009 "Effectiveness of expenditures under structural measures for waste water treatment during the 1994-1999 and 2000-2006 programming periods" • No 7/2009 "Management of the development and validation phase of the Galileo programme" • No 8/2009 "Excellence networks and integrated projects in the Community research policy: have the objectives been achieved?" • No 13/2009 "Has the transfer of implementing tasks to executive agencies proved to be an appropriate instrument?" • No 17/2009 "Vocational training measures for women co-financed by the European Social Fund" 25 Management of the Galileo programme's development and validation phase The Court examined the development and validation phase of the Galileo programme, which was launched with the aim of creating a European Global Satellite Navigation System (GNSS) and explained the causes of the misdevelopments identified.
It concluded that the development and validation phase was inadequately managed.
The Commission must significantly improve its programme management if the realignment of the EGNOS (European Geostationary Navigation Supplement Service) and Galileo programmes in mid-2007 are to be successful.
The report contains a number of recommendations designed to facilitate this task for the Commission.
Finally, if the EU decides to engage in other major infrastructure programmes, the Commission must ensure that appropriate administrative instruments are available to it.
MONITORING AND MANAGEMENT OF NATURAL RESOURCES • No 6/2009 "European Union food aid for the most deprived: assessment of objectives, resources and methods employed" • No 10/2009 "Information and promotion measures for agricultural products" • No 11/2009 "Sustainability of LIFE-Nature projects and their management by the Commission" • No 14/2009 "Have the market control instruments for the market in milk and milk products achieved their main objectives?
26 Have the market management instruments for the market in milk and milk products achieved their main objectives?
The Court took stock of the functioning of the market in milk and milk products since the introduction of milk quotas in 1984 and examined the Commission's approach in the management of the gradual deregulation of the milk sector, which began in 2003.
The situation at the end of 2008 is the basis for the Court's recommendations to the Commission: preventing new overproduction, monitoring the price formation process in the food chain, deepening the reflection on the future of producers in disadvantaged areas and on the impact of the geographical concentration of milk production on the environment, continuing the focus of milk production on meeting the needs of the European single market and on milk products with high added value which are exportable without budget support to the world market.
EU CITIZENSHIP, FREEDOM, SECURITY AND JUSTICE • No 2/2009 ‘The European Union Public Health Programme (2003-2007): an effective way to improve health?' The European Union Public Health Programme (2003-2007): an effective way to improve health?
The Court analysed the European Union Public Health Programme (HPH) for the period 2003-2007.
The Court's audit was aimed at determining whether the framework conditions for projects financed by the EU budget were defined in such a way as to effectively complement Member States' actions to protect and improve public health.
The report shall contain detailed conclusions and recommendations on the design, implementation and management of the programme.
On the basis of its findings, the Court calls into question the benefits of certain programme components of European public health programmes such as PHP.
The Commission and the Member States are invited to reconsider the EU's public health funding approach.
THE EU AS GLOBALER PARTNER • No 1/2009 "Banking activities in the Mediterranean region under the MEDA programme and the previous Protocols" • No 4/2009 "Management of the involvement of non-state actors in Community development cooperation by the Commission" • No 12/2009 "The effectiveness of Commission projects in the area of justice and home affairs for the Western Balkans" • No 15/2009 "The EU's assistance provided through United Nations organisations: decision-making and control" • No 16/2009 "The European Commission's management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey" • No 18/2009 "The effectiveness of EDF assistance for regional economic integration in East Africa and West Africa" 27 The European Commission's management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey The Court examined the management of pre-accession assistance to Turkey by the European Commission.
In particular, the first period of implementation of pre-accession aid (2002-2006) was characterised by many weaknesses that had already occurred in previous pre-accession programmes.
The objectives set by the Commission with regard to grants were not sufficiently concrete to allow for an evaluation of the impact of the project and the Commission did not have the necessary information to demonstrate the effectiveness of pre-accession assistance.
Nevertheless, the projects examined provided the planned outputs and the project results are likely to be sustainable.
The Commission has already made some significant improvements, but the Court makes recommendations for further corrective action.
Areas where improvements are most necessary include defining strategic objectives for financial assistance, setting more realistic deadlines for achieving objectives, and monitoring actual project performance and results on the basis of clear objectives and appropriate indicators.
28 MANAGEMENT • No 5/2009 'Administration of funds to the Commission' • No 9/2009 'Economy and effectiveness of personnel selection activities of the European Personnel Selection Office' Economic efficiency and effectiveness of staff selection activities of the European Personnel Selection Office The Court focused on how the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) managed the sharp increase in the number of selection procedures resulting from the enlargement of the European Union and whether it provided timely aptitude lists containing the required number of successful candidates and were geographically balanced.
It concluded that EPSO had successfully managed the increase in the number of competitions as a result of the enlargement of the European Union.
However, the following weaknesses were to be overcome: the staffing needs of the institutions were not notified to the EPSO in time, the personnel selection process took too long, the selection process produced on average only two-thirds of the planned number of successful candidates (inscribed in the aptitude list) and the management information was not consistently reliable or complete.
OPINIONS The Court's further contribution to improving EU financial management is to deliver opinions on proposals or budgetary management issues.
These opinions are required as part of the procedure for the adoption of financial rules8, or may be submitted at the request of one of the other institutions of the Union9.
In 2009, the Court adopted an opinion on the proposal to amend the Regulation of the Budget Committee of the Office for Harmonisation in the Internal Market on the Office's financial rules (‘the Financial Regulation').

29 CONTINUATION AND EFFECTIVENESS The Court's audits serve as a direct source of information for decision-makers in the institutions concerned, primarily the Commission, Parliament, the Council and the Member States, in the European context.
On the basis of that information, they may take measures with or without reference to the Court's conclusions on the audit.
Although the Court's audit activity has its main effect on the reports and opinions published, it has already had some effect throughout the course of the audits.
The replies of the audited body, namely the Commission, will be 29 together. Examples of the impact of the Court's work can be found in actions taken by the Commission in response to the 2007 discharge resolution (and their impact mainly came into effect in 2009): In the area of agricultural expenditure The management and control system for expenditure under the newly created European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) has been aligned with the EAGF guarantee system, so that the largely recognised benefits of this system will also apply to EAFRD expenditure (see point 5.54 of the annual report for the financial year 2004 and point 5.57 of the 2007 annual report).
In the area of cohesion The Commission is continuing to work on a revision of the rules applicable for 2007-2013 in order to simplify the system for reporting irregularities, and has undertaken to prepare a report in early 2010 on the measures implemented in 2009 and the initial impact of all the measures in its action plan to strengthen the Commission's supervisory role in the management of structural measures (see points 1.53 and 6.36(a) of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the field of external policies In order to strengthen controls at the level of implementing organisations, the Commission plans to develop a specific instrument to better assist these organisations in the management of EU funds and compliance with EU rules (see point 8.33(a) of the 2007 Annual Report).
In the field of internal policies, including research The Commission has established a multiannual control strategy for the Sixth Framework Programme, based on the detection and correction of errors that could not be detected by file checks prior to payment.
In order to simplify the procedures of the Seventh Framework Programme, the Commission introduced a Participant Guarantee Fund which has significantly reduced the number of ex ante financial controls and the safeguards to be provided (see points 7.43(b), 10.34 and 2.42(a) of the 2007 annual report).
Source: Commission report to the European Parliament on the follow-up to the 2007 discharge decisions.
The special reports will also be taken into account in the discharge procedure.
Due to the fact that they are published during the course of the year, the presentation of the special reports and the debate on this matter have usually taken place at an earlier stage at the meetings of Parliament and the Council.
The impact of the audit reports can be enhanced by the thematic nature of the reports in the relevant media, which provides greater attention and stimulates public debate.
As a rule, media coverage of the Court's annual report is quite comprehensive.
This was also the case in 2009, with media attention focused primarily on improvements in agricultural spending.
Several special reports were also followed with interest by the press.
For example, the special report on the milk market (No 14/2009), which assessed the extent to which the management instruments for the milk and milk products market have achieved their main objectives, was the subject of intensive discussions in the Council and in Parliament, and at a time when the sector is facing a variety of problems, it triggered a wide response in the media and in the professions concerned.
The Court is working to further analyse the impact of its work.
In 2009, it started to develop a systematic follow-up process for its special reports to identify and document progress made by the audited bodies in addressing identified weaknesses and implementing the recommendations made.
This procedure will provide the Court, as well as Parliament and other interested parties, with additional feedback on the impact of its activities.
31 POSITION OF THE COURT OPINION No 1/2010 – IMPROVEMENT OF THE EUROPEAN UNION'S FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT: RISKS AND CHALLENGES In February 2010, the Court first issued an opinion on measures to reduce the level of irregular payments at the level of the EU budget and to improve the quality of expenditure (sparability, efficiency and effectiveness).
The Court concluded that, in order to improve recent progress in reducing the level of irregular payments, legislation in high-risk areas needs to be simplified and more cost-effective control systems set up.
Such reforms should be undertaken in the context of the ongoing broader review of EU spending regimes.
The Court considers that the improvement of the quality of expenditure is of high importance, which can be achieved by applying the concept of European added value in determining expenditure priorities and by addressing the specific problems identified by the Court in the selection, design and implementation of expenditure programmes and grant schemes.
LENDED GOVERNMENT ON THE FIELDS CONCERNED IN THE STRENGTH OF PROVISIONAL PAYMENTS Although the level of irregular payments from the EU budget as a whole has fallen, it remains high in the "Cohesion" and "External assistance, development and enlargement" themes, as well as in the framework programme for research and technological development and in rural development expenditure.
Most irregularities are based on the reporting of ineligible expenditure by beneficiaries, the reporting of excessive eligible expenditure and the non-compliance with payment conditions, for example in the area of public procurement rules.
They are primarily due to the complexity of the rules and payment conditions as well as to shortcomings in the management of risks at the level of the final beneficiaries.
ASSESSMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF THE SINGLE LEGAL FRAMEWORK CONDITIONS AND MONITORING AND CONTROL The Commission should address the specific system deficiencies identified by the Court in the high-risk areas and improve its oversight.
However, with more and more controls and correspondingly lower error rates, the point at which control costs are no longer proportionate to the benefits achieved is at some point reached.
Simplification should therefore remain a priority objective.
Clear and easy to interpret regulations and legislation can reduce not only the risk of errors, but also control costs. 31
32 IMPROVING THE CONCEPT OF EXPENDITURE PROGRAMMES In addition to simplification, the Commission should ensure that clear objectives are set when revising existing and shaping new measures.
Often more sense of reality and greater transparency and accountability are needed.
In this respect, the Commission could further strengthen existing procedures for the development of future strategies, in particular ex ante evaluation and impact assessment.
The Court proposes that the concept of European added value be clarified in an appropriate policy statement or in EU legislation in order to provide guidance to EU policy-makers in determining expenditure priorities.
THE GOODS REFORM TO IMPROVE EXPENDITURE QUALITY In the Court's view, the Commission should complete the budgetary review as soon as possible and take into account the results of the preparation of the financial framework starting in 2014.
Improving the quality of expenditure should be a high priority for the institutions of the European Union and thus a main objective of the new Commission.
33 HIGHING OF WORK FOR 201010 The Court shall present its future audit work annually in a work programme submitted to the European Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control and available to the public on the Court's website.
The work programme shall provide interested parties with information on new and ongoing audits and on planned reports.
The Court developed an audit strategy for the period 2009-2012 based on two priority objectives: maximising the overall impact of the audits and improving efficiency by making the best use of resources.
These objectives will be decisive for the Court's 2010 work programme and its efforts to improve continuously.
The Court seeks to maximise the overall impact of its audits over the period concerned by: • selecting and designing audits that focus on issues from risk areas and are of great interest to the Court's audience; • continuing to provide sound audit conclusions and useful suggestions for improvement and monitoring whether these proposals are being implemented; • carrying out a wider range of audits and presenting new types of audit products that complement the current annual and special reports; • producing a larger number of special reports and improving their closeness to time and ease of use; • developing its relations with its main addressees, including the relevant parliamentary committees, as well as with the media and the general public.
These include: • better management; • effective and dynamic personnel policy; • rationalisation of audit tasks; • improvement of IT tools; • development of expertise; • strengthening relations with audited bodies.
33 10 A more complete and detailed overview of the Court's future work can be found in the Court's 2010 work programme, which is available on its website (www.eca.europa.eu).
34 The Court has selected certain audit priorities for the 2010 work programme, including: • the multi-annual nature of a large proportion of Community expenditure, including flat-rate corrections and recoveries; • innovation and the internal market; • human capital; • sustainable energy; • the Commission's strategy to simplify the legal framework for businesses and citizens.
FOURTH PRINCIPLE FOR A NEW BUILDING On 1 July 2009, the foundation stone for a new building, the second extension of the European Court of Auditors, was laid in Luxembourg.
Vítor Caldeira, President of the European Court of Auditors, Claude Wiseler, Minister of Buildings in Luxembourg, Patrick Gillen, President of the Fonds d'urbanisation et d'aménagement du Kirchberg, and Eduardo Ruiz García, General Secretary of the Court, signalled the start of the construction work with the symbolic first groundbreaking ceremony.
This extension of the European Court of Auditors' building complex, which already consists of two buildings, will make it possible to accommodate staff recruited in the course of successive Union enlargements.
The Court will seek to broaden its range of audit-related reporting types in 2009-2012.
To this end, it will coordinate with its main external addressees to ensure that it obtains a clear understanding of their different needs and how it can best meet its expectations in the fulfilment of its mandate under the Treaty.
A significant part of the resources available to the Court will be used to audit the accounts with a view to drawing up a statement of assurance (the so-called ‘DAS').
This requires the examination and audit of the accounts and transactions under the EU's general budget for each financial year.
Separate Statements of Assurance shall be drawn up on the European Development Funds and on each of the 40 European agencies and bodies.
The audit work covers from June of year n to June of year n+1 so that the annual reports can be published in accordance with the Financial Regulation in November of year n+1.
The Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2009 is therefore drawn up and published in 2010 and at the same time the Statement of Assurance for the financial year 2010 will start11.
The Court's work aims at providing clear conclusions on the status of accounting and budgetary management in the various areas of the general budget, as well as providing appropriate and cost-effective recommendations where improvements are possible.
The Court's annual report on the general budget for 2009 will continue to be in line with the structure established in 2007 and taking into account the redeployment of the budget12.
The findings are presented within the framework of chapters which relate to coherent groups of policy areas (thematics), which largely, but not entirely, correspond to the headings of the new financial framework.
It will also be a particular concern of the Court to present its results and conclusions more clearly and coherently to make them more comprehensible and readable and to simplify comparisons within and between themes and between them and between financial years.
