36 36 MEASUREMENT AND IMPROVEMENT OF CENTRAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS In 2008, the Court decided to establish a system of key performance indicators (CLI) for its audit and non-audit activities in order to measure performance in achieving the Court's strategic objectives and objectives set out in the annual work programmes.
ZLI serves to strengthen internal and external accountability and increase work efficiency and quality. WOZU CENTRAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS? • To inform management of the success of the Court as an institution in implementing what it has undertaken; • To support the decision-making process, by focusing the institution's attention on efficiency issues and promoting improvements; • To provide the audience with information on relevant aspects related to the Court's performance.
The main purpose of the CSOs is to achieve the Court's strategic objectives by covering quality of audit, output, impact and economic management of the Court's resources.
They provide information on the Court's performance as "enterprises", and are an integral part of the Court's management system.
THE CENTRAL PERFORMANCE INDICATORS OF THE COURT 37 ZLI 1 Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit activities by the main addressees of the Court's reports ZLI 2 Assessment of the quality and impact of the Court's audit activities by the audited Body ZLI 3 Evaluation of the content and presentation of the Court's reports by a panel of external experts ZLI 4 Percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the audited Body a) Implementation of the audited Body within a certain number of years ZLI 5 Number of approved reports compared to the number of planned reports ZLI 6 Number of reports accepted on schedule ZLI 7 Percentage of audit reports produced on time ZLI 8 External evaluation of the Court's financial management: a) Audit judgment of the independent auditor b) Decision of the discharge authority ZLI 9 Degree of satisfaction of the Court's staff ZLI 10 Average number of training days per person Quantity and quality of audit work can also be improved when considering the impact of the Court's reports and opinions on financial management.
Four key performance indicators (1 to 4) are used to measure the impact of the Court's work.
They were included in the Court's 2010 annual work programme.
38 Number of reports adopted compared to the number of reports planned In 2009, the Court adopted 91% of the planned number of reports.
The annual report and all special annual reports were adopted as planned.
Of the planned 24 special reports, only 18 were adopted.
The remaining six special reports were still in the final drafting phase as at 31 December 2009.
Number of reports adopted on time In 2009, the Court adopted 67% of its reports within the given timeframe.
The annual report and all specific annual reports were adopted on time.
Due to delays in the Special Reports, the Court failed to set the ZLI 6 target 6. Further efforts are needed to improve compliance with the deadlines for the adoption of the Special Reports.
Measurement of the number of key audit statements prepared on time The Court shall forward its preliminary audit results to the audited body in an audit report.
It seeks to increase the proportion of audit communications submitted on time by 10 % per year, the long-term objective being to produce 80 % of audit communications within the specified timeframe (two months after the final audit visit).
In 2009, the number of audit notifications issued on time increased by 16 % compared to 2008.
External assessment of the Court's financial management: a) Audit opinion of the independent auditor, b) Decision of the discharge authority The independent auditor of the Court gave a full audit opinion on the annual accounts and the use of resources, and the European Parliament, on a positive recommendation from the Council, gave discharge.
Degree of satisfaction of the Court's staff In an internal employee satisfaction survey conducted in 2009, 86% of the Court's employees were generally satisfied with their work (target: 80 %), while the overall level of employee satisfaction was 2.8 on a scale of 4 (target: 2.5).
Average number of training days for examiners (excluding language courses) In line with guidelines published by IFAC (International Federation of Accountants), the Court strives to provide examiners with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training.
In 2009, the average was four days.
39 INTERNATIONAL COOPERATION The Court continued its international cooperation in the framework of the following fora: • the Contact Committee composed of the Presidents of the Supreme Audit Institutions of the EU Member States and the Court; • the Network of Supreme Audit Institutions of the Countries applying for EU membership; • the European Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (EUROSAI); and • the International Organization of Supreme Audit Institutions (INTOSAI).
The Court contributed to the annual meetings of these organisations and to the improvement of international audit principles and procedures and was also actively involved in the committees and working groups set up by these organisations.
In particular, he took on the following tasks: • Chair of the Working Groups "Common Audit Standards" and "VAT"; • Participation in the Working Groups "Reports of National SAIs" and "Structural Funds" set up by the Contact Committee; • Participation in the EUROSAI Environmental Working Group and the IT Working Group, in the EUROSAI Group, which prepares a guide on good practices for achieving quality, in the EUROSAI Training Committee and in the EUROSAI Task Force on the Audit of Disaster Aids; • Chair of the INTOSAI Working Group on Accountability and Auditing of Disaster Aid; • Participation in the INTOSAI Sub-Committees on Guidelines for Auditing Accounting, for Auditing Compliance with Legal Standards and Economic Assessments, and in the Task Force on the Global Financial Crisis.
40 40 PERSONAL AND SUPPORT SERVICES The Court's most important capital is its employees.
At 31 December 2009, the staff of the Court amounted to 880 staff (officials and temporary staff, but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of the staff, 525 (including 115 in the members' cabinets) were audit-related; 163 were translators, 171 were administrative support staff, and 21 were presidents.
The Court's employees have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
RECOGNITION OF THE HOF'S PLANTS TO 31 DECEMBER (occupied and vacant posts) Translation Administrative support The Court has committed itself to achieving its strategic goal of improving efficiency through the best possible use of resources.
Therefore, in 2009 it continued to explore and exploit the potential for efficiency gains in all its activities by simplifying procedures and streamlining services.
In particular, the resources of the support services, which have become available through efficiency gains, have been deducted from these services as far as possible and made available for audit-related tasks.
This process has not yet been completed and its impact will be even more evident in 2010.
As a central performance indicator (ZLI 9) for human resources, the Court has defined the assessment of the level of satisfaction of the Court's staff (see page 37).
To this end, a satisfaction survey has been carried out to provide information on this issue and to support the decision-making process in this area.
The Court is implementing measures to ensure that opportunities are fully exploited to achieve better results in the coming years.

TERMINATION The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions and the staff consists of both officials and temporary staff.
General selection procedures for posts at the Court are organised by the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
The Court also provides placements for a limited number of university graduates for periods of three to five months.
In 2009, the Court hired 112 employees: 69 officials, 14 temporary staff and 29 contract staff.
The recruitment depends on whether reserve lists of EPSO competitions are available and sufficient.
In 2009, the Court succeeded in recruiting an adequate number of new staff.
73 vacant posts as at 31 December 2009 were reduced by 33% to 49 by 26 January 2010. The number of vacant posts will continue to fall sharply in the coming months, as further audit officers will take up their duties in the wake of the recent recruitment wave.
At 31 December 2008, 68 posts were not filled.
The reserve list for recruitment on the basis of the EPSO AD/126/08 selection procedure was published in August and the first successful candidates entered the Court's service at the beginning of November, i.e. only three months later.
VOCATIONAL TRAINING The occupation of the examiner requires continuous training.
In addition, due to the specific circumstances of the Court's audit environment, the auditors need good knowledge of foreign languages.
In 2009, the Court staff completed an average of nine days of professional training.
Language courses accounted for 64% of the total number of training days in 2009 (compared to 48% in 2008).
Without taking the language courses into account, the examiners completed four days of professional training in 2009 (see ZLI 10 on page 38).
This figure is expected to increase in 2010 as new staff have to go through a mandatory training programme.
On the basis of the long-term strategic objective "Development and growth" and the 2008-2011 continuing training framework and the continuing training pathways adopted in 2009, the "Vocational Training" unit has improved the content of the continuing training activities and has developed new training courses in line with the priorities decided by the Court.
Cooperation with the other institutions and with interinstitutional bodies such as the European School of Administration has also been successfully pursued.
Box 5 presents a portrait of the staff of an examination unit within the Court to give the reader a picture of the work carried out and the persons involved. 43
44 BOX 5 – THE TEAM COMPETENT TO THE TESTING ON "JUSTIC AND INNER IN THE ESSENTIAL BALKAN" The Western Balkans were marked by violence in the past.
The European Union's interest in this region is to promote security and long-term stability.
The rule of law, border security and the fight against corruption are key prerequisites for EU accession and are a major challenge in the Western Balkans.
The European Commission is the main donor of funding in the region.
The Court's report on the effectiveness of Commission projects in the field of justice and home affairs for the Western Balkans (Special Report No 12/2009) produced in 2009 provided an insight into the situation in this particularly important area.
The audit covered both investment projects and institution building projects in the four areas of asylum, integrated border management, justice and police.
33 completed projects were examined on the spot, including an asylum centre, a prison in Albania, and a court in Bosnia and Herzegovina responsible for human rights and war crimes.
In addition, several EU-funded border crossing points in the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Montenegro and Serbia were visited to assess whether EU action has led to improvements.
The team responsible for carrying out the audit worked closely with the rapporteur, Maarten B. Engwirda.
The heads of the unit responsible for monitoring the audit were Raija Peltonen and Ossi Louko, and the team leader was Jussi Bright.
The examiners involved were Enrico Grassi and Miroslav Matej, with Horst Fischer and Jan Pieter Lingen from Maarten B. Engwirda's cabinet also playing an important role.
From left to right: Raija PELTONEN, Head of Unit; Jan Pieter LINGEN, Head of Cabinet; Horst FISCHER, Cabinet-Attaché; Jussi BRIGHT, Chief Auditor; Maarten B. ENGWIRDA, Member of the Court; Ossi LOUKO, Head of Unit; Enrico GRASSI, Chief Auditor; Miroslav MATEJ, Financial Auditlor; E. E.
TRANSLATION Translation is an important activity of audit support that allows the Court to fulfil its mission and to achieve its communication objectives.
In 2009, the overall volume of translation increased by 5.2% compared to 2008.
The proportion of translation services provided on time was over 95 %.
The linguistic support of examiners in the context of verification visits and in the drafting of reports has been increased.
The Directorate for Translation and Working Groups of INTOSAI also supported other specific needs related to the audit activities of the Court.
In January 2010, a new computerised application (Artemis) was introduced to better manage translation work.
INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY Information technology provides auditors with essential tools and services.
The most important developments in 2009 have been: • Simplification of processes and continuation of the transition to a paperless office through the application of automated permits and electronic forms, the introduction of electronic signatures and the launching of work to establish an archive database; • Improvement of the security of the Court's IT infrastructure through the establishment of a Centre for the Recovery of Data and the promotion of an enhanced version of the Lotus Note Platform, the basic framework for the Court's news and audit documentation/archiving systems; • Adoption of a long-term IT plan for the 2010-2012 period to align information technology with the Court's main audit strategic objectives and pursue efforts to provide high-quality services. 45
46 MANAGEMENT AND INFRASTRUCTURE The Directorate for Finance and Support Services is responsible for administrative services and infrastructure.
These include internal controls and accounting as well as administrative and logistical services.
In 2009, the Directorate focused on reorganising its services in order to improve efficiency and effectiveness, and to release staff to re-train in favour of audit services.
This reorganisation led to a reduction in the number of units belonging to the Directorate (from five to three) and the implementation of several posts in audit services.
One of the main activities of the Directorate was the construction of a new courtyard building (the "K3 Building").
In 2009, a project manager was appointed following a call for tenders.
Construction will begin in March 2010 and is expected to be completed in 2013.
The time and cost framework set for the project will continue to be respected.
TESTS During the Court's audit work, auditors must travel to Member States and other recipient countries from EU funds in order to obtain adequate audit evidence.
The visits are generally made by central and local authorities involved in granting, managing and disbursing EU funds, as well as by the final recipients concerned.
The audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors and the duration of an audit trip may be up to two weeks, depending on the type of examination and the distance.
Within the EU, audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Authorities of the Member State visited, which provide useful logistical and practical support.
The following graph gives an overview of the number of audit visits carried out by the Court in 2009 in the EU Member States (300).
In addition, 36 verification visits took place outside the Union in 2009.

The funds will be used in the manner set out in the Court's request to the European Parliament and the Council at the end of 2008.

50 SERVICE "INTERNE REVISION" The Court's Internal Audit Service is intended to assist the Court in the implementation of its objectives through a systematic, methodological evaluation of risk management, internal control and administrative procedures.
Moreover, the Internal Audit Service provides proposals to increase the efficiency of the Court.
This requires a continuous evaluation of the internal control systems within the Court to assess their effectiveness.
In 2009, the Court's Internal Audit Service focused its work on auditing the accounts (audit of accounts), checking ex ante controls, auditing the salary list and deposit accounts, monitoring public procurement contracts and procedures, and analysing the promotion procedure.
Most of the audit recommendations issued by the Internal Auditor in 2009 were accepted by the audited bodies and included in action plans for corrective action.
The Court's Internal Audit Committee shall monitor the activity of the Internal Auditor and ensure its independence.
It shall also examine and approve the work programme and the internal auditor's reports and, if necessary, entrust them with specific audit tasks.
In 2009, the Internal Audit Service was audited and certified by an independent auditor, Deloitte S.A.
EXTERNAL AUDIT OF THE HOFES The report of the independent auditor on the annual accounts of the Court of Auditors for the financial year 2008 was published in the Official Journal of the European Union on 23 October 2009 (OJ L 349, 20.12.2009, p.
In its audit opinion, the Court's independent auditor (PricewaterhouseCoopers SARL) concluded as follows: ‘As regards the annual accounts, it is our belief that the annual accounts give a true and fair view of the financial and financial situation of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2008 and of the profitability and cash flows for the year ending on that date, in accordance with Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 of 25 June 2002 and Commission Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 2342/2002 of 23 December 2002 laying down detailed rules for the implementation of the above Council Regulation and the accounting rules of the European Court of Auditors.' As regards the use of resources and the control procedures: ‘Based on our work described in this report, we have not encountered any facts from which we should conclude that, in all material matters and taking into account the above assessment criteria, a) the appropriations allocated to the Court have not been used for the purposes envisaged, and b) the control procedures established do not provide the necessary assurance that the financial operations have been carried out in accordance with the applicable rules and regulations.

European Court of Auditors ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT 2010
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS PREPARATION FIELD OF VALUES The Court of Auditors is committed to the following values: The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, it contributes to the improvement of EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens by promoting accountability and transparency.
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, characterised by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact of its work, providing valuable support to its audience in order to improve EU financial management.
INTEGRITY, INTEGRITY AND UNPARPILITY PROFESSIONALITY VALUE ADDITIONAL EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution whose members and staff produce relevant, timely high-quality reports based on sound findings and supporting documents, take account of the interests of its addressees, and key and indicative statements include appreciation of the individual's value, support in the development of special abilities and reward of performance, promoting team spirit through effective communication, providing its addressees with adequate audit results, rejecting any form of influence through external instructions or pressure, maintaining a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of its work, active participation in the further development of public financial control at EU level and increasing efficiency worldwide in all aspects of its work, contributing to an effective improvement in the management of the EU budget and contributing to strengthening accountability for the management of EU funds

4 PRESIDENCY OF THE PRESIDENT Welcome to reading the fourth edition of the Annual Activity Report of the European Court of Auditors. This year, we took the opportunity to reassess the content, namely the two main sections "Our Activities" and "Our Management" and for the first time provide an overview of all the performance indicators.
In 2010, the Court of Auditors provided two important opportunities for participation in the debate on the reform of EU financial management.
At the beginning of the year, the Court delivered an opinion to the new Commission on the main risks and challenges associated with improving EU financial management and, towards the end of the year, an opinion on the Commission's proposals for amending the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the EU.
With a view to 2011, the court will implement its values unchanged and further expand the performance and result achieved.
We will once again submit high-quality, independent and objective reports and opinions which contribute to the improvement of EU financial management and promote accountability and transparency.The Court will continue to closely monitor developments in the EU's economic governance and deal with the new legislative proposals that impact on EU financial management after 2013.
We plan to publish 45 annual reports, i.e. the annual reports on the implementation of the EU budget and on the European Development Funds, as well as the special annual reports on agencies, institutions and other bodies.
Special reports provide an important opportunity to achieve added value as they focus on areas at higher risk and on issues of particular relevance to the target groups.The Court intends, in particular, to report on the quality of EU expenditure in a wide range of areas ranging from financial instruments and the SME Guarantee Facility to projects funded by the EU in the field of eGovernment and the single payment scheme in agriculture.
In continuing to implement its 2009-2012 strategy, the Court hopes to fully exploit the benefits of its recent reforms, including streamlined decision-making procedures. The Court will continue its efforts to recruit suitable staff, limit vacancy to a minimum and promote the professional development of its staff.
Without the commitment and professionalism of all the farm's employees, we would not have achieved what we have achieved in 2010.

9 OUR ACTIVITIES AUDIT REPORTS AND OPINIONS The three main products of the European Court of Auditors are: o Annual reports – with the results of its audits of the accounts and compliance audits on specific financial years (including the separate published special annual reports of the agencies, institutions and other bodies of the European Union); o Special reports – which can be published at any time during the year, with the results of its selected audits, mainly economic audits to assess the economy, economic efficiency and effectiveness of selected EU revenue and expenditure sectors; o Opinions on draft legislative acts with financial implications.

The key statements of the annual report were as follows: • The annual accounts of the European Union represent the financial situation and the results of operations and cash flows in all essential respects. • Except for two areas of expenditure (Economy and Finance), as well as "Administrative and other expenditure"), budgetary payments continue to be largely affected by errors. • According to the Court's estimates, the most likely error rate in cohesion expenditure was significantly lower than in previous years, and for the budget as a whole, the error rate estimated by the Court has declined in recent years. • The Commission has improved its information on recoveries of unduly paid amounts and other corrections.
However, this information is not yet fully reliable, and the Commission's information on corrective measures does not allow a meaningful comparison with the Court's estimated error rate. In the report, the Court sets out recommendations on how financial management could be improved by strengthening administrative systems and simplifying regulations and regulations.
The Annual Report on the European Development Funds for 2009 The Court published its Annual Report on the European Development Funds (EDF) for the financial year 2009 on 9 November 2010, together with the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for 2009.
The special annual reports on the EU agencies, bodies and bodies for 2009 In December 2010, the Court published 40 special annual reports on the EU agencies, bodies and bodies for the financial year 20092.
The Court concluded that the monitoring and control systems ensure that payments are made in a conditionally effective manner.In the report, the Court recommended improvements to some aspects of EDF financial management, including the cost-effectiveness of expenditure controls, checks on the annual audit of completed projects, and controls on the use and monitoring of budget support.
12 Special reports adopted in 2010 When selecting and designing its tasks for economic and compliance audits, the Court is always concerned with achieving the greatest possible impact and with the best possible use of the resources provided for these tasks.
In selecting the topics, the Court takes into account the following factors: • the risks to economic viability or compliance with legal standards in the area of revenue or expenditure concerned; • the level of revenue or expenditure concerned; • the time elapsed since any prior examination; • upcoming developments within the relevant legal or operational framework; • the political and public interest.
In order to obtain the required audit evidence, the selected economic and compliance audits must be carefully planned and carried out, and before the report is published, the Court gives the audited bodies the opportunity to comment on its findings and the formulation of answers.
As a result, these examinations usually take more than one year.

In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of the ‘Design studies' and ‘Development of new infrastructures' support measures under the Sixth Framework Programme for Research (Special Report No 2/2010) – With the help of ‘Design studies', feasibility aspects are to be examined in potential future research institutions, and the ‘Development of new infrastructures' action is to support the development of new or improved existing infrastructures.
In the course of the audit, the Court examined whether the two measures have effectively contributed to achieving the objectives of the 6th Framework Programme for Research (FP6) infrastructure activities for 2002-2006. • Impact assessments in the EU institutions: do they help in decision-making?
(Special Report No 3/2010) – Impact assessments are one of the cornerstones of better regulation policy in order to improve and simplify EU legislative proposals. In the course of the audit, it was analysed whether the Commission's impact assessments have effectively supported decision-making in the EU institutions. The comments made in this report are also relevant for other budgetary areas.
• Are the Leonardo da Vinci programme's mobility measures designed and managed to produce effective results?
(Special Report No 4/2010) – The mobility projects of the Leonardo da Vinci programme enable organisations active in the field of vocational education and training to organise study visits to participants in another European country. The measures are part of the integrated lifelong learning programme. In the course of the examination, an evaluation of the design and management of the Commission and the national agencies has been carried out to assess whether the measures are likely to achieve their objectives. • Improving transport performance on the trans-European rail axes: Have EU rail infrastructure investments been effective?
(Special Report No 8/2010) (see box ‘Initiation of an economic impact assessment'). • Is EU spending on structural measures in the water supply of households used in an optimal way?
(Special Report No 9/2010) – The Cohesion Fund and the European Regional Development Fund have allocated more than EUR 4 billion to support projects in the field of water supply infrastructure to households over the 2000-2006 programming period.The Court examined whether these funds have been effectively used to address a number of needs, such as increasing water availability, extending geographical coverage, improving the cost-effectiveness of water supply systems and improving the quality of services. 15
16 ENFORCEMENT OF TRANS-EUROPEAN TRANS-EUROPEAN RAIL BANS: ARE EU INVESTMENTS EFFECTIVE INFRASTRUCTURE? 匽SPECIFIC REPORT NO. 8/2010 − The focus of the review was on EU co-financing of rail infrastructure, investigating whether an effective contribution has been made to increasing the performance of the trans-European axes.
In the light of the revision of the TEN-T guidelines due for 2011, the Court's report was presented at a particularly favourable time.The Court recommended that the Commission: • cooperate with the Member States and the railway authorities to identify the trans-European corridors on which there is a significant need and, where necessary, develop knowledge and improve analytical bases; • strengthen the emphasis on reducing the practical constraints on international rail transport; • promote and facilitate cooperation between Member States' bodies responsible for the railway sector in order to plan developments together and to create common solutions to practical problems.
17 "The test presented the team with a number of challenges," reports Gareth Roberts, head of the audit team. "We had to familiarize ourselves very quickly with the conditions of European rail transport and have seen some examples of success of fantastic modern railways, but also some sections of the network that seemed to date from a different era.
We wanted to explore to what extent the European rail system gradually develops from a patchwork to a network.
Up to 10 examiners were involved in the work on site, as we had to cover many different languages."I really enjoyed working on this test.
Since then, I've become a fan of the railway industry!Eh, says Andrej Minarovič, the inspector responsible for the work in Germany and Austria.
At the end of the test, Fernando Pascual Gil got the nickname "Mulwurf" from spending some time in railway tunnels in the Alps and the Pyrenees. The inspector team visited eight Member States and examined the impact of 21 rail projects co-financed by the European Union under the trans-European transport networks and cohesion policy on trans-European rail transport.
For this purpose the team members travelled with freight trains over and through the Alps and visited large tunnel construction sites.
These visits were a valuable addition to the findings of the auditors from the review of reports, the interviews of railway workers and the usual financial analyses.
18 Conservation and management of natural resources With a budget of EUR 413 billion for the period 2007-2013, the EU has far-reaching powers and political responsibility in the fields of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment. Three-quarters of the funds will be spent on agricultural markets and direct payments to farmers, financed by the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), the "first pillar" of the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
More than one fifth of the expenditure comes from support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the second ‘pillar' of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Implementation of the Leader approach to rural development (Special Report No 5/2010) – Leader is a bottom-up approach based on local partnerships to promote rural development. In the course of the review, it was examined whether the Leader approach has been implemented in such a way that additional benefits have been achieved compared to the traditional top-down approach while minimising the risks to sound financial management. • Has the sugar market reform achieved its main objectives?
(Special Report No 6/2010) – In 2006, the EU carried out a profound reform of its sugar sector aimed at ensuring the competitiveness of the EU sugar industry, stabilising markets and ensuring supply and ensuring an adequate standard of living for the agricultural population.
The EU as a global partner In addition to enlargement, the EU has three main objectives in the field of external relations: to achieve stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood (the EU and its neighbourhood policy), to actively support sustainable development at international level (the EU as a partner for sustainable development), to promote global political governance and to ensure strategic and civil security (the EU as a global player).
Expenditure is mainly managed directly by the Commission through its central services or delegations.
• Commission management of the system of veterinary checks on meat imports following the 2004 health legislation reform (Special Report No 14/2010) – Veterinary controls on imports are an essential part of the EU's food safety policy and contribute to reducing the risk of outbreaks of diseases and health crises which may result from high costs to the EU budget.
In 2010, the Court adopted the following special reports in this area: • Commission management of general budget support in ACP, Latin American and Asian countries (Special Report No 11/2010) – General budget support is generally considered by many donors, including the European Commission, to be the most effective way to provide development aid.
The audit examined whether the Commission effectively managed its budget support programmes in the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States as well as in Latin America and Asia. 19
20 • EU development assistance for basic education in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia (Special Report 12/2010) – Through the Education for All initiative and the Millennium Development Goals, the EU and the international donor community have committed themselves to ensuring primary education for all children, eliminating gender inequalities and improving education quality. The review examined whether EU development assistance has contributed to these goals in sub-Saharan Africa and South Asia and whether the Commission has managed its interventions satisfactorily.
Revenue The European Union budget is primarily financed by own resources and other revenue. Traditional own resources – mainly customs duties – account for around 12% and VAT-based own resources for a further 12% of total revenue. Most of the EU own resources (70%) come from own resources derived from gross national income, which ensure that the budget is always balanced. • Has the new European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument been successfully launched and achieved in the Southern Caucasus (Armenia, Azerbaijan and Georgia)?
(Special Report No 13/2010) – The European Neighbourhood and Partnership Instrument (ENPI) provides a framework for the planning and management of assistance to partner countries and regions.
Since 2007, more than EUR 311 million has been allocated to three countries in the Southern Caucasus, examining whether the ENPI has been successfully launched there and whether it achieves results.
In 2010, the Court adopted a special report on • Simplified customs procedures (No 1/2010) – In simplified customs procedures, authorised economic operators benefit from accelerated customs clearance and a simplified system of payment of EU revenue.
The audit assessed the effectiveness of the legal framework and the control approach adopted by the Commission and the Member States.Opinions delivered in 2010 The Court also contributes to improving EU financial management in its opinions on proposals for new or amended acts with financial implications.
21 22 The revision of the Financial Regulation from the point of view of the Court of Auditors Opinion No 6/2010 concerns an important proposal by the Commission for a revision of the Financial Regulation, which sets out how the EU's budget is collected, spent and accounted for.
Based on its statements in opinion 1/2010 (see above), the Court also points out that in order to improve the quality of EU expenditure in certain areas of expenditure of the EU budget, simpler and better legislation and other measures to support, promote and require economic action by managers in the Commission, the other institutions and in the Member States are needed.
The ongoing contacts are maintained by liaison officers appointed by the individual SAIs.
The pilot project will be completed in 2011. 24 Network of SAIs of Candidate Countries and Potential Candidate Countries The Court actively participated in meetings of the SAIs of Candidate Countries and potential candidate countries (Turkey, Croatia, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Iceland, Montenegro, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Serbia)4 which took place in parallel with the meetings of the Contact Committee.
4 as at February 2011. Other forms of cooperation The Court continued its active participation and participation in the improvement of international auditing principles and procedures through its membership of European and international organisations for public financial control bodies, including INTOSAI5 and its European regional group EUROSAI.
A delegation of the Court took part in the XXth INCOSAI Congress, which took place in South Africa from 22 to 27 November 2010.
Since 2004, when the Court became a full member of the INTOSAI, it has actively participated in the subcommittees on the various types of examination. In addition, the Court contributed to the subcommittee "Promoting best practices and quality assurance through voluntary peer reviews" and supported the increased activities in the field of the development of expertise of the INTOSAI members.
Since 2008, the Court has chaired the Working Group on Responsibility and Audit of Disaster Relief.
An important objective of this working group is to develop guidelines in the area of accountability for disaster relief and to identify and disseminate best practices, focusing on activities aimed at stakeholders (multilateral institutions, relief organisations, governments, private auditors). The interim report of the working group was submitted to the INTOSAI Congress in November 2010.
In 2010, the Court also participated in the INTOSAI Task Force on the Global Financial Crisis. Within the framework of EUROSAI, the Court is represented in the Environmental Working Group and in the IT Working Group and participates in the EUROSAI Training Committee.
The Court also participated in the working group set up at the VII EUROSAI Congress in 2008 to draw up a guide to best practices for achieving quality within an SAIs. In addition, the Court is one of the auditors of EUROSAI. 25
26 OUR MANAGEMENT IMPLEMENTATION OF THE STRATEGY FOR 2009阁2012 In recent years, after a self-assessment and a peer review procedure (2008) on the framework conditions for its audit management, the Court has launched an internal reform process.
A strategy for the period 2009-20126 has been developed to address the weaknesses identified and the overall objectives for the period are: to maximise the overall impact of the audits; to improve efficiency by making the best use of resources.
Many of the priority actions envisaged in the strategy have already been completed and the other measures will be implemented in 2011 and 2012. Key achievements in 2010 include: o meeting the target of submitting 12 to 15 reports per year on audit reports; o developing new products – a document on risks and challenges for the new Commission (Opinion No 1/2010) and establishing a new system for reporting on the follow-up to the Court's recommendations from 2012; o revising the Court's rules of procedure to streamline decision-making procedures through the introduction of chambers and strengthening the governance structure; o drawing up an overview of all performance indicators; o developing the approach for the annual audit of the EU budget (declaration of reliability) on the basis of recommendations from an internal panel supported by external experts; o redeploying a number of posts from support services in favour of audit services.
6 The audit strategy 2009-2012 is available on the Court's website.
27 INTRODUCTION OF CHAMBERS HAVING REGARD TO THE NEW RULES OF PROCEDURE One of the main recommendations resulting from the Court's reform process was that the Court should make use of the possibility provided for in Article 287(4) of the Treaty of allowing certain categories of reports and opinions of chambers to be adopted while maintaining the principle of collegiality.
After the Council approved the necessary amendments to the Court's Rules of Procedure, Chambers were set up on 1 June 2010 consisting of members of the Court and adopting special reports, special annual reports and opinions on draft acts. Previously, all these reports and opinions were adopted by the entire College, and this is still the case with the annual reports on the EU budget and the EDFs.
Although most of the Court's reports are now accepted by the Chambers, the Chambers have the option of transferring their documents to the Court for adoption.
All members may attend meetings of chambers to which they are not members without voting rights.
Members of the Court
28 MEASUREMENT DATA ON THE HOUSE IN 2010 Since 2008, the Court has gradually developed a set of key performance indicators (ZLI) to inform o management of progress made in implementing the 2009-2012 objectives; o to support the decision-making process; o to provide performance-related information to the Court's audience.
Since for the first time an overview of all indicators is available for 2010, this year serves as a reference year for future assessments of progress. The Court is very pleased with the results it received in 2010 in its key performance indicators, in particular on the quality and impact of its work.
More importantly, however, the indicators show clearly the areas in which progress is needed and the problems that need to be addressed in order to achieve a future performance increase.
29 Quality and impact of the Court's work The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports on the basis of assessments made by the addressees as well as expert reviews and follow-up to its recommendations.
Assessment by addressees By means of a survey, the Court asked the main addressees of its reports (the European Parliament's Budgetary Control Committee and the Council's Budgetary Committee) and the main audited bodies (mainly European Commission staff) to assess the quality and impact of the annual reports published in 2009 (general budget and EDF) and special reports.
The assessment should be based on a five-stage scale (1 – very bad, 2 – bad, 3 – appropriate, 4 – good, 5 – very good).
2010 Objective Assessment of the quality and effect of the Court's reports by a main addressee 4.2 ≥4 Assessment of the quality and effect of the Court's audit work by the audited body The result shows that the main addressees of the Court's reports find these on average for ‘good'.
The Court strives to maintain or improve this level of performance.
Expert reviews Two external bodies have reviewed the content and presentation of a sample of Court reports published in 2009 and 2010. e reviewers have assessed eight special reports and the annual report on the general budget and the EDFs for both years and assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale of ‘significantly impaired' (1) to ‘qualitatively high-quality' (4).
2010 target 3.0 ≥ 3 3.7 ≥4 External expert reviews of the Court's reports and presentation The result shows that the auditors consider the quality of the Court's reports to be "satisfactory".
The reviews have provided valuable insights and the resulting recommendations will be used to improve the quality of future reports.
30 Follow-up to recommendations The Court uses its audit experience primarily in the form of recommendations to contribute to improving financial management.To make changes, the Court's recommendations must first be accepted by the audited bodies and subsequently implemented.The indicator is based on the recommendations published in 2009, i.e. the latest available annual and special reports.
2010 target 90 % ≥ 90 % Percentage of audit recommendations accepted by the audited body The Court strives to maintain or even improve this high level of acceptance in its recommendations.
In 2010, the Court established a system for monitoring the implementation of the recommendations by the audited bodies.
In the coming years, this system will serve as a basis for a further indicator of the extent to which recommendations will be implemented in practice and will lead to improvements.
It will also provide the Court with valuable insights into improving the quality of its recommendations and thereby increasing their acceptance by the audited bodies.
31 Efficiency and effectiveness of resource use The Court assesses the efficiency and effectiveness of its resource use according to its ability to present reports and audit findings on time, to fulfil its obligations in the area of financial management and to ensure the well-being and expertise of its employees.Pecinity of reports The Court strives to accept all planned reports within the specified time limits.
Legal deadlines for the publication of the annual reports and the specific annual reports are to be met.
In the case of special reports where there is no publication date laid down in legislation, the planned date of adoption shall be deemed to be the date.
2010 target Number of reports adopted compared to the number of reports planned 90% 100% Percentage of reports adopted on time 80% 100% Overall, the Court missed the target in 2010.
The Court adopted fewer reports in 2010 than planned, the performance level is comparable to that of the previous year (91% in 2009), and although the proportion of reports adopted on schedule increased in 2010 (80% compared with 67% in 2009), there is still a need for further improvement.
While all annual reports and all special annual reports were adopted and published on schedule, this was only the case with three special reports.
The adoption of six special reports was delayed until 2011.
The Court is committed to achieving the targets by introducing further measures to improve the management of the procedures for special reports by the end of 2012.
2010 Target percentage of audit notices prepared on time 54% 80% by 2012 The performance achieved in 2010 has not yet reached the required level, but significant progress has been made over the past two years towards achieving the target (43% in 2009 and 27% in 2008).
The Court will continue its efforts to achieve the target.External assessment of financial management The Court strives to obtain a full audit opinion from its independent auditor on the annual accounts and the use of resources, as well as discharge from the European Parliament following a favourable Council recommendation.

Professional Training In accordance with guidelines published by the International Federation of Accountants (IFAC), the Court strives to provide auditors with an average of 40 hours (five days) of professional training.
2010 target Average number of training days per person 5.7 days ≥ 5 days 33 In 2010, the required level of performance was reached, which means an improvement compared to 2009 (average of 4 days).
Staff satisfaction level In an internal employee satisfaction survey conducted in 2009, 86% of the Court's staff were generally satisfied with their work, with a total staff satisfaction level of 2.8 on a scale of 1 to 4. Each score above 2.5 indicates general satisfaction.The Court strives to maintain or improve this result if a similar survey is carried out at the end of 2012.
34 ASSESSMENT SUPPORT The success of the Court's audit activities depends to a large extent on the quality of the support provided by its specialised services, providing the logistical, technical and technical know-how enabling the Court to o recruit, maintain and motivate its staff and develop its professional skills; o disseminate the audit results in all official languages of the EU; o make the best use of information technologies; o manage its budget and maintain its infrastructure; o carry out audit visits to all countries where EU funds are spent.
Staff Personnel allocation The Court's main capital is its staff. At 31 December 2010, the Court's staff was 889 (officials and temporary staff but without members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees).
Of these, 557 are in audit chambers (including 123 staff in members' cabinets), 151 in the Translation Directorate, 157 in administrative support services, and 24 in the President's services. In 2010, in view of the objective of the best possible use of resources, possibilities for improving efficiency were once again explored and implemented in all activities by simplifying procedures and streamlining services.
Where possible, the number of posts released outside the audit area has been transferred to the audit service, increasing the number of posts used for audit tasks by 6%. This process will continue in 2011.

37 Continuing vocational training The occupation of the examiner requires continuous training in order to be able to keep pace with new developments and acquire new skills.
Efforts were made in 2010 to implement the staff redeployment plan adopted by the Secretary-General, in which posts and staff from the translation service are to be transferred to the audit service in 2011. On the basis of the 2008-2011 training plan and the training pathways adopted in 2009, the Vocational Training Unit in 2010 has improved the content of the training activities and has developed new training courses in line with the priorities decided by the Court.
In addition, the Directorate "Translation" provided valuable linguistic support to examiners on business trips and in the subsequent stages of drafting audit reports.
In addition, the Directorate "Translation" supported INTOSAI working groups and met other specific needs related to the audit activities of the Court.
Work on the Artemis project to improve the functions of this important IT application for translators continued in 2010. In addition, the Directorate "Translation" of the Court actively participated in interinstitutional and international specialised bodies.
38 Information Technology Information Technology (IT) plays a key role in implementing the overarching objectives of the Court's 2009-2012 strategy. Developments have been made in 2010: • establishing a cooperation platform in line with the Strategic IT Plan 2010-2012 to support knowledge exchange, in particular in the audit area; • continuing efforts to optimise and simplify internal processes through electronic workflows to increase efficiency and effectiveness; management and infrastructure The task of the Financial and Support Services Directorate is to provide the Court's auditors with efficient, effective and timely adequate support services and to ensure that the necessary financing, internal control and accounting mechanisms are available to support all of the Court's activities.
In 2010, the Directorate continued its efforts to further improve efficiency and effectiveness in order to unlock resources to relocate to the audit service. • Use of smart phones and laptop com-puters to enable the efficient execution of audit work at any location and at any time, including in the context of the Court's contingency plan.
Following an agreement reached at the end of 2008 with the budgetary authority on the financing of the K3 building, a priority activity in 2010 was the preparation of tenders for construction and ancillary services and their publication by the project manager.
Most of the contracts for this project were awarded in the course of the year. The time and budget frame of the construction project is complied with. Completion is planned at the end of 2012.

This adequate security is based on the assessment of the undersigned and on the information available to him, such as the results of ex-post checks, the internal auditor's reports and the confirmation reports of the independent auditor on previous financial years. The undersigned confirms that he has no knowledge of any unreported circumstance which could harm the interests of the institution.
The examination chambers I to IV cover various areas of revenue and expenditure, while the fifth, the CEAD Chamber, is responsible for horizontal matters. The chambers are supported by examination directorates.
Each member is responsible for specific tasks, primarily in the audit area, and the members submit proposals for examination and reports on the tasks for which they are responsible to the respective Chamber and the Court.
The members are supported by their cabinet staff and the examiner team appointed for the audit task.

European Court of Auditors ANNUAL ACTIVITY REPORT 2011
EUROPEAN COURT OF AUDITORS DIRECTORATE-GENERAL VALUES The European Court of Auditors is responsible for the audit of EU finances in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, it contributes to improving EU financial management while acting as an independent guardian of the financial interests of EU citizens.
An independent and dynamic Court of Auditors, distinguished by its integrity and impartiality, recognised for its professionalism, quality and impact, and providing valuable support to its audience with a view to improving EU financial management.
INDEPENDENT, INTEGRATION AND INTEGRATION PROFESSIONALITY VALUE EXCELLENCE AND EFFICIENCY Independence, integrity and impartiality for the institution, its members and staff.
impartial examination, taking into account the positions of the bodies concerned, but rejecting any form of interference by instructions or external pressure.
Maintaining a high and exemplary degree of professionalism in all aspects of his work.
To contribute to the further development of public financial control at EU and worldwide level.
Preparing relevant, timely, high quality reports based on sound findings and evidence, taking into account the interests of its addressees and containing important and trend-setting statements.
contributing to the effective improvement of EU management and contributing to the strengthening of accountability for the management of EU financial resources.
Promote team spirit through effective communication.
increase efficiency in all aspects of his work.
