Our activities 13 Agriculture and Cohesion: Overview of EU expenditure for the period 2007-2013 In parallel with the annual reports, the Court published a background document for the first time – in 23 official EU languages – in order to provide a multiannual perspective on the findings underlying the Statement of Assurance in the two main areas of agriculture and cohesion.
It drew lessons on the problems encountered in EU financial management and control over the past period of expenditure, summarised audit results and identified challenges related to the new 2014-2020 period.
In addition, with this overview, it was in line with the desire expressed by the European Parliament to obtain country-specific information on shared management. Key messages: ο Except for direct aid and market support measures for farmers in the agricultural sector, the pressure to make use of funds is a key aspect of the risk associated with shared management expenditure. ο The main risks to the regularity of agricultural expenditure are that the areas or animals or the costs on which the aid payments are based are not eligible, the beneficiaries of the aid do not meet the conditions and the aid is not calculated correctly.
Infringements of agri-environment requirements, specific requirements for investment projects and procurement rules are important factors that increase the risk of spending on rural development.
The second largest risk is that expenditure (or projects) cannot be eligible for EU support. ο Although there is a considerable need for improvement in control systems, the main challenge is to take action to simplify the management of programmes.
The Court notes errors in all EU Member States.
Many errors have occurred due to the complexity of the overall management and control architecture. ο Despite improvements in the reporting of risks and errors by the Member States' authorities, it is still very difficult for the Commission to ensure the reliability of this information. ο The amendments to the regulations for the new programming period may have no significant impact on the level of risk.
Our activities 14 Annual Report on the European Development Funds for 2013 The European Development Funds (EDFs) are financed by the EU Member States, subject to their own financial regulation and managed outside the EU's general budget.
The European Commission is responsible for the financial management of operations financed from EDF resources.
Under the EDFs, under the Cotonou Agreement of 2000, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific States (ACP States) and the overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
Expenditure is designed to reduce poverty and ultimately defeat it, in line with the objectives of sustainable development and the gradual integration of the ACP States and OCTs into the world economy.
The agreement is based on three complementary pillars, namely development cooperation, economic and trade cooperation and the political dimension.
The Court's 2013 annual report on the EDF was published in parallel with the annual report on the EU budget on 5 November 2014.
It contains the 20th Statement of Assurance on EDFs.
The Court noted that the annual accounts for 2013 were appropriate in terms of the assets and financial position of the EDFs, the results of their operations and cash flows, and the changes in net assets as a whole.
The Court estimated the error rate in EDF expenditure operations for the financial year 2013 at 3.4 %, which means an increase of 3.0% compared to 2012.
Special annual reports on the financial year 2013 In 2014, the Court produced and published 51 special annual reports on the financial year 2013.
The reports covered 41 decentralised bodies, executive agencies and other EU bodies, the seven EU Joint Undertakings in the field of research, as well as the European Central Bank, the European Schools and the Sisnet communication infrastructure.
The Court also published two summaries of the results of its annual audits for the financial year 2013, one on EU agencies and other bodies, and the second on research-based companies.
These two analytical and comparative summaries were submitted to the President of the European Parliament, the Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Committee on Budgets.
Together with the special annual reports, these summaries are available on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu).
EU agencies, bodies and Joint Undertakings are established on the basis of EU legislation to carry out specific tasks, with their seats located throughout the European Union.
They are active in many areas, such as security, health, research, finance, migration and travel.
They all have a mandate, a board of directors, a director, staff and a budget.
While the agencies, bodies and Joint Undertakings, in relation to the EU budget as a whole, have a relatively low financial risk, the Union's reputation risk is high because it is clearly visible in the Member States and has a significant impact on policy design, decision-making and programme implementation in areas of major importance to European citizens.
51 special annual reports during the year
Our activities 15 The Court gave the 41 agencies and other bodies full audit opinions on the reliability of the 2013 accounts.
The transactions underlying these financial statements were legal and orderly for all agencies and other bodies except for two on all essential matters. For the EIT (European Institute of Innovation and Technology) and Frontex (European Agency for the Management of Operational Cooperation at the External Borders of the Member States of the European Union), the Court gave limited audit opinions.
In addition, the 2013 accounts were reliable for all seven Joint Undertakings, but the Court gave a limited audit opinion on the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying its annual accounts for three Joint Undertakings: Artemis (embedded ICT systems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and IMI (Innovative Medicines Initiative).
With regard to the European Schools, the Court was unable to conclude whether the consolidated annual accounts for 2013 were free of material misrepresentations, as the schools still lack accounting and control.
The Court examined the management of the European Central Bank's carbon footprint and noted that, although the Bank has taken measures to reduce the negative impact of its administrative activities on the environment, further efforts and measures are needed.
Special reports adopted in 2014 In addition to its annual reports and special annual reports, the Court shall publish special reports throughout the year containing the results of its economic and compliance audits on specific budgetary areas or management issues of its choice.
When selecting and designing these audit tasks, the Court is committed to achieving maximum impact and thus making the best use of its resources.
In the selection of themes, the Court takes into account the following factors: • the risks of irregularity or low economic viability in the expenditure or policy area; • the potential to achieve added value in an audit carried out by the Court; • the political and public interest. 24 special reports in 2014
Our Activities 16 The main stages of a selected audit audit on-the-spot audit On-the-spot audit Preparation of the report Voting of the report Adoption Publication Determination of the suitability and feasibility of a proposed audit; definition of the scope, objectives, approach, methods and timing of the audit Multi-disciplinary teams carry together on-the-spot audit evidence in the Commission's central services as well as in Member States and beneficiary countries Clear, structured presentation of the main findings and conclusions; preparation of recommendations Confirmation of facts and findings by the audited bodies Adoption of the report by the Audit Board or the entire Court College of Auditors Publication of the special report in 23 official languages together with the audited opinion On the following pages, the subjects of the 24 special reports prepared by the Court in 2014 will be briefly presented, each under the relevant headings of the 2014-2020 multiannual financial framework, the EU's multiannual budget.
Our activities 17 Smart and inclusive growth Smart and inclusive growth covers two areas: competitiveness for growth and employment, funding for research and innovation, education and training, trans-European energy, transport and telecommunications networks, social policy, business development, etc. The EU's funding for growth and jobs for the period 2014-2020, at current prices, amounts to EUR 142 billion and 13% of the total EU budget.
Economic, social and territorial cohesion includes regional policy, which aims at helping the most developed countries and regions in the EU to join the rest, with a view to strengthening the competitiveness of all regions and developing cooperation between them.
EU cohesion funding for 2014-2020 amounts to EUR 367 billion at current prices, or 34% of the total EU budget.
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Effectiveness of EU-funded projects in the field of public transport (No 1/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed the implementation and effectiveness of projects in the field of public transport co-financed by EU Structural Funds to determine whether the projects met users' needs and achieved their objectives.
The audit showed that two-thirds of the local transport projects co-financed by EU Structural Funds were insufficiently used.
This development was primarily caused by weaknesses in project design and inadequate mobility policies.
However, this insufficient performance has generally not been followed up by the promoters or the national authorities.
As a rule, infrastructure and rolling stock have been established for most projects in line with project specifications.
Significant delays and cost overruns were noted, but after completion almost all audited projects were in line with users' needs.
European cities need to improve mobility and reduce congestion, accidents and pollution through local mobility strategies.
The co-financed projects provided support to cities to set up local transport systems such as metros, trams and buses.
Trams and buses are important means of transport for public transport.
Our activities 18 • Did the cohesion policy funds help to promote renewable energy production produce good results?
(No 6/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the two main sources of finance for the promotion of renewable energy – the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF) – had achieved good results. To this end, it was examined whether the funds had been allocated to adequately prioritised, cost-effective and mature renewable energy production projects in this period, with the aim of achieving meaningful objectives, and to what extent these funds have provided good results that have contributed to the achievement of the EU 2020 renewable energy target.
The audit found that improvements were needed to ensure that EU funding contributed as much as possible to achieving the objective.
The projects audited provided the outputs as planned and most of the projects were sufficiently mature and ready to be implemented at the time they were selected.
There were no significant cost overruns or major delays, and renewable energy production capacities were installed as planned and were operational as planned.
However, the results in terms of energy production have not always been achieved or measured properly.
Overall, the efficiency of the use of funds was limited, as cost-effectiveness in the planning and implementation of projects was not the guiding principle and expenditure had a limited EU added value.
The EU Council has set a binding EU target of 20% for the share of renewable energy in gross final energy consumption by 2020.
For renewable energy, around 4.7 million euros were made available from the ERDF and the CF during the period 2007–2013. • Was the ERDF successful in supporting the development of incubators?
(No 7/2014) – In this special report, the Court analysed whether the incubators co-financed by the ERDF had successfully supported start-up companies with great growth potential.
The audit found that the EU has made a significant financial contribution to the creation of an incubator infrastructure, particularly in Member States where this type of business support is relatively rare.
However, the performance of the audited incubators left much to be desired.
The provision of start-up services was rather limited due to financial constraints and the small size of start-up activities.
This situation was mainly due to a lack of expertise in start-up support procedures and poor management systems.
Incubators pursue the goal of supporting new companies in their successful establishment and further development.
Support for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has become an increasingly political priority over time.
EU expenditure in this area amounted to EUR 38 billion in the period 2007-2013.
The building "Delta" in the Wrocław Technology Park, co-financed by the ERDF.
Our activities 19 • Is the ERDF effective in financing projects directly to promote biodiversity under the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2020?
(No 12/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the ERDF funding available for the direct promotion of biodiversity has been used by Member States.
The audit showed that Member States are lagging behind in using ERDF funds to finance projects compared to other ERDF spending areas.
In order to ensure that the ERDF continues to be useful in implementing the EU biodiversity loss management strategy by 2020, the Commission should strengthen its support to Member States in implementing specific conservation and management plans for natural habitats and species.
The co-financed projects were generally in line with the biodiversity priorities set at national and EU level.
However, the assessment of the effectiveness of these projects was hampered by the fact that most Member States did not provide results indicators or monitoring systems to assess the development of natural habitats and species.
Protecting biodiversity is one of the EU's most important priorities.
Following the failure of the previous objective of halting the loss of biodiversity in Europe by 2010, the Council approved a new strategy by 2020. Direct support for biodiversity and nature conservation was allocated EUR 2.8 billion to ERDF funds in the 2007-2013 programming period. • Was ERDF support to SMEs in the field of e-commerce effective?
(No 20/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether operational programmes provided a good basis for effective support for e-commerce measures for SMEs, whether managing authorities properly selected and monitored e-commerce projects, and whether the e-commerce projects co-financed by the ERDF have been successfully implemented and provided measurable benefits.
The Court noted that ERDF support for SMEs in the field of e-commerce – purchasing and selling goods via the Internet – helped to increase the online availability of business services.
However, the lack of monitoring was such that it was impossible to assess the extent to which ERDF support has contributed to the achievement of the IT objectives of the Member States and the EU.
Insufficient selection procedures by Member States mean that a good cost-benefit ratio is unlikely to exist in many projects.
Programme managers focused more on the use of resources (outputs) than on achieving results.
The Commission supports e-commerce through its Digi-tal Agenda for Europe. Under the ERDF budget, EUR 3 billion of EU funding for improving the use of ICT by SMEs was allocated to the period 2007-2013. Court video on Special Report No 20/2014 "Is the ERDF effective in financing projects directly promoting biodiversity in the context of the EU Biodiversity Strategy for 2020?" – EU AuditorsECA on Youtube.
Our activities 20 Close-up of an economic assessment: EU-funded airport infrastructure – insufficient cost-benefit ratio (No. 21/2014) Closed part of the oversized terminal at Fuerteventura Airport.
Although EU aviation policy aims to overcome capacity problems – by building additional infrastructures, improving the use of existing structures, optimising airport services and better connecting to other modes of transport – Europe will not be able to meet much of this demand because of the lack of runways and ground infrastructure.
In Europe, there are more than 500 airports where one million people work directly or indirectly and, together with the airlines, they contribute more than EUR 140 billion to Europe's economic performance.
Airport-related infrastructure projects are an important area of expenditure for the EU budget: projects of this kind were allocated around EUR 4.5 billion to the EU in the 2000-2013 programming periods, of which more than EUR 2.8 billion were allocated from the Cohesion Policy Funds.
As part of its economic assessment of this support, the Court examined whether the investments were clearly needed, whether the respective time and cost frameworks were respected in the construction projects and whether the newly built or modernised infrastructure was fully used.
The Court assessed whether the investments led to higher passenger numbers and improved customer service and whether the airports supported were financially viable.
The auditors carried out their work between May 2013 and October 2014, with a focus on 20 EU-funded airports in Estonia, Greece, Italy, Poland and Spain.
A total of more than EUR 600 million was allocated to these airports in the period 2000-2013.
The team carried out an action review of relevant legislation, air traffic planning in the five Member States and publications of the main interbranch organisations.
In particular, the auditors visited the 20 airports in order to assess and provide direct evidence of the outputs, uses, results and impacts of the EU funds and the economic situation of the airports.
The Court concluded that the cost-benefit ratio of EU-funded investments for airports was not right.
Too many airports, often close together, received financial support for similar infrastructures, and in many cases it was found that these infrastructures were oversized.
Only half of the airports audited managed to increase their passenger numbers.
Improvements in customer service or regional socio-economic benefits such as the creation of additional jobs have not been measured or there has been no evidence of this.
The investigation also showed that seven of the airports were not financially self-supporting and would have difficulties without further public support.
At most of the airports audited, the audit team found significant delays in the construction and provision of infrastructure.
Nearly half of airports exceeded costs, so that Member States had to contribute almost EUR 100 million more from their national budgets than originally planned.
Our activities 21 The financing was not well coordinated by the Member States: in most Member States there was no strategic long-term airport development plan.
In addition, the Commission has inadequately monitored the financing, which generally does not know which airports receive subsidies or what amounts are involved.
As a result, it does not have a full picture of all EU airport investment and has limited scope for monitoring and ensuring that strategies are properly designed and implemented.
On the basis of these findings, the Court recommended that the Commission, as from the 2014-2020 programming period, ensure that Member States use EU funds only for airport infrastructure which is financially viable and whose investment needs have been adequately assessed and demonstrated.
Another recommendation was that Member States should have coherent plans for airport expansion at regional, national and supranational level in order to avoid overcapacity, duplication and uncoordinated investment in airport infrastructure.
In its reply, the Commission confirmed that lessons have been learned from these experiences.
As a result, it has ensured that the relevant legislation for the 2014-2020 programming period has a fundamentally different approach.
The report was presented to the European Parliament, which fully supports the Court's conclusions and recommendations.
The publication of the report attracted great media interest.
The media response was greatest in Spain, but also included headlines in major international newspapers, television coverage and social media.
From left to right: Afonso de Castro Malheiro, Jasmine Mitterbuchner, Patrick Weldon, Mircea Radulescu, Pietro Puricella, Joël Costantzer, George Pufan (member of the Court responsible for the report), Fernando Pascual Gil, Luc T'Joen, Tomasz Plebanowicz, Lorenzo Pirelli, Efstratios Varetidis, Jelena Magermane, Erki Must.
Our activities 22 Sustainable growth: natural resources The EU has a high political responsibility in the fields of agriculture and rural development, fisheries and the environment.
The planned budget for 2014-2020, at current prices, is EUR 420 billion and 39 % of the EU budget as a whole.
Three-quarters of expenditure concerns direct payments to farmers and support for agricultural markets through the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) – the ‘first pillar' of the common agricultural policy (CAP).
Another fifth of the expenditure is allocated to EU support for rural development financed by the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD), the "second pillar" of the CAP.
Agriculture and rural development are subject to shared management by the Commission and the Member States.
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Integration of the objectives of EU water policy into the CAP: a partial success (No 4/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the objectives of EU water policy were successfully integrated into the Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
The audit showed that the EU can only achieve partial success in integrating the objectives of water policy into the CAP.
The two instruments for integrating water-related issues (cross compliance and rural development) have shortcomings and the implementation of the Water Framework Directive is characterised by delays and weaknesses.
The CAP instruments have so far had a positive impact on supporting the policy objectives of improving water quantity and quality.
However, these instruments are limited compared to the ambitious objectives of the CAP.
For example, neither of these two instruments allows the full application of the "polluter pays" principle in the allocation of CAP funds.
Furthermore, at the level of the EU institutions and Member States, it is not sufficiently known what the pressures on water resources are from agricultural activities and what developments these pressures are.
The EU attaches high priority to the protection of European water resources.
Agriculture, one of the largest consumers and polluters of water resources, plays a key role in sustainable water management.
The CAP will generate nearly 40% of the EU's budget (over EUR 50 billion in 2014) and the EU is working under the CAP to influence the agricultural practices that have an impact on water resources.
Our activities 23 • Has the Commission managed effectively the integration of coupled support into the single payment scheme?
(No 8/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed how well the Commission managed to integrate EU support linked to production volumes (e.g. farmed areas or livestock numbers) into the single payment scheme after the health check of the CAP carried out in 2008.
The audit found that the Commission did not adequately monitor during the 2010-2012 period how Member States calculated farmers' entitlements to EU support payments for farms under the farm payment scheme.
While most Member States had correctly used the reference data of farmers, there were serious deficiencies in the correct application of the calculation rules and principles.
The Commission did not use its mandate to ensure that the criteria for allocating available support were always in line with EU principles, that they complied with the principle of sound budgetary management and that they had no potential impact on market conditions.
The framework established by the Commission did not provide sufficiently clear rules on which controls Member States have to carry out and the Member States' control systems have been of varying quality. The main objective of the single payment scheme was to shift the focus of the CAP from market support to decoupled income support for farmers: the farm owners should be able to adapt their production to market demand and their income should be stabilised.
The single payment scheme, which has so far been introduced in 18 Member States, accounts for 54 % of the total EU budget for agriculture and rural development. • Is EU support for investment and promotion in the wine sector well managed and is there evidence of results in terms of the competitiveness of EU wines?
(No 9/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the investment and promotion measures were adequately designed, and examined the available monitoring and evaluation data in order to assess whether the Commission and the Member States achieved the desired results in an efficient manner.
The audit found that the management of support for investment and promotion in the wine sector was hampered by design and implementation deficiencies and that effects on the competitiveness of EU wines could not always be demonstrated.
The specific investment measure for the wine sector is not justified, as support is already provided under EU rural development policy.
EU support for the promotion of wines often served to consolidate existing markets rather than to develop new markets or to regain old ones.
The impact of the investment measure cannot easily be separated from the investment in rural development.
The EU is the world's largest wine producer.
EU support should improve competitiveness and ensure a better balance between supply and demand.
Member States spent EUR 522 million on the promotion measure and EUR 518 million on the investment measure during the period 2009-2013.
For 2014-2018, the resources allocated to the Member States under this measure have increased significantly.
Our activities 24 • Effectiveness of support for aquaculture provided by the European Fisheries Fund (EFF) (No 10/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the measures to support aquaculture at EU and Member State level were well designed and adequately implemented, and whether the EFF was an adequate cost-benefit ratio and supported the sustainable development of aquaculture.
The audit found that the aquaculture support measures were not well designed and implemented at EU and Member State level by 2013; that the EFF did not achieve an adequate cost-benefit ratio and that the sustainable development of aquaculture was not supported effectively.
The current framework was not suitable for realising the EU's objectives for the sustainable development of aquaculture and the results were insufficient.
Measures to support the sustainable development of aquaculture in the Member States were not well designed and implemented.
The national strategic plans and operational programmes of the Member States were not sufficiently clear and the Member States did not have a coherent strategy for the sector.
The EFF funding was often not sufficiently targeted for aquaculture projects and the audit showed that these projects normally did not deliver the planned results or a good cost-benefit ratio.
Aquaculture produces around 1.3 million tonnes of fish every year in the EU, accounting for a turnover of EUR 4 billion.
One of the objectives of the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) for the period up to 2013 was to promote the sustainable development of aquaculture.
By May 2013, the EFF provided more than EUR 400 million to finance measures to promote productive investments and environmental and health policies in the aquaculture sector. • Economic efficiency: maintain control over the costs of EU-funded rural development aid (No 22/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the approaches adopted by the Commission and Member States were the most effective in keeping the costs of rural development aid under control.
The audit showed that EU Member States could achieve significant savings in aid to rural development projects while allowing for a more efficient use of funds.
The auditors identified practical and cost-effective approaches that could be more widely used in Member States' control of the costs of rural development aid.
Member States' control systems were aimed at checking the prices of goods or works listed in the aid applications without equal consideration being paid to the question of whether the goods themselves were suitable.
Some price controls were time-consuming or provided little certainty that the approved costs were reasonable.
At the beginning of the programming period, the Commission did not provide sufficient guidance, nor did it ensure the dissemination of recommended procedures.
It did not ensure that the Member States' systems were effective, particularly in the case of large-scale aid.
Around half of the EU's rural development spending in the period 2007-2013, amounting to EUR 100 billion, has been implemented in the form of grants for investment projects and other projects carried out by farmers, agricultural enterprises, associations and local authorities.
Our activities 25 • Mistakes in rural development expenditure: what are the causes and what is being done to eliminate them?
(No 23/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined compliance with current legislation and other legislation on the implementation of rural development and outlined the main causes of the high error rate in this area.
The audit found that most of the errors in rural development policy were due to non-compliance with conditions established at Member State level.
The control authorities of the Member States could and should have been able to detect and correct most of the errors in investment measures in the field of rural development.
Member States' control systems are inadequate as controls are not comprehensive and are based on insufficient information.
The average error rate for rural development expenditure over the last three years was 8.2 %.
Errors in investment measures accounted for two-thirds of the error rate, while area-related aid accounted for one-third.
Only 16% of the error rate was due to non-compliance with provisions directly contained in EU regulations, while the largest proportion of the crime rate – 84% – was due to non-compliance with conditions set at Member State level.
The EU and the Member States provided more than EUR 150 billion for rural development policy in the 2007-2013 programming period, almost equally used for investment and land-based aid.
These expenditures are particularly flawed. • Are EU aid to prevent and remedy forest damage caused by fires and natural disasters well managed?
(No 24/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD) support measure for the reconstruction of forest potential and the implementation of preventive actions (measure 226) was well managed and whether the Commission and Member States could demonstrate that the objectives of the aid were achieved in a cost-effective manner.
The audit found that the EU's funding for the prevention of forest fires and the restoration of forests damaged by natural disasters and fires was not well enough managed.
The Commission and the Member States cannot prove that the results of the financial instruments have been achieved in a cost-effective way.
Over the past 30 years, on average, 480 000 hectares of forest have been destroyed annually in the EU by fires.
Preventive actions accounted for more than 80% of EU funding of 1.5 billion euros for the period 2007-2013.
Our activities 26 Security and Citizenship This policy area has been established to ensure the free movement of persons and to provide citizens with a high level of protection.
It ranges from the administration of the EU's external borders to judicial cooperation in civil and criminal matters and includes asylum and immigration policy, police cooperation and the fight against crime.
Expenditure in this area for the period 2014-2020 is expected to be 18 million euro or less than 2% of the total budget.
In 2014 the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • Findings from the development of the second generation (SIS II) information system by the European Commission (No. 3/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined why the Commission provided SIS II more than six years later than planned and incurred eight times more costs than originally estimated.
A robust business case for SIS II was examined for the entire duration of the project, taking into account major changes in costs and expected benefits.
The audit found that the delays and excessive costs were due to weaknesses in management by the Commission.
The initial deadline was unrealistic and the Commission was unable to manage effectively the main task for development before 2009.
The initial estimates of costs significantly underestimated the actual level of investment required.
The total cost of SIS II amounted to EUR 189 million, which was originally estimated at EUR 23 million.
The Commission did not fully demonstrate that SIS II provided it with the best cost-benefit ratio.
However, it has learned from its experience during the first phase of the project and has already used some of these findings for other large-scale IT projects.
The Schengen Information System is used by border protection, police, customs, visa and judicial authorities throughout the Schengen area.
It contains information (an alert) on persons who may have been involved in a serious offence or who do not have the right to enter or reside in the EU.
It also includes calls for tender for missing persons and lost or stolen property. • The External Borders Fund contributed to more financial solidarity, but the result measurement needs to be improved and additional EU added value created (No 15/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed the effectiveness and EU added value of the External Borders Fund and highlighted the extent to which the objectives of the co-financed projects and programmes have been achieved.
The audit showed that the External Borders Fund has contributed to the management of the EU's external borders and increased financial solidarity between Member States.
However, its additional EU added value was limited and the overall results could not be measured due to weaknesses in monitoring by the competent authorities and serious deficiencies in the evaluations carried out at Commission and Member State level.
Member States' programmes were not embedded in national border control and visa policies and contained neither SMART targets nor measurable indicators.
The project selection procedures did not ensure that the actual needs of the Member States were met.
Unbiased procurement procedures in Member States represent a risk to the sound financial management of the budget.
In the predominantly affected Member States (Greece, Spain, Italy and also Malta in the first years of support), the management of the Fund has been seriously weak.
As the EU's main financial instrument to support the management of external borders, the External Borders Fund for the period 2007-2013 was endowed with EUR 1.9 billion.
Its overarching objective was to assist current and future Schengen States in ensuring uniform, effective and efficient controls at their common external borders.
Our activities 27 Europe in the world The EU's activities in the field of external relations focus on: enlargement, achieving stability, security and prosperity in its neighbourhood, active support for sustainable development at international level, promoting global political governance and ensuring strategic and civil security.
The EU has allocated EUR 66 billion for the period 2014-2020 – at current prices – or 6% of its planned total expenditure for these objectives.
Expenditure is managed by the Commission, mainly directly through its central services or delegations.
In 2014, the Court produced the following special reports in this area: • The establishment of the European External Action Service (EEAS) (No 11/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the establishment of the EEAS has been adequately prepared, whether its resources have been efficiently prioritised, organised and allocated, and whether it has been effectively coordinated with the Commission and the Member States.
The audit found that the EEAS should increase its efficiency and do more for the EU and its citizens.
The establishment of the EEAS was overtaken and was not well prepared enough.
Inadequacies in prioritisation, organisation and allocation of resources reduced its efficiency.
Coordination between the EEAS and the Commission was only partially effective, mainly due to the lack of effective coordination mechanisms and to a rigid financial and administrative framework at the level of delegation.
Coordination with Member States can be further developed to exploit synergies in the area of information exchange or joint accommodation and to improve consular services, including the protection of EU citizens.
The EEAS shall have its headquarters in Brussels and shall have a worldwide network of 140 delegations.
For 2014, the EEAS had a budget of EUR 519 million, divided between the Headquarters (41%) and delegations (59%). • EU rehabilitation assistance following the earthquake in Haiti (No 13/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether the EU's regional rehabilitation assistance was well designed and adequately implemented, as well as whether the Commission ensured an appropriate link between emergency aid and rehabilitation and development measures.
The audit found that the EU's rehabilitation aid was well designed and focused on the country's urgent needs after the 2010 earthquake, but that the programmes had not been implemented effectively enough and that emergency aid, rehabilitation and development had not been sufficiently linked.
For most of the programmes audited, output has been achieved or is expected to be delivered, although almost all programmes have been delayed.
Although the Commission was aware of the difficult situation, it did not sufficiently take into account some of the major risks which threatened the implementation and achievement of the programme's objectives.
The programmes have been monitored, but the Commission and the EEAS have not taken timely action to increase the resources of the EU Delegation in Haiti.
In March 2010, 55 donors pledged $5.4 billion for 2010-2012 for rehabilitation and development and another $3.0 billion for 2013 and beyond.
The EU was one of the most important donors, with an individual commitment of EUR 1.2 billion.
Our activities 28 • Effectiveness of combining financial aid from regional investment facilities with loans (mixed financing) granted by financial institutions to support EU foreign policy (No. 16/2014) – In this special report, the Court addressed the establishment and management of the investment facilities and examined whether mixed financing has achieved the desired benefits.
The audit found a positive assessment on mixed financing, i.e. the combination of financial aid from regional investment facilities with loans granted by financial institutions to support EU foreign policy in terms of structure and overall effectiveness, but the Court also points to a number of key issues that need to be addressed as a matter of urgency.
Although the facilities were well-structured, the potential benefits of the mixed financing were not fully realised due to shortcomings in the Commission's management of these facilities.
Almost half of the projects examined have not had sufficient evidence to show that the grants were justified.
In some cases, investments would likely have been made without the EU contribution.
The Commission should ensure that the allocation of funds is based on a thorough, documented assessment of the added value with regard to the achievement of the objectives of the EU's development, neighbourhood and enlargement policies.
Since 2007, the Commission has created eight regional investment facilities.
These combine financial assistance from the EDF and the EU's overall budget with loans mainly from European development finance institutions.
Mixed funding is usually intended to exploit investment opportunities in the form of large infrastructure projects which could be financially viable but for which insufficient resources cannot be mobilised in the financial markets. • Can the EU initiative of centres of excellence contribute effectively to mitigating the chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear (CBRN) risks that originate outside the EU?
(No 17/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the initiative was based on a sound analysis of the situation existing before 2010, whether the organisational structure of the initiative was appropriate to meet the identified challenges and whether there was an appropriate administrative system and whether it was applied.
In the context of the audit, the Court adopted a generally positive view of the contribution of the Centres of Excellence to the reduction of CBRN risks.
The initiative is in line with the priorities set in the framework of the European Security Strategy and the EU Strategy against the Proliferation of Weapons of Mass Destruction.
It provides for the involvement of all stakeholders in the partner countries in order to improve the sustainability of the measures taken.
The organisational structure is generally appropriate, but its complexity contributed to delaying the start of project activities.
The Centres of Excellence initiative is aimed at setting up regional platforms in different regions of the world to counter CBRN risks.
It is the largest individual measure of the long-term component of the Instrument for Stability and has a budget of EUR 100 million for the period 2010-2013.
Our activities 29 • Systems established at EuropeAid for evaluation and results-oriented monitoring (ROM) (No 18/2014) – In this special report, the Court examined whether these systems are reliable, whether their structure and resources are adequate, and whether they ensure that relevant and meaningful findings are made and where possible benefit from the findings.
As part of the audit, the Court reached a critical assessment of the reliability of these systems.
The agencies responsible for evaluation and results-oriented monitoring are well organised, but more attention should be paid to the efficient use of resources.
The systems do not provide sufficient information on the results obtained and do not ensure that the findings are used as far as possible.
The evaluations of projects and programmes organised by the Commission delegations and carried out in partner countries are not managed satisfactorily: overall monitoring is not appropriate, there is uncertainty about the extent of resources used and there is a lack of access to the results.
Two key elements of the European Commission's framework for accountability in the Directorate-General for Development and Cooperation (EuropeAid) are their systems for evaluation and results-oriented monitoring.
The total annual cost of the systems is estimated at 34 to 38 million euros.
The annual development expenditure covered by these systems is estimated to be around EUR 8 billion. • EU pre-accession assistance to Serbia (No 19/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the Commission had effectively managed pre-accession assistance to Serbia during the period 2007-2013, and assessed its support for the key area of governance.
Together with other forms of support, the resources provided by the Instrument for Pre-Accession Assistance (IPA) helped Serbia implement social and economic reforms and improve public financial management.
Based on its experience with other IPA beneficiary countries, the Commission is increasingly putting emphasis on governance issues in the planning of financial and non-financial assistance to Serbia.
The Commission has effectively managed non-financial assistance to Serbia in the areas of governance and the fight against corruption.
As regards Serbia's preparations for the discreet management of EU funds, the Commission has also provided effective support, but only in the limited area of IPA administrative structures.
A quarter of the IPA funding for Serbia has been allocated to governance, which, according to the Commission, is the biggest challenge facing Serbia.
The EU complements IPA funding with a number of non-financial resources to help Serbia prepare for EU membership.
Our activities 30 Administration The administrative expenditure of the EU institutions, agencies and other bodies includes expenditure on staff (wages and pensions) as well as on buildings, equipment, energy, communication and information technology.
The planned budget for the period 2014-2020 is – at current prices – EUR 70 million, or 6 % of the total EU budget.
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report: • How do EU institutions and bodies calculate, reduce and compensate their greenhouse gas emissions?
(No 14/2014) – In this special report, the Court assessed whether the EU institutions and bodies had strategies to reduce the environmental impact of their administrative activities and whether they had been effectively implemented.
In the report, the Court called on the EU institutions and bodies to develop a common policy approach to reduce their greenhouse gas emissions (CO2 footprint).
The introduction of the environmental management and audit system is slow and the available information on the actual level of emissions is incomplete.
Few bodies and institutions systematically use environmental procurement.
While the EU institutions and bodies have managed to reverse the trend of rising greenhouse gas emissions related to energy consumption in their buildings, no clear trends of reductions in other emission sources, such as missions, could be identified based on the available data.
More than half of the EU's audited institutions and bodies had not set any quantified targets for reducing their emissions.
EU environmental policy aims at a high level of protection.
The Treaty (TFEU) requires that environmental protection requirements be included in the definition and implementation of Union policies and measures to promote sustainable development.
Our activities 31 revenue/own resources Own resources are the revenue of the EU, which is used to finance its expenditure.
There are three types of own resources: traditional own resources (tariff duties on imports from outside the EU and sugar production levies), own resources based on VAT and own resources derived from GNI (the largest source of revenue for the EU budget).
In 2014, the Court adopted the following special report in this area: • Will preferential trade arrangements be managed in a proportionate manner?
(No 2/2014) – In this report, the Court assessed whether the Commission adequately assessed the economic impact of preferential trade arrangements and whether controls effectively ensure that imports could not wrongly be subject to preferential duties, resulting in a loss of EU revenue.
The audit found that while the Commission has increased the quality of its impact assessments over time, the economic impact of preferential trade arrangements remains insufficiently analysed.
The EU escapes revenue due to weaknesses in Member States' customs controls: these controls do not prevent some imports from being wrongly subject to preferential customs duties.
Through unilateral preferential trade arrangements, the EU grants preferences to developing countries in order to provide them with duty-free access to the EU market and thus contribute to the eradication of poverty and to the promotion of sustainable development.
In 2011, the value of goods imported into the EU under preferential trade arrangements was more than EUR 242 billion, representing 14% of imports into the EU.
Our activities 32 Financial and economic governance The European Union's framework for economic governance aims to prevent or investigate and correct problematic economic developments, such as excessive government deficits or debt levels, which can inhibit growth and expose the sustainability of public finances to risk.
In 2014, the Court adopted its first Special Report in this area: • European Banking Supervision is taking shape – EBA in a changing environment (No 5/2014) – In this Special Report, the Court examined whether the Commission and the European Banking Authority (EBA) have satisfactorily exercised their responsibilities with a view to establishing new regulatory and supervisory arrangements in the banking sector and how effective these arrangements worked.
The audit showed that the Commission's lead reform of banking legislation and the establishment of EBA were the first major responses to the financial crisis.
EBA has laid the foundations for a new regulatory and supervisory system for the banking sector.
The weaknesses identified concerned cross-border banking supervision, the assessment of the resilience of EU banks and the promotion of consumer protection.
In the context of the implementation of the 2011 stress test, which was carried out at EU level without the last financial protection measures, the EBA had only a limited legal mandate and scarce staff resources.
Although the 2011 stress test resulted in the recapitalisation of many banks, it has also shown that such stress tests are subject to restrictions if they do not go hand in hand with the assessment of the quality of the overall assets.
Questions remain as to the future role of EBA in banking supervision and the respective roles and responsibilities of EBA and the ECB.
As a result of the financial crisis, the Commission has launched measures to stabilise the banking sector, aimed at strengthening the regulatory framework and the supervision of banks, particularly in cross-border banks.
In the course of the detailed proposals for regulatory changes, EBA was created in 2011.
EBA plays a role in supervising European banking regulation and consumer protection.
Our activities 33 Opinions and other declarations adopted in 2014 The Court's opinions on proposals for new or amended acts with financial implications help to improve EU financial management.
These opinions will be delivered at the request of the other EU institutions and used by the legislative authorities – the European Parliament and the Council – in their work.
The Court may also, on its own initiative, issue position papers and analyses on other issues.
At the Court's initiative, the European Court of Auditors' position on the Commission's report on the fight against corruption was presented, while the study on the possible savings in the EU budget was carried out by pooling the activities of the European Parliament in a single place at the request of the European Parliament.
7 comments in 2014
Our activities 34 Landscape analyses The year 2014 was marked by profound innovations for the European Union.
Against the background of this change, the Court has conceived and created a new product: the Landscape Analysis.
Taking into account the Court's work and the wealth of knowledge and experience, each analysis covers a wide range of topics.
The analyses should serve as a basis for consultation and dialogue with the Court's addressees and help the Court to submit comments on important issues which are not currently subject to scrutiny.
The first Landscape Analysis, published in September 2014, dealt with questions of EU accountability and public financial control rules (see box).This analysis was the main basis for the conference on EU accountability, which took place in October 2014 (see page 42).
The second analysis entitled "An optimal use of EU funds: a landscape analysis on risks to EU financial management" was published in November 2014.
It provides an overview of the EU's financial flows and a summary of the issues to be addressed, inter alia, to ensure that EU taxpayers can be offered a better cost-benefit ratio with regard to the EU budget (see box).
The opinions and landscape analyses are available in full in 23 official EU languages on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu).
2 2 Landscape analyses in 2014
Our activities 35 gaps, overlaps and challenges: A landscape analysis of EU rules on accountability and public financial control This landscape analysis aims to raise awareness of an issue that is of utmost importance for the democratic legitimacy of the EU's institutional system and to stimulate reflection on this issue.
It describes the main features of a framework for accountability, the role of public financial control, the key elements for a sound chain of accountability and financial control, as well as six key areas where challenges in terms of accountability and public financial control exist at EU level, and analyses the accountability and financial control arrangements in relation to the various new EU and intergovernmental instruments developed in response to the financial crisis.
Making the most of EU funds: A Landscape Analysis on the Risks to EU Financial Management At a time when Member State governments and taxpayers want greater benefit from the resources they contribute, this Landscape Analysis summarises the Court's comments on all aspects of EU financial management.
Based on the Court's 35-year experience in assessing EU revenue and expenditure, this Landscape Analysis provides an overview of EU financial management and a summary of the issues to be addressed to ensure a better cost-benefit ratio with the EU budget.
This analysis is complemented by detailed data sheets on the main features and issues linked to the various revenue and expenditure sectors and suggestions for improvement are made.
Our activities 36 The analysis identifies a number of key points that deserve particular attention: ο excessively complex eligibility schemes and other conditions for EU support that make their understanding, management and control difficult and lead to different interpretations; ο rules and procedures for public procurement that are not always complied with – either intentionally or because they are not properly understood – and thus lead to higher costs or delays in EU-funded projects; ο insufficient capacity of national authorities to manage and disbursement of EU funds that increases the risk of errors and the risk of low quality of expenditure; ο poor coordination of EU budget and national budgets; a lack of co-financing by Member States; and a greater emphasis on compliance with rules than achieving results; ο a high volume of commitments from the previous period of expenditure that still need to be financed from the EU budget.
Accountability framework for the management and financial control of the EU European Parliament and Council (MS) European audit Court of Auditors European Commission and managing authorities of the MS chart from the Landscape analysis of the EU rules on accountability and public financial control.

Our activities 37 Relations with the addressees The value of the Court's contribution to the EU's accountability obligation depends to a large extent on the benefits its main partners derive from its work and its products in the process of accountability.
These partners are the political bodies responsible for public oversight of the use of EU financial resources (i.e. the European Parliament, the Council of the EU and national parliaments).
Through its 2013-2017 strategy, the Court is required to step up the provision to monitor external developments and to actively shape relations with its partners.
The President and the members of the Court shall maintain regular contacts with the committees of the European Parliament, in particular the Committee on Budgetary Control.
In 2014, President Caldeira attended two meetings of the Committee on Budgetary Control and a number of plenary sessions of the European Parliament.
This included the presentation of the annual work programme and the annual reports.
One of the Court's strategic objectives is to strengthen the partnership with its main stakeholders, including the various specialised committees of the European Parliament and the Council.
In April 2014, the Court transferred the newly created function of the member responsible for institutional relations to Ville Itälä, which helped to strengthen our institution's relations with other EU institutions in a strategic way and to increase the opportunities for greater impact with our work.
In 2014, additional Court members stood 64 times before the Committee on Budgetary Control in conjunction with the Court's annual reports and special reports at 17 meetings.
The ensuing discussions resulted in reports drawn up by individual members of the Committee on Budgetary Control on the Court's special reports, including a draft report on the special reports related to the 2013 discharge procedure.
In 2014, the Committee on Budgetary Control started to systematically invite the technical committees to the ideas of our special reports at its meetings, thus contributing to an increased impact of our work.
In early 2014, the European Parliament adopted a report on the future role of the European Court of Auditors.
The Court welcomed the view expressed in this report that any reform should be considered in the wider context of the challenge of improving EU accountability.
This applies in particular to the Court's work, its relations with the addressees and its use of resources.
The progress made on these issues was highlighted in the 2014 peer review report (see ‘Important events').
Our activities 38 In many cases, the Court has already launched a number of initiatives to improve the implementation of its 2013-2017 strategy, including streamlining the audit and reporting process and more flexible management of resources.
This led to more reports being produced in the course of the year and reduced the average time needed for this.
Further efficiency gains and increased effectiveness of the audit process are expected from the internal reform project launched in 2014.
In a resolution of November 2013, the European Parliament asked the Court to present a comprehensive analysis of the potential savings for the EU budget, which would arise if Parliament had a single seat, taking into account the savings made due to the reduced loss of working time and greater efficiency.
The Court presented the outcome of this work in July 2014 and concluded that a move from Strasbourg to Brussels could lead to considerable savings, which were slightly higher due to an additional move from Luxembourg to Brussels.
In 2014, the Court continued regular cooperation with the Council in its various configurations and activities.
President Caldeira presented the annual reports to the ECOFIN Council in December 2014, and the Court was regularly invited to present special reports to the various Council committees and working groups.
Ensuring effective relations with national parliaments is another priority for the Court.
The committees of national parliaments responsible for European affairs and financial control are regularly informed of the Court's activities.
Delegations from several national parliaments visited the Court during the year, including the visit of a delegation from the French Senate in July 2014.
The Court also invited the main addressees to the annual seminar of its members in December 2014 to present their views on the challenges of accountability in the EU.
The Court cooperates with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) to combat fraud as a follow-up to the EU budget.
It shall forward to OLAF any evidence of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity affecting the financial interests of the EU which it identifies as part of its audit work or which it is informed of by third parties.
In 2014, the Court informed OLAF of 16 cases in which fraud, corruption or illegal activities were suspected during the audit work.
Our activities 39 Cooperation with other Supreme Audit Institutions The Court cooperates with other Supreme Audit Institutions (ORCBs) mainly in the following fora: • Contact Committee of the SAIs of EU Member States; • Network of the SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries; • International organisations for public financial control bodies, in particular the International Organization of the Supreme Audit Authorities (INTOSAI) and their European Regional Group (EUROSAI).
In September 2014, the Court revised and updated its international cooperation strategy (see box).
EUROSAI Congress, The Hague, June 2014.
The Court's Strategy for International Cooperation The Court's Strategy for Cooperation, in line with its overarching 2013-2017 strategy, aims to make the greatest possible contribution to the EU's public accountability, in particular through enhanced bi- and multilateral cooperation with relevant partners such as national Supreme Audit Institutions and international audit organisations.
Since the Court's audit obligations cover areas which are pan-European (e.g. financial governance) and global (e.g. climate change) impact, our international cooperation activities are even more important than in the past.
The Court's cooperation strategy has the following priorities: ο Cooperation at EU level within the Contact Committee and individual cooperation with the SAIs of the EU Member States will continue to be the main priorities.
This may include participation in joint audits and joint work in the area of accountability relevant to the EU budget and other EU policies. ο In the context of EU enlargement, the Court will continue to support the SAIs of candidate countries and potential candidate countries in their actions for the development of expertise. ο As a member of international audit organisations such as INTOSAI, the Court will increase its participation in cooperation activities to establish technical standards, as this organisation is of great importance for the development of expertise and for the exchange of knowledge in the public financial control sector.
Through its cooperation strategy, in conjunction with other recent actions, such as the newly established high-level conferences and meetings, the Court will help raise awareness of EU financial management and accountability.
Our activities 40 Contact Committee of the Supreme Audit Authorities of the EU Member States In accordance with the EU Treaty, the European Court of Auditors and the national audit bodies are working together with confidence in respect of their independence.
The Court cooperates actively with the SAIs of EU Member States within the Contact Committee, including an annual meeting and the various working groups, networks and task forces set up to address specific issues of common interest.
In October 2013, the Court took over the chair of the Contact Committee for a year.
As chairman, the Court hosted the annual meeting of the Contact Committee, which took place in October 2014.
The main agenda items included a seminar on strengthening cooperation, in particular in the areas related to the Europe 2020 strategy and the Banking Union, reporting on the activities of the Contact Committee and its technical partners and audits carried out by members of the Contact Committee with regard to the EU.
The Court also cooperates with the SAIs of EU Member States on a bilateral basis.
A good example of this is a project jointly carried out by the Court and the SAIs of Poland, Najwyższa Izba Kontroli, in which the auditors of the Polish SAIs took an active part in our audit work in Poland on the eradication, control and monitoring of animal diseases.
In addition, in the context of the chapter on the outcome of the 2014 annual report, the Court is working with the SAIs of Poland and Portugal on Europe 2020.
Meeting of the Contact Committee in Luxembourg on 15-17 October 2014.
Our activities 41 Network of Supreme Audit Institutions of Candidate Countries and Potential Candidate Countries Cooperation between the Court and the SAIs of Candidate Countries and potential candidate countries is primarily carried out through a network similar to the Contact Committee1.
During 2014, the Court supported the network in carrying out a parallel audit of energy efficiency, in particular by providing experts for the sector and for the methodology of the audit.
International organisations for public financial control bodies In 2014, the Court continued to participate comprehensively and actively in the activities of INTOSAI and released important contributions to various committees and working groups: • under Objective 1 of INTOSAI as a member of the Technical Standards Committee and as a member of the Sub-Committee for the Audit of Accounting, the Sub-Committee for the Audit of Legal Standards and the Sub-Committee for Economic Audits; • under Objective 2 of INTOSAI as a member of the Committee for the Development of Skills and the Sub-Committee for the Promotion of Best Practices and Quality Assurance through Voluntary Peer Reviews; • under Objective 3 of INTOSAI as a member of the Committee for the Exchange of Knowledge and its Working Group on Environmental Audit and the Working Group on Financial Modernisation and Regulatory Reform. The Court participated in the IXth EUROSAI Congress in June 2014.
He also attended the XLI. and the XLII. meeting of the EUROSAI Bureau, to which he has been a member since 2011.The Court continued to actively participate in the EUROSAI working groups, in particular the IT audit and environmental audit work groups, the Accompanying Committee for the Establishment and Operation of the Electronic Good Practice Database on Quality of Audit, as well as the Audit and Ethics Task Force.
The Court also joined the newly established Task Force on Disaster Aid.
At the INTOSAI Joint Conferences, the Court took an active part in the Second Joint ASOSAI2-EUROSAI Conference, focusing on the lessons learned from the experience gained in the context of the adoption of the ISSAI3 and its implications for the future.

Our activities 42 Key events International expert review of the Court In 2013, the Court asked the SAIs of France, Germany and Sweden to carry out a peer review of their business audit practice.
The peer review was based on the experience of all three partners and was a very useful exercise for both the court and the expert reviewers.
The methodology was based on generally accepted criteria for the work of SAIs and took into account the guidelines set out in international standards.
The peer review was published on the Court's website (eca.europa.eu) in 2014.
The peers concluded that the Court had made considerable progress since the last peer review in 2008.
The Court had examined the challenges posed by the complex institutional framework of the EU and had taken a number of steps to increase the efficiency and effectiveness of its audits and the quality of its audit reports.
International auditing principles encourage international peer reviews to be carried out.
They allow Supreme Audit Institutions to obtain a voluntary assessment of the performance of their tasks based on international standards.
In 2014, the Court headed the peer review of the Supreme Audit Authority of Lithuania and was asked to review the Swiss Federal Financial Control and to participate in peer reviews of the SAIs of Spain and Latvia.
High-level conference to improve accountability in the EU From left to right: Jacques Sciberras, Head of Cabinet, Kevin Cardiff, Member of the Court, President Vítor Caldeira and EP Vice-President Olli Rehn.
In October 2014, the Court organised a high-level conference to which many people were invited to ensure that the European Union complied with its accountability with regard to public funding to achieve its objectives.
The conference focused on the gaps, overlaps and challenges at EU and Member State level identified in the Court's Landscape Analysis of EU Accountability and Public Financial Control Regulations (see page 35).
The conference provided an opportunity for discussion among participants, including members or representatives of the European Parliament, the European Commission, the Court, the European Central Bank, the European Investment Bank, the European Stability Mechanism, national audit courts and science. It discussed how these arrangements should be developed in response to developments in economic, budgetary and monetary integration.
The focus was on accountability within the EU, in particular with regard to central banks and supervisors, post-crisis structures, increasing the leverage of EU funds through external participation and focusing more on the EU's performance.
The conference agreed that there is a need for greater cooperation between government authorities, parliaments and auditors at EU and Member State level in order to give the public a better idea of what the EU's policies and programmes are doing.
Our activities 43 Strengthening partnerships with national authorities in Lithuania A high-level delegation from the Court visited Lithuania in September 2014 to strengthen partnerships with Parliament, the Government, the Central Bank and the SAIs of the country and to promote the best possible use and control of EU expenditure there.
The Court and its partners in Lithuania exchanged views on the priorities for improving the EU's accountability and considered how they could best contribute to the added value of EU expenditure through their cooperation and help policy-makers and Parliament in Lithuania to make the best use of the Court's audit results.
During the visit, the Court delegation took an active part in the Lithuanian Parliament's conference on the challenges of accountability and audit in the public sector.
In addition, the delegation and its partners discussed financial and economic governance issues as well as the benefits of Lithuania's accession to the euro area on 1 January 2015.
Lithuania was the first of a number of EU Member States to visit the Court in the coming years in order to strengthen partnerships with national authorities responsible for managing and controlling EU funds.
Our Management 44 The College of the Court The College of the Court is composed of one member from each Member State.
Under the contract, the term of office of the members of the Court shall be six years, and a reappointment shall be possible.
Members are assigned to one of five chambers.
The boards adopt audit reports and opinions and take decisions on wider strategic and administrative issues.
In addition, each member is responsible for his or her own duties, which are primarily audit-related tasks.
The audit work is carried out by the Court's auditors and coordinated by the competent member, assisted by his cabinet.
The member shall then present the report for adoption by the Chamber and/or by the whole College of the Court, and subsequently the presentation in the European Parliament, the Council and other interested parties, including the media.
In accordance with the proposals of its Member States and after consulting the European Parliament, the Council of the European Union appointed six new Members of the European Court of Auditors in 2014.
Four of these members – Alex Brenninkmeijer (Netherlands), Danièle Lamarque (France), Nikolaos Milionis (Greece) and Phil Wynn Owen (United Kingdom) – welcomed the Court on 1 January, two more – Klaus‐Heiner Lehne (Germany) and Oskar Herics (Austria) – were welcomed on 1 March 2014.
On 23 January 2014, the 28 members of the Court again elected Vítor Caldeira President for a third three-year period.
The President shall be responsible for supervising the performance of the Court's mandate and representing the institution externally.
Members of the Court at the end of 2014.
Meeting of the Court's members on 27 October 2014.

Our management 46 Court strategy for 2013-2017: Progress achieved 2014 was the second year in which the Court implemented its strategy for the period 2013-2017.
In this period, the value of the contribution made by the Court to the EU's public accountability will be maximised.
In order to achieve this objective, the Court's main priorities are to: ο focus the Court's products on improving the accountability of the EU; ο cooperate with other actors to reinforce the Court's contribution to the accountability of the EU; ο develop the Court as a professional audit body; ο make optimum use of the Court's knowledge and expertise available to it; ο demonstrate the Court's capacity and accountability.
In 2014, the strategy initiated a major restructuring of the Court's organisational structure.
Two internal working groups on the strategy ("Strengthening the audit process" and "better definition of tasks and responsibilities") presented their results.
This coincided with the European Parliament's report on the future role of the ECA and the results of the peer review procedure to which the Court has subjected itself.
The various recommendations were summarised in a far-reaching reform project, whose implementation started at the end of 2014 and will last until mid-2016.
In the case of special reports, this means that they are to be prepared in a shorter time and in the case of the annual report, greater focus and resource savings are sought.
The Court is to be transformed into a task-based organisation in two respects.
This will make it better able to use resources specifically for those audits and analyses that provide the greatest added value for EU citizens.
Our management 47 Measuring the performance of the Court Since 2008, the Court has been applying central performance indicators (ZLI) to inform the management of the progress made with regard to its objectives, to support the decision-making process and to provide information on performance to its addressees.
The ZLI reflects the Court's priorities and provides information on its performance and accountability as a professional audit body.
The indicators are used to measure core parameters for the quality and impact of the Court's work, with particular regard to the point of view of key stakeholders and the efficiency and effectiveness of its use of resources.
The ZLIs have been updated for the period covered by the 2013-2017 strategy.
Assessment by addressees Relevance of reports Probable impact of reports Quality and impact of the Court's work The Court assesses the quality and impact of its reports on the basis of assessments by addressees and expert reviews. A further assessment criterion is the measures taken as a result of its recommendations to improve EU financial management.
In addition, the court measures its media presence.
The Court has asked its main addressees, the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets of the European Parliament, the Council's Committee on Budgets, the main audited bodies at the Commission and EU agencies, as well as the Presidents of the EU – ORCB, to assess the relevance and impact of its reports published in 2014 on a five-stage scale from "very high" to "very low".

They assessed the quality of different aspects of the reports on a four-stage scale from "significantly impaired" (1) to "highly-valued" (4).

Our Management 49 Media Presence The indicator concerning the court's media presence reflects the court's effect in the media.
It concerns the strategic objective of raising awareness of the Court, its products and its audit findings and conclusions.
In 2014, the Court identified more than 5 100 online activities related to its special reports, the annual reports 2013 and the institution in general.
40 % of these covered audit reports and in the other articles reference was made to the institution and its work in general.
Over 800 articles have been published on the Special Report on Airports of the ECA Implementation of the work programme The Court plans its audits and other tasks on the basis of the annual work programme and monitors progress during the year.
In 2014, the Court carried out 95% of the tasks foreseen in its work programme (in 2013: 90%).
While work on the annual reports and specific annual reports was carried out as planned, this was the case with the special reports for 85% (2013: 70%).
The 2014 non-completed economic audits were carried over to 2015.

Our management 50 Preparation of special reports In order for special reports of the Court to have an effect, they must be submitted promptly.
In recent years, the Court has managed to shorten the time required for the tests.
The aim of the 2013-2017 strategy is to achieve further improvements and this strategy is expected to produce measurable results in the coming years.
Processing duration of the special reports issued in 2014 In 2014, the Court produced 24 special reports, of which 42 % (2013: 37 %) were completed within the 18-month timeframe envisaged by the Court.
On average, 19 months were needed for the preparation of the special reports adopted in 2014 (2013: 20 months).
