Support for audit activities Personnel resources Personnel allocation As a result of the difficult situation of public finances in Europe, the Court continued the reduction of staff for a period of five years (2013-2017) by 1% per year, as laid down in the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline and sound financial management of December 2013.
As a result, staffing was reduced from 891 to 882 temporary officials (excluding members, contract staff, seconded national experts and trainees) in 2014.
Of the posts in total, 561 are allocated to audit posts (including 113 staff in members' cabinets).
With a view to achieving the best possible use of resources, all activities in 2014 once again identified and implemented ways of improving efficiency through the establishment of procedures.
The transfer of staff from support to audit services was also continued in 2014.
However, this was compensated by the redeployment of certain support services from members' cabinets into an administrative pool, and the transfer of the Communication and Institutional Relations Unit to the President's services.
51 Recruitment The Court's staff have a broad academic and professional background, and the quality of their work and their commitment are reflected in the Court's output.
The Court's recruitment policy follows the general principles and conditions of employment of the EU institutions, and the staff consists of both officials and operators with temporary contracts.
In 2014, an internal selection procedure for grade AST 1 and a selection procedure for the recruitment of a speaker were carried out.
The Court also provided placements for 77 university graduates for periods of three to five months throughout the year.
The Court recruited 78 staff in 2014: 31 officials, 29 temporary staff, 13 contract staff and five seconded national experts.
The number of vacant posts has been close to 3% since 2011 (on 31 December 2014 there were 27 vacant posts).

Supporting audit activities 55 Support services Professional training To further develop the Court as a professional examination body and to make the best use of its existing knowledge as well as the expertise and expertise at its disposal, a continuous training of staff is necessary in order to keep pace with professional developments and to acquire new skills.
In 2014, the Court's staff (auditors and other employees) completed on average eight days of professional training.
The proportion of language courses in continuing vocational training is continuing to decline.
In 2014, this represented 43% of the total number of training days (compared to 46% in 2013).
In order to make the best use of existing resources and technologies, the Court has been offering its staff individually tailored e-learning courses and training activities since 2014 in the form of integrated learning, in which participants complete the general theory in an online training before the attendance event.
Furthermore, the objective of exchanging existing internal knowledge and providing the Court's auditors with the most up-to-date status of developments in the public sector audit process has continued to organise presentations of internal and external experts on developments in audit and other relevant areas.
Translation Translation is an audit support activity which enables the Court to fulfil its mission and achieve its communication objectives by providing the results it has provided in the languages of EU citizens.
In 2014, the total translation volume was 4% higher than in 2013.
More than 98% of the translations were completed on time.
In addition to normal translation work, the Translation Directorate further enhanced the direct participation of translators in the Court's audit and core business: translators provided linguistic support during 40 audit visits throughout the EU and in drafting audit reports.
In 2014, the Translation Directorate focused on quality assurance.
To this end, the first quality assurance manual in the translation field was adopted and a system for customer feedback was developed.
Finally, in order to make the services more efficient, the course of the translation work was reviewed and optimised.In cooperation with the Information Technologies Directorate, the automation of the process was started.
Support for audit activities 56 All processes related to the development and provision of instruments were carried out in order to ensure the security and continuity of operations: for example, in 2014 after the new K3 building had been purchased, a comprehensive test was carried out to re-launch it following a collapse of the IT systems (disaster recovery) and new IT components were modernised (e.g. the introduction of the Court's e-mail system).
Administration and Infrastructure The role of the Finance and Support Services Directorate is to provide adequate resources, services and infrastructure so that the Court can fulfil its mandate and achieve its strategic objectives, and to ensure that the necessary financial, internal controls and accounting mechanisms are available to support all the Court's activities.
In 2014, the Directorate continued to focus on making its activities even more efficient and economic.
An environmental management system for the Court is currently being developed in accordance with the principles of the Community system for environmental management and audit (EMAS), with certification to be obtained by the end of 2016.
In 2014, a number of measures were successfully implemented that provided concrete results and demonstrated the Court's commitment to the environment, including: • adoption of an environmental policy; • implementation of an environmental analysis and verification of compliance with environmental legislation; • increasing the number of environmental awareness campaigns from four in 2013 to eight in 2014; • obtaining BREEAM environmental certification (the world's leading method of designing and evaluating sustainable buildings) for the K3 building and maintaining the certification mark for good waste management; • encouraging sustainable transport among workers by providing a new bicycle room with showers and changing areas for cyclists, installing a charging station for electric cars and reserving good parking places for cycling communities.
Support for audit activities 57 Financial information The Court is financed by the general budget of the European Union.
The Court's budget accounts for around 0.093 % of total EU expenditure and 1.58% of total administrative expenditure.
In 2014, the overall budget execution rate was 98.8%, compared with 92% in 2013.
The higher execution rate is mainly due to a better estimate and planning of expenditure in Title 1, which achieved an average execution rate of 98.8%.
For Title 2, the average execution rate was 98.4%.

Supporting audit activities 59 Auditing and accountability Internal audit of the Court The Internal Auditor advises the Court on risk control issues by providing opinions on the quality of management and control systems and recommendations to improve the conditions for the management of operations and to promote sound financial management.
The internal auditor also supports the work of the external auditor, whose mission is to certify the Court's annual accounts.
The internal auditor reported to the Court on the results of the audits carried out during 2014, the findings, the recommendations and the measures taken on the basis of those recommendations.
The Court reports annually to the European Parliament and the Council on the results of the internal auditor's work.
In October 2014, the Court's internal audit certified compliance with the definition of internal audit, code of conduct and standards established by the Institute of Internal Auditors (IAA).
This certification was the result of a comprehensive quality assessment of the Court's internal audit carried out at the request of the Internal Auditor and the Internal Audit Committee by an external evaluator, Deloitte SARL, which also met the IIA's international standards for internal audit professional practice.
External audit of the Court The Court's annual accounts are audited by an independent auditor.
This is an important aspect of the Court's approach to applying the same transparency and accountability principles to itself as to its audited bodies.
The auditor's report – Pricewaterhouse‐ Coopers SARL – on the Court of Auditors' annual accounts for the financial year 2013 was published on 18 September 2014.
Audit opinions of the independent auditor – Financial year 2013 As regards the annual accounts: "We believe that the annual closure provides a true picture of the financial and financial situation of the European Court of Auditors as at 31 December 2013, its profitability and cash flows for the year ending on that reference date, in accordance with Regulation (EU, Eura‐tom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union and to Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1268/2012 of 29 October 2012 on the provisions for the application of the Financial Regulation.
Declaration by the 60 authorising officer by delegation The undersigned, Secretary-General of the European Court of Auditors, hereby declares, in his capacity as authorising officer by delegation, that the information contained in this report is accurate and accurate and confirms with sufficient certainty that the resources provided for the activities described in this report have been used for the purposes envisaged and in accordance with the principles of sound financial management, and that the control procedures established provide the necessary assurance for the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions and for the appropriate handling of fraud or suspicions of fraud, costs and benefits of the controls are appropriate.
This security shall be based on the assessment of the undersigned and the information at his disposal, such as the reports and statements of the authorising officer by subdelegation, the internal auditor's reports and the independent auditor's audit reports on previous financial years.

European Court of Auditors EU FINANCING HOURS
European Court of Auditors 02 About the Court The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
He has 28 members – one from each EU Member State – and has around 900 staff from all EU Member States in the audit and administrative field.
Since its establishment in 1977, the Court has been committed to better EU financial management and better accounting.
The Court's tasks The Court shall verify that the EU funds have been properly accounted for, taken up and spent in accordance with the relevant rules and regulations, and that optimum use is made of the funds.
It warns against risks, provides security and provides guidance to EU policy-makers on how to improve public financial management and ensure that European citizens know how to use their money.
Through its audit work and other activities, the Court contributes to strengthening the democratic legitimacy and sustainability of the European Union.

Foreword by President 04 Dear reader, in 2015, to which this report refers, the European Union was once again faced with major challenges: significant developments in EU governance, policy and financial management, including the establishment of the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI) and the introduction of the Single Resolution Mechanism for Banks in the euro area.
These and other developments have led to new audit tasks for the Court.
In 2015, we also reviewed the activities of the EU institutions and other bodies, as well as all EU funds paid to Member States, countries outside the EU, international organisations and other beneficiaries.
In accordance with our obligations arising from the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, we have produced annual reports on the general budget of the EU and on the European Development Funds, as well as special annual reports on the accounts of more than 50 EU agencies and other bodies.
In addition, we produced 25 special reports on many topics, the results of which are summarised in the present activity report.
We would like to draw your attention in particular to two special reports: our report on the emissions trading system, which shows that our work goes beyond purely financial matters, and our report on financial assistance to countries in difficulty, which is part of a series of new special reports on financial and economic governance.
In addition, we delivered eight opinions last year on new or amended EU legislation with significant financial implications, including an opinion on the Regulation establishing the EFSI.
To make a difference with our work, we need to pass on the lessons learned to stakeholders at EU and national level.
During the year, we have further deepened our cooperation with the European Parliament and the Council of the European Union – our key partners in ensuring EU accountability.
We presented the results of our audits to an increasing number of specialised committees of these bodies, and we took their concerns into account when planning future audits.
The Court also paid high-level visits to the Member States in order to strengthen partnerships with national authorities, parliaments and audit bodies.
In 2015, we organised two noteworthy conferences: one in Brussels on EU energy security and the other in Luxembourg on the future of development aid in the context of the new United Nations Sustainable Development Goals.
We also prepared a major internal reform in order to be able to respond better to the continuous developments within the European Union.
The present report explains some important changes that we have made in relation to our relationships with stakeholders, our audits and our resources.
Furthermore, you will receive important information about our human resources management, finances and performance and the results of our internal and external audits last year, as well as about the recent annual discharge procedure.
I hope that this report will give you a useful and interesting overview of the Court's activities in 2015, and with these activities we want to fulfil our mission of improving EU financial management, promoting accountability and transparency and protecting the financial interests of EU citizens.
In 2015, at a glance 05 Our activities Our management • Annual reports on the general budget of the EU • and on the European Development Funds for the financial year 2014, which essentially contain the Statements of Assurance and the audit results. • 52 special annual reports with the Court's audit opinions on the accounting of individual agencies and other bodies of the EU as well as two summary reports. We carried out an internal reform to streamline our audit and reporting procedures and allow greater flexibility in the management of our resources. • 25 special reports on specific management issues and budgetary areas, including the emissions trading system, youth employment programmes and assistance during the financial crisis. • 8 opinions on new or amended EU legislation and other decisions affecting financial management, from the proposed regulation on the European Fund for Strategic Investments to the amended regulation on the single resolution mechanism. • Meetings, seminars and conferences with our addressees, including two high-level conferences on EU accountability, one on the security of energy supply and the other on the future of development assistance.
We continued our equal opportunities policy in terms of recruitment and human resources management. • We made considerable progress in integrating audit management and audit documentation information systems. We also made audit related information available on mobile devices. The premises of the European Court of Auditors in Luxembourg.
Our Activities 06 Audits Our audit reports and opinions are an important link in the EU's accountability chain, as they are used to bring the authorities responsible for the EU's budgetary management to account, especially in the context of the annual discharge procedure.
These bodies are primarily the European Commission, but also the other EU institutions and bodies.
Member States also play an important role in areas of shared management, such as expenditure on agricultural and cohesion measures.
Our three main products are: • Annual reports which essentially contain the results of audits of the accounts and compliance audits on the budget of the European Union and on the European Development Funds (EDF), but also cover aspects of budgetary management and performance aspects.
• Special reports presenting the results of selected economic or compliance audits on specific expenditure or policy areas or on budgetary or management issues. • Opinions on new or amended legislative acts affecting financial management and other products based on analyses, drawn up either at the request of another institution or at the Court's own initiative.
We strive to manage our resources in a way that ensures an adequate balance between our various activities, while ensuring that the various areas of the EU budget are well covered and achieving sound results.
In 2015, we used a significant share of our resources to draw up the annual Statements of Assurance, which were then presented in our annual reports.
The work of the Statement of Assurance encompasses the two aspects on which we have to make an annual audit opinion in accordance with the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union: the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
We also take into account, where possible, the work of other auditors (see section on the audit of EU agencies on page 14) and the management declarations in the form of the Annual Activity Reports of the Directors-General of the Commission.
In addition to the statutory audits, we select at our discretion special expenditure or policy areas. This is based on criteria such as the risk of irregularities or inadequate performance, potential for improvement and public interest.
We choose these topics entirely independently, but take into account the points of view of our addressees.
In 2015, we produced 25 special reports, which are the result of our audit work.
The summaries of the special reports are presented in this activity report (pp. 15-33).
In 2015, we issued eight opinions on proposals for new or amended regulations and regulations (p. 34).
In particular, we draw attention to our opinion on the EFSI to clarify both the issue and the impact of our opinions.
All audit reports and opinions are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).

Our activities 08 audit visits in 2015 While most of the audit work was carried out at the Court's premises in Luxembourg, the auditors also carried out audit visits to Member State authorities, other beneficiaries of EU funds within and outside the European Union (including organisations involved in the award of EU funds, such as the European Investment Bank's regional offices in Kenya and Uganda) and other EU institutions, agencies and bodies.
Through these visits, we obtained direct audit evidence from the bodies involved in granting, managing, collecting and disbursing EU funds, as well as from the respective final recipients.
Our audit teams usually consist of two to three auditors, and the duration of an inspection visit may be a few days, but also several weeks.
The frequency and intensity of the audit work in each Member State and recipient country will depend on the type of audit and, where appropriate, sample selection.
The number of visits may therefore vary from country to country and from year to year.
Within the EU, our audit visits are often carried out in conjunction with the Supreme Audit Institutions of the Member States visited.
In 2015, the Court's auditors spent 4 310 days with on-the-spot audits – in Member States and outside the EU – and obtained audit evidence for annual reports and selected audit tasks (special reports).
They also spent a lot of time with the EU institutions in Brussels and Luxembourg, as well as with decentralised agencies and bodies throughout the EU.
The on-site checks took less days than in 2014.
This is due to more efficient working methods and an increasing use of technologies such as secure exchange of data and documents as well as videoconferencing.
Detecting fraud Although our audits are not specifically designed to detect fraud, we occasionally encounter cases where we suspect irregularities or fraudulent activities in our audit work.
In combating fraud against the EU budget, the Court cooperates with the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF).
We shall forward any suspicion of fraud, corruption or any other illegal activity to OLAF at the expense of the EU's financial interests that comes into play during our audit work.
OLAF will then follow up these cases, which will decide on possible investigations and, where appropriate, cooperate with Member States' authorities.
In 2015, we forwarded 27 cases of suspected fraud to OLAF (2014: 16 cases).

Our activities 10 annual reports on the financial year 2014 In 2015, we dedicated most of our audits to accounting and compliance audits to the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2014.
The 2014 Annual Report resulting from this work was published on 10 November 2015 and presented to our audience, including the European Parliament and its Committee on Budgetary Control, the Council of the European Union (Economy and Finance Council), national parliaments and governments, as well as the media.
The main objective of our annual report is to support the European Parliament, the Council and citizens in their assessment of the quality of EU financial management by presenting findings and conclusions.
In the 2014 Annual Report, we provide a reliability assurance on the use of EU funds during the financial year under review and highlight the areas where the risk that EU funds were not properly used was greatest.
In addition, we analyse why errors have occurred and make useful and cost-effective recommendations on possible improvements.
We have revised the structure of our annual report on the financial year 2014 in order to make the report more readable.
The headings of the chapters now correspond to those of the headings of the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.
The key element of the report remains the Statement of Assurance, in which we deliver our audit opinion on the reliability of the EU's annual accounts and on compliance with revenue and expenditure rules.
In addition, we have specifically assessed all of the EU's key areas of activity and provided extensive information on budgetary and financial management.
The report shall also provide information on the performance of the EU budget and the Commission's performance reporting, in particular as regards progress towards the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy.
President Vítor Caldeira presents the European Parliament with the Annual Report 2014 of the European Court of Auditors. EU expenditure in 2014 amounted to 142.5 billion euros = nearly 300 euros per citizen
Our activities 11 The key statements of the 2014 Annual Report The European Court of Auditors calls for a new approach to EU investment and expenditure. ▁warst The reliability of the EU's accounts has been confirmed for 2014. ✴ Revenues were lawful and regular in 2014.
Conclusions and recommendations ▁Und The 2014 EU annual accounts were properly drawn up in accordance with international principles and give a true picture of the situation.
Therefore, we were once again able to give an unqualified assessment of their reliability.
However, we issued a failed audit opinion on the regularity of the payments. ḳ The estimated error rate, which measures the extent of the irregularities, is 4.4% for the 2014 payments, close to the 2013 error rate (4.5%) and constantly above the materiality threshold of 2%. 我 The estimated error rates we have calculated were equal (4.6%) for expenditure subject to shared management with the Member States and for expenditure directly managed by the Commission.
The highest error rates were found in the expenditure under the heading 'Economic, social and territorial cohesion' (5.7 %) and 'Competitiveness for growth and employment' (5.6 %).
For administrative expenditure, the lowest estimated error rate (0.5 %) has been established.  and there is a clear link between types of expenditure and error rates.
The estimated error rate for reimbursement schemes (5.5%), where the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities on the basis of the cost statements drawn up by beneficiaries, is twice the estimated error rate for payment entitlement-based schemes (2.7%) where the payment is not reimbursed but depends on compliance with certain conditions.
Without these measures, the estimated total error rate would have been 5,5 %.
The Commission needs further improvement in terms of risk assessment and the impact of corrective measures. 📌 If the Commission, Member State authorities and independent auditors had used all the information available to them, they would have been able to prevent, detect and correct a significant part of the errors prior to their emergence.
The Commission should take action to address this persistent problem.
Partnership agreements and programmes do not sufficiently take into account the objectives of Europe 2020 by Member States.
These two aspects allow the Commission to monitor and report only partially on the performance and contribution of the EU budget to Europe 2020. 귀 The forthcoming mid-term review of the 2014-2020 Multiannual Financial Framework is crucial for the management of EU expenditure.
It is important that the Commission analysed the areas with persistently high error rates as soon as possible, assessed the possibilities to reduce these error rates, paying greater attention to the performance of expenditure.

Our activities 13 Annual Report on the European Development Funds (EDF) for 2014 ோ Revenue was not affected by errors. 的 Payments were substantially affected by errors. Under the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and the overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
The EDFs are financed by the Member States and managed outside the EU budget by the European Commission and – in some cases – by the European Investment Bank.
Their revenue was not significantly affected by errors, while payments had an estimated error rate of 3.8%.
As in previous years, we identified weaknesses in ex ante controls.
The estimated error rate is almost two thirds due to errors related to non-compliance with procurement rules and lack of supporting evidence to justify expenditure.
Our annual report on the EDFs will be published together with our annual report on the implementation of the EU budget and is available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
Our activities 14 Special annual reports for the financial year 2014 In total, funding of around 4 billion euros was allocated to all EU agencies, bodies and Joint Undertakings in 2014.
EU agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings perform certain tasks on behalf of the EU and are based in different EU Member States.
They operate in a wide range of areas, such as safety, health, research, finance, migration and transport, and each has its own mandate, a board of directors, a director, staff and a budget.
In 2015, we produced 52 special annual reports on the financial year 2014.
They covered 41 decentralised agencies, executive agencies and other EU bodies, eight European research Joint Undertakings, the European Schools, the Galileo Joint Undertaking in liquidation and the Sisnet communication infrastructure.
We also published two summaries that give an overview of the results of our audits in this area (one on EU agencies and other bodies and the other on the Joint Undertakings).
These reports were submitted to the President of the European Parliament and the Parliament's Committee on Budgetary Control, the General Affairs Council and the Council's Committee on Budgets.
In 2014, the individual accounts of the 33 decentralised agencies and other bodies of the EU were independently audited for the first time by a private audit firm.
In preparing our audit opinions on these financial statements, we took account of this audit work and of the measures taken by the audited bodies on the basis of the auditor's findings.
The financial statements of the other agencies and Joint Undertakings have been fully audited by us.
We found the accounting of all agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings in 2014 to be reliable.
The operations were lawful and proper, except for Artemis (embedded ICT systems), ENIAC (nanoelectronics) and ECSEL (electronic components and systems).
In general, the agencies have further improved their procedures by taking corrective action on the basis of our comments from previous years.
Our special annual reports and the two summaries of the results of our audits of the agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings for 2014 are available on our website (eca.europa.eu).
52 special annual reports on EU agencies, other bodies and Joint Undertakings based throughout Europe Headquartered by Europol, The Hague, Netherlands.
Our Activities 15 Special Reports produced in 2015 In addition to our annual reports and special annual reports, we publish special reports throughout the year that contain the results of the cost-effectiveness and compliance audits that we carry out on specific budget areas or management topics of our choice.
When selecting and designing these examination tasks, we are committed to achieving maximum impact and thus to making the best use of our resources.
Our economic assessments often cover several years and their subject matter is complex, so it may take more than a year for these audits to be completed.
In 2015, the special reports focused in particular on the following topics: the overall EU objective of creating added value and growth, and the EU's response to global challenges such as the sustainability of public finances, the environment and climate change.
The 25 special reports prepared in 2015 will be briefly presented under the respective headings corresponding to the headings of the multiannual financial framework.
