Overall results 12 The Court analyses the contribution of the different types of error and the different areas of expenditure to the estimated total error rate (see Graph 6).
Expenditure that did not meet the necessary conditions to be claimed under EU-funded projects had the largest share of the estimated total error rate (involving ineligible costs in cost statements: 39 % or 1.8 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
Second, there were projects where either the funded object/activity or the beneficiary could not have been funded under the applicable rules (non-eligible projects/activities or beneficiaries: 22 % or 1.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
The largest expenditure area with the highest estimated error rate, the regional policy, transport and energy sector is by far the most important contributor to the estimated overall error rate (44% or 2.1 percentage points of the estimated total error rate).
The agricultural sector: market support and direct payments, where expenditure was almost the same, contributes roughly half as much to the estimated overall error rate.
Corrective measures have a positive impact on the error rate Member States and the Commission apply corrective measures to protect the EU budget in cases of ineffective control systems or irregular expenditure.
If such corrective measures had not been taken in respect of the 2013 payments audited by the Court, the estimated total error rate would have been 6,3 % instead of 4,7 %.
However, the estimated error rate could be significantly further reduced by better application of existing control systems and corrective measures.
The Court noted that the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors in a large part of the error in the areas of shared management before the Commission was asked to refund them.
For example, this would have reduced the estimated error rate in regional policy, transport and energy from 6.9% to 3.9%, in rural development, environment, fisheries and health from 6.7% to 2.0% and in employment and social affairs from 3.1% to 1.9%.
New challenges for the presentation of reliable financial information Reporting on the above-mentioned corrective adjustments does not clearly distinguish between the main types of corrective adjustments and the information is largely provided outside the accounting system.
This makes a more in-depth analysis difficult and reduces the accuracy of the figures in the accounts and related financial reporting.
A further development is the increasing use of financial instruments to support investment in potentially economically viable projects in the form of loans, guarantees, equity and other risk mechanisms.
Due to its complex structure, financial instruments require particular diligence in their valuation and recording in accordance with internationally recognised public sector accounting principles.
Overall results 13 Continuous increase in the amounts to be financed from future budgets Among the main features of the EU's budget and financial management in 2013 are: ο a strong increase in the volume of payments that the Commission was allowed to make by means of amending budgets: 9.6% of the initial budget; ο a sustained increase in commitments that will give rise to payments in the future (by 2.6%) despite the high level of payment; ο an unchanged period (on average more than two years) between the date of the initial commitment and the date on which the Commission accepted the declarations of expenditure; ο only 37% of the funds provided for financial instruments had been paid to final beneficiaries at the end of 2012; ο repayments, interest and dividends of EUR 259 million accumulated since 2008 were not recognised as revenue.
What are obligations and payments?
The EU budget consists of two elements: obligations (payments to be paid in current or coming years) and payments (covering the current year of disbursed support).
Payments can only be made against valid commitments.
The annual ceilings for commitments and payments are laid down in the multiannual financial framework agreed by the Council and Parliament.
The nature of EU spending programmes, in particular the long period between commitment and payment, is putting increasing pressure on future payment budgets.
This is reflected in a significantly higher budget for payments in 2013, and this trend will continue in a similar way in future budgets.
Overall results 14 How can financial management and management improve the Commission's ability to publish ο more meaningful information on the functioning of the correction mechanisms (time, origin and nature) and the accuracy of the relevant figures by recording information within traditional accounting systems; ο record and evaluate all financial instruments and financial instruments in accordance with internationally recognised accounting principles for the public sector, in particular by means of reliable procedures for identifying and recording impairments; ο provide information on cash held until disbursement to final beneficiaries; ο prepare and publish a long-term cash flow forecast which is updated annually; this would make it easier for the stakeholders concerned to identify future payment requirements and set budget priorities. ο improve? Do you want to know more?
Full information on the main audit findings can be found in Chapter 1 "Declaration of reliability and related statements" of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
Overall results 15 EU funds and the provision of results EU funds should be used in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (sparability, efficiency and effectiveness).
Against this background, it is necessary to achieve good performance inputs (financial, personnel, material, organisational or regulatory resources required for programme implementation), outputs (to be achieved under the programme), results (immediate changes caused by the programme among the direct stakeholders or the direct recipients) and effects (long-term societal changes, at least partly due to EU action).
The Court assesses these aspects in its audits.
The focus is not enough on performance In the period 2007-2013, the use of EU funds was focused on absorption (use it or lose it – decay in case of non-use) and compliance with legislation and not on good performance.∠-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
The selection of projects for EU funding, for example, saw the need to use available EU funds as a top priority. Secondly, the required compliance with the rules was achieved, and thirdly, and only to a certain extent, was the achievement of results and impacts.
This lack of emphasis on performance is a crucial weak point in the way in which a large part of the EU budget is built.
According to the Commission, the focus in the 2014-2020 programming period is more on performance, with performance-related reserves being the main incentives.
By way of these reserves, the Commission will hold back 6% of the funds allocated to individual Member States until the performance is considered satisfactory.
In practice, however, input and output indicators will continue to be largely decisive for the release of funds.
The Commission will only use result indicators in a few areas.
The effectiveness of performance-based reserves will depend on the success of the Commission in negotiating appropriate targets and milestones at the beginning of the programming period and in obtaining accurate, reliable and up-to-date data from Member States to determine whether the targets have been achieved.
The reporting framework is not appropriate for the desired performance culture Performance reporting is spread across a number of general reports at the level of the general budget.
These reports do not provide any information on progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 Strategy objectives, nor do they provide a comprehensive overview of the results in the form of EU added value.
However, the fourth evaluation report is a step in the right direction in that it seeks to link the main financial programmes with the available performance information relevant to the Europe 2020 strategy.
At the level of each Directorate-General of the Commission, performance objectives for policy areas within their respective responsibilities will be defined in the management plans, and the annual activity reports will then report on them.
The Court's analysis of the management plans and annual activity reports of the Directorates-General of the Commission shows that the reliability assurance is limited to aspects of regularity and internal control and does not take performance aspects into account.
Moreover, the objectives would be too general to serve for management purposes, and the selected indicators are not always suitable for performance measurement.
Overall results 16 The added value of EU expenditure is not always proven The 19 special reports adopted by the Court in 2013 deal with a wide range of issues in economic audits and assess whether the EU intervention has been carried out in accordance with the principles of sound financial management (sparability, efficiency and effectiveness).
The Court examined the lessons to be learned from its 2013 Special Reports on the development of new programmes and projects for the 2014-2020 programming period and concluded that ο The EU added value could not always be ensured. ο In several cases there were potential take-up effects, i.e. the beneficiaries would have undertaken the activity without EU funding.
Example: European Globalisation Adjustment Fund The European Globalisation Adjustment Fund compensates workers affected by mass redundancies.
The Court noted that one third of the funding was used for measures that would have been paid by Member States in any case (Special Report No 7/2013 "Did the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund provide an EU added value in the reintegration of redundant workers?").
Example: Risk-Sharing Finance Facility The Commission had not sufficiently demonstrated that the EU funds provided under the Risk-Sharing Finance Facility (financial instrument designed to facilitate access to debt financing in the field of research) resulted in higher investments than the beneficiaries would make without public funds (Special Report No 2/2013 "Did the Commission ensure an efficient implementation of the Seventh Research Framework Programme?").
Overall results 17 Most of the Court's recommendations have been implemented The follow-up to the Court's recommendations made as a result of economic audits is a key component of the accountability cycle and can contribute to the effective implementation by the Commission of the recommendations contained in the reports.
The Court analysed the follow-up to the Commission's recommendations from eight special reports adopted in 2007-2010, and noted that the Commission had implemented either fully or to a large extent 79 % of the recommendations.
The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should streamline the framework for its performance reporting in the next revision of the Financial Regulation. ο The Commission should ensure that the evaluation report contains a summary overview of all available information on progress towards achieving the Europe 2020 objectives. ο The Commission should further develop its performance management and reporting system so that it can take responsibility for the sound management of the budget and the contribution of the EU budget to policy achievements. ο Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's assessment of performance can be found in Chapter 10 "EU budget and yielding results" of the annual report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
All special reports are available on the Court's website: http://www.eca.europa.eu/en/ Pages/AuditReportsOpinions.aspx.
The contributions calculated on the basis of the gross national income (GNI) of the Member States and the VAT collected by the Member States accounted for 74 % and 10 % respectively of the revenue in 2013.
Import duties and the sugar production levy charged by the authorities in the Member States on behalf of the EU accounted for 10% of the EU's revenue, while the remaining 6% came from other revenue.
Explanation on the audit of EU revenue EU revenue based on GNI and VAT is calculated on the basis of macroeconomic statistics and estimates provided by Member States.
The Court's audit of the regularity of the underlying transactions refers to the processing of these data by the Commission, but not to the original collection of these data by the authorities in the Member States.
Consequently, the Court's assessment of the Court's conclusion concerns the impact on the total amount of revenue of any errors made by the Commission.
With regard to customs duties, the Court examines the way in which the Commission deals with the documents submitted by the Member States concerning the claims found.
These data are not sufficiently harmonised among Member States.
A reservation is an instrument that may be used to keep open the possibility of correction for a disputed element in GNI data transmitted by a Member State.
There is a general reservation regarding the Greek GNI data for 2008 and 2009 as the data remains based on provisional estimates.
This aspect is part of a problem that affects Greece's national accounts.
Detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure sectors 19 The customs authorities of the Member States shall carry out checks to verify that importers comply with customs and import requirements.
The Court noted that the quality of these checks was very different in the Member States visited.
This may result in importers deciding to notify goods in a Member State other than the Member State in which they are established in order to reduce the likelihood of control and to make it more difficult to collect the duties due.
One example of this approach seems to be the case of an importer who unloaded Chinese textiles in Hamburg, Germany, who transported them to Rotterdam, where they were declared for free circulation and subsequently sent to Poland for final sale.
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should work to ensure that Member States harmonise their methods for calculating data on unobserved economic activity. ο The Commission should draw up a detailed plan of action with clear milestones and monitor its implementation in order to tackle the problems of drawing up Greece's economic accounts. ο The Commission should establish minimum standards for controls by Member States' customs authorities in order to allow for a more targeted focus on high-risk importers. Do you want to know more?
The full information on the Court's audit of EU revenue can be found in Chapter 2 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
20 This area of expenditure comprises the European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF), one of the two main instruments of the EU's common agricultural policy.
The aim of this policy is to increase the productivity of agriculture, ensure a fair standard of living for the agricultural population, stabilise markets, ensure supply and ensure that consumers are supplied at reasonable prices.
Expenditure shall be subject to shared management with the Member States.
Yes Estimated error rate: 3.6% (2012: 3.8%) Control systems examined: Effective Most expenditure in this area is calculated on the basis of agricultural land.
Many quantifiable errors are the result of inaccuracies in the applications submitted by beneficiaries, the most common being excessive area data (see example).
Example: Overdeclarations – application for aid for non-eligible land In Germany, Ireland, Greece, France, Poland and Romania*, some areas declared as permanent pasture for which payments were made were in fact fully or partially covered with uneligible vegetation (density of bushes or trees).
No EU aid should have been paid for these non-eligible areas.
In Greece, this error occurred because such land was classified as eligible grassland and was included in the agricultural parcel identification system accordingly. * Note on Member States' reference in the examples: the sampling approach used by the Court does not examine operations every year in each Member State, beneficiary country and/or region.
Examples of errors are intended to illustrate the most common types of errors.
They do not form the basis for conclusions on the Member States, beneficiary countries and/or regions concerned.
For all EAGF direct aid schemes, recipients of EU aid are legally obliged to "obtain cross-compliance" that relates to environmental protection, human, animal and plant health and animal welfare and to the conservation of land in good agricultural and environmental conditions.
If farmers fail to meet these obligations, their aid will be reduced.
In the course of its audits, the Court found that 25 % of the transactions related to these obligations were non-compliance.
In the case of a significant number of errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before requesting a refund from the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2,5 %.
The Court's analysis of the integrated management and control systems (IPCoS) in four Member States (Germany, Ireland, France and Italy) revealed weaknesses in administrative control procedures and the quality of databases in three Member States (Ireland, France and Italy), shortcomings in the quality of on-the-spot checks in two Member States (Germany and Italy), weaknesses in recovery procedures in two Member States (Ireland and Italy).
In spite of the shortcomings identified during the examination, the IACOS contributes significantly to the prevention of errors in the expenditure covered by this system.
In the Member States that joined the EU in 2004 or later, producer groups in the fruit and vegetable sector can receive EU aid.
For recognition as a producer group, certain conditions relating to the number and relative size of the member producers must be met.
The Court found that nine out of the 40 producer groups examined in Poland did not meet these conditions.
In its 2013 Annual Activity Report, the Commission reported that it had reserved a risk amount of 25% of the total expenditure under the measure in question in Poland.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations: ο The Commission and the Member States should take the necessary measures to ensure that the potential of the IACS is fully exploited, for example, to ensure that the eligibility and size of agricultural parcels are properly assessed and recorded. ο The Commission should monitor the remedial measures related to the shortcomings in EU aid to producer groups in Poland. Do you want to know more?
The Court's full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on market support and direct payments in the field of agriculture can be found in Chapter 3 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
22 This area of expenditure covers the policies of "rural development", "climate and environmental policy", "maritime affairs and fisheries", as well as "health and consumer protection".
Of the payments in this area, 88% are attributable to the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
Expenditure shall be subject to shared management with the Member States.
The EAFRD will co-finance rural development expenditure under relevant programmes in the Member States.
Expenditure covers land-related measures (such as agri-environment payments and compensation to farmers in areas with natural handicaps) and non-area-related measures (such as modernisation of agricultural holdings and basic services for the rural economy and population).
Yes Estimated error rate: 6.7% (2012: 7.9%) Control systems under investigation: Due to limited effectiveness Most errors were due to the fact that the aid conditions were not met, in particular the following conditions: agri-environmental obligations (see example), special requirements for investment projects and procurement rules.
Example: non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments A farmer in Sardinia (Italy) received a compensation for not using polluting plant protection products when growing artichokes.
In its on-the-spot checks, the Court found that the beneficiary had used such plant protection products 12 times during the period under review.
Therefore, the payment of aid was not eligible.
Similar cases of non-compliance with agri-environmental commitments have also been identified in the Piedmont region (Italy) as well as in Hungary, the Netherlands, Poland and Romania.
Detailed analysis of revenue and expenditure 23 In the case of a significant number of irregular transactions, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before requesting a refund from the Commission.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 2.0 %.
The Court's investigation of the control systems for rural development revealed: ο shortcomings in the controls on eligibility conditions, e.g. non-recovery of non-eligible VAT amounts or risk of double financing (in seven of the eight Member States examined – Germany, Spain, Italy, Latvia, Malta, Romania and Slovenia; Poland was the exception); ο inadequate assessment of the plausibility of costs (in all four Member States examined – Italy, Latvia, Poland and Romania); ο shortcomings in the design and implementation of cross-compliance controls (in all four of the Member States examined – Czech Republic, Spain, Italy and Malta); the cross-compliance obligations require beneficiaries to meet special conditions, such as environmental or social standards, in order to qualify for aid; ο deficiencies in the controls on award rules (in all three Member States examined – Italy, Latvia and Poland; see for example).
For example, insufficient controls on procurement rules by the Member State In Latvia, the paying agency was the beneficiary of an EAFRD grant of EUR 2 million to finance its outsourced IT system, which was subject to public procurement rules.
The Court noted that several serious errors had occurred in the procurement of the IT system and the subsequent data files.
For example, instead of an open or restricted procedure, as provided for in the legislation, the paying agency applied a negotiation procedure.
Due to non-compliance with the required procedures, expenditure is not eligible for EU funding.
Our recommendations The Court makes the following recommendations for rural development: ο Member States should improve the implementation of their existing administrative controls by using all relevant information available to paying agencies.
In this way, the bulk of the errors could be identified and corrected. ο Member States should ensure that the Action Plans aimed at addressing the high estimated level of rural development are inclusive of all regions and take into account all measures, in particular investment measures, and that they take account of the Commission and the Court's audit findings.
Full information on the Court's audit of EU rural, environmental, fisheries and health expenditure can be found in Chapter 4 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
A closer look at the revenue and expenditure areas of regional policy, transport and energy EUR 45.5 billion Subject matter of our audit 24 This audit covered regional policy (which accounts for 96% of payments in this area of expenditure), financed mainly from the European Regional Development Fund (ERDF) and the Cohesion Fund (CF).
The aim of regional policy is to strengthen economic and social cohesion in the European Union by reducing the disparities in development between the different regions.
Expenditure on regional policies is subject to shared management by the Commission and Member States, with projects co-financed under approved spending programmes.
The remaining 4 % of this audited expenditure is covered by transport and energy policies.
Transport and energy policy aims to provide European citizens and businesses with safe, sustainable and competitive transport and energy systems and services.
These expenditure shall be managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Estimated most likely error rate: 6.9% (2012: 6.8%) Control systems under investigation: Conditionally effective The Court found serious errors in public procurement, accounting for 39% of the Court's estimated error rate.
The cumulative value of the 122 audited procurement procedures is estimated at EUR 4.2 billion.
For example: Unjustified free-hand contracts for additional construction work at the passenger terminal of an airport in Germany were awarded to the original contractor by hand.
This additional work was necessary because of the process of preparation, planning and implementation of the project and not because of unforeseen circumstances.
In such cases, a non-executive award is inadmissible and the additional work should therefore have been advertised.
Similar cases where an unjustified free-hand award took place have been identified for projects in Belgium, the Czech Republic, elsewhere in Germany, Spain, Italy and Sweden.
Detailed examination of revenue and expenditure sectors 25 The Court's auditors also check whether EU state aid rules are being complied with.
Illegal State aid confers an unjustified advantage on the beneficiaries and therefore affects the internal market.
Errors related to State aid accounted for 17% of the estimated error rate in this area (see example).
For example, state aid for a viable project of a small or medium-sized enterprise (SMEs) in Slovenia has been granted for research and development activities in the automotive industry.
However, the SME was wholly owned by large companies and carried out its research activities exclusively for them.
As more stringent rules on public funding apply to large companies, the company was not entitled to all the funding.
Similar cases were found in Bulgaria and Hungary.
In the case of a significant number of cases of error, the authorities in Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the errors before the Commission was requested to obtain them.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 3,9 %.
The Court's auditors also noted that financial instruments still accounted for lower rates of disbursement to final beneficiaries in 2013.
The funds concerned support companies or urban development projects through equity investments, loans or guarantees.
The funds will be provided once their legal structure has been established and will then use these funds to support projects.
A total of 940 financial instruments have been set up in 25 Member States, totalling approximately EUR 12.6 billion.
Our recommendations The Court recommends that the Commission: ο The Commission should require Member States to carry out a thorough assessment of the ongoing problem of primary controls carried out by authorities in the Member States during the programming period 2007-2013, as required by the Financial Regulation. ο The Commission should analyse the reasons for the frequency of non-compliance with EU state aid rules. ο The Commission should reduce the continuing delays in disbursement of EU funds through financial instruments. Do you want to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on regional policy, transport and energy can be found in Chapter 5 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
More detailed analysis of the income and expenditure areas of employment and social affairs 16.2 billion euros Subject of our audit 26 The audit covered the expenditure area of employment and social affairs, which forms part of the EU's cohesion policy.
The main objectives of spending in this area are to combat unemployment, develop human resources and promote integration into the labour market.
Employment and social policy is mainly implemented through the European Social Fund (ESF): 98 % of the payments made in 2013 in this area of expenditure have been financed by this Fund.
The ESF supports investment in human capital in the form of training and other employment measures.
In a private school in Portugal, the full salary of the school director was charged to the EU project, although he also had other tasks to perform.
In addition, the ceiling for co-financing salaries has not been respected.
The Court also found similar findings for projects in Germany, Spain, Italy, Poland and the United Kingdom.
In the case of a significant number of errors, the authorities in the Member States had sufficient information to detect and correct the error before the Commission had been requested to obtain it.
If this information had been used to correct errors before the Commission's expenditure was reported, the estimated error rate in this area would have been 1.8 %.
Detailed assessment of revenue and expenditure areas 27 On the recommendation of the Court and with the aim of reducing the likelihood of errors and administrative burdens for project promoters, the application of lump sums and flat rates was extended in 2009 instead of the reimbursement of ‘actual costs'.
In its 2013 audit, the Court did not detect any quantifiable error in relation to the application of lump sums and flat rates.
This suggests that projects whose costs are reported using such payment options are less error-prone.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that : ο The Commission should invite Member States to reinforce controls on procurement rules, not project-related costs or projects without EU added value. ο The Commission should ensure that Member States address the problem that EU projects impose staff costs at higher rates than national funded projects. ο The Commission should ensure that the Member States have taken into account all the simplification options provided for in the Regulations for the European Structural and Investment Funds for the period 2014-2020. Would you like to know more?
Full information on the Court's audit of EU expenditure on employment and social affairs can be found in Chapter 6 of the Annual Report on the implementation of the EU budget for the financial year 2013.
28 This expenditure covers expenditure on external relations, development and humanitarian aid, as well as actions for candidate countries and candidate countries.
The development projects are spread across more than 150 countries around the world and implementation bodies vary considerably in size and experience.
Support for EU funding projects is conditional on compliance with conditions laid down in specific financing agreements, as well as compliance with other requirements, such as tendering and procurement procedures.
Expenditure is managed either directly by the Commission's Directorates-General – through the central Commission services in Brussels or EU delegations in the beneficiary countries – or jointly with international organisations.
Yes Estimated error rate: 2.6% (2012: 3.3%) Control systems under investigation: Not applicable Most errors were related to ineligible expenditure at the level of the final beneficiaries, such as expenditure incurred outside the eligibility period, the inclusion of ineligible expenditure in project cost statements (e.g. VAT, unjustified personnel costs or overheads) and not supported by adequate supporting documents.
The Commission validated pre-accession expenditure for a total of EUR 150 million, although it was not confirmed by evidence that the expenditure was incurred and eligible.
The validated amounts were based on Commission own estimates rather than on incurred, paid and accepted costs supported by relevant evidence.
Following the detection by the Court of this systematic error, the Commission corrected the accounting operations in question.
Example: Undisbursed expenditure The Commission signed an agreement of EUR 9.5 million with the United Nations Development Programme to promote social development in Moldova.
In 2013, the Commission accepted contracts worth EUR 1.8 million for reimbursement for which no underlying expenditure had yet been incurred.
More details on revenue and expenditure sectors 29 Commission Directorate-General EuropeAid manages most of the EU's expenditure on external action undertaken from the budget.
The EuropeAid systems examined are assessed as conditionally effective.
In May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main identified shortcomings.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should ensure that the instructions for staff indicate that the final management of expenditure should be based only on expenditure actually incurred and should not be based on own estimates.
The Commission has already agreed to modify its final expenditure procedure accordingly. Would you like to know more?

30 The main component of this expenditure area is research and innovation projects, which accounted for €7.7 billion in payments in 2013.
The other internal policies concern expenditure on a number of policy objectives, including education and culture, security, migration and measures to address the consequences of the financial crisis.
Most of the expenditure is managed directly by the Commission.
Yes Estimated error rate: 4.6% (2012: 3.9%) Control systems under investigation: conditionally effective With most payments in this area of expenditure, the Commission is reimbursing costs claimed by beneficiaries in project cost statements.
Errors arise when beneficiaries report ineligible costs that are not detected by the control systems prior to reimbursement by the Commission.
35% of the estimated error rate is due to incorrectly calculated or ineligible personnel costs.
Among other things, the estimated and not actual personnel costs and working hours not spent on the project are claimed.
Apart from non-compliance with the expenditure rules, the reimbursement of ineligible costs is also hampered by the successful implementation of policy objectives and thus limits the added value provided by EU support (see example).
Example: Ineligible expenditure reduces EU added value The EU provides funding to ensure efficient and effective controls at EU external borders.
The Court examined a project in Spain, which consisted in the purchase of four helicopters, which were to be used 75 % for the surveillance and control of the external borders.
However, the Court found that only 25 % of the hours worked by helicopters were related to this purpose.
As a result, the EU should have paid only 25% of the costs of helicopters and not the 75% actually paid.
Further consideration of revenue and expenditure areas 31 In the framework of the control system for research expenditure, the Commission controls progress reports and cost statements on funded projects before making payments.
The Court noted that the Commission did not always apply procedures in a uniform manner, which could impair the efficiency of the programmes and increase the administrative burden on beneficiaries.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission that: ο The Commission should provide the beneficiaries and the authorities in the Member States with up-to-date, consistent and clear guidance on eligibility rules and control rules for the new research programmes for the period 2014-2020 (Horizon 2020) and other internal policies. ο The Commission should make its control activities more risk-oriented by focusing audits on high-risk beneficiaries (e.g. less experienced bodies with EU support) and reducing the burden on less-risk beneficiaries from controls.
Would you like to know more?

More detailed analysis of the European Development Fund's (EDF) revenue and expenditure areas 2.6 billion euros Subject of our audit 33 Under the EDF, the European Union grants funds for development cooperation with the African, Caribbean and Pacific (ACP) States and the overseas countries and territories (OCTs).
It will also promote sustainable development and the integration of the ACP States and OCTs into the global economy.
The EDFs are financed by the Member States and are subject to their own financial rules and are managed by the European Commission outside the general budget of the EU.
The environment in which external assistance financed by the EDF is implemented is at high risk, in particular because the activities are geographically dispersed and the partner countries do not have sufficient institutional and administrative capacity.

Yes Estimated error rate: 3.4% (2012: 3.0%) Failure to comply with procurement rules was the cause of around half of the estimated error rate (see example).
Another significant source of error is the lack of supporting evidence.
Example: non-compliance with the award rules by the beneficiary The Court reviewed an invitation to tender for IT equipment for a business information centre, financed by a micro and small business support programme.
The test showed that the contract was not awarded to the tenderer with the lowest price offer, although the lowest price was the award criterion.
The error was not detected by the auditor who audited the programme in accordance with the relevant framework agreement with the Commission.
Further consideration of revenue and expenditure 34 The EDFs will also provide budget support for payments directly to the budget of a developing country, provided that specific conditions are met.
The Court noted errors in transactions relating to budget support where the fulfilment of the conditions had been misjudged and where the wrong exchange rate was applied for the conversion of the payment into the local currency.
The Commission's Directorate-General for EuropeAid manages not only most of the expenditure on external assistance from the EU budget, but also almost all expenditure incurred under the European Development Fund (EDF).
EuropeAid's systems studied are assessed as conditionally effective.
However, in May 2013, EuropeAid adopted an action plan to address the main shortcomings identified.
Our recommendations The Court recommends to the Commission: ο The Commission should recover interest on pre-financing. ο The Commission should review the quantification of the benefits of the controls carried out. ο The Commission should report on progress in implementing the action plan to remedy deficiencies in the control system.

Background information 37 The European Court of Auditors and its work The European Court of Auditors (EuRH) is the independent audit body of the European Union based in Luxembourg.
It employs around 900 staff from all EU nationalities, composed of auditors and staff in horizontal services.
Since its establishment in 1977, it has raised awareness of the importance of EU financial management and contributed to its improvement.
The Court's audit reports and opinions form an important part of the EU's accountability chain.
Our results are used to hold the bodies responsible for the EU's financial management accountable, especially in the context of the discharge procedure.
This is mainly the Commission, but it also affects the other EU institutions, bodies and agencies.
Member States also play an important role in shared management.
Our main tasks are: ο audits of accounts and compliance audits, mainly with regard to the Statement of Assurance; ο economic audits on subjects selected in such a way that our work can have the greatest impact; ο opinions on legislation relating to financial management and other important issues.
We strive to use our resources to strike a balance between our various areas of activity in order to achieve sound results and to cover the various areas of the EU budget effectively.
Background information 38 Our results We present the following results: ο Annual reports on the general budget of the EU and the European Development Funds; the annual reports mainly cover audit opinions in the context of the Statement of Assurance and the relevant findings and will be published annually in November; ο Special annual reports on audit opinions on the accounts of each EU agency and other body; 53 reports to be published in 2014; ο Special reports on selected audit topics to be published throughout the year; these are mainly economic assessments; approximately 25 reports to be published in 2014; ο Opinions to be used by the European Parliament and the Council in adopting EU legislation with a significant impact on financial management; six opinions to be published in 2014; ο Landscape analyses on selected areas of EU policy where major challenges and long-term trends will be analysed; ο The annual activity report, information and explanations on our activities in the year concerned.
With our work, we contribute to raising awareness of EU financial management and increasing transparency in this regard by providing a guarantee of reliability in the state of financial management and making recommendations for further improvements.
This is in the interests of the citizens of the European Union.
Information on the Court's audits of the agencies and other decentralised bodies of the European Union can be found in the specific annual reports for the financial year 2013, available on the Court's website.
The European Court of Auditors is the independent external audit body of the EU - custodians of EU finances In its annual reports on the EU budget and the European Development Funds, the Court gives an audit opinion (reliability statement) on the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This briefing provides an overview of the main findings and conclusions.
The full text of the reports is available on the Court's website and will be published in the Official Journal of the European Union.
2 INTRODUCTION 1. The Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (hereinafter "the Agency"), based in Ljubljana, was established by Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council1.
The Agency's main task is to assist national regulatory authorities to fulfil the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and, where necessary, to coordinate the actions of those authorities.
In the framework of the Regulation on the integrity and transparency of the wholesale energy market (REMIT Regulation)2, the Agency will, together with the national regulatory authorities, be given additional responsibilities for monitoring the wholesale European energy market3.
Therefore, the period from 8 March to 31 December 2011 was reviewed with regard to the financial year 2011.

8 Annex Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (Ljubljana) Areas of competence of the Union under the Treaty (Article 114 (ex Article 95 TEC) and Article 194 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union) Responsibilities of the Agency (Regulation (EC) No 713/2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council; Commission Regulation (EU) No 838/2010; Regulation (EU) No 1227/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council) Responsibilities and activities The European Parliament and the Council shall adopt, in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure and after consulting the Economic and Social Committee, measures to approximate the laws, regulations and administrative provisions of the Member States relating to the establishment and functioning of the internal market.
The Union's energy policy, in a spirit of solidarity between the Member States, in the context of the achievement or functioning of the internal market and taking into account the need to preserve and improve the environment, pursues the following objectives: (a) ensuring the functioning of the energy market; (b) ensuring security of energy supply in the Union; (c) promoting energy efficiency and savings, as well as developing new and renewable energy sources; and (d) promoting the interconnection of energy networks.
The European Parliament and the Council, acting in accordance with the ordinary legislative procedure, shall adopt the measures necessary to achieve the objectives.
These measures shall be adopted after consulting the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions.
Objectives The Agency's purpose is to support national regulatory authorities in carrying out the regulatory tasks performed in the Member States at Union level and, where necessary, to coordinate their actions.
Tasks - supplementing and coordinating the work of national regulatory authorities - participating in the drafting of rules on European networks - under certain circumstances making binding individual decisions on the modalities of access and operational security of cross-border infrastructures, - advising European institutions on energy-related issues, - monitoring and reporting on developments in energy markets, - drawing up a proposal addressed to the European Commission on the annual compensation amount for cross-border infrastructures under the ITC mechanism, - cooperation with national regulatory authorities, ESMA, the competent financial authorities of the Member States and, where appropriate, national competition authorities to monitor wholesale energy markets, - assessing the functioning and transparency of various categories of market places and of different types of trade, - issuing recommendations to the Commission in relation to market rules, records of transactions, trade orders, standards and procedures which could improve the integrity of the market and the functioning of the internal market.

In the first year of its operations, ACER had to recruit a large part of its staff, which involved problems and resulted in vacancies being filled late; this was clearly reflected in the use rate of the Agency's budget.

COMMENTS ON THE BUDGET 11.The Agency has carried over EUR 1.9 million or 56% of the total committed appropriations under Title II (Buildings of the Agency and ancillary costs) which are mainly related to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation.
This would have been an operational, multiannual activity which would have been suspended under Title III of the budget.
12.In addition, the Agency has transferred EUR 3.1 million or 91% of the total committed under Title III, also in connection with the implementation of the REMIT Regulation.
The exceptionally high transfer rate for Title III is primarily due to an increase in appropriations of an additional EUR 3 million by means of an amending budget approved on 31 October 2013.
OTHER COMMENTS 13.At the end of the year, the Agency had EUR 5.5 million in cash, including around 3 million from the late adopted ADB001936DE04-14PP-CH068-14APCFIN-RAS-2013_ACER-TR.DOC 8.7.2014 7 Amending budget (see paragraph 12).
Nevertheless, average cash balances during the year were significantly higher than are justified by operational needs.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 17. In its May 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) stressed the urgent need to clarify roles and responsibilities and to analyse the workload of the contracting authority in order to increase the efficiency of processes and procedures.
The IAS also concluded that planning and monitoring of procurement must be significantly improved.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 18. The Agency transferred EUR 4.9 million and 86 % of the appropriations committed under Title III (operational expenditure) to the following financial year (2015: EUR 1.4 million and 59 %).
As in previous years, these transfers were mainly linked to the implementation of the REMIT Regulation on the Integrity and Transparency of the Energy Wholesale Trade Market(7) and amounted to 4.7 million euros in 2016 (2015: 1.1 million euros).
For Title II (Administrative expenditure), the Agency transferred EUR 1 million or 38% of the committed appropriations to the following financial year (2015: EUR 0.8 million and 35% respectively).
19. The increase in appropriations is worrying and is contrary to the budget principle of annuality.
The higher transfer rate is directly linked to the conclusion and signing of procurement procedures and parts of contracts towards the end of the year, leading to a shift of deliveries and/or payments to the following year.
In 2016, 98 out of a total of 299 contracts were signed in November and December (5 976 122.47 euros and 40 % of the total value of the contracts closed in 2016 respectively).
The Agency may draw up a separate budget in order to better accommodate the multi-annual nature of the activities, as well as the inevitable distortions between contracts, deliveries and payments.

1), as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1946/93 (OJ No L 356, 31.12.1993, p. 1).
The Court examined the financial statements of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training for the financial year ending 31 December 1995.
Under Article 18(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76,
15), the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Management Board.
In accordance with Articles 65, 61 and 68 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93, the latter shall also be responsible for drawing up and presenting the financial statements in accordance with the financial rules.
The Court of Auditors is required to examine these financial statements in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
The European Council of 29 October 1993 decided to transfer Cedefop's headquarters from Berlin to Thessaloniki.
In order to facilitate this move, certain changes were made to staff's conditions of employment, some of which were not in accordance with the rules in force.
The exact circumstances are explained in paragraphs 46 - 66.
In addition, a number of other cases have been identified where payments were not fully in line with the existing regulations.
The Court's audit shows with sufficient certainty that the financial statements for points on page 10 11 12 are reliable for the financial year ending 31 December 1995 in so far as they accurately reflect the revenue and expenditure for 1995 and the financial situation at the end of the year.
Apart from the important exception in the area of expenditure mentioned in the previous paragraph, the underlying transactions were, as a whole, lawful and proper.
General comments Background 6. The European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training (Cedefop) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 as a satellite body of the European Community and is intended to promote vocational training at Community level.
Cedefop began its work in Berlin in 1976 and moved to Thessaloniki in 1995.
(c) the monitoring of the implementation of the common vocational training policy and in particular the exchange of information and experience.
In the field of vocational training, the Centre's task is 'to prepare documentation, contribute to the development and coordination of research, to ensure the dissemination of relevant documentation and information, to promote and support the initiatives that can achieve a coordinated solution (in particular in the alignment of training levels and mutual recognition of certificates) and to set up a meeting place for the parties concerned'. 8. The Centre is managed by a board of 48 members (in 1995 costs of ECU 334 000 were incurred in this context).
The Board of Directors shall elect, from among its members, one Chairman and three Vice-Chairmen for a period of one year.
At the time of the audit (May 1996), the Administrative Council was chaired by the Director General of DG XXII — Education, Training and Youth.
The Director of the Centre shall be appointed by the Commission on the basis of a list of candidates submitted by the Management Board.
9. In accordance with the basic Regulation, the Director is responsible for the day-to-day management of the Centre, while the Management Board bears overall responsibility.
The Management Board shall take decisions, adopt the work programme and the annual report, draw up the revenue and expenditure plan for the previous year and the estimate of revenue and expenditure for the coming year.
The Commission's role, under the basic regulation, is not only to represent the Commission's interests within the Management Board, but also to adopt the work programme, to review the annual report and the revenue and expenditure schedule and to forward the estimates of revenue and expenditure to the Council and the European Parliament.
(a) a reasonable cost-benefit-benefit-for-Cedefop's budgetary expenditure; (b) the efficient use of human resources and other resources; (c) high-quality products meeting Cedefop's customers' needs; (d) a clear and coherent role in the European Community's vocational training policy.
Financial data 14. For the 1995 financial year, the Centre had a budget of ECU 16.50 million.
The commitments entered into resulted in payments of ECU 10.11 million and transfers to the 1996 financial year of ECU 4.67 million, with the remaining amount of ECU 1.72 million being cancelled.
Out of the previous year's appropriations carried over, ECU 2.16 million was disbursed and ECU 0.29 million annulled.
Annex 1 to this report gives an analysis of the use made of the appropriations for the financial year and of the appropriations carried over from the 1994 financial year.
Annex 2 provides an overview of the budget accounts for the financial year 1995 and the balance sheet of assets and liabilities as at 31 December 1995.
Comments on the implementation of the budget Separation of activities 15. After moving to Thessaloniki, the Centre had not yet put in place adequate procedures for separating the activities of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the imprest administrator until the date of the audit (May 1996).
For example, it was observed that the accounting officer took over duties of the imprest administrator.
The proportion of payments made without the approval of the financial control is still high (in 1995 it was 60% excluding salaries).
The strong use of the paying agency procedure is not in line with the spirit of the financial rules.
A more acceptable practice would be to handle only current expenditures and expenditures at a low level, where the risk of irregularities is comparatively low, through the paying agency.
Transfers within the budget 17. The transfers of appropriations between different budget lines amounted to ECU 922,000 in 1995, i.e. 5.6% of the initial budget compared with 10.9% in 1994.
No. C 81/4 EN 井 Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Transfers of appropriations (ECU 570 000) were made in the last two months of 1995, while in 1994 this share amounted to 33%.
18. The Centre did not carry out transfers of funds between different titles in 1995.
Thus, the Court's remark made last year (2) was taken into account.
Transfers and cancellations of appropriations 19. The practice of transferring large amounts of appropriations already observed in previous years (3) continued to increase in 1995.
Only 61% of the final resources available were paid in 1995 compared with 73% in 1994.
The proportion of commitments transferred to 1996 was 28% (compared to 23% in 1994).
The proportion of appropriations lost was 10%, compared with 5% in 1994.
Table 1 shows by title the appropriations carried over from the original 1995 budget and their subsequent use.
Transfers in the field of operational expenditure amounted to 53% of the initial appropriations compared with 40% in 1994.
Since 8% of operational expenditure was spent, this means that in 1995 the Centre paid only 39% of its operating budget for 1995.
At the end of the first quarter of 1996, only 34% of the appropriations carried over from 1995 were paid out under Title 3.
In the light of the fact that the Commission has not yet adopted a proposal for a Council Decision on the accession of Spain and Portugal to the European Economic Community, the Council has decided to initiate the procedure laid down in Article 100a of the Treaty on European Union.
This fact and the lack of staff (see paragraphs 42 - 45) will have serious implications for the implementation of the 1996 budget.

As in previous years (4), this rate of payment is not in line with the Court's annual report for 1994.
(3) Annual reports of the Court on the 1992 financial year, 1993 with Article 26 of the Financial Regulation for the Centre, according to which payments are to be made in the first half of each quarter and adapted to actual needs.
Expenditure 23. Following the decision to relocate the Centre to Thessaloniki, a new Deputy Director was appointed in 1994, who at that time lived and worked in Thessaloniki.
Staff moved to Berlin and received an institution allowance equal to twice the basic salary. Not even one year later, i.e. after the move of the centre to Thessaloniki, the same staff member received a further amount of institution allowance equal to twice the basic salary.
As the transfer of the Centre took place rapidly, the stay of the operator concerned in Berlin was only of short duration (11 months); moreover, he spent part of that time in Thessaloniki, and he also received the full daily allowances (including weekends). The Court considered that these decisions were not in line with the principle of sound financial management and were contrary to the principles of Cedefop.
24. The contract of another deputy director, who had already moved from Berlin to Madrid in July 1995, was signed by the Board of Directors with effect from 3 January 1995.
This staff member then received a payment of ECU 71 030.
The Court considers that this decision by the Board of Directors is not in line with the principles of economic governance.
25. Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993, provides that the award of a contract may be carried out by private individuals if the total amount of the contract does not exceed ECU 12 000.
At least 12 cases have been awarded in respect of a higher amount than ECU 12 000 without complying with the procurement procedure described in Article 45 of the abovementioned Regulation.
26. Almost 40% of the commitments under the 'pilot studies and projects' budget line for the 1995 budget (ECU 300 000) have been made in the last two months of 1995.
A commitment of ECU 150 572 was made to the budget line 'exchange of officials and experts' to pay an expert who started his work at Cedefop on 1 February 1.996 and another expert whose contract was signed on 22 December 1995.
These commitments were overburdened in order not to let the funds lapse.
27. The rent for the temporary premises of Cedefop for January 1996 (22 750 ECU) has already been included in the 1995 budget.
As these expenditures relate to the 1996 financial year, they should also have been charged to 1996 and 1994.
The Court urges the Centre to draw up an up-to-date inventory as soon as possible, as required by Article 52 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1416/76 of 1 June 1976, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1948/93 of 30 June 1993.
The balance sheet shall show an outstanding amount of ECU 3 134 for an invoice issued in 1991 among outstanding claims from the previous financial year.
The Court's comment made last year (5) was not taken into account, although the Centre had given an assurance in its reply.
The Court recommends that the Centre write off this amount as long as there is no reason to believe that this amount will be recovered.
At the end of the year, the Centre had a balance of ECU 5.9 million.
The Centre is therefore responsible for managing large amounts of cash even though it has little expertise in this area.
The Court reiterates its comment made last year (6) that this situation should be avoided by making the Centre more adaptable to the Commission's actual cash needs in a quarterly manner. - At the same time, the Commission should ensure that the Centre receives a realistic liquidity forecast before making its payments.

Staff: General comments 42. The 1995 establishment plan provides for 79 posts, including 24A,11LA,15B,26Cund3D.At the time of the audit (May 1996), 37 persons actually worked for Cedefop (14A,7B,14C and2D), 11 had been taken over by other EU institutions, 14 had left the Centre before moving to Thessaloniki and 17 had decided to stay in Berlin.
In 1995 and 1996, many new employees had to be recruited, and this development will continue in 1996.
43. The 17 remaining persons in Berlin are free to work for public and private institutions or other EU institutions, while they continue to receive their salary for a period up to a maximum of 18 months, depending on their seniority at Cedefop (each service is equivalent to one month's salary and the minimum service period must be 6 months).
At the end of this period, the parties concerned may either move to Thessaloniki or seek another solution.
This situation has led, among other things, to the fact that Cedefop cannot fill these 17 posts (May 1996), since they are blocked in the budget and cannot be filled, since those affected may decide to move to Thessaloniki at a later stage.
44. It is unclear what should happen to those of this group of 17 people who do not wish to move to Thessaloniki after the fixed duration of their stay in Berlin.
Article 20 of the Staff Regulations provides that 'the official shall take the place of his official's service or, at such distance from that place, his place of residence where he is not hindered in the performance of his duties'.
Irrespective of this, three cases of officials who were not ready to move to Thessaloniki have already been brought to the EU Court of Justice.
45. This situation, in which 17 important items foreseen in the budget are blocked by staff who are not currently working for Cedefop, had a considerable impact on the Centre's work already in 1995 and will continue to do so in 1996 and 1997.
Staff: Amendment of the status of 46.I n Article 13 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 of 10 February 1975, as amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995, states: "The staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Centre shall exercise over its staff the powers delegated to the Appointing Authority.
The Management Board of the Centre shall, after consulting the Commission, lay down the corresponding implementing rules."
Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 also repeals Council Regulation (ECSC, EEC, Euratom) No 1859/76 of 29 June 1976 laying down the conditions of employment for the staff of the European Centre for the Development of Vocational Training.
The amendment was needed in order to 'consistently manage the staff of the various decentralised bodies (...) at Community level' (8).
While the Centre's staff have been appointed officials, the staff of the other decentralised bodies are temporary staff.
47. The Court has examined the changes in employment conditions and other agreements between the Board of Directors and staff and has identified a number of irregularities, the most serious irregularities from the Court's point of view being described in paragraphs 49-66.
48. The Management Board has not submitted these agreements to the Financial Controller in order to issue its endorsement.
Nevertheless, all appropriations resulting from these arrangements were carried out through the paying agency procedure and subsequently received the financial controller's endorsement.
The Centre has taken the following measures to adapt the situation of its staff: — a first step, on 1 March 1995, was the appointment of all members of staff as temporary staff (Article 2(b) of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants of the European Communities), in the same grade and grade as those of contract staff. — a second step, these staff were recruited as EU officials as from 1 April 1995 on the basis of an internal selection procedure, which was ultimately ‘ar designated' on the basis of qualifications.
Infringement of the Staff Regulations in relation to the classification of seniority in the initial appointment of Cedefop's former contract staff at a time of 50 years. When the contract staff of Cedefop were first appointed as temporary staff on 1 March 1995, none of the staff could have been classified as seniority in seniority than level 3 (or step 4 in grades A 1 (8) Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 amending Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 on the establishment of Cedefop, fourth recital).
(See Article 32 of the Staff Regulations applicable to temporary staff in accordance with Article 15 of the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants).
51. However, 33 of the 59 temporary staff appointed to Cedefop were placed at a higher level than level 3.
The role of the Centre in implementing the internal selection process for the appointment of former Cedefop contract staff to civil servants 52. On 1 March 1995 the Centre published 15 linked job offers and announcements of internal competitions.
These are the tasks of the Staff Regulations (Articles 27(1) of the Staff Regulations) and the tasks of the Staff Regulations (Article 27(1) of the Staff Regulations) and the tasks of the Staff Regulations (Article 27(2) of the Staff Regulations).
A selection procedure is therefore by definition linked to a competitive situation and the risk of non-existence (10).
As a result, appointment decisions are to be considered illegal following a selection procedure in which there is an abuse of discretion (n ).
The Commission's Legal Service came to the same conclusion as was confirmed in its memo of 4 January 1995 (12).
57. Since the selection procedures concerned have pursued an objective other than that set out in the Staff Regulations, it must be assumed that the selection process carried out by Cedefop has had a misuse of discretion and must therefore be regarded as unlawful.
Under Article 31 of the Staff Regulations, Cedefop staff should have been appointed as officials as from 1 April 1995 as follows: — officials of category A or of special career language service (LA): in the initial grade of their category or special career (i.e. A 7 or LA 7) (Article 31, paragraph 1); — officials of other categories: in the entrance grade corresponding to the post for which they were recruited (i.e. Β 1, Β 3 or Β 5; C 1, C 3 or C 5, D 1, D 3 or D 4) (Article 31, paragraph 2); — in the case of up to half of the appointments, except in the case of exceptional staff members in the next higher grade group; this applies to six posts to be filled within each grade group (Article 31, paragraph 2b).
59. Contrary to the provisions of the Staff Regulations, 32 out of 43 staff were appointed in a higher grade than the starting grade of their career (13).

(12)A selection procedure involves, by definition, the risk of non-existence and there are obvious legal reasons why this risk margin should remain.

65. This means that a system has been established whereby up to 50 % of the remuneration of staff is transferred to Thessaloniki in a currency to which a higher correction coefficient applies (namely the correction coefficient of 111.4 %) is applied to Germany (for Greece an adjustment coefficient of 80.2% is applied ).
Disparity in treatment with other officials through the introduction of special mobility provisions 66. The Commission committed itself to introducing specific rules on mobility in relation to the Centre.
These provisions are contrary to the principle of equal treatment of all officials.
Article 13 of Council Regulation (EC) No 251/95 of 6 February 1995 clearly provides that the Staff Regulations and the Conditions of Employment of Other Servants shall apply to the staff of the Centre.
This means that all the provisions contained therein shall apply to the staff of the Centre, including the subparagraph (c) of Article 29(1) which concerns the taking over of officials by other institutions.
The Court's audit showed that the Centre's work programme was not carried out as planned due to considerable staff shortages.
This led to large transfers and cancellations.
The audit has also shown that no operational management and accounting procedures have yet been established.
68.Two Deputy Directors received remuneration equal to the basic salary for four months, payments of ECU 71 030 to one of the Deputy Directors were not in line with sound financial management and the Centre's interests.
69. At the time of the Court's audit, there were 79 approved posts, but only 37 persons actually worked at the Centre.
17 staff had been appointed as EU officials, although they had not wished to move to Thessaloniki, nor had they been taken over by any other Community institution.
Conclusion 71. It is understandable that efforts have been made in the context of the move to Thessaloniki to keep staff at the EU institutions and to reduce the complex problems associated with the move.
The problem, however, is that the regulatory framework "within which the move had to be carried out was not compatible with the proper treatment of senior staff even after the changes to the employment arrangements, and did not allow for the smooth transfer of Cedefop without subscribing to its activities.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 21 November 1996.
