The Management Board will follow the structure of the observations and conclusions of the Court of Auditors.
The Management Board has the right to expect that all institutions and decentralised bodies will be treated in the same way and on the basis of the same technical standards and procedures that ensure equal treatment.
The Management Board considers that the uniform presentation of the problems fails to mention the essential facts which could be summarised as follows: — The decision of the European Council of 29 October 1993 was taken without prior assessment of the effects of such a transfer.
At his first meeting with the staff, he expressed his firm determination to move to 1 September 1995, a timetable which CEDEFOP kept despite the problems caused by the transfer of the Centre. — The Chairman of the Board of Directors sent a letter to the Commissioners responsible, Mr van Miert and Mr Ruberti.
On 18 November 1994, the Chairman and Vice-Chairmen of the Management Board of CEDEFOP were received by the members of the Commission.
The Chairman urged the Commission to draw up social accompanying measures, in particular for those staff who were unable to leave Berlin.
In the light of the regulations in force, the Commissioners stated that they were prepared to examine the specific problems of some staff members in a positive and pragmatic spirit.
This is what they expected from the other Community institutions (European Parliament, Council, etc.) — The 'Administrative Council was unable to decide at its meeting on 8 and 9 December 1994 on the date of the transfer, since it did not appear acceptable that staff members who could not move to Thessaloniki were simply dismissed without a modern social plan.
At the same meeting the Management Board instructed the Director to prepare a Administrative Council Decision (adopted at an extraordinary meeting on 27 January 1995), which provided for a socially acceptable transfer of the Centre to 1 September. "— In the second half of December 1994, the Council began to examine the Commission's proposal to amend Article 13 of the Regulation applicable to CEDEFOP, which provided for the staff of the Centre to be subject to regulations and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities.
The Director adopted this amendment on the basis of the drafting of the framework agreement on social accompanying measures relating to the transfer of CEDEFOP to Thessaloniki.
On 23 January 1995 the framework agreement was signed with the staff.
The preparations were carried out in close cooperation with the European Commission, which proved to be very helpful throughout the transition period (1994-96). — The Management Board decided to accept the framework agreement and move the Centre to Thessaloniki on 1 September 1995.
Official Journal of the European Communities No C 81/13
Under the framework agreement, staff members who were unable to leave Berlin decided to make themselves available to other EU institutions or public/privat organisations and to receive a salary from the Centre for at least six months, with a monthly salary paid for each year of service begun.
The principle of the payment of a monthly salary for each year of service largely corresponds to the social plans and customary procedures in Germany and neighbouring countries. — Early retirement was considered in 1995 for 17 employees (aged over 55 years with 10 years of service and over 50 years with 15 years of service).
These measures were not part of the framework agreement and were, after all, not proposed by the Commission in the light of the decisions of the Council of Ministers of 17 November 1995 to accept the'release' of officials in connection with the accession of new Member States only for officials of the European Parliament.
In its opinions on points 46-66, the Management Board will respond in more detail.
More generally, it should be stressed that the political aspects should be taken seriously and that subsequent criticism should be avoided.
In the Community's history, the relocation of a complete Community body within the restrictive framework of a large number of different regulations and given a considerable amount of social and individual problems is truly unique.
5. The Board of Directors will return below in this reply to the exception mentioned in the last sentence.
The costs of meetings of the Management Board in 1995 are due to the fact that two additional meetings (in January and June) had to be held in connection with the transfer.
In addition, the December 1995 meeting caused higher costs due to the official start of operations in Greece.
Only two meetings are planned for 1996.
The Management Board regrets that the Court did not respond to the European Parliament's decision to postpone discharge for the 1994 budget.
This raises serious questions as — the discharge for 1994 in connection with the Court of Auditors' report for 1994 and the Council's recommendation on granting discharge should be seen and be in line with the normal rules and procedures; — the European Parliament's assessment of the 1995 financial year without the Court of Auditors' report for 1995, on which the Board of Directors could have given its opinion, leads to a mix of very different situations; — the Centre was transferred to Greece in 1995.
The relocation was carried out smoothly and under acceptable conditions.
This transfer requires a transitional period, which can only be completed in 1997, due to the interruptions to which staff members have been exposed.
A remarkable improvement can be observed in this respect.
At the initial stage in Thessaloniki, staff helped each other to carry out the work.
16. As has been pointed out last year, the increased use of the paying agency procedure came at the request of the financial controller, who justified this by the cost-benefit ratio; the previous system caused high rapid delivery costs and led to delays.
Similarly, the financial controller had to act more frequently.
The use of the imprest account procedure for all expenditure that could require preliminary commitments limited administrative costs and avoided delays.
The situation is even more difficult because of the payment arrangements in Greece (most payments are made in cash or by cheque).
Invoices indicating bank details are rare; contractors collect their own claims.
The geographical distance to the financial controller and the lack of reliability of the mail delivery must also be taken into account.
In addition, DHL express deliveries may only be made once a week for cost reasons (3 000 francs per shipment).
An amendment to the decision to set up the paying agency procedure will shortly be submitted to the Management Board in order to take better account of the Court of Auditors' wishes.
17. The transfers over the last two months are explained by the need for optimum use of the budget (of which ECU 2 000 000 had been deferred and were only released shortly before the Centre was transferred to Thessaloniki) and by the decision of the Management Board (7/8-12/1995) to hire national experts seconded to the Commission (also to promote the Centre's work).
The Management Board was aware that 1995 and 1996 would be years of transition and renewal.
A certain reduction in productivity is inevitable in this international transfer, which the Board of Directors believes has been carried out in an acceptable and smooth manner.
The Centre is still facing problems caused by the transition phase.
20. As the centre was relocated to a significantly reduced number of employees, the work of the administration and of all other services slowed down.
For this reason, a non-automatic transfer of appropriations was requested and approved.
No C 81/14  Flachau Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 22. The Management Board notes that the Commission is making every effort to comply with the rules laid down in Article 26 of the Financial Regulation of the Centre and to pay out the grant in accordance with the actual needs during the first two weeks of the quarter.
There was an improvement in 1995 compared to 1994.
However, due to the long internal procedures (in which the issuing authority, the financial controller and the accounting officer are involved) and the length of the bank's referral procedure, an overall delay in the handling period (on average 12 days in 1995) cannot be fully avoided.
Nevertheless, in 1995 three payments would have been made almost in accordance with the provisions of Article 26, as they arrived at the Centre less than four days after the end of the first two weeks of the quarter.
If the processing period had corresponded to the average period of 12 days for all payments (between 9 and 22 days), all payments would have been made in accordance with Article 26 of the Financial Regulation.
The first payment was not in line with the rules, but this payment must be preceded by the commitment of funds which requires a certain amount of time.
23. The Deputy Director moved from Thessaloniki to Berlin because there was uncertainty about the actual date of the transfer of the Centre.
At the time of the appointment (1 October 1994) no decision had been taken on the date of the move (which could have been postponed even further).
It was to be hoped that his stay would be short, but his final duration was still unknown at that time.
For the usual family reasons, he moved to Berlin under the conditions of his status.
Daily allowances for missions were granted in accordance with the same procedure as for other servants.
As regards the second set-up aid, the Deputy Director paid back this amount to the Centre after the audit, although he would have had full entitlement.
24. At its meeting in June 1995, the Management Board cancelled its contract on 31 December 1995 and instructed the Director to implement this Decision and to arrange for payments to be made in accordance with the Staff Regulations.
The Management Board was pleased that the Deputy Director was ready to take part in the implementation of the 1995 work programme and to support the Centre at its new start in Thessaloniki.
The compensation (the payment of one third of the basic salary from the date on which his duty expired until the expiry of his contract) was in accordance with his contract and Article 47 BBSB.
25. In view of the difficulties of the initial phase and the large number of new contracts, the Centre was not able to carry out the usual tendering procedures in each case.
In the case of longer-term contracts, tendering procedures are under way or are planned for 1996.
In addition, in order to ensure balanced budgetary management throughout the year, the Management Board will prefer the adoption of the work programme so that the services can have the necessary time for tenders and make commitments so that the relevant contracts can be concluded in the first months of the financial year.
The 40 % of the commitments for the pilot studies and projects budget line (ECU 300 000) were made in the last months of the year, due to the late release by the budgetary authority of the appropriations allocated to the 1995 budget and the transfer of the Centre to Thessaloniki.
The Centre had to act logically and consistently, leaving it with no other choice, since it had to fulfil its financial obligations under Titles I and II and was only able to make further commitments under Title III after the funds had been decommissioned.
The possibility of seconding national experts was granted by the Management Board at its meeting in December 1995 and could only be financed by the resources allocated.
The director had to act quickly and within a short period of time to prevent funds (which became available very late) from falling.
The application of the (Austrian) expert (officially supported by the government) was already in early 1995.
27. The reason for recording the rent for January 1996 in the 1995 financial statements was purely practical.
According to the contract, the rent must be paid in advance in two instalments on 1 January and 1 July.
Since the first payment was only made in October 1995 and it would have been difficult to reimburse immediately on 1 January 1996, the first payment was made for a period of five months, including January 1996.

The Centre shall ensure that it submits to the Commission a realistic statement on the cash flow.

Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/15 36.-37.
Some additional investments and changes were needed as the centre was expected to resume its work immediately after the move.
As has been noted, the agreements do not contain any clear statement as the centre needed more power connections and stronger computer cables than the existing ones.
Other investments concerned additional security requirements and communication facilities, such as Europe by Satellite, in order to be able to receive broadcasts directly through the institutions.
However, the Centre has put questions concerning the provisional building on the agenda of the Steering Committee dealing with the new and (if necessary) the provisional building.
The Board is aware that the content of the agreement on the new building gave the Greek Government a great responsibility, which is currently fulfilling the agreement.
Two points are particularly concerned: — securing the provision of a high quality building at a reasonable price; — securing the timely completion of the building (if possible before 1 September 1998).
The fact that substantial payments were made in advance (half of the building has already been paid, although construction has not yet begun) can also have positive effects, since the actual construction work (after selecting the construction plan and the construction company in October/November 1996) could advance rapidly due to the immediate availability of the necessary financing.
In general, the Board of Directors fully understood the Court's concerns, which were also shared by members of the European Parliament, Mr Kellet-Bowmann and Mr Tappin, who visited the Centre on 1/2 May and 14/15 May respectively.
The Management Board is prepared to take action on this issue in accordance with the Commission's recommendations.
The impact of these programmes on the situation of the workforce has been very complex, but all the persons on the CEDEFOP payroll who were not made available to other organisations or who were seconded in Berlin have worked for CEDEFOP and its work programme.
43. The Management Board has taken a decision on the social accompanying measures relating to the transfer (framework agreement) in order to take 'as soon as possible appropriate measures' (see the declarations in the minutes of the Council).
The evaluation of the measures must therefore take into account their political background.
The Centre is located in Thessaloniki and the Management Board and the Director decide on the organisation of the work.
There are certainly a few items blocked as long as the social accompanying measures are effective.
However, almost all activities will expire at the end of 1996 and CEDEFOP will be able to operate with full capacity on the basis of medium-term priorities (adopted by the Administration in November 1996) and the 1997 work programme, which will also be based on these priorities.
CEDEFOP will therefore move into the future from 1997 onwards with a revitalised and new approach.
44. The persons who, for social or personal reasons, cannot leave Berlin when the fixed duration of their stay in Berlin ends have three alternatives.
In this respect, the President of the Court of First Instance declared three decisions rejecting requests for transitional proceedings.
Such persons must move, withdraw from the service of the Centre or find solutions in accordance with the Staff Regulations.
45. The impact in 1996 is, of course, serious but will be minimal after the first months of 1997.
The transfer had its consequences and costs.
However, if they are compared with a similar transfer at national level, such as that of the Centre d'Etudes et de Recherches sur les Qualifications (CEREQ) from Paris to Marseille (where only 21 of the 120 employees moved to the Centre), then CEDEFOP has not had an excessive negative impact given an international transfer over a distance of almost 2 000 km.
Precautionary cost estimates indicate that cost neutrality will be achieved in 2000, and that work will be even more cost-effective thereafter (mainly due to lower labour costs in Greece). 46.-66.
(b) It is not, however, the Board's failure to act, "that the regulatory framework within which the relocation took place was [...] incompatible with the proper treatment of senior staff and did not allow for the smooth transfer of CEDEFOP". (c) Following the decision of the Board of Directors of 27 January 1995, on 6 February 1995 (Regulation (EC) No 251/95), the Council amended Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 337/75 so that "the staff of the Centre are subject to the rules and regulations applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities".
Despite the lack of transitional provisions, as was the case with the adoption of Council Regulation (EEC, Eura: torn, ECSC) No 269/68 (see Article 102 of the Staff Regulations of Officials of the European Communities, the Court of Justice, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance, the Court of First Instance.
(d) Since the Community legislation did not provide for transitional measures, the Board had no choice but to act on its own responsibility in order to safeguard the rights and interests of CEDEFOP staff.
(f) In view of these circumstances, the Management Board had to: — provide staff with a high level of safety with regard to their place of work (appointment to permanent officials), — ensure that their category, grade and step are respected, and — provide staff wishing to help find another job. (g) The Management Board would also like to point out that posts approved by the budgetary authority were permanent posts.
(h) In addition, the wording of Regulation (EC) No 251/95 (the staff of the Centre shall be subject to the regulations and arrangements applicable to officials and other servants of the European Communities) clearly provides for the employment of officials.
Since the posts filled by the staff are of a permanent nature, the decision on the status of civil servants was reasonable and justified rather than on temporary contracts.
The Board of Directors would also like to comment on the individual points raised by the Court: 46. (last sentence) The Board of Directors had the choice of either appointing its staff as life-long officials or offering them two-year contracts (see opinion (g) above).
It was considered unacceptable to require employees to move from Berlin to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract.
The Council and the Member States shall ensure that the Commission and the Member States of the European Communities and of the European Economic Community are fully informed of the decisions taken by the Commission in the light of this Decision.
At the time of signature of the agreement, the pending individual decisions of the staff were not yet clear as to the exact financial implications of the agreement.
It provided a framework that provided the basis for individual decisions and received the full approval of the financial controller during his visit to Berlin.
50-51.
In view of the argument referred to above (e), the decision taken (see remark, second indent) was the only possible one.
It was also in line with the Commission's clear statement (see last sentence of the declaration for the Council's minutes in the annex) that 'there should be no deterioration in the conditions of employment of CEDEFOP's staff'.
The considerations of the Commission's legal service, which are only partially quoted in paragraph 56, leave sufficient room for such a decision.
The Management Board reiterates that Article 29 of the Staff Regulations entitles the appointing authority to conduct internal competitions for the purpose of filling vacant posts in an institution (point lb).
The selection procedures have been carried out in full compliance with Annex III to the Staff Regulations.
55. The aim and obligation of the Management Board was to ensure that as many CEDEFOP staff as possible agreed to move to Thessaloniki.
It should be borne in mind that Regulation (EC) No 251/95 amended the rules applicable to staff with effect from 1 March 1995 and that the move to Thessaloniki took place in August of that year.
The Management Board's approach was based on the following considerations: — it was unthinkable to require staff to move to Thessaloniki on the basis of a two-year contract (recital (g) and (46) above); — there was not enough time to conduct a general selection procedure before moving to Thessaloniki, and even here it would not have been realistic to expect staff to move without a secure commitment to employment.
13. 3. 97 I EN 負 Official Journal of the European Communities No. C 81/17 56.-59./ The Administrative Board has already explained (see above, comment under e) that the move to Thessaloniki meant a sudden change in the place of employment which inevitably caused social problems and for a certain period of time affected productivity.
To require the staff to move after a low grade or step has been allocated would have aggravated their situation even further.
The Commission's Legal Service, mentioned in paragraph 56, provides sufficient arguments under point (d) to justify the position adopted by the Centre. 60.-61.
All staff who have applied for appointment as lifetime officials have completed the probationary period laid down in Article 34 of the Statute.
62. In accordance with note (f), 3rd indent, above, the Management Board considered it its duty to assist staff in an acceptable manner.
This view was also taken by the Commission's Legal Service.
65. The rules governing the methods of transfer of part of the remuneration allow for the possibility of increasing this percentage from 35 % to 50 % in individual cases where there are legitimate reasons in accordance with Article 4 of the Regulation.
The framework agreement, in individual cases and in the case of certain liabilities provided for in the Staff Regulations which were received before 29 October 1993 (the date on which the European Council decided to transfer the Centre), made it possible to transfer a higher percentage (> 35 %' according to the Staff Regulations but < 50 %).
The application of these rules is quite different in the case of CEDEFOP and concerns only a limited number of people with high liabilities in Berlin.
66. The Management Board wishes to thank the Commission for the support it has provided in a number of cases in the search for alternative employment opportunities for staff who have not been able to move to Thessaloniki and for any other assistance it has provided to the Centre almost daily during the move.
68. See observations of the Management Board on paragraphs 23 and 24. 69.-70.
See in particular the general comments under points 46-66.
71. The Administrative Council regrets that the legislator has not introduced any transitional legal arrangements in Regulation (EC) No 251/95 to address the difficult staffing problems caused by the move to Thessaloniki.
In view of the lack of suitable instruments, the Management Board was all the more obliged to give its full support to CEDEFOP staff.
The Board of Directors believes that, in the present and truly unprecedented circumstances, it has acted in the only acceptable manner.
Finally, it was obvious that he had to make such an effort (as the Court acknowledges) because it is his duty as an employer to carry out the international mission of a complete institution in a socially acceptable manner.
The Board of Directors, the Director and staff acted in this positive spirit, perhaps taking some risks, but not abused power or acted unlawfully.

• The Financial Statement of the European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions for the 1995 financial year 1. This report shall be submitted to the Council and the European Parliament in accordance with Article 16 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1365/75 (OJ L 347, 30.12.1975, p. 1).
The Court examined the financial statements of the European Foundation for the Improvement of Living and Working Conditions for the financial year ending 31 December 1995.
Pursuant to Article 16 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93,
16) the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Management Board.
It shall apply in accordance with Articles 52, 54 and 55 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 (OJ L 298, 24.10.1993, p.
26) amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 (OJ L 46, 25.2.1976, p.
The Court of Auditors is required to examine these financial statements in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
The Court held that the Court had carried out its audit in accordance with the generally accepted audit standards in so far as they were applicable to the Community context. Accordingly, it carried out audits of the accounts and applied other audit procedures which it considered necessary in this context.
It is intended to "contribute to the design and creation of better living and working conditions through action to promote and disseminate knowledge likely to support this development".
The Dublin Foundation began its activities in 1976.
The Court of Auditors examined the annual accounts and the financial management for 1995 of the Dublin Foundation in accordance with the relevant regulations (2).
Financial data 7. For the 1995 financial year, the Foundation had funds of ECU 12.5 million.
The commitments entered into resulted in payments of ECU 9.3 million and transfers to the 1996 financial year of ECU 3 million, with the balance of ECU 0.2 million being cancelled.
Of the appropriations carried over from the previous year, 1.9 million ECU was disbursed and 0.2 million ECU annulled.
Annex 3 to this report contains an analysis, broken down by title, of the use of appropriations for the financial year and of the appropriations carried over from 1994.
Follow-up to previous observations Separation of duties 8. The Court repeats its earlier observations that the duties of the authorising officer and the accounting officer are not sufficiently separate.
This is contrary to Article 15 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76, which stipulates that the principle of ‘separation of authorising powers and accounting' applies and that ‘the activities of the authorising officer, the financial controller and the accounting officer [...] are incompatible'.
Paying agency 9. A large part of the payments (1995: 5 9%, excluding salaries) continue without prior approval by a financial controller.
The extent to which the paying agency is used is not in line with the financial rules.
It would be more acceptable if only (2) Council Regulation (EEC) No 1365/75 of 26 May 1975 establishing the Foundation (OJ No L 345, 15.12.1975, p. 1).

The Foundation should define in writing, in consultation with the financial controller, what is meant by current and smaller expenditure.
Transfers from title to title 10. The Foundation continued to carry out transfers from title to title in 1995 (see paragraph 16).
This is in breach of Article 21 of Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 of the 1 494 000 ECU (11.9% of the budget) while in 1994 it was ECU 756000 (6.5%).
16. By transferring ECU 500 000 from Title 1 (Personnel) to Title 3 (operational expenditure), the Foundation was able to transfer commitments to the following financial year, which would otherwise have been cancelled in accordance with Article 6(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76.
As stated in paragraph 10 above, the Court considers that such transfers from title to title are contrary to the financial rules.
Transfers and cancellations of appropriations 17. As shown in Annex 3, the total payment rate is 75 %, while the payment rate for Title 3 ‘Operational expenditure' is only 54 %.

The transfers under Title 3 amounted to 45 % of the original appropriations.
By the end of March 1996, only 20% of the transfers had been used.
Revenue 18. The EU grant to the Foundation was ECU 12.5 million in 1995.
The amounts actually requested and received amounted to ECU 2.5 million as at 26 April 1995, ECU 2 million as at 14 June 1995, ECU 4.3 million as at 12 October 1995 and ECU 1.3 million as at 31 December 1995.
The difference of ECU 2.4 million corresponded to the unnecessary cash resources, which were not received from the Commission in accordance with the Court's recommendation last year.
As in previous years, this type of financing is not compatible with Article 26 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76, as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93, according to which the grant is paid in the first half of each quarter.
Expenditure 19. Under Article 63 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93 of 30 June 1993 amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 of 1 June 1976, contracts of more than ECU 12 000 must be awarded following a tendering procedure.
The following exceptions were found: — a contract worth ECU 533 072 for carrying out a Europe-wide survey of working conditions was awarded freely. — Six contracts were awarded in a sample of 26 contracts selected for examination on the basis of Article 46 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1417/76 of 1 June 1976, Council as amended by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1949/93.
Article 46 was used to avoid the tender procedure in three cases (supply of computers in one case and study contracts in the other).
It was found in two cases that expenditure had already been invoiced before the commitment was made.
In one case, accounts for November and December 1994 were taken into account in the commitment made in 1995, although the framework agreement between the Foundation and the contractor only began on 1 January 1995.
In a sample of 10 study contracts drawn for the examination, the final reports were received for five contracts only months after the time limit laid down in the contract.
22. During its examination, the Court found that the documents had been modified by means of correction fluid: — the date of an invoice of DM 45 365 (ECU 23 817) faxed to the financial controller was overwritten with correction fluid and changed from 17 January 1995 to 17 December 1994.
The financial controller gave his endorsement on the basis of this fax and the change in the date was such that the 1994 and 1995 carryovers were accounted for. — The amount in a recovery order was overwritten with the amount of the correction and changed by hand from ECU 1 680.16 to ECU 4 741.97.
It is not clear what the financial controller's endorsement refers to.
27. The examination of a sample of payments revealed problems with order management and inappropriate changes to important documents, see paragraphs 19-22.

The Foundation has introduced a series of measures to separate the tasks of the authorising officer and the accounting officer.
The Court of Auditors has taken note of these initiatives in previous reports.
The only problem that remains in practice is the procedure whereby the authorising officer records expenditure in the existing integrated accounting system.
This problem will be solved once the Foundation has acquired a new accounting system.
Following consultations in 1995, the Foundation, together with other EU agencies, took part in a joint tendering procedure for the purchase of an appropriate accounting system.
The result of this was, however, that none of the candidates met the requirements of the institutions 100%.
Following in-depth contacts with the Commission services, it is expected that the Foundation will acquire an appropriate accounting system from the Commission in the course of 1997 after work on an appropriate system that meets the technical and legal requirements of the agencies has recently been completed.

General bill 1.9.
As a result of the settlement through the paying agency, the accounts and budget entries were not made until September and December 1995.
This contravenes accounting practices.

The commercial accounting systems available on the market do not take into account the specificities of Community financial rules.
For this reason, in 1995 the agencies published a call for tenders for a system corresponding to their needs.

No C 81/36 p 5 疫 Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 REPLY OF THE OFFICE'S Commission's financial contribution 1.5.
The need for a recovery order was not recognised by the Commission or the OHIM.
The OHIM has taken note of this observation by the Court of Auditors and has caused a recovery order for the 1996 financial year to be issued immediately for the total amount of the grant minus the provisions.
The accounting system currently in use by the OHIM allows subsequent changes to the accounts.
For the period up to the introduction of the Sincom2 system developed by the Commission, OHIM has made organisational arrangements for additional security guarantees for the use of the current system.
Until then, OHIM has no other option but to wait for the Commission's accounting system, which is likely to be available before the end of the year, because the development of such a system is a major financial burden that an office cannot bear on its own.
In 1995, the Office's budget was adopted, taking into account a provision of ECU 2 million requested by Parliament for an overall budget of ECU 10.1 million.
The provision was cancelled in two stages: — ECU 1 million in October 1995, — the balance in November 1995.
The temporary blocking of funds has, of course, had an impact on their use, especially the appropriations under the heading I (personnel), as there was uncertainty as to whether the provisions would be effectively cancelled.
OHIM was in no way able to engage in recruitment as long as the payment of salaries was not guaranteed by the end of the financial year.
Once the provisions were released, measures were taken to use the appropriations released, in the budget lines where the time-limits for the commitment procedures still made it possible and where there was real need.
For this reason, the Office has requested a transfer from Title I to Title II, in order to create mainly computerised material which was particularly needed during the initial phase of the Office.
It must be recalled that OHIM began its activities on 1 April 1996 and that more than 30 000 trade mark applications have been received since then, and that the incidence of work had been estimated at 15 000 applications for the whole financial year.
Inventory 1.8. At the time of audit by the Court, OHIM had only just received from the Commission the software for computerised management of the inventory, which was just installed at that time.
Division of tasks 1.9.
A question to the Court of Auditors made it clear that this item concerns the order of signatures which must be adhered to in the budgetary and payment procedures.
It is therefore not a confusion as to the duties of the authorising officer, the accounting officer and the financial controller.
The amendment concerned the fact that the operation was first signed by the accounting officer and then by the authorising officer. · This procedure had the advantage that, in the initial phase of the Office, when there was still no financial manager, it was ensured that the appropriations were available before a transaction was signed by the authorising officer. However, after the OHIM now has a financial manager, the order of signatures indicated below can be followed for the various budget documents: 1. Management officer, 2. Authorising officer, 3. Financial controller, 4. Accounting officer.
Fixed assets 1.10.

No. C 81/42 EN 空 Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 REPLY OF THE FOUNDATION 1.5.
Accounting - The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.
The latter has also played a crucial role in the introduction of a uniform system for the management of the budget and the accounting system in all departments.
Discussions are currently being held with the Commission's departments responsible, which will enable us to overcome all the concerns expressed by the Court of Auditors by introducing a new system for the management of the budget, which will enter into force on 1 January 1997.
It should be stressed that during the period under review none of the amounts allocated had been exceeded.
1.6. Administration of advances It should be stressed that advances had not been used for all purchases of equipment or for participating in real estate, which represented a significant part of the budget.
Moreover, the use of the general advance payments has been reduced in accordance with Article 43 of the Financial Regulation and all accounting documents for a given month will be sent to the auditor in Brussels within the 10th and 20th of the following month.
Contracts On the one hand, the contracts under discussion, which are closely linked to the activities and projects of the Foundation's work programme, represent an extremely small proportion of the Foundation's activities, both in terms of number and budget.
On the other hand, it is true that the inclusion of the competition which led to these contracts took place informally.
This procedure was chosen at the time mainly because of the urgency.
In addition, the contracts under discussion had the task of organizing conferences and seminars on behalf of and on behalf of the Foundation and under its strict control.
The budget was divided into two parts: the fixed part of the remuneration (less than ECU 12 000) and the operational part, which was predetermined by the Foundation and remunerated on the basis of the supporting documents.
On the basis of these elements, the Foundation considered that the actual contract amount would not exceed ECU 12 000.
At the beginning of 1996, when it became clear that the Court of Auditors did not share this view, this system was abandoned.
Accountants The Foundation shares the opinion of the Court of Auditors.
This report shall be submitted to the Management Board of the European Environment Agency in accordance with Article 13(4) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990.1
The Court examined the financial statements of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995.
In accordance with Article 13(1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Executive Director.
Whereas the Court of Auditors is obliged to examine this account in accordance with Article 188c of the Treaty establishing the European Community;
The Court has carried out its audit in accordance with generally accepted audit standards to the extent that they are applicable to the Community context.
It has carried out audits of the accounts and applied other audit procedures considered necessary in this context.
The financial statements for 1994 and 1995 are reliable and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions are ensured overall.
Main comments on the implementation of the budget of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995 Commission grant 1.5.
During the 1995 financial year, the Agency has only a part of the legislation contained in its budget (i1) OJ L 120, 11.5.1990, p. 4.
(2) In accordance with Article 13(3) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the accounts for all the Agency's revenue and expenditure for the financial year 1995 were drawn up on 20 June 1996, signed by the Executive Director of the Agency and forwarded to the Commission, the Management Board and the Court of Auditors.
These accounts were received by the Court of Auditors on 29 June 1996.
The tables in the annex to this report reflect these financial statements in the form of a reduction in the amount allocated to the Commission (budget: ECU 12 million — funds recovered: ECU 6.2 million).
The Court considers that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the 1995 financial year for the remaining balance (ECU 5.8 million) in order to meet the commitments carried over to the 1996 financial year (a total of ECU 7 million).
Under Titles I (staff expenditure) and II (technical expenditure) of the budget, several overruns of some ECU 0.4 million have been recorded.
This amount, which could not be accounted for in the 1995 budget, is shown on the assets side of the balance sheet in a depositary account and must be entered in the accounts for the 1996 budget (in breach of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Paying agency 1.7.
The payment appropriations for Titles I and II of the budget were almost all carried out through a paying agency.
The use of this paying agency is not compatible with Article 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, since the imprest administrator at that time was both the accounting officer and the budget manager of some budget lines.
Furthermore, the deadlines for submitting the supporting documents have not been respected and the availability of the committed appropriations for payments has not been verified.
This seems to be the main reason for the above-mentioned excesses.
Transfers 1.8.
As at the end of 1994, a very large proportion of available appropriations was carried over at the end of 1995 (7 million ECU — 57.2% of the total).
Most transfers concerned Title III (operational expenditure) (ECU 6.4 million — 90.3% of the appropriations entered in this Title).
A large part (ECU 1.8 million) of the ECU 8.5 million carried over from 1994 to 1995 had to be cancelled (21% of the appropriations carried over).
No. C 81/44 - Official Journal of the European Communities 13. 3. 97 Subsequent referral to the financial controller 1.9.
A number of commitments totalling ECU 0.5 million were submitted to the financial controller after the end of the year.
In these cases, the financial control authority has refused its endorsement, which has been ignored by the Board of Directors.
The Court underlines the obligation to comply with the financial regulation under which "all measures which could result in expenditure at the expense of the budget" (Article 27 of the Agency's Financial Regulation) must be subject to prior application for a commitment in accordance with the rules. Separation of tasks 1.10.
The division of responsibilities was not respected in the administrative department of the Agency.
Due to the lack of accounting staff, the same person was also the accounting officer, the administrator and the managing director/indicator of some budget lines.
Accounting systems 1.11.
Two systems which are independent and not linked to each other are used for the accounting of budgetary operations and for the general accounting.
In addition, the accounting system does not provide for any grants in respect of budgetary operations if the available or committed appropriations are exceeded.
Financial controller 1.12.
The Management Board has appointed the financial controller of the Commission as the financial controller.
On the basis of the current functioning of the Agency, the Court considers that it is appropriate to assign to it a V omzeit, a financial controller, which was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 28 October 1996 and for the Court of Auditors, Mr Bernhard FRI EDMANN, President of the Court of Auditors.

• The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was adopted on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on the seat of the Agency had been delayed, the work had to be done particularly quickly at the beginning of the Environment Agency's activities.
Projects could be identified and commitments made before the end of the year thanks to a large amount of work, but for obvious reasons the implementation of commitments could hardly begin before the end of 1994.
In 1995, the Agency was faced with the difficult task of implementing not only the 1994 budget, but also a new budget of ECU 10.5 million for 1995, before the regular staff of the Agency began their duties.
The Agency's vacancies were advertised in November 1994 and after a lengthy selection process with more than 7 000 applications, the first selected candidates started their work in the summer of 1995.
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work programme and had practically two budgets, but had only a very limited number of staff for this task.
Nevertheless, the work progressed and in 1995 major projects such as the Dobris Management Report and the revision of the 5th Environmental Action Plan were completed.
Five European thematic contact centres have been set up and the development of EIONET has progressed.
The Agency's regular staff increased by 1 person on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, such as national experts and auxiliary staff) and reached the level of 22 regular staff on 31 December 1995 with 10 temporary staff.
The administrative machinery of the Agency has gradually been expanded as the same open recruitment procedure has been applied.
Nevertheless, in 1995, the Agency was clearly not sufficiently equipped to cope with the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
As regards the financial side, only one person was available in the first half of the year to work on the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme.
In June 1995, the Head of the Administration Department began his duties, and only at the beginning of 1996 did the other staff for financial and contract matters come in.
While the Agency has been doing its job, in the field of finance and budget a number of errors have been made with regard to the prescribed procedures.
Overruns Some budget lines have been overrun.
On the one hand, this was because the Agency's budgetary control system did not function satisfactorily and, on the other hand, some payments made were not recorded, as the Agency's financial department was clearly understaffed.
Consequently, the clearance of the accounts gave rise to a discrepancy between the accounting system and the payments actually made, which appeared as an overdraft of certain budget lines.
Since no more account may be taken of different budget lines after 1 January, these amounts have to be included in the 1996 accounts, i.e. financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996, expenditure and the appropriations available under Titles I and II (i.e. the 1995 problem points) were carefully monitored in order to avoid an expenditure surplus.
Unfulfilled procedures (subsequent referral to the financial controller) A work programme was drawn up during the Agency's development phase and its implementation started before the administrative procedures were clearly defined and an administrative structure was available to monitor compliance with the procedures.
In some cases this led to work being commissioned and carried out in the absence of certain procedural rules.
In particular, work was commissioned without the financial controller's endorsement being obtained in Brussels, which is a prerequisite for this type of operational expenditure.
The error was purely procedural and was justified in the fact that work had to be done, but that the necessary administrative structures to ensure compliance with the rules laid down by Brussels had not yet been set up.
A clear delegation of the powers of instruction has been carried out and the staff are informed of the procedural rules.
Delimitation of tasks As in all public institutions, certain functions of a financial technical nature should remain separate with the Environment Agency.
One of the basic principles is that commitments and payment orders should not be made by the same person.
However, during the period of construction of the agency in Copenhagen, the number of staff was so low that this principle could not be complied with.
The Court of Auditors rightly complains about this fact.
In the case of the Environment Agency, the financial controller of the Agency and that of the Commission shall be one and the same person established in Brussels.
This would significantly impede the Agency's work.
The way out of this dilemma is to set up a paying agency.
Im principle, it works like a small cash reserve, although the amounts spent on it are quite significant.
Instead of obtaining the prior approval of the financial control, the Agency orders the payment and sends once a month the establishment of the procedures by the paying agency for the subsequent approval of the financial control.
On the one hand, this will facilitate the work of the paying agency, but on the other hand, it will also be a two-part sword, as internal control of the agency and the financial department will have to be able to fulfil this additional responsibility.
In this respect, the Court of Auditors' complaint is understandable, but as long as the financial controller is based in Brussels, the Agency does not see any alternance as an extensible means of making use of the paying agency.
Computerised accounting system The Court of Auditors stresses the need for the Agency to implement a modern accounting system covering both general accounting and budgetary control.
Such a computerised system is indispensable for the EU's complicated financial system if we are to avoid substantial financial and budgetary commitments.
The Environment Agency wholeheartedly supports the Court of Auditors' conclusions.
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has repeatedly tried to find a solution to this problem.
It is in the same form, by the way, for the other EU agencies.
In 1996, the agencies issued a joint call for proposals, but this was unsuccessful, i.e. no satisfactory system was found.
The agency is currently considering the possibility of using the new Sincom 2 budgetary control system.
The plan will provide for its timely installation and operational operation in order to implement the 1997 budget.
But there will continue to be a soft point for budgetary control and another for general accounting.
The payment agencies will not be integrated into the software either. The agency will continue to look for a suitable solution to these problems and strive to coordinate this work with the other agencies.

The following remarks relate to the Court of Auditors' most important observations on the implementation of the EMCDDA budget for 1994 and 1995 (points 1.5 to 1.11 of the Court's observations).
The EMCDDA shares the Court's view that it would have been more appropriate to issue a recovery order for all the appropriations entered in the balance sheet as a contribution to the Commission, and that for the 1996 budget, the budget was adopted accordingly. (b) The Portuguese Government (point 1.6 of the Court's observations) The EMCDDA acted in accordance with the Commission's financial control guidelines (which is also the EMCDDA's financial controller). For the purposes of Article 54 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities and Article 82 of the Implementing Rules for the same (in accordance with the spirit of Article 142 of the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the European Communities), the EMCDDA initially used the payment account for the expenditure referred to in Article 54 of the abovementioned implementing provisions.
However, the EMCDDA is aware that this can only be a provisional system (based on Excel) and that it needs a more efficient accounting system.
In this context, the decentralised agencies (including the EMCDDA) launched a call for proposals at the end of December 1995 under the co-ordination of the European Training Foundation in Turin with the aim of equipping themselves with an integrated computerised system for general accounting and accounting.
No. C 81/54  the Official Journal of the Communities 13. 3. 97 For the following financial years, the EMCDDA shall implement a plan for programming and monitoring the implementation of the budget and its work programme to improve the use of the appropriations allocated and, in particular, to limit the transfers to exceptional cases. f) Separation of tasks (point 1.10 of the Court of Auditors' comments) C Due to its very limited staff numbers in 1994 and 1995, the EMCDDA was unable to fully ensure compliance with the principle of separation of duties, as the Court of Auditors pointed out.
The separation of the duties of authorising officer, financial controller and accounting officer, as required by Article 16 of OEDT's financial rules for the duties of authorising officer, has been fully respected.
The EMCDDA is already working to ensure the separation of tasks in the implementation of the various tasks in question.
In this context, it shall, as far as possible, take into account the requirements communicated by the Court of Auditors in defining their short-term needs in order to ensure that the administrative tasks referred to by the Court of Auditors (payment management, accounting, management of staff and contracts) are carried out by different persons.
(g) Financial Controller (point 1.11 of the Court's observations) The EMCDDA's Management Board, when adopting EMCDDA's financial rules in June, issued a negative decision on the delegation of the tasks of the financial controller to an EMCDDA official (in particular on the basis of the European Commission's objection).
Since the European Commission's financial controller is also the EMCDDA's financial controller, it would also be up to the Commission to assess the feasibility of the possible designation of a financial controller on the spot, taking into account the rules on this issue in the other decentralised agencies.

EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 1 of 5 Avis juridique important 31997Y0313(06) Report on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies Official Journal C 081, 13/03/1997 P. 0043 - 0048 REPORT on the financial statements of the European Environment Agency (EEA-Copenhagen), together with the Agency's replies (97/C 81/06/) (For the period from 1 September 1994 to 31 December 1995) 1.1.
This report is addressed to the Management Board of the European Environment Agency in agreement with Article 13 (4) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1).
The Court of Auditors has examined the financial statements of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995.
The budget was implemented under the responsibility of the Executive Director in agreement with the requirements of Article 13 (1) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. His responsibility includes the preparation and presentation of the accounts (2) in agreement with the internal financial provisions set out in Article 14 of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90. Article 188c of the Treaty establishment the European Community requires the Court of Auditors to audit these accounts.
This report constitutes the first audit of the Agency.
The Court conducted its audit in accordance with generally accepted auditing standards in so far as they are applicable in the Community context.
The Court carried out checks on the accounts and records and also applied search additional auditing procedures as it considered necessary in this context.
The main observations resulting from the Court's audit are presented in the second part of this report.
The financial statements for the financial years 1994 and 1995 are reliable and the underlying operations were carried out, on the whole, in agreement with the rules concerning legality and regularity.
Main observations concerning the implementation of the budget of the European Environment Agency for the financial years 1994 and 1995 The Commission subsidiary 1.5.
During the financial year 1995 the Agency used only part of the Commission submity provided for in the general budget (ECU 12 million, of which ECU 6.2 million was drawn down).
It is the Court's opinion that the Agency should have issued a recovery order during the financial year 1995 for the balance maintenance due (ECU 5,8 million) in order to meet the commitments that were carried over to the financial year 1996 (totaling ECU 7 million).
Spending in excess of available appropriation 1.6.
Several cases of expenditure in excess of available appropriation, spending to approximate ECU 0.4 million altoghether, were found under headings I (staff expenditure) and II (administrative expenditure) of the budget.
This http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997... 26/10/2010
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 2 of 5 amount, which could not be charged to the budget for 1995, was entered on the assess side of the balance sheet in a suspense account, and had to be charged to the budget for the financial year 1996 (contravention of Articles 5, 27, 29c and 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Imprest account 1.7.
Almost all payments charged to the budget under chapters I and II were made via an imprest account.
The utilization of this account was not in agreement with Article 43 of the Agency's Financial Regulation, since the administrator of the imprest accounts was, at the time, both the Accounting and the Authorizing Officer for certain budget heads.
Furthermore, the deadlines for the submission of supporting documents were not met and the availability of recommendations committed was not verified before payments were made.
This situation seems to be the principal cause of the cases of spending in excess of available approaches pointed out out above.
Approvals carried forward 1.8.
At the end of the financial year 1995, as was already the case at the end of the financial year 1994, the percentage of appropriations carried forward was very high in relation to the appropriations available (ECU 7 million - 57.2% of the total budget).
The majority of these carryovers concern title III (ECU 6.4 million, representing 90.3% of the appropriations under this title).
A large share (ECU 1.8 million) of the appropriations carried over from 1994 to 1995, totalling ECU 8.5 million, had to be cancelled (21% of the appropriations carried over).
A posteriori referral to the Financial Controller 1.9.
Several proposals for the commitment of funds totalling ECU 0.5 million were submitted, a posteriori, to the Financial Controller for his approach.
In these cases, the Financial Controller withheld his approximation, but this refusal was overruled by the Management Board.
The Court wishes to emphasize the obligation to respect the Financial Regulation and to submit proposals for commitments in due form prior to 'any measure of a child which might lead to expenditure from the budget' (Article 27 of the Agency's Financial Regulation).
Separation of duties 1.10.
The separation of duties within the administration of the Agency has not been observed.
Due to atoday of staff in the financial accounting department, the same person was, at one and the same time, Accounting Officer, administrator of the imprest accounts and Authorizing Officer for certain budget headers.
Accounting systems 1.11.
The budgetary accounting and general accounting are carried out on two independent and unrelated computer systems.
The budgetary accounting system is, moreover, not programmed to refuse entries in the event of appropriation available, or approvals committed, being exceeded.
The Financial Controller 1.12.
The Management Board appointed the Commission's Financial Controller as their own Financial Controller.
The Court regards it would be advisable, in respect of the Agency's present mode of operation, to accept a full-time Financial Controller for the Agency.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors in Luxembourg at the Court meeting of 28 October 1996. http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 3 of 5 For the Court of Auditors Bernhard FRIEDMANN President >TABLE> >TABLE> >TABLE> (1) OJ No L 120, 11.5.1990, p. 4.
(2) Contrary to the requirements of Article 13 (3) of Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90, the accounts for all revenue and expenditure of the Agency in respect of the financial year 1995 were not prepared until 20 June 1996, the date on which the accounts were signed by the Executive Director of the Agency and sent to the Commission, to the Board of Management and to the Court of Auditors.
These accounts were received by the Court on 28 June 1996.
The revised version of these financial statements is presented in the tables annexed to this report.
THE AGENCY'S REPLIES The European Environment Agency was established in Copenhagen in mid-1994.
A first budget of ECU 10.2 million was adopted already on 31 October 1994.
Since the decision on where to locate the Agency had been delayed a fast start was needed.
Through a significant efficiency, projects could be identified and the budget committed before the end of the year, but for previous reasons the execution of the commitments could be quite start before the end of 1994.
Thus, in 1995 the Agency faced the daunting task of executing, not only the budget from 1994 but also a new budget for 1995 of ECU 10.5 million, and this before the regular staff of the Agency had taken up duty.
The vacant posts in the Agency were published in November 1994 and the selected candidates started coming on board in summer 1995 after a long selection procedure involving more than 7 000 applications.
In short, the Agency had an ambitious work program and virtually two budgets to execute, but very limited staff for the task.
Despite this, work went ahead and in 1995 the Agency finalized major projects, like the Dobris assessment, the review of the fifth environmental action plan.
Five European topic centres were established and the build-up of the EIONET advanced.
The build-up of the Agency progressed with regular staff increasing from 1 on 1 January 1995 (supported by 10 temporary staff, for example national experts and auxiliary staff) to 22 on 31 December 1995, still supported by 10 temporary staff.
The Agency's administration has progressively developed since the same open procedure to recruit was applied.
Nevertheless, it was clearly too understaffed in 1995 to handle the procedural and financial aspects of the work.
On the finance side only one person was available to handle the financial, budgetary and contractual aspects of the work programme during the first half of the year.
In June 1995 the Head of Administration took up duty, and only in the beginning of 1996 did the rest of the finance and contract staff come on board.
The Agency rose to the challenge, but some themes of a procedural nature were made in the areas of finance and budget.
Overspending There was overspending on some budget lines.
The season was, on the one http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
26/10/2010
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 4 of 5 hand, that the Agency's budgetary monitoring system did not function in a satisfactory way and on the other hand some executed payments were not introduced due to the fact that the Agency was seriously understaffed in the finance department.
As a consequence, when the accounts were closed, the discount between the accounts and the payments actually made, shown up as overspending on some budget lines.
Since no adjustment between budget lines can be made after 1 January, this has to be booked on the 1996 accounts, i.e. be financed from the 1996 budget.
In 1996 the expenditures and the availability of approvals in titles I and II, which was where the problems occurred in 1995, were carefully monitored in order to avoid overspending.
Procedures overlooked (Saisine a posteriori) During the build-up of the Agency, a work program was established and started being executed before administrative procedures had been well established and an administration in place to monitor that procedures were followed.
In some cases this led to work being ordered and carried out without all the procedures being observed.
In particular, work was contracted without the Financial Controller in Brussels having given his visa which is a prerequisite for this kind of operational expenditure.
It was not a question of finances being lost or that the finances were not there.
The mistake was procedural and reflected that work had to be done and the procedures to ascertain that this was done according to Community rules were not yet in place.
Procedures are now in place to avoid similar problems.
A clear delegation of authorizing powers have been established and staff informed of the rules.
Separation of functions In the financial framework of the Agency, as is the case in all public institutions, certain functions should be kept separate.
A basic principle is that the same person should not commit money and order payment.
However, during the period of establishment of the Agency in Copenhagen the number of staff in the Agency was so small that it was not possible to observe this principal.
This is legally criticalized by the Court of Auditors.
However, once the staffing of the Agency started to increase this was corrected and these functions have been rigorously separated in the Agency since 1995.
Extensive use of imprest accounts The normal procedure forcommitting and ordering payments in the EU system is to have prior approval by the Financial Controller in practice all cases.
In the case of the Agency, the Agency Financial Controller is the same as the Commission's and located in Brussels.
To send all financial transactions to Brussels for approach before they could actually be executed would be an excessively tiresome procedure.
It would seriously obstruct the working of the Agency.
The way out of this dilemma is the imprest account.
It works in principle as a petty-cash reserve oldough the mountains involved are important.
Instead of seeing prior approval from Financial Control, the Agency executes the payment and once a month the imprest account is sent to the Financial Controller to have the ex post approval of the payments which have been made.
On the one hand this facilitates the functioning of the Agency, but, on the other hand, it is a double-edged word since the Agency's internal controls and the financial department must have the capacity to handle this additional responsibility.
Dues, the criticalism by the Court of Auditors is understandable, but as long as http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:31997...
EUR-Lex - 31997Y0313(06) - EN Page 5 of 5 the Financial Controller is located in Brussels there is, in the Agency's view no alternative to an extensive use of the imprest account.
It is there with great interest that the Agency has noted the recommendation by the Court of Auditors that the Financial Controller of the Commission should place a Financial Controller in the Agency.
The Agency would welcome this step.
Computerized financial system The Court of Auditors subordinates the need for the Agency to find an up-to-date computerized financial system which can integrate the accounting side with the budget monitoring side.
In the compliant financial system of the European Union such a computerized system is crucial to avoid having to tie down a lot of resources in financial and budgetary work.
The Agency supports whoreheartedly the conclusion by the Court of Auditors.
Since the beginning of 1995, the Agency has again and again tried to find a solution to this problem.
It is a problem which the European Environment Agency shares with the other EU Agencies.
In 1996, the Agencies launched a joint call for tenders to find a solution but this call for tenders has not been successful, i.e. no satisfactory system has been found.
Thus, the Agency is at present pursuing the likelihood of using the new budget monitoring system Sincom 2. The plan is to have it installed and operational in time to execute the 1997 budget on the basis of this system.
There will be still one software for the budget monitoring system and another for the general leather.
Nor will the imprest accounts be integrated in the software the Agency will continue to look for an efficient way of solving these problems and will finishavour to coordinate this work with the other Agencies.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/25 INTRODUCTION 1. The European Environment Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 of 7 May 1990 (1).
The Agency's mission is to set up an environmental monitoring network that will provide the Commission, the Member States and the general public with reliable information on the state of the environment.
This information is intended to give the European Union and the Member States, in particular, the ability to take environmental measures and to assess the effectiveness of these measures.
2. Table 1 summarises the Agency's obligations and responsibilities.
Tables 2, 3 and 4 provide information on the main elements of the Agency's financial statements for the financial year 2006.
The European Parliament and the Council are presented to the European Parliament and the Council pursuant to Article 185(2) of Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (2). It is based on an examination of the Agency's accounts, which the Court must carry out pursuant to Article 248 of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
The annual accounts of the Agency for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 (3) were drawn up in accordance with Article 13 of Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90 by its Executive Director and forwarded to the Court, which provides an explanation of the applicability of the annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
5. The Court carried out its examination in compliance with the guidelines for financial control and the INTOSAI Code of Obligations and Code of Conduct as well as the international professional principles for the final examination of IFAC, if these are applicable in the Community context.
The audit was planned and implemented with a view to obtaining adequate assurance that the financial statements were reliable and that the underlying results were correct and orderly.
6. The Court has an adequate basis for the following calculation of the amount of guarantee. Insufficiency of the financial statements The Agency's annual accounts for the financial year ended on 31 December 2006 are subject to change in all main respects.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's consideration.
COMMENTS 7.  just over 30 % of the financial year's commitments had to be transferred.
In operational expenditure (Title III and assigned revenue) more than half of the appropriations were transferred.
These transfers were partly not justified: in the last two months of 2006, the Agency made commitments of EUR 1.3 million, but transferred the corresponding payments to 2007.
A sampling (4) of these transfers showed that they were exclusively related to 2007-performing activities.
The budgetary principle of legality was therefore not strictly applied.
8. The authorising officer, who was subordinated, not only carried out ex-ante checks, but also managed the access rights to the electronic accounting system, which is a violation of the principle of separation of tasks.
This report was adopted by the Court of Auditors at its meeting in Luxembourg on 27 September 2007.

C 309/28 EN Official Journal of the European Union 19.12.2007 ANSWER OF THE AGENCY The higher proportion of transfers to 2007 is mainly due to other events in 2006, which led us to postpone interim payments at theme centres until the satisfactory delivery of the services.
The limits for the later commitments entered into were the obligation to conclude licensing agreements before 1 January each year in order to maintain the continuity, as well as the time required to define and negotiate the costs and time limits for complex new work.
The Agency will continue to encourage the reduction of the share of transfers in this context.
The risks associated with the described situation were assessed by management and controls were carried out to mitigate the risks.
The remaining risk is considered acceptable.
This situation will be reassessed in the context of a safety-sensitive tasks that will take place in mid-2007.

19.12.2007 EN Official Journal of the European Union C 309/41 INTRODUCTION 1. The European Agency for Reconstruction (hereinafter referred to as the Agency) was established by Council Regulation (EC) No 1628/96(1), as last amended by Council Regulation (EC) No 756/2006 of 28 November 2006 (2).
The agency, which was established in 2000, originally had the task of managing the European Union's aid programmes in Kosovo.
The mission was also extended to Serbia-Montenegro and the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia.
The Agency implements programmes to promote institution building and good governance to support the establishment of a market economy and basic infrastructure for civil society.
The Agency's mandate is in principle to expire on 31 December 2008.
Tables 2, 3 and 4 contain, for information purposes, essential information from the Agency's annual accounts for the financial year 2006.
This declaration shall be submitted to the European Parliament and to the Council in accordance with Article 185(2) of Council Regulation (EC, Euratom) No 1605/2002 (3).
It follows a review of the Agency's bill, which the Court must carry out in accordance with Article 248 of the Treaty establishing the European Community.
4. The Agency's annual accounts for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 (4) were drawn up by its Director in accordance with Article 8(2) of Council Regulation (EC) No 2667/2000 (5) and forwarded to the Court, which gives an explanation of the reliability of the annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying accounts.
The Agency's annual accounts for the financial year ended 31 December 2006 are due in all material respects.
The following comments do not call into question the Court's powers.
OBSERVATIONS 7. The budget implementation rate was satisfactory.
However, the Agency will be made aware of the extent of the resources still to be committed, which will require special monitoring of the Agency's programmes, as its mandate expires at the end of 2008.
8. With regard to the accounting system and the internal control system, the Court noted improvements over previous years, in particular with regard to the monitoring of funds managed by external bodies and the application of procurement procedures.
