EN C 434/16 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 INTRODUCTION 2.1.
This chapter presents a review of the results of the annual inspections carried out by the Court by the agencies for the year 2017 as well as further inspections with regard to the agencies carried out by the Court in the course of 2017.
THE RESULTS OF THE AGENCY'S ANNUAL PRINTS FOR 2017 ARE OVERALL POSITIV 2.3.
Overall, the Court's audit of the agencies' annual accounts for the year ending December 31, 2017 and the revenue and payments underlying these annual accounts confirm the positive results from previous years.
The Court has given undisclosed opinions on the annual accounts of all agencies.
According to the Agency's assessment, the agencies' annual accounts represent their financial and financial situation as at 31 December 2017 and the results of their accounts and cash flows for the year ending on that date in accordance with their respective financial rules and the accounting rules adopted by the Commission's accounting officer (13) in all essential respects.
The emphasis on an issue is fundamentally linked to the understanding of annual accounts 2.5.
With respect to EASO, the Court pointed out that the personnel situation in the B toro deteriorated exponentially.
The B厅ro currently does not have the administrative capacity to fill the many vacancies.
Overall, the continuing nature of the work of the B樟ros is very much affected by the human resources situation to the present extent.
In the case of the SRB, the Court stressed that the contributions to the Single Resolution Fund are calculated on the basis of the information provided by credit institutions to the Committee on National Resolution Authorities.
However, the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework to ensure that this information is reliable.
The Court also found that the method set out in the legislation for calculating contributions is very complex, which entails risks for accuracy.
For reasons of confidentiality, the Committee may not disclose the data of credit institutions used for the calculation of the operations of the Funds, which reduces transparency.
With regard to ECHA, the Court stressed that the Agency is partially self-financed and that it receives a certificate from any company applying for the registration of chemicals as provided for in the REACH Regulation(14).
The calculation and invoicing of fees shall be carried out by the Agency on the basis of the information provided by the undertakings at the time of the application.
The ex-post processing carried out by the Agency has revealed the need for financial corrections of which the total amount was not known at the end of 2017.
This conclusion shows the limitations of a system which is based too heavily on the self-discipline of the applicants.
As regards the GSA, the Court pointed out that the outcome of the public procurement procedure for one of the Agency's most important contracts (the EUR 1.5 billion framework agreement) was contested by one of the tenderers.
As regards the two agencies in London (EMA and EBA), the Court pointed out that they will leave the United Kingdom in 2019 and that their annual accounts have been prepared along with their accompanying statements on the basis of the information available at the time of their signing.
The Court also pointed out the impact of the existing London lease agreements and the possible decline in revenue resulting from the United Kingdom's withdrawal from the EU.
These are based on internationally accepted accounting principles for the public sector. Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 18 December 2006 on the Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals (REACH) (OJ L 298, 20.10.2006, p.
(OJ L 396, 30.12.2006, p. 1).
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/17 Unrestricted judgments on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the accounts of all agencies 2.12.
For all agencies, the Court has given undue judgements on the legality and regularity of the revenue underlying the annual accounts for the year ending 31 December 2017.
According to the Court's judgement, the revenues in all essential matters were legal and orderly.
Unrestricted judgements on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the agencies' annual accounts (except EASO) 2.13.
For 40 agencies, the Court has issued undisturbed rulings on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts for the year ending 31 December 2017.
According to the Court's assessment, payments in all essential respects were legal and orderly.
As the understandings occur systematically, the internal control system is obviously impracticable.
The accumulated error due to the irregular payments concerns at least EUR 7.7 million or 10.3% of the total payments made by the BՕro in 2017.
The reference to other matters deals with issues of particular importance 2.15.
Paragraphs referring to other matters should point the reader to important points which are not presented or stated in the annual accounts or which concern the legality and regularity of revenue and payments.
As regards the EIT, the Court noted that the original reimbursements for Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) were increased towards the end of the period.
In addition, two KICs have included some new activities in the annual business activities.
In one of the KICs, this resulted in a significant change in the original grant decision.
Substantial changes can affect the equal treatment of the KICs and are not in line with the Financial Regulation.
In the case of Frontex, the Court has repeatedly reported since 2014 that the cooperating states often show insufficient evidence of the expenditure they claim.
This was also supported by this year's results.
In response to the recommendation made by the Court in 2016, Frontex is currently implementing a simplified reimbursement model.
With regard to EBA, EIOPA and ESMA, the Court pointed out that their budgets are partly financed from European Union funds and partly from direct contributions from supervisory authorities and/or supervised bodies of the EU Member States.
As a result of the United Kingdom's decision to leave the EU, the revenues of the farmers could fall in the future.
With regard to GSA, the Court reported that the Agency operates both the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) and Galileo ground stations in the United Kingdom, which may need to be relocated.
As regards the CdT, the Court pointed out that several agencies increasingly resort to in-house or other alternative translation operations, which meant that the capacity of the Centre was not used to the maximum.
There is also a double burden on the development of translation systems and on current costs at European level.
In December 2016, the Bussek Board of European Regulators for Electronic Communications (B买ro des BEREK) commissioned the CdT to translate four calls for expressions of interest in order to draw up reserve lists, despite the fact that all the posts approved by the budgetary authority in the Bęros establishment plan were filled.
In the Court's view, the translation order issued in December 2016 was not justified.
The payment on this order in March 2017 amounted to 2.5% of the 2017 budget.
EN C 434/18 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 2.1 Annual reports 2014-2017 on the financial statements and projections of the agencies Source: European Court of Auditors.
The Court's observations cover a large number of issues 2.22.
The Court made a total of 145 comments concerning 37 agencies in order to highlight important issues and identify areas where there is a need for improvement.
These comments set out in Chapter 3 are summarised below.
Large risks lead to significant vulnerabilities in EASO 2.23.
In the case of EASO, the Court drew attention to the major risks that arise from the nature of its activities, as well as to the extraordinary challenges posed by the migration crisis.
These risks were not mitigated by a sound governance structure and effective controls, which led to numerous essential infringements of the legislation.
Since 2014, the B滨ro has been working with a high staff turnover. Recruitment procedures were suspended in December 2017.
Furthermore, the B任ro does not establish an internal audit office or a legal service, and legal documents are not systematically translated.
Almost all the services provided, which were based on public procurement or recruitment procedures, were systematically accused of being systematically damaged by substantial regulations in connection with the determination of the needs of the farm, the elaboration of service descriptions, the choice of the type of contract, the evaluation and award procedures, the changes and extensions of the works, the execution of the works and the supervision of the services provided, etc.
These rules are contrary to the principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/19 Progress towards a more unified IT landscape 2.26.
The operational capabilities of the agencies are broad and require appropriate IT solutions, sometimes tailor-made.
However, central operational and administrative activities are carried out on the basis of the same legal framework, which suggests that their procedures can be changed and that similar IT schemes can be used to support these procedures.
While the agencies made very great progress with regard to the use of similar systems for budget and accounting management, the Court reported here in its summary report 2016 on the results of the inspections carried out by the agencies, a large number of IT solutions were still used in other core areas such as personnel management and procurement and management.
Agencies are managing to further unify IT solutions in these areas, especially in order to increase cost efficiency, reduce the risks associated with internal control and strengthen IT governance.
In 2017, a number of progress was made with regard to IT tools for human resources management, with 20 agencies concluding agreements with the Commission on the use of the SYSPER II tool, which will create a more unified IT landscape in this area.
The majority of the agencies will use the Commission's tool from 1 January 2019, while some agencies will use it from the third quarter of 2018.
In this fragmented IT landscape, the use of similar electronic tools for procurement of supplies and services (electronic procurement) would also be an important step towards a more unified IT framework among agencies.
In the context of the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation, which entered into force in 2012 and 2013, all EU institutions and agencies shall, as far as possible, draw up and implement solutions for the submission, storage and processing of data submitted in grant and award procedures, and shall establish a common area for electronic data exchange for applicants, candidates and tenderers (15), (16).
While the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation do not set a target date for the introduction of electronic procurement, the 2014 EU Directive on public procurement(17) requires the use of electronic means for public procurement in the EU Member States by 2018, and in accordance with the 2014 EU Directive on electronic invoicing(18), all public entities must allow the receipt of electronic invoices by 2019.

EN C 434/20 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 2.29.
All agencies publish their tenders electronically via TED (Tenders Electronic Daily), the online version of the EU Official Journal for public procurement. In addition, the Commission launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents on contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015). Most agencies had initiated the electronic invoicing and the electronic invitation to tender for certain procedures by the end of 2017, but not the electronic submission of tenders.
Improvement in IT consulting services and project management at EMA and eu-LISA IT consulting services and project management at EMA 2.30.
In the course of the previous year's review, the Court analysed how the Agency manages advisory services.
The overriding use of consulting companies has led to a critical dependence of external expertise.
The Court also reported that the control of project development and implementation was insufficient and that the projects had suffered serious reduction and cost increases.
During 2017, the Agency took several measures to improve the situation.
However, it will take time to reduce the critical nature of the agency of consultancy firms, and the impact of the measures taken will not be apparent until the years have passed.
IT consulting and project management at eu-LISA 2.32.
The agency uses consulting services mainly in connection with IT projects due to the nature of its activity.
In 2017, the Agency's IT projects were implemented within the financial and time frame.
The Agency uses a outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, in which around 90 % of the corresponding work is carried out by three contractors.
Although the IT projects are the property of the agency and are under its control, a model in which the development capabilities for such sensitive IT systems are outsourced to this extent, involves the risk of over-reliance from the contractors.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/21 2.34.
At the same time, the small number of employees in operational key meetings generates a risk for the continuity of the operation.
Public procurement aims to ensure competition between economic operators and to make the most economically viable purchase, using a transparent, objective and coherent approach based on the current legal framework.
The Court of Auditors found in 14 agencies (B⓬ro des BEREK, EPA, Chafea, eu-LISA, EASO, EBA, EEA, EFSA, EIGE, EUIPO, ERA, EASA, FRA and SRB) schemes in the field of public procurement, mostly in terms of services that pose risks for optimal use of funds.
Among the most frequently identified sources are the lack of a balanced relationship between price and quality aspects in award criteria, the not optimal design of framework agreements, the use of framework agreements allowing the procurement of services, the description and/or price of which were not sufficiently specified and the use of intermediate services.
Most agencies analysed the impact of Brexit 2.36. On March 29, 2017, the United Kingdom informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit).
Unlike most other agencies, five agencies (ACER, B何ro des BEREK, EPA, ENISA and EU-OSHA) did not carry out a comprehensive analysis of the potential impact of Brexit on their organisation, operations and accounting.
Job advertisements could be published on the EPSO website 2.37.
Most agencies (ACER, Cedefop, EPA, Chafea, EASA, EBA, ECHA, EEA, EIGE, EIOPA, EIT, EMA, EMCDDA, EMSA, ENISA, ESMA, eu-LISA, Eurojust, Europol, Frontex, GSA and SRB) publish job advertisements on their own websites and in social media, but frequently not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
A publication on the EPSO website would increase transparency and publicity, enabling the citizens of Europe to view job advertisements of all European institutions.
The main reason given by the agencies is that the EPSO is calling for job advertisements to be published in all the official languages of the EU, with high translation costs.
Less comments on the legality and regularity of payments 2.38.
The number of comments on the legality and regularity of payments went back to eight (2016: 11), highlighting the ongoing efforts of the agencies to comply with the legal framework, in particular the provisions of the Financial Regulation and the Framework Financial Regulation and the Staff Regulations.
While five comments were made again in connection with procurement procedures (EASO, EASA, EIGE and Frontex), three were related to recruitment procedures (EASO, Cedefop and Frontex).
The budget management has improved 2.39.
Under certain conditions, budget appropriations granted for a given year may be transferred to the next year (19).
Although the Financial Regulation does not set any limits for such transfers, the multi-annual nature of the transfers is also largely justified. Nevertheless, transfers can be an indication of the delays in the execution of the work programmes or contracts, and can also run counter to the budgetary principle of annuality.
Illustration 2.4 shows how many agencies the Court reported in 2017 and in previous years on the high transfer of funds.
The return on only two agencies (Chafea and EU-OSHA) in 2017 is due to the fact that the transfers from the agencies were better and more transparently explained and founded, but also to the changed approach of the Court for reporting 2017.
(19) The conditions for transfers are laid down in Article 13 of the Financial Regulation.
EN C 434/22 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Illustration 2.4 Less comments on European Court of Auditors or high transfers of funds Source: European Court of Auditors based on information provided by the agencies.
In addition, the Court noted that two agencies (Frontex and EUIPO) cancelled budget transfers from previous years.
This indicated that the budget was too high, in particular on the part of the public authorities of the Member States and other cooperating countries.
Accounting could be further improved 2.42.
In the course of this year's proceedings, the Court also considered the accounting of the agencies, which had an important role to play in the preparation of reliable annual accounts.
The Financial Regulation has been approved by each agency with its own accountant. This has resulted in a total of 37 accounts being held responsible for 2% of the EU budget.
The main tasks of the invoicing officer are the performance of payments, the receipt of revenue and the collection of receivables, the preparation and presentation of the annual accounts as well as the management of invoices, the establishment and validation of the accounting systems and the treasury management.
In order to increase efficiency, the Commission's accountant asked all agencies to delegate their accounting function to him on a contractual basis in 2012.
The first agency to accept this proposal was the EPO in 2014.
By the end of 2017, only three other agencies (GSA, B抽ro des BEREK and ACER) had joined this scheme.
The hierarchical position of an accountant within an agency can affect his independence.
In particular, the accountants must be independent of persons (subordinately) charged with making commitments and making legal commitments and reporting payments.
This observation concerns a total of 13 agencies (CdT, EACEA, EASA, EASME, EEA, EFSA, EIOPA, EMA, EMCDDA, ERA, EU-OSHA, Eurofound and FRA).
The Board of Governors' appointment and annual assessment must also fall within the scope of responsibility of the Board of Governors.
The financial regulation must ensure that the agencies' accounting systems function correctly (validation).
While the validation of the accounting systems of most agencies is up-to-date, the Court noted that the accounting systems of seven agencies (ACER, B与ro des BEREK, EPA, EASME, EIT, EMA and GSA) could require timely revalidation due to extensive changes.

In three agencies (EASO, CPVO and REA) awarding, grant and recruitment procedures were insufficiently documented.
Three agencies (ACER, EIT and Frontex) have identified Mussals for internal control in the implementation of the standard concerning the emergency devices.
These accounts could represent a significant risk for maintaining business in the event of disasters, as data could be irrevocably lost.

The Court concluded that the agencies had implemented a 5% reduction in staff, albeit with some decreases.

Special Report of the Court 항 about the SRB 2.51.
The Single Resolution Committee (SRB), based in Brussels, was established in August 2014 and is part of the political response to the financial crisis.
The task of the Committee is to resolve insolvency-threatening banks which fall within its scope of responsibility.
In January 2017, the SRB was responsible for 139 banks, including 130 banking groups (21).
In the course of the survey (22) it was examined whether the Board was prepared to handle banks effectively. Particular attention was paid to the quality of resolution planning for individual banks and whether the Board was prepared to meet the legal requirements in the field of resolution planning and had sufficient personnel resources to carry out its tasks.
The Court identified deficits in all these areas. However, as the establishment of the Committee as a completely new structure constituted a huge challenge, the weaknesses should be seen against this background.
The Court made a number of recommendations to the Committee with a view to drawing up resolution plans and implementing its rules and guidelines, and to increasing staff and improving procedures in the area of human resources management.
(21) On 1 January 2018, the number has decreased to 127 banks and 119 banking groups.
(22) Special Report No 23/2017: ăSingle Resolution Committee: First steps on the challenging path to the Banking Union have been taken, but there is still a long way to go, published on 19 December 2017.
DE C 434/26 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 Special Court annual report on contingent liabilities resulting from the Single Resolution Committee's duties 2.54.
In accordance with the Single Resolution Mechanism Regulation (23), the Court must draw up a report on all contingent liabilities resulting from the fact that the Committee, the Council and the Commission carry out their tasks under this Regulation.
As at 31 December 2016, the Committee's contingent liabilities resulting from the pre-estimated contributions amounted to EUR 842 million, which increased to EUR 1 420 million as at 30 September 2017.
In 2016, the Board did not initiate bank resolution, and therefore no contingent liability related to resolution decisions was required for the 2016 financial year.
At the time when the Court's report on contingent liabilities in 2016 was published, which resulted from the Committee's carrying out its duties, 90 legal proceedings against the Committee had been brought before the European Union Court of Justice by the end of October 2017 following the resolution decision taken in June 2017 regarding Banco Popular Españal S.A., and 46 complaints had been lodged with the SRB's Appeals Committee.
The Commission and the Council were informed of the 26 cases brought before the Court of First Instance relating to the above-mentioned resolution decision.

EN C 434/28 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE NETWORK OF THE EU AGENCIES The agencies attach importance to the Court's positive conclusions regarding the accuracy of their annual accounts and the underlying accounts.
The Network would like to express its concerns that, given the fact that the Commission only provides them with a basic package of modules in Sysper, the agencies will be forced to do so and will continue to be forced to use separate tools for evaluation, teleworking, flexitime and personnel reporting.
The IT landscape in the area of human resources management will therefore only become partially more uniform and even much less so as the Commission is able to adopt legislation.
The agencies also demonstrated the possibility of introducing a common solution for the services in question in order to support recruitment procedures which are not currently covered by Sysper.
In the field of procurement, there has been a definite trend towards the harmonisation of electronic tools over the last two years.
This development began in the years 2015/2016 when the tools for e-PRIOR/electronic procurement designed by DG DIGIT in cooperation with DG BUDG were developed.
Since that time, this series of electronic modules has become more and more a standard for all phases of the procurement cycle, to which the agencies adhere.▁schädliche-----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
In 2018, this trend continued to deteriorate when new modules were introduced for electronic submission and the ABAC LCK module, and presented to agencies.
In time, agencies are making use of their own isolated tools, some speedily, some less fast, but regardless of how fast this development will take place, the trend in itself is no longer in place.
The proposed increases in efficiency, which could be achieved by transferring accounting tasks to the European Commission, are difficult to achieve in practice.
The required workload not only depends on the balance of the budget, but also on the fact that the annual accounts have to be completed at the beginning of each year in a narrow window of time.
Experience shows that for more than one package of annual accounts (i.e. additional financing via delegation agreements), nearly twice as much personnel is needed, although the corresponding items are smaller (and the number of financial assets is smaller).
In transferring these activities to the Commission, each agency would nevertheless employ an accounting team, since accounting tasks still have to be carried out.
As long as this is the case, any savings in personnel would not correspond to a full-time equivalent.
In addition, the annual fee has to be paid.
For this reason only a few agencies have decided to transfer this task to the Commission.
The network would like to point out that no investigation or risk assessment has yet been carried out to justify the conclusion that the independence of the accountant would be reinforced if it were directly subordinated to the authorising officer and not to an authorised authorising officer.
Some agencies have decided to adopt a charter of accountants, including regulations for reporting to the board, if necessary.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/31 3.1.
We have carried out our audit in compliance with the International Standards on Auditing (ISA) as well as the professional conduct requirements of IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions (ISSAI) of INTOSAI.
Our responsibilities according to these standards are described in more detail in the section ăResponsibilities of the President of our report.

Responsibilities of the management and the responsible for monitoring 3.1.2.
For the purposes of Articles 310 to 325 TFEU and the financial regulations of the agencies, management is responsible for the preparation and presentation of the annual accounts on the basis of internationally recognized accounting grounds for the public sector as well as for the legality and regularity of the underlying accounts.
This includes the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures, as necessary for the preparation and presentation of an annual financial statements that is free from material լ intended or unintentional ▁ferner misrepresentations.
The management of the agencies bears the final responsibility for the legality and regularity of the results underlying their annual accounts.
In the preparation of the annual accounts, the management of the company is responsible for assessing the ability of the agencies to carry out the business, for assessing the facts relating to the continuation of the business, if necessary to indicate the business, and for applying the accounting principle of the continuation of the business, unless the management intends to either liquidate the establishment or discontinue business, or has no realistic alternative to that.
Responsibilities of the supervisor for the examination of the annual accounts and the underlying proposals 3.1.5.
Our aims are to obtain sufficient certainty as to whether the annual accounts of the agencies are free from material misrepresentations and whether the underlying proposals are correct and orderly, as well as to the European Parliament and the Council or other competent relief authorities on the basis of our examination of the accuracy of the accounts of the agencies and the legality and regularity of the underlying proposals.
False representations and interpretations can be intended or unintentional and will be considered essential if, individually or collectively, users could reasonably expect them to make the economic decisions made on the basis of these annual accounts.
3.1.6.
With regard to revenue, we review the grants received by the agencies from the Commission or cooperating States, and assess their procedures for collecting fees and other revenue, if relevant.
3.1.7.
With regard to expenditure, we examine the payment arrangements after the expenditure has been dealt with, recorded and accepted.
Advance payments are carried out after the remedyer has proven their correct use and the agency has accepted the proofs by billing the advance payment in the same year or also later 사.
3.1.8.
As part of a review in agreement with the ISA and ISSAI, we exercise discretion during the entire review process and maintain a critical attitude.
In addition, we identify and assess the risks of essential 極拳 intended or unintended misrepresentations in the annual accounts, as well as significant 理 intended or unintended interests against the legal framework of the European Union in the underlying proposals, plan and carry out trial actions in response to these risks, and obtain evidence of inspection that is sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for our review judgments.
The risk that material misrepresentations or misconceptions resulting from non-doing activities will not be exposed against legislation is more likely than a misrepresentation resulting from misrepresentation, as indiscriminate acts may involve contemplative interaction, fulfillments, intended imperfections, misleading representations, or the imposition of internal controls;
C 434/32 午  Ĺ ulär 以 බල Ɱ Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 we win a consent from the internal control system relevant for the investigation, in order to plan preparatory actions appropriate to the given circumstances, but not with the aim of giving an opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system; we assess the appropriateness of the accounting methods employed by the management, as well as the reprehensibility of the protection values presented by the management in the accounting and related information; we conclude on the appropriateness of the management's application of the accounting principle of continuity and on the basis of the evidence obtained, whether there is a material uncertainty in relation to events or circumstances, the significant doubts about the ability of an agency to carry on its business.
If we conclude that there is a substantial uncertainty, we are obliged, in our note of the final report, to draw attention to the relevant information in the annual accounts or, if this information is inappropriate, to modify our audit judgment.
We draw our conclusions on the basis of the evidence obtained by the date of our final examination report.
We are responsible for the instruction, monitoring and execution of the inspection.
DE 3.1.9.
We exchange views with the management, among other things, about the planned scope and timing of the inspection as well as about significant inspection findings, including any significant errors in the internal control system which we recognize during our inspection.
3.1.10.
We determine the facts about which we have exchanged with the agencies, those facts that were the most important for the examination of the annual accounts of the current period and are therefore the most important considerations.
We describe these facts in our note of the Final Judge, unless laws or other laws exclude the public disclosure of the facts or we determine in very rare cases that a matter should not be disclosed in our note of the Final Judge, because it is expected that the negative consequences of such a communication will exceed their advantages for the public interest.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF ACCOUNTS 3.2.8. In the course of this annual review of EU agencies, the Court analysed the accounting system, including the aspect of the timely (re)validation of accounting systems.
In October 2017, the Agency delegated its accounting function to the Commission's invoicing officer.
Despite this drastic change, the accounting system was last validated in 2011.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.2.9.
In 2011, the agency received an additional task in connection with the monitoring of the energy wholesale market (REMIT).
In 2017, for the first time, all the components provided for in the REMIT monitoring framework were implemented.
However, the site originally set up in Maribor, Slovenia, was relocated to the Agency's main data center for disaster recovery in April 2017 in Ljubljana.
As a result, the backup data is now stored at the same location as the original data.
This means that during disasters there is a considerable risk of maintaining business operations as data could be lost irrevocably. COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.2.10. On 29 March 2017, the United Kingdom (UK) informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit).
Unlike most other agencies, the agency did not carry out a comprehensive analysis of Brexit's potential impact on its organisation, business operations and accounting.
3.2.11.
The Agency publishes job offers on its own website and on social media, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), which would increase transparency and publicity and enable the citizens of Europe to view job offers from the various European institutions and agencies.

It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
The agency had not introduced any of these tools by the end of 2017.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/37 AGENCY REPLY 3.2.8.
The Agency agrees with the outcome and clarifies that the Agency shall record all financial transactions in the financial system provided by the European Commission, updated, maintained and validated by the Commission.
With the outsourcing of service accounting to the Commission from October 2017, the Agency will accept the validation of the accounting system provided by the Commission in 2018.
Since the ARIS primary site and the disaster management site were migrated to the internal ACER data center at the beginning of April 2016 and integrated into a single site in June 2017 to optimize and increase performance and address the growing need for space, the maintenance of operations can no longer be ensured.
However, it should be noted that the current situation, in which the maintenance of the holding cannot be ensured, has been imposed on the Agency by the serious reduction in its budget over the last two years.
The Agency has repeatedly warned the Commission and the budgetary authorities about the serious consequences of budgetary constraints, but without achieving any result in terms of additional resources.
The Agency will continue to demonstrate the ability to restore a disaster management site for ARIS, but without providing the necessary resources in 2018.
Re-establishment of the site for disaster management would require additional financial resources from the Agency.
Given that the risks associated with BREXIT were considered to be low and limited, in 2017, management carried out only an informal analysis of Brexit.
At the beginning of 2018, the Agency published a comprehensive analysis of Brexit's impact on governance, operation and financial areas, highlighting the impact and measures required.
In 2014, the Agency's Management Board adopted Decision AB No 15/2014 on the Agency's language regime.
Nevertheless, the Agency still needs to translate the job advertisements published on the EPSO website into all official EU languages.
Due to the very limited financial resources that the budget authority has repeatedly shown against the budget, the Agency cannot raise the translation costs for each job advertisement in all official EU languages for the publication of this call on the EPSO website.
In 2017, four of the nine job advertisements, including two public calls, were published on the EPSO website and therefore translated into all official EU languages.
The remaining five tenders of positions in operational departments were only published on the Agency's website, as they were mainly of interest to applicants who are already active in the area and who usually follow the Agency's actions on our website.
This approach reflects a pragmatic focus between contact with potential candidates and the efficient use of limited resources.

Experience shows that it is very difficult to organise a training course in the first quarter of a year without transferring funds from the previous year; BEREK's team will therefore be able to work on future training courses later in time.
3.3.11.
The decision for a framework contract was made in 2015.
It is generally considered that it is compatible with the financial regulation since other EU institutions have concluded several such agreements and still closes (e.g. via services provided by travel agencies or banks).
The specific nature of BEREC's activity means that a large part of BEREC's expenditure on BEREC's activities is directed towards BEREC's expertise, mainly from public bodies in the EU Member States (e.g. national regulatory bodies) and on BEREC's activities.
It should therefore be noted that the contractor has no influence on this type of expenditure.
Following the comments and the valuable exchange of views with the Court, BEREC's BTO will also take into account other types of framework contracts that were not provided for under the 2015 regulatory framework when the procurement procedure was reopened.
BEREC's office is taking note of the Court's observations and informs the Court that it intends to implement these modules by the end of 2018, taking into account the Agency's ability to implement appropriate budget appropriations.

The Court considers it necessary to strengthen the independence of the auditor by being directly subordinated to the Director (administrative concerns) and the Management Board (functional concerns) of the Agency. COMMENTS ON THE LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDER ASSESSMENT OF THE PRINCIPLES 3.5.9.
Framework agreements are concluded with companies to determine the conditions applicable during the lifetime of the agreement for certain procurements (individual contracts).
For the award of IT services of up to EUR 22 million, the Agency used a framework agreement with three contractors in the cascade system.
This procedure will place contractors in a hierarchy (the cascade) following a competitive process, which must be respected in all individual cases.
However, the terms of the Framework Agreement were not specific enough to allow fair competition and to justify the establishment of a ranking of contractors for all future individual contracts.
Under the terms of the Financial Regulation(54), the individual contracts must be awarded between the selected contractors by a competitive procedure under these circumstances.
3.5.10.
(55) procurements must be approved by the Board of Directors, either in the Agency's annual work programme or through an ad hoc financing decision.
An IT framework agreement with a maximum amount of EUR 15 million was tendered and signed, although the financing decision covered only EUR 5 million.
In 2014, the Commission concluded a framework agreement on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including EASA) with a contractor on the acquisition of IT hardware and software, as well as maintenance and support services (IT services).
The contractor of the framework agreement acts as intermediary between the agency and companies that can provide the IT services.
Most of these IT services and the corresponding prices were set out in the framework agreement concluded as a result of the competitive award procedure, but the latter is also the source of non-specific IT services.
In the case of a convenient payment about 300 000 euros, the agency had acquired via the contractor IT services without competitive procedure.
In 2017, a total of EUR 2 million was paid to the contractor of the framework agreement.

EUROPEAN CHEMICAL AGENCY (ECHA) INTRODUCTION 3.7.1.
The European Chemicals Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), based in Helsinki, was established by Regulation (EC) No 1907/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council (68).
Its main task is to ensure a high level of protection for human health and the environment and to ensure the free movement of substances in the internal market while improving competitiveness and innovation.
The Agency also promotes the development of alternative assessment methods for substances-related hazards.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/57 Highlighting a case 3.7.5.
Without questioning the judgment of the Court in paragraph 3.7.4, the Court would stress that the Agency is partly self-financed and that it receives a certificate (72) from any company applying for the registration of chemicals, as provided for in the REACH Regulation.
The applicable charges are based on the size of the enterprises (smallest enterprises, small, medium and large enterprises) and the quantity of registered chemicals (various quantitative thresholds).
3.7.6.
As provided for in the implementing regulation(73), the Agency calculates and invoices the fees on the basis of information provided by the enterprises at the time of application.
Since the first registrations in 2009, around 30 % of enterprises have said they are micro, small or medium-sized enterprises.
The agency was using considerable effort to implement a system of ex-post information, which would be used to make the information of these applicants about the size of the company.
The Agency was able to establish that, on the basis of the operations completed so far, about 55% of the above-mentioned enterprises, which according to their own data were micro, small or medium-sized enterprises (16% of all enterprises), had misstated their size, leading to lower costs.
In order to remedy the situation, the agency has charged around 16.4 million euros as a result of ex-post inspections over the years in order to correct expenses.
However, the overruns are considerably reduced, and the remaining amount of necessary allowance corrections was not known at the end of 2017 (74).
This finding shows the constraints of a system which is based in too high a level on the self-explanatory opinions of the applicants.
The REACH Regulation stipulates that the quantity declared by the enterprises is the tasks of the Member State authorities responsible for enforcement.
The Agency is therefore not involved in the implementation of this second element for the calculation of the costs.
Payments Opinion on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts 3.7.8.
According to our assessment, the payments underlying the annual accounts for the financial year ending 31 December 2017 are legal and regular in all essential respects.
3.7.9.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.7.10.
The agency's ex post surveys have shown that for more than half of companies that registered chemicals and reported micro-enterprises, small or medium-sized enterprises, the information on size was incorrect (see paragraph 3.7.5).
This can be partly explained by the Commission's complex rules for determining the size of the enterprise (75) and partly by the financial incentive to specify a too small size, since the registration fees for larger enterprises are far higher.
Since the original registration fees are collected on the basis of the company size indicated, false information can have a significant negative impact on the Agency's revenue if it is not discovered.
Although the agency's designation of size for smaller companies in the context of ex-post inspections, the results are considerably reduced and only completed by 2012 (for years with the largest quantities of registered chemicals).

EN C 434/58 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.7.11.
If errors are identified, the agency will account for the difference between the original fee paid and the final fee, as well as an administrative fee.
On December 31, 2017, the amount to be recovered amounted to EUR 4.7 million, of which EUR 3.2 million was related to excessive administrative fees.
However, the Agency appears to be experiencing difficulties in collecting administrative fees.
In its 2017 annual accounts, the Agency posted a reduction in irrecoverable claims of EUR 2.8 million (i.e. EUR 600 000 more than at the end of 2016).
3.7.12.
The transfer of the quantities declared by the undertakings is the task of the Member State authorities responsible for enforcement; the Agency has no enforcement powers (see the paragraph highlighting a case in point 3.7.5).
The measures taken by the enforcement authorities in the Member States are coordinated by the Forum for the exchange of information on enforcement.
On 6 December 2017, the Forum adopted new strategies and minimum criteria for the enforcement of chemical regulations (ăStrategies and minimum criteria for enforcement of chemical regulations), which provide a framework for the development of national enforcement strategies.
The Agency's ability to fulfil its mission depends on the effectiveness of the implementation of this framework by national authorities.
In its 2017 general report, the Agency states that around two thirds of companies did not update the registered information on the quantities of chemicals they handle.
This concerns the effective implementation of the REACH Regulation and also the accuracy of the calculation of costs.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY EMPLOYMENT AND SERVICES 3.7.13. The Agency publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
OTHER COMMENTS 3.7.14.
The Agency's revenue from fees is linked to the registration periods for chemicals in the EU as laid down in the REACH Regulation (2010, 2013 and 2018).
The Agency therefore does not impose any regular charges and with a misrepresentation between relatively stable expenditures and more fluctuating, less predictable revenues, has to struggle with a misrepresentation, which makes budgeting more difficult.
The Agency is supported in dealing with this situation by a grant it receives from the Commission.
As the third and final registration period for chemicals expires in 2018 under the REACH Regulation, revenue from fees and charges is expected to fall from 2019 and the Agency will be dependent on the EU budget when financing its operations.

In progress (1) In progress Due to pending ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Remarks of the Court The expenditure for procedures related to a new specific activity of the Agency, the implementation of the Ordinance on Biocidal Products, was in principle covered by fees for the evaluation of the findings on registration of these products.
However, the expenses collected in 2014 only covered 17% of this expenditure, so that the rest was actually financed by contributions from the Union (6.3 million euros) and EFTA countries (0.2 million euros) to the budget of the Agency. At 10.1 million euros and 39% respectively (2015: 7.3 million euros and 32%), the rate of committed appropriations for Title III (operational expenditures ) was still high with Title IV (operational expenditures ) biocides, at 1.3 million euros and 68% (2015: 1.5 million euros and 74%).
Such a high transfer rate is in contradiction with the principle of legality. The Agency can, in conjunction with the Agency, use reduced budgetary resources to better accommodate the multi-annual nature of activities as well as inevitable distortions between contract signatures, deliveries and payments.
The ECHA is assisting the functioning of the biocidal and biocidal products market in accordance with the regulation on biocidal products.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that the structure and practical implementation of ECHA's internal control system in relation to the Agency's processes and activities under the Biocidal Products Regulation is effective and efficient.
Although no serious findings were made, the IAS still sees a need for improvement.
Unlike most other agencies, the ECHA's Regulation on the basis of the scope of the declaration does not explicitly require periodic external evaluations of their activities, which are essential for performance assessment.

EN C 434/60 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.7.10.
The relevant legislation (REACH Regulation (EC) 340/2008) does not provide that the Agency should carry out an ex-post verification of the size of all SME registrants.
The Agency's Management Board approved a concept in which SME registrants with the largest financial impact (i.e. with most registrations within the largest volume range) are primarily covered by the scheme.
The agency Ưberpr个ft currently the enterprise size of SME registrants, who submitted their dossiers until 2015. In 2017 the agency also focused on SME registrants from the United Kingdom, in order to increase their enterprise size before the United Kingdom's departure from the European Union.
In the future, we will be increasingly implementing the Agency of SME Sizes on the basis of the cost-benefit principle.
3.7.11.
REACH Regulation (EC) No 340/2008 does not provide the Agency with any tools necessary to enforce the collection of administrative fees.
The Agency proactively reminds debtors of their obligation to pay. If this is not successful, it commissions local law firms to enforce the outstanding fees and charges directly in the Member States.
The law firms have so far contacted 74% of companies that have to pay over-the-counter administration fees. The result of this initiative will then be subjected to a cost-benefit analysis to determine the next steps.
Member States have the primary responsibility for the enforcement of REACH and CLP regulations, in particular the obligation to register chemical substances.
The ability of the agency to fulfil its mandate and to obtain revenues from the fees to an appropriate extent depends on the effectiveness of the practical implementation of enforcement strategies by the national authorities.
Discussions are being held with the Commission to address this problem.
3.7.13.
The Agency takes note of the previous comment, which is a horizontal matter involving a number of agencies.
The Agency publishes job advertisements similar to other agencies on its own website, on social media and on the EU Agency Network (EUAN) website (https://euagencies.eu/).
The Agency recommends that the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO) refer to the EUAN website in order to increase transparency and publicity, and to enable the citizens to look at job vacancies.
3.7.14.
The previous remark is correct.
The Agency shall be financed by a combination of revenue from fees and charges, as well as from a compensatory subsidy from the European Union.
The Agency has submitted a number of alternative financing proposals to the Commission, including the introduction of fees, which are normally incurred, as with some other EU agencies.
The Agency points out that, according to its communication on the revision of the REACH regulation of 5 March 2018 (COM(2018) 116 final), the Commission will implement all possible options to ensure sustainable financing of the Agency in the future.

EN C 434/64 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.9.
EUROPEAN INNOVATION AND TECHNOLOGY INSTITUTE (EIT) INTRODUCTION 3.9.1.
The European Institute of Innovation and Technology (hereinafter referred to as the Institute), which is based in Budapest, was established by Regulation (EC) No 294/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council (82).
The aim of the Institute is to contribute to sustainable economic growth in Europe and to increase competitiveness by strengthening the innovation capacity of the Member States and the European Union.
The Institute receives financial assistance from an increasing number of Knowledge and Innovation Communities (KICs) that link higher education, research and business, in order to promote innovation and entrepreneurship.
The KICs coordinate the activities of hundreds of partners.

Other comments 3.9.7.
In December 2016 ُ shortly before the end of the support period (January 1st 2016-December 31st 2016), the EIT signed changes to its individual financial assistance agreements with the KIC EIT Digital, InnoEnergy, Health and RawMaterials.
The modification of the individual grant agreement with Climate KIC was even signed in January 2017, after the end of the funding period.
The increase in individual reimbursements agreed in these changes enabled the KICs to receive an additional 15 million euros in EIT financial support for Climate KIC, 5.6 million euros for EIT Health, 2.2 million euros for KIC InnoEnergy and 1.2 million euros for EIT RawMaterials, at the same rate as the approved costs.
This approach runs counter to the intention of encouraging the KICs to develop sources of funding and to encourage them to gradually reduce their financial dependence on the EIT.
It could also affect fair competition between the KICs, as co-financing of expenditure also plays a role in the annual grant decisions.
3.9.8.
Also due to changes in the business portfolios of KIC InnoEnergy and EIT Digital, some of the items not planned in the original business plans had been added to the total value of approximately 3.3 million euros and 0.6 million euros respectively.
The Court considers that the activity added in the case of KIC InnoEnergy constitutes a substantial change in the original business plan, on the basis of which the maximum amount of financial assistance was obtained.
Since the amount of the financial assistance granted to each of the KICs is the result of a performance-oriented audit procedure to which their originally proposed operations are subjected, more substantial changes to these plans may be considered to be the grant decisions and equal treatment of the KICs and hence an infringement of Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation.
3.9.9.
COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.9.10.
In 2017, the Institute introduced a paperless payment system.
Although this led to changes in his procedures and his accounting system, the accounting system has not been revalidated since 2012.
COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.9.11.
To further strengthen the internal control system for financial assistance to KICs, the EIT introduced centralised ex ante controls for those KIC partners whose costs exceeded EUR 325 000.
The controls were carried out by two economic operators on behalf of the EIT (86) and led to certified cost statements by the KIC partners.
The results of ex post controls carried out by another EIT-managed business operator confirm that the new approach to certified cost statements is effective and important, as most of the material errors identified involved cost statements that had not been subject to these ex ante controls.
(86) In previous years, the certification was carried out by a large number of private economic operators on behalf of the individual KIC partners, whose submitted cost statements exceeded the threshold of EUR 325 000 (refund of actual costs and unit costs).
EN C 434/66 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.9.12.
The business continuity plan and the plan for re-launching following a disaster recovery plan of the EIT were adopted in 2013 and are outdated.
For example, more than half of the members of the crisis management team no longer worked for the EIT in 2017.
An updated version of the Pl࠳ne has been being worked on for two years, but it has not yet been adopted.
As in previous years, the KICs have not exhausted the grants awarded by the EIT in full.
The accepted FTT total costs of the KIC surplus assets of the FTT, which were functional before 2016 (the first and second wave combined KICs) were 15% lower than those agreed in the early 2016 individual financial assistance agreements (87).
The fact that the funds were not used was mainly due to the ∨ partly due to the late approval of the grant agreements and the multi-year nature of the KIC activities, which necessitated an incomplete implementation of the business plans as well as to the own financing rate of the administrative costs, which was higher for some KICs than planned.
Part of this appropriation has been used to increase the cost for R & D related to KIC value added activities, according to the origin of the individual refund (see point 3.9.7).
Especially the KICs of the second wave (EIT Health and RawMaterials) had to struggle with disruptions when starting their activities.
The performance of Climate KIC in the first wave was particularly insufficient, according to the EIT assessment reports.
3.9.14.
The EIT evaluated the implementation of the business plans and then calculated some corrections.
However, these corrections did not have any financial impact on the KICs.
In line with the Horizon 2020 methodology for the grant calculation, the EIT only applies the higher of the two in the case of corrections necessary due to financial controls and performance assessments.
While this methodology is appropriate for individual Horizon 2020 projects, it is less suitable for the grants awarded to the KICs, which finance a wide range of different activities.
It is questionable whether it is justified to set aside corrections to be made on the basis of performance, e.g. for educational activities, against corrections to be made on the basis of financial controls, which may, for example, affect innovation projects.
3.9.15.
In 2017, all KICs, in line with the EIT guidelines, adopted sustainable financing, which is an important step towards a greater sustainability of KICs in the future.
Nevertheless, the first wave of KICs still generated little revenue (between 2% and 6% of the cost of the KICs' value added activities) and little progress was made in 2017.
The co-financing by the KIC partners is also low (and lower than in the original signed individual grant agreements): the KIC value-added activities are still financed by 62% to 90% of EIT financial aid, depending on the KIC.
3.9.16.
The EIT publishes job advertisements on its own website and on the DG Human Resources and Security website, but usually not on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO).
3.9.17.
In the context of its Framework Financial Regulation, the agencies should establish a single framework for electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (88). As an equivalent provision also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT aggregate covering all stages of public procurement procedures.
It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic call for tenders in the online edition of the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
OTHER COMMENTS 3.9.18.
The current interim director of the EIT took office in July 2014.
A selection procedure for the appointment of a new director was launched in 2016, but remained unsuccessful.
Since then, no new recruitment procedure has been initiated.
To fill this post over such a long period of time ad interim is in contradiction to the statute, according to which a post may be temporarily occupied for a maximum of a year.
3.9.19.
Article 5(1) of the Statute of the EIT shall be directly employed by the EIT staff within the framework of fixed-term contracts and shall apply to the EIT staff the conditions of employment for other servants of the European Union.
The EIT can therefore only offer its temporary staff temporary employment contracts with a maximum duration of five years, which can be renewed by five years.
Those employees who have started working at the EIT shortly after its establishment in 2009 will reach the maximum contract duration of ten years in 2020, which in the coming years could lead to complaints in connection with the continuity of the measures and the administration.

The Institute estimated that its budget requirements for 2014 were too high by 13.1 million euros, or 5.6 % (2013: 3.4 million euros and 2.5% respectively), with the result that only 220 million euros were committed to the 233.1 million available.
The low implementation rate is mainly due to unused funds for grants (11.4 million euros) to finance KIC activities.
The KICs, on the basis of which the grant agreements were concluded, did not have to make full use of the funds available to the Institute for 2014.
The unused funds will be entered in the budget for 2015-2017 in accordance with the financial regulation of the Institute.
Although the KIC strategies must develop a sustainable financing process, to this day they continue to be completely dependent on the funding of the Institute and the KIC partners in the fifth year of their existence.
Since its establishment in 2009, the Institute has had to struggle with a high staff turnover and instabilization at the management level.
Two of the three Head of Unit posts have been vacant since 2013.
One of them has been cancelled ad interim since 2013, which is contrary to the statute, which provides for a maximum duration of one year.
The other currently holds the COO, which is also interim director and thus fulfils three functions at the same time.
In its Special Report No 4/2016, the Court concluded that the requirement under which the EIT contribution to the KICs should not exceed 25% does not provide a significant advantage and that its removal would significantly reduce the burden on KIC partners on operational and financial reporting (4).
However, these certificates are of a very different quality, so that the security that can be derived from them is limited and the Institute must carry out additional controls.
30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/69 DE The Court's comments on the EIT's Framework Regulation include the mobilisation of funds from public and private sources and the use of resources in accordance with the provisions of this Regulation.
In particular, the Institute aims to raise a significant and growing share of its budget from private financial contributions and revenue generated by its own activities.
Despite this provision, which clearly refers to the budget of the EIT, the contribution from Horizon 2020 was 99% of its budget for 2015.
Although the institution may use unused funds (i.e. funds not committed or released at the end of the year) in the budget for the following three years, it has not adjusted its procedures in time to estimate €26.6 million in the budget for 2015-2017 from the 2014 grant agreements.
These funds were available because the KICs used less resources than expected.
According to the Commission's original objective, the Institute should gain its financial autonomy in 2010.
In June 2011, however, the Institute received financial autonomy only in part, as financial assistance proposals and procurement procedures worth over EUR 60 000 will continue to be subject to prior approval by the Directorate-General for Education and Culture (which has been superordinate in the Institute).
The Institute supports EIT Digital's Master School programme, in which 16 European universities participate.
The model for the reimbursement of the costs of the universities is based on a combination of a lump sum of up to 8 000 Euro/students (as per the provisions of the Erasmus Mundus programme) plus the actual costs including flat-rate calculated indirect costs.
On this basis, the universities received an average of 15 000 euros/students in 2015 (including the lump sum).
However, the model was not defined at any point in time, and it is not possible to distinguish which activities fall under the flat-rate amount and which fall under the actual costs.
The Institute should convert the application of costs to a clear and formalised model based on a single method, such as a single lump sum based on proof of costs.

C 434/70 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court's observations Against the principle of sound financial management was violated when another KIC partner ordered public relations services with daily rates of between 800 euros and 3 250 euros per person, refunded by the Institute in full (7).

In these cases, the institute had accepted the direct target or the additional expansions of the applications.

The IAS also concluded that measures should be taken urgently to ensure the reliable application of the framework for Horizon 2020 and to further improve the start-up phase of new KICs.The Institute and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/71 EN Court's observations The grants for the calendar year 2015 were awarded only in April 2015 and the grant agreements were signed in June and July 2015.
For the calendar year 2016, the grants and the signing of the grant agreements were awarded in April 2016.
Despite an improvement in 2016, these erosions in the decisions on the granting of grants and the signing of grant agreements lead to uncertainty and create the willingness of the partners to commit resources at the beginning of the year and to raise the opportunities.
The most recent calls for new KICs, whose thematic areas were defined in the Strategic Innovation Agenda of the EIT for the period 2014-2020, left little competition.
Only seven proposals were submitted for the call for two KICs (Health and RawMaterials) launched in 2014.
Following the 2016 call for two additional KICs (Food and Manufacturing) three proposals were submitted, and the only proposal for KIC manufacturing (additional value in manufacturing) was not selected from the quality standards.
The Director's post has been occupied since August 2014, and another leadership post since February 2013  some ad interim.
Not only does this violate the Statute, which states that the temporary occupation may not last longer than a year, but the frequent change and long-term interim changes also make the stakeholders insecure and affect the strategic continuity. With a budget of 2.4 billion euros over the period 2014-2020, the Institute is an important player in the implementation of the Horizon 2020 programme.
The Commission has set up a central support body for Horizon 2020 to ensure coherence between the project-run bodies in areas such as legal services, IT tools, grant management, dissemination and exploitation of research results, etc.
However, unlike bodies such as the Commission's executive agencies and public-private partnerships, the Institute does not have direct access to the support body, but has to be approved in any case by the Commission's superordinate directorate-general.
This requirement relates to the efficiency of the Institute's activities.

C 434/72 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court's observations The coordination and representation of the KICs is carried out by the legal entities of the KICs, which are financed almost entirely by the Institute.
The Court, in its examination, paid particular attention to the procurement procedures implemented by these bodies, which it considers to be a highly risky area.
In accordance with the 2015 grant agreements, the legal entities of the KICs and/or the KIC partners must ensure that the best possible price-performance ratio is achieved in procurements or that 
For all contracts of more than EUR 60 000, the legal persons of the KICs and/or the KIC partners must, according to the grant agreements, request at least three economic operators to tender and document the award procedure to demonstrate its transparency.
The Court carried out a sample of public procurement procedures worth around EUR 7 million, which were carried out by the legal entities of the KIC and financed entirely by the EIT.
The survey revealed significant margins, such as direct procurement, lack of essential elements in tenders, significant expansions of original interventions with respect to duration and/or scope, increases without limitation of duration and/or scope or quality/price weights, which led to price competition.
The Institute had also identified the angels in the procurement procedures of a KIC legal entity and had drawn up an action plan to improve the procurement procedures of all KIC legal entities in the future.
Despite the substantial increase in the budget from EUR 309 million (2008-2013) to EUR 2.4 billion (2014-2020) and although there have been six and no longer three KICs since the end of 2016, the number of posts approved to the Institute has barely changed (see Table 2).
As the Court noted in its Special Report No 4/2016 (9), there is a risk that the Institute will not have sufficient capacity to address the workload.
The interim director of the institute has pointed to this risk in the annual report of the institute for 2015.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/73 REPLY OF THE INSTITUTE 3.9.7.
The EIT would like to clarify that, with regard to the individual grant agreements under the terms of the KIC Framework Partnership Agreements of the EIT, amendments may be submitted at any time during the period under review.
The KIC's amendments were subject to a technical and financial assessment by the EIT and prior approval by the European Commission.
Subsequently, the changes were signed in December 2016.
In the case of EIT Climate-KIC, the KIC was formally informed of the approval of the amendment request on 21 December 2016 (i.e. within the period of application).
The EIT notes that, with regard to the increase in the individual reimbursements, KICs were not paid out any additional financial assistance as a result of the changes to the individual financial assistance agreements in 2016.
The total amount of the final grant (241.8 million euros) was significantly lower than the initial amount (274.9 million euros).
In response to our reply to section 3.9.15, we would like to draw attention to the call for KICs to develop their own sources of financing and to become financially viable.
In assessing the change agenda, the EIT, after consultation with the European Commission, concluded that the adjustment of the individual refund budgets corresponds to the current legal basis and does not affect the equal treatment of KICs.
The possibility of adjusting the individual refund rates was open to all KICs on equal terms.
As regards the second observation, the EIT considers that the amendments were in line with Article 180(4) of the Financial Regulation's implementing provisions, since they did not call into question the decisions on the award of grants and did not contradict the equal treatment of applicants.
It should be noted that there is no provision for a materiality threshold which shows what change of a measure is to be considered as essential in assessing whether the change is relevant for the benefit of the grant.
Whether the inclusion of new activities corresponds to the provision mentioned above must be established on a case-by-case basis on the basis of the relevance and impact of the activities for the entire KIC business plan.
The EIT carried out the assessment prior to the approval of the change agreement and came to the conclusion that the changes did not call into question the decisions on the provision of financial assistance.
Since each KIC had the power to include, on equal terms, new existing activities in its changed businesses, the equal treatment of KICs was also ensured.
Finally, the EIT points out that in the case of EIT InnoEnergy, the only activity in question was only 3.9% of the modified budget estimate of the KIC budget.
For EIT Digital, this share was 0.6%.

3.9.12.

3.9.13.
The 2016 individual financial assistance agreements with EIT Health and EIT RawMaterials were signed more recently than foreseen, as the framework partnership agreements had to be signed first.
The individual financial assistance agreements for 2017 and 2018 were systematically signed in February, so that the KICs were able to take up their activities in good time each year.
Due to their dynamic and fast-moving nature, innovative measures cannot be planned linearly.
Some innovation projects or projects will not meet the expectations of their potential and will have to be discontinued during the implementation of the grant agreements. Moreover, some of the operational activities of the KICs, such as master and doctoral studies or long-term research and innovation projects, are based on several years.
The EIT intends to address this issue after 2020 by establishing multiannual grant agreements with KICs, provided the EIT budget allocates corresponding funds for commitments in multi-annual tranches.
In fact, the EIT has followed the methodology laid down in the legal basis of ăHorizont 2020, and will continue to comply with the current legislation.
The financial sustainability of KIC is a unique ambition of the EIT-KIC model and one of the most difficult aspects of the EIT's mission.
Meanwhile, some of the innovation communities can already have a serious co-financing with which they are able to compete, and generate considerable revenue compared to their budgets.
EIT Digital decided to co-finance 26% (22 million euros) in order to cover the costs for the 2016 KIC value-added activities. In addition to this, complementary KIC activities of more than 200 million euros were carried out and paid by the partner organisations.
Another example is EIT Health: In its first year of operation, KIC generated over EUR 6 million in revenue compared to the total funding it received from the EIT (around EUR 19 million).

EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR THE SAFETY OF SEA TRANSPORT (EMSA) INTRODUCTION 3.10.1.
The European Maritime Safety Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), based in Lisbon, was established by Regulation (EC) No 1406/2002 of the European Parliament and of the Council (92).
The Agency's tasks include the achievement of a high level of maritime safety, the prevention of pollution from ships, the technical assistance of the Member States and the Commission, and the monitoring of the application of Union legislation and the assessment of its effectiveness.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.10.8.
In 2014, the Commission concluded, on behalf of more than 50 EU institutions and bodies (including the Agency), a framework agreement with a contractor on the acquisition of software licenses and maintenance and support services.
The contractor of the framework agreement acts as intermediary between the agency and companies that can meet the Agency's needs.
For these intermediate services, the contractor of the framework agreement adds up two to nine percent to the supplier prices. In 2017, the contractor of the framework agreement paid a total of 1.7 million euros.
The Agency did not systematically compare the calculated prices and quotations with the offers of the companies and did not systematically examine the invoices issued to the contractor of the framework agreement. 3.10.9.
Following a court decision, the EPSO decided that only job advertisements can be published on the EPSO website in the official languages of the EU or in the languages indicated in the Agency's Greening Act.
Based on the high translation costs of this new policy (about EUR 19000 per advertised post) EMSA  we no longer use EPSO services as well as many other agencies in its job postings.
This point was raised in December 2015 by some agencies against the EPSO.
EMSA would like to see a solution that would provide both sufficient transparency and comply with the principle of sound financial management.
The Agency strives to promote its job advertisements to a wide audience by spreading them to different social media used by many people.
It should be noted that most of EMSA's job alerts are addressed to technical professionals who regularly access EMSA's website.
In 2017, EMSA made extensive preparations for adapting all internal procedures to the use of e-procurement.
EMSA can best argue that since the beginning of 2018, it has introduced the modules for electronic procurement.
The deadline for the use of e-procurement by EU bodies is October 2018.

DE ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Statements by the Court The Agency plans to transfer the administrative staff from Heraklion to Athens in 2016.
The rate of committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year is high for Title II (administrative expenditure) at EUR 0.3 million and 25% (2015: EUR 0.15 million and 22%).
This high rate is mainly due to transfers of funds under Title I (personnel expenditure) and Title III (operational expenditure) and is primarily related to IT investments carried out shortly before the end of the year and the acquisition of a service car.
As foreseen in the Agency's financial rules, external evaluations of the Agency's performance for 2014 and 2015 were carried out; the final reports were submitted in October 2015 and May 2016 respectively.
The 2014 evaluation concluded that the operational core competences under the 2014 work programme were clearly related to the Agency's legal mandate and that the Agency's effectiveness was well assessed.
However, there was a need for improvement as regards the division of the Agency between Heraklion and Athens, which leads to heavy workloads and a lack of communication and cooperation.
The 2015 evaluation concluded that the Agency's activities and outputs meet the needs for network and information security across the EU and in the Member States and that the Agency effectively meets the expectations of its stakeholders.
However, the report stresses that the communication between the Agency and its stakeholders ಉಡುಪಿ whose view is that the mandate and reach of the Agency are too much limited 鼻 needs to be improved.
The Agency is currently implementing an action plan, which it has subsequently agreed with the Management Board.
In 2016, the Agency moved eight more employees to Athens, reducing the number of employees in Heraklion to 14 (1).
As the Court pointed out in its 2013 report, the costs could probably be further reduced by pooling the entire staff at one location.
