AGENCY FOR EUROPEAN GNSS (GLOBAL SATELLITE NAVIGATION SYSTEM) (GSA) INTRODUCTION 3.16.1.
The agency for the European GNSS (global satellite navigation system) (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), the seat of which was moved from Brussels to Prague on 1 September 2012(131), was created by Regulation (EU) No 912/2010 of the European Parliament and of the Council (132) repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1321/2004 (133) on the administrative bodies of the European satellite navigation programmes and amending Regulation (EC) No 683/2008 of the European Parliament and of the Council(134).
The European GNSS Advisory Board, set up under Council Regulation (EC) No 1321/2004, officially carried out on 1 January 2007 all the tasks previously entrusted to the Galileo Joint Undertaking. e Agency continues to carry out these tasks as an agency for the European GNSS, on the basis of Regulation (EU) No 912/2010, as amended.
The Commission also mandated the Agency to operate the European Geostationary Navigation Overlay System (EGNOS) by means of a transfer agreement.

Payments Payments on the legality and regularity of the payments underlying the annual accounts 3.16.6.
Emphasis on a matter 3.16.7.
On 15 December 2016, the Agency concluded a framework agreement worth EUR 1.5 billion on the operation of the Galileo satellite system during the period 2017-2027.
The agreement was awarded following a public procurement procedure.
One of the tenderers involved brought proceedings against the Agency before the Court of Justice of the European Union in order to challenge the outcome of the award procedure.
The judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union will decide on the legality and regularity of the procurement procedure for the framework agreement and all associated individual and future payments.
The Agency reported the situation in its 2017 annual accounts and reported that in 2017 EUR 49 million (7% of the 2017 budget, including the amounts received by the transfer agreements) were paid out in connection with the framework agreement.
Note 3.16.8.
Negotiations on an agreement on the details of the withdrawal are currently under way.
The agency operates both the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) and Galileo ground stations in the United Kingdom.
In the annual accounts, the Agency refers to the Commission's decision, adopted on 24 January 2018, to move the second location of the Galileo Security Centre (GSMC) from the United Kingdom to Spain in the chapter ăEvents after the closing date.
3.16.9.
COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.16.10.
The Agency's headquarters were relocated and its mission was redefined in 2013.
In 2014, the Agency revised its financial rules and delegated its accounting function to the Commission's accountant in 2015.
Although these events have led to significant changes in the Agency's procedures, the accounting system has not been validated again since 2012 (138).

As part of its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform solution for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (139) (140). As a provision is also applicable to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT framework covering all stages of public procurement procedures.
It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic invitation to tender in the online edition of the EU Official Journal (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
The Agency did not use any of these tools at the end of 2017.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/101 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Court's comments The property, plant and equipment (net book value: EUR 1.0 million) are not insured.
The accounting systems were last validated in 2012.
The promised validation of the systems due to the expected major changes in procedures and the flow of information after the relocation of the agency did not take place.
The new accountant is planning the next validation for 2020.
The agency has created emergency plans for the security sites in France, the United Kingdom and the Netherlands.
However, there is no contingency plan for the headquarters in Prague and the agency as a whole.
The Agency's annual work plan for 2015 was only adopted in March 2015, and the adoption of its multiannual work programme 2014-2020 is still pending.
The late adoption of central planning documents entails risks for the achievement of the Agency's objectives.
In 2015, the agency had a high staff turnover with 14 outgoing and 26 new employees.
In its November 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) concluded that no agency-wide annual risk assessment was carried out in 2016 and that the significant risks for the Agency are not identified either in its planning documents or in its activity reports.
The IAS also noted that the terminology used for the various elements of the performance measurement system is not uniform, making it difficult to monitor performance.
The Agency and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures. At EUR 2.8 million and 46% (2015: EUR 2.5 million and 42%), the rate of committed appropriations for Title II (administrative expenditure) was high for the following financial year.
EN C 434/102 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.16.10.
The GSA agrees with the Court's comment.
In 2015, the GSA transferred its accounts to the European Commission, so that the Commission's invoicing officer (within the DG Budget) provides all the services, including the validation of local systems, required by Article 50 of the framework financial regulation applicable to the agencies.
The validation approach is currently being analysed and planned within DG Budget departments.
3.16.11.
There are a number of developments in the field of labour market policy and labour market policy, as well as in the field of labour market policy and labour market policy.
Furthermore, the translation of job advertisements into all EU official languages would mean an additional financial and time-consuming effort for the agency, so that there will also be no benefit from this from the above reasons. Instead, the GSA intends to publish all job advertisements on the agency's cross-border portal, which the agencies consider equivalent to the EPSO and offers the EU citizens a sufficient amount of transparency.
In addition, the agency publishes its job advertisements also on specialized space websites.
Electronic communications in TED (published by the Office for Publications) are currently being used in the GSA for the publication of contract notices, award notices, notices of corrections, alteration notices, etc. whenever this is indicated in accordance with Article 264 of the Rules of Application.
The Agency also intends to use the e-Tendering system TED to create and publish tenders.
Against this background, the GSA is currently coordinating with the Office for Publications to register and create a system account.
With regard to offers of high value (within the thresholds set out in Article 118(1) HO), GSA is currently undertaking the necessary administrative steps to use the ăe Submission module of the information system ăe-PRIOR (made available by DG DIGIT) developed by the European Commission to ensure that the electronic system set up for the submission of all offers meets all the requirements of HO and AB.
It is pointed out that the module ăe-Submission, currently only supports open procedures and that the GSA is therefore allowed to use it only for such procedures.
In this context, the GSA has already held an initial coordination meeting with DG DIGIT and is in the process of concluding and signing an agreement with it to define and start implementing the framework for ăe Submission.

EUROPEAN ENVIRONMENTAL AGENCY (EEA) INTRODUCTION 3.17.1.
The European Environment Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), based in Copenhagen, was established by Council Regulation (EEC) No 1210/90(143).
The Agency's mission is to set up an environmental monitoring network to provide the Commission, Parliament, Member States and, more generally, public information on the state of the environment.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF THE CURRENCY 3.17.8.
In the course of this annual examination of these EU agencies, the Court analysed the accounting system, including the hierarchical position and the independence of its auditors.
The head of the Agency's accountant is the head of administrative services.
BREAKDOWN OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.17.9. The EEA noted that one of the European Topic Centres (ETZs) implemented the action plan for 2016 with considerable distortions.
It therefore did not recognise some of the results and rejected some of the costs claimed by the ETZ.
The correction of the amount of the final payment also indicates that the financial and performance checks have been further improved in relation to the grants granted to the ETZ.
3.17.10.
Several awards have been granted to a number of angels.
The Agency used service descriptions for several calls for tenders, which did not include minimum economic and financial performance requirements for the selection criteria.
These criteria are used to establish the conditions necessary for the execution of the contract, contrary to their objective 藁 so as not to determine whether a tenderer fulfils the conditions necessary for implementing the contract.
3.17.11.
The price competition in some high value tenders was based exclusively on the daily hours offered for certain profiles and not on the expected time required to complete the tasks.
Framework agreements were concluded with only one tenderer, although a renewed call for competition between different bidders would lead to better results in relation to individual bidders.
3.17.12.
In line with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform framework for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (147) (148). As a requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT summary covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
3.17.13.
In particular, the decisions taken in the minutes of the selection committee were not sufficiently detailed.
The criteria used in the various stages of the selection procedure and the role of the individual members of the selection committee must be specified in more detail in order to improve transparency and equal treatment of candidates.
(147) Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1271/2013, Article 79 Electronic Administration (ăe-Government)

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/105 3.17.14.
The agency publishes job advertisements on its own website and in social media, but not on the website of the European Agency for Personnel Selection (EPSO), which would increase transparency and publicity and enable the citizens to view job advertisements from the various European bodies and agencies. The main reason given by the Agency is the high translation costs for EPSO publications, for which translations into all the official languages of the EU must be made.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.17.15.
In order to implement the Copernicus transfer agreement concluded with the Commission, the Agency entered into several legal commitments linked with Copernicus before receiving pre-financing from the Commission.
Although an exceptional report was signed by the Agency's director, this approach is contrary to the provisions of the Financial Regulation.

COMMENTS ON THE ECONOMICITY OF BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.17.9.
The Agency welcomes the fact that the Court wishes to further improve its management of the ETZ in terms of both financial and operational controls.
In order to repeat the problem experienced at the 2017 ETZ, internal, coastal and marine waters, the task in question was taken out of the annual action plan and transferred to the Agency.
The Agency is committed to maintaining the current level of controls on grants granted to the ETZ.
The Agency shall acknowledge that it has amended the requirements for the financial performance of tenderers in the course of 2017 and that the tenderers are now required to provide information on financial indicators (liquid, solvency and profitability) and, in line with the provisions of Article 147(1)(a) of the Rules of Application (AB), a minimum turnover shall be required, at least twice the value of the estimated annual value of the contract.
The Agency would like to stress once again that the decision to offer framework contracts to individual contractors has been taken aware and taking into account the fact that competition is limited to the relevant markets, as well as the nature and complexity of the services to be provided.
When awarding individual contracts on the basis of the framework contracts, the Agency takes into account not only the contractually agreed days, but also the number of days required for the execution of the tasks in order to calculate a value for the budgetary resources required for a specific individual contract.
Only then will negotiations be opened with the contractor on the details of his offer, while always paying attention to achieving the best price-performance ratio.
In the event of a resumption of the tender, the Agency shall not manage any further negotiations on the tenderers' bids.
In accordance with the decision of the Management Board on 9 November 2015 to introduce an E-invoicing programme for electronic procurement procedures in the EEA, in the course of 2014 the Agency introduced e-invoicing for certain procedures and is now in the process of extending the application of this module to all its procedures, whereas the E-invoicing programme has been in force since 1 January 2015 for all general invitations to tender.
The integration of the electronic submission of tenders was started at the beginning of December 2017, and the first call for tenders for this module was launched on 18 June 2018 (EEA/COM/18/002 军 provision of publishing services for the EEA).
The Agency takes note of the Court's observations and confirms that it currently adapts its selection/recruitment procedures to the following points: a) The completion of the individual steps in the various phases (pre-selection, selection, interview and written examination) is confirmed in the relevant documents in addition to the time (not only with the date). b) An electronic (paperless) procedure is introduced in order to improve the reporting process.
3.17.14.
The EPSO has rejected a publication for the Agency with the recognition that the prerequisite that all job offers are to be translated into all official languages is not fulfilled.
However, the Agency does not have the resources or resources to respond to the call of the EPSO.
In this case, not only all job vacancies should be translated, but also the applications should be processed in all official languages, which is associated with unsustainable additional costs.
As with most other EU agencies, the Agency has therefore looked for an alternative to the EPSO website and has been using a website for its announcements since May 2018 that fulfils the same purpose; it is the Job Advertising Board set up and maintained by the EU Agency Network.
In addition, the agency uses LinkedIn, its own website and Facebook pages to ensure the best possible distribution.
EN C 434/108 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.17.15.
Before the conclusion of the transfer agreement for Copernicus with DG GROW, the Agency subsequently pointed out that the conditions for pre-financing are not compatible with the financial regulation (Article 7 AR of the Financial Regulation 2014).
First of all, DG GROW was convincing in its reply, but DG BUDG, responsible for the drafting of the standard template, refused to change the transfer agreement.
After the implementation of the transfer agreement began, the Agency continued to point out the problems and stated that it is regularly obliged to apply exemptions in order to be able to continue its operational activity; this prompted DG GROW to change the pre-financing conditions of the transfer agreement in August 2017 and to make additional pre-financing in November 2017.

COMMENTS ON THE RELIABILITY OF ACCOUNTS 3.19.8.
The Agency delegated its accounting function in 2014 to the Commission's invoicing officer.
In addition, the Agency's headquarters were moved in 2014 and its mission was redefined in 2016.
Although these events have led to changes in the Agency's procedures, the accounting system has not been validated again since 2013.
In December 2016, the Agency concluded a framework agreement with an economic operator with a value of 1.6 million euros and a term of four years on the provision of temporary jobs.
The only competition criterion in the award procedure was the price.
A framework agreement with several companies selected on the basis of price and quality criteria would have been better in terms of timely provision of high-quality services.
3.19.10.
On 29 March 2017, the United Kingdom informed the European Council of its decision to withdraw from the European Union (Brexit).
3.19.11.
The Agency publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but not on the website of the European Agency for Personnel Selection (EPSO), which would give transparency and publicity, enabling the citizens to consult job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies.
3.19.1.12.
In line with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a single format for electronic storage and electronic exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (160) (161). As an equivalent requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT overview covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents on contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).

Emphasis on a point of view 3.20.8.
From the end of 2017, the personnel situation at the B清ro deteriorated exponentially.
At management level, four out of ten Head of Unit posts and 18 out of 27 Head of Division posts were not filled.
In the ăVerwaltung-department three out of four Head of Unit posts and five out of ten Head of Division posts were not filled, which represents a serious challenge for the management level of the B绵ros.
At the end of May 2018, 129 positions were also filled for temporary staff, but 78 were still open.
Of the posts for contract staff, 71 were occupied and 13 were still open.
The B⌘ro currently does not have the administrative capacity to fill so many vacancies (see Table 2).
Overall, the current level of the B.O.R.'s continued activity is considerably affected by this situation.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/119 COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND RULES FOR PAYMENTS AND INTERNAL CONTROLS OF ENTERPRISES The nature of its activities gives rise to major risks for the bank 3.20.9.
Since 2016, the B🇹ro has been facing unprecedented expansion of tasks and activities to provide operational and technical support to Member States in the context of the migration crisis.
This is reflected in an increase in budget appropriations from original EUR 19 million in 2016 to EUR 79 million after the second change in the 2017 budget.
The number of procurement procedures increased from 87 in 2015 to 140 in 2017.
Payments increased by 225% from 2 578 in 2015 to 8 381 in 2017.
3.20.10.
The B氛ro is one of the few institutions of the European Union, which has several locations.
In addition to its headquarters in Malta, with 179 staff members, the B-RO manages two large-scale support actions in Greece and Italy, involving 747 experts from Member States and associated countries, 202 cultural mediators (interpreters), 178 temporary workers and 21 staff members of the B-ROS in 2017.
3.20.11.
As the Court has already stated in its Special Report No 6/2017 ăReaction of the EU to the refugee crisis: the hotspot concept 淯 the B鋝ro in high proportions rejects the provision of sufficient resources by the Member States.
The efficiency of the activities is particularly affected by the fact that Member States send their experts for a very short period of time (six to eight weeks).
The exceptional operational challenge posed by the migration crisis was not weakened by a sound management structure and effective internal controls 3.20.12.
When the activities in support of Greece and Italy were launched in 2015, the country faced the need for Member States to provide insufficient resources for deployments.
The Committee had previously found it difficult to fill the posts provided for in its establishment plan.
Since 2014, the Court has regularly repeated its remark that the B紀ro has to struggle with a high staff turnover.
The Court has repeatedly stressed in its previous annual reports that this situation is a serious risk for achieving the objectives set out in the annual and multiannual work programmes.
Despite repeated attempts (36 recruitment procedures and 100 new contracts in 2017), the B子ro has not been able to recruit and maintain employees (see also paragraph 3.20.8).
3.20.13.
The extraordinary challenge in the operational area caused by the migration crisis was not eroded by a solid management structure.
The Board of Directors did not set up an internal audit post at the B泽ro, and the actions in Greece and Italy were not subject to an internal audit.
By the end of 2017, the Board of Directors had only limited supervision over the budget.
3.20.14.
At the Bዝro is neither an internal legal service nor are legal documents systematically internalized.
The Bếro issues most of the legal questions (mainly personnel and procurement questions) to the outside, without being clearly defined in internal decisions or guidelines, who is allowed to award which legal questions externally, to which law firm and under what conditions.
Although the company draws on at least eight different law firms, it lacks a comprehensive list of all the relevant courts, cases and expert opinions.
3.20.15.
Legal services are not adequately provided by the B➟ro to ensure that they are exclusively used to defend the interests of the B伟ros and not to defend the interests of individuals.
The relevant procedures to protect against conflicts of interest are not always effective.
In general, the use of external assets has reduced the ability to settle disputes before bringing an action.
3.20.16.
The facts described in paragraphs 3.20.13-3.20.14 expose the bank to the risk of financial losses and reputation losses.
These matters are currently being investigated internally by the B垂ro.
Many essential amendments to regulations resulting from the lack of internal controls Payments for auxiliary services 3.20.17.
In 2017, €7.7 million was paid for relief services.
Since no competitive public procurement procedure had taken place, the Court found the order for auxiliary services in Greece to be contrary to the rules laid down for the year 2016.
Nevertheless, the Bʹro made payments of EUR 4.8 million in 2017 within the framework of this illegal order.
EN C 434/120 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 3.20.18.
The procurement procedures implemented in Malta in 2017 for auxiliary services (volume of payments in 2017: 1.0 million euros) were insufficient in their execution (e.g. short deadlines for submission of tenders, lack of transparency in extension of deadlines), making the competition one of the most important reasons in public procurement procedures  prerogatives.
As a result, the procedures had to be repeated several times because no tenders were received.
3.20.19.
The levels of employment were inadequately controlled on compliance with national regulations for temporary employment, which exposed the B觉ro to significant financial and reputational risks.
In addition, there were considerable weaknesses in the supervision of proofs of working time for temporary workers and found irregularities.
Payments for staff expenditure 3.20.20.
The personnel-related payments amounted to 13.5 million euros in 2017. The Court found serious errors in four of the 14 recruitment procedures.
3.20.21.
For example, the B가ro did not publish a job advertisement to fill the post of senior advisor, but did the recruitment directly on the basis of a reserve list drawn up for the post of head of department.
The extension of the deadline was not always justified in view of the number of applications received up to the original deadline.
3.20.22.
Some procedures for hiring AD staff were not suitable for the advertised grade.
In a procedure for filling a management post in the ăVerwaltungs Department, the job posting was more restrictive than for the same posts in other departments.
In another procedure, the examination of the suitability of the applicants was not adequately documented by the B棒ro.
Payments for rents and related works 3.20.23.
The total rent for all Bಬಾಗಲಕೋಟೆros at the different locations amounted to two million euros in 2017.
The Court found that the Bংro had signed the rental contracts for the extension of its head office in Malta and several new B Founders in Athens, Lesbos and Chios, without having previously adequately analysed the local market.
3.20.24.

Travel expenses 3.20.26.

The B尔ro continued to make payments of 1.5 million in 2017 on the basis of this irregular order.
3.20.27.

Other payments 3.20.28.
Other services such as cleaning services, security services, interpreting and consulting services based on public procurement procedures were also systematically affected by the same rules.
The Court identified substantial shortcomings in the determination of needs for the purposes of the contract, the preparation of performance descriptions, the choice of the type of contract, the award procedures applied, the time limits for the submission of tenders, the assessment and award procedures (i.e. the weighting of the price criteria against the quality criteria), the changes and extensions of contracts, the execution of the contracts and the supervision of the services provided.
These rules have an impact on the basic principles of competition, transparency, equal treatment and non-discrimination of bidders.

DE C 434/126 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE BORN The B鲯ro thanks the Court for the very helpful report.
At the same time, the Court is grateful for its appreciation of the first difficult situation that the Court found in the period under review due to the enormous expansion of its tasks: it was also charged with supporting Member States and participating in the implementation of initiatives at EU level; for this purpose, the redistribution and declaration of EU-Turkey, the increase in the budget, the exponential increase in payments and the increase in the award procedures (both in terms of number and complexity).
On top of that, the company is required to manage a large number of sites and many management positions (Heads of Division, Head of Unit, Sectoral Leaders) are not filled.
In his reply, the Court will comment on some of the Court's observations, but in general it accepts the report and the findings contained in it.
3.20.6. and 3.20.13.
With regard to the systematic interpretations against the regulations in the B➥ro, under the new leadership ₩, the B也ro began to initiate the necessary steps to ensure that the observance of the regulations gained priority and became the central element of culture and in the implementation of all its measures.
This includes objective, honest and open internal control, self-assessment.
The Court accepts the Court's statement that the monitoring structures and internal control structures responsible for the Beuro have not received in the past the attention that is required to ensure adequate fairness and regularity.
In this regard, too, the agency would like to state that the structure and procedures for the systematic achievement of lawfulness and orderliness (and correspondingly pr舜zise and comprehensive reporting) will have absolute priority under the new leadership.
3.20.6., 3.20.8. and 3.20.12.
The Court is right to underline the fact that the human resources situation in the B何ro has deteriorated and is insufficient, and that it is also an obstacle to the proper functioning of the internal control system.
The current human resources situation is one of the major challenges in order to resolve the difficulties identified by the Court in its observations, which can largely be seen as a result of the lack of resources for structured and regular work.
The expert is directly addressing this problem and, on the basis of a well-founded recruitment plan leading to a needs assessment, is urgently undertaking recruitment procedures to fill the management posts and other important (operational and administrative) posts.
In this context, although it needs to be taken into account that the low correction coefficient, compared to the relatively high cost of living in Malta, plays an important role in this process, the B堯ro acknowledges that greater efforts must be made to improve employee satisfaction.
Some measures such as flexible work opportunities, improved internal communication and organisation of employee events have already been introduced.
3.20.9. and 3.20.19.
The Court gives a correct description of the difficulties and, expressed in absolute figures, rapid increase in financial transactions and procurement procedures.
These figures speak a clear language, but basically reflect the divergences in finance and not in terms of awarding them.
The following additional facts and measures, in addition to the requirements in the procurement area, remain unconsidered, such as the following two aspects: 捉摸 the involvement of externally funded experts (Articles 204 and 287 of the Financial Regulation), which represent a high workload for the procurement sector.
In the coming years, further deterioration is to be expected in this regard, since the medical expert must be involved in supporting tasks related to medical information about countries of origin.
통 market-specific difficulties and restrictions related to our geographical areas of activity.
In the Italian and Greek regions, conditions for a competitive market for the provision of services and products are not very good.
On top of that, the Bਰਬro is not typical for Malta's economic operators as customers in terms of order size, as they usually lack the capacity to meet the requirements associated with the B花ros' more extensive subsidiaries.

Completed (1) Completed (2) ANNEX Follow-up to observations from previous years Statements by the Court The Court established various regulations affecting the transparency of the advertised procurement procedures, such as the absence of a clear link with the annual work programme of the Centre, insufficient support for the estimated contract value or the lack of a financial benchmark for assessing the tenderer's financial capacity.
In May 2015, the Interim Director of the Centre was appointed by a decision of the Management Board.
As of 31 December 2016, this vacancy exceeded the maximum period of one year by eight months provided for in the Staff Regulations.
This led to 15 other transitional arrangements for other staff.
In its October 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) pointed out that despite the Centre's ongoing efforts to reinforce its internal control of procurement, there are still significant obstacles to procurement.
The IAS concluded that the planning and monitoring of procurement procedures are weak and that procurement procedures are not always covered by the annual work programme or a financing decision.
Furthermore, reference is made to the Court's report on the Centre's 2015 annual accounts and to the findings of the Court of Auditors, which concerned the transparency of the procurement procedures.
The Centre and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
As in previous years, the rate of committed appropriations carried over to the following financial year was high for Title III (operational expenditure) of 7.9 million euros and 41% (2015: 7.5 million euros and 42%).
The financial transfers were primarily linked to several-year projects in the fields of scientific advice (2.4 million euros), monitoring (1.3 million euros), public health training (1.4 million euros) and IT applications for public health (2.1 million euros).
The Centre may request the introduction of separate budgetary resources in order to better meet the multi-annual nature of the activities and inevitable distortions between contract subscriptions, deliveries and payments.

3.22.8.
In order to ensure the independence of the accountant, the formal requirement set out in the EFSA financial regulations will be implemented by EFSA as follows: The current accountant was appointed by the EFSA Board of Directors in 2008.
The accountant is responsible for the head of the BuS department. To ensure the functional independence of the accountant in the procedures for performance assessment, the head of the BuS department functions as assessor and the chairman of the Audit Committee as a counter-signed staff member.
The accounting officer may be suspended at any time by the Board of Directors, either temporarily or definitively.
3.22.9.
On the question of individual invitations to tender for framework contracts awarded in the cascade system, there is no obligation to use the model of individual invitations to tender and both models may be suitable depending on the relevant scenario.
EFSA believes that renewed calls for standard services to be awarded to competition are more appropriate and used in EFSA's statistical services, systematic review of literature and target group research.
EFSA uses the cascade model in the mud when a long-term contractual relationship is in the foreground.
In particular, in the case of the framework agreement for external inspection services, the main objective is (i) to ensure an appropriate understanding of EFSA's activities, (ii) to ensure a cohesive testing method and (iii) to ensure credibility at all administrative levels.
EFSA has control over the budget for proposals made by the contractor in the cascade system.

The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgment. COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDER PROJECT PROJECT 3.23.8.
At the end of the 2017 financial year, the Institute was the defendant in four disputes in connection with three procurement procedures brought before the Court by rejected bidders.
In each of these cases, the applicant applied for annulment of the award decision and for compensation.
The claim for damages in these four cases amounts to EUR 700 000 or 9% of the annual budget of the Institute.
According to the evaluation of the Institute's external attorney, a restitution of EUR 75 000 (or 1% of the Institute's annual budget) was booked to cover the expected losses.
The judgment passed by the Court in each of these cases will decide on the legality and regularity of the procedures for awarding the contracts and future payments.
In 2016, the Institute launched an open call for travel services.
The performance descriptions and the evaluation process did not provide a sufficient guarantee for the best price-performance ratio.
The formula and pricing mechanism were not appropriate as they did not allow for an appropriate evaluation of tenders submitted by the tenderers.
The framework agreement was concluded over a maximum term of four years and a maximum amount of EUR 700 000.
In 2017, payments of EUR 137,000 were made in H£he.
3.23.10.
Under its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a uniform definition for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (180) (181). As a corresponding requirement also applies for the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an IT overview covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents for contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
According to the Commission, by the end of 2017, the Institute had implemented electronic invoicing for certain procedures, but not the electronic tendering and submission of tenders.
3.23.11.
The Institute publishes job advertisements on its own website and on social media, but not on the website of the European Office for Personnel Selection (EPSO), which would increase transparency and publicity and enable the citizens to consult job advertisements from the various European institutions and agencies.

Administration of advisory services 3.24.15.
In the previous year, the Agency's management of advisory services was completed. Amongst other things, two selected projects to implement the Pharmacovigilance Regulation (Regulation (EU) No 1027/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council (189) and Regulation (EU) No 536/ 2014 of the European Parliament and of the Council (190) were selected, which required the development of complex EU-wide networks for the extensive technical IT developments.
Since the number of posts in the agency's establishment plan was not increased, which would enable it to build up the necessary expertise internally, the agency drew on consultancy firms for performing these tasks.
However, the use of consulting firms in a superior way has led the agency to be dependent on this external expertise in a critical manner.
3.24.16.
To get the projects back under control, the agency decided which functions should not be allocated externally, but should be perceived internally.
In addition, the agency goes on to award consultant contracts no longer according to the criteria time and resources expenses, but on a fixed price basis.
It also established a more appropriate procedure for the approval of project changes.
3.24.17.
It will take time to reduce the critical nature of the agency's advisory firms, and the impact of the measures taken will only show up with the years.

These tasks were transferred to the Agency at a time when it was expected to reduce its staff in accordance with the Interinstitutional Agreement on budgetary discipline of 2 December 2013.
The number of posts in the Agency's establishment plan has not been increased, which would allow it to acquire the necessary expertise in business and IT development.
Extensive use of external consultants Since the agency had only over 13 employees in its IT delivery department, it used the services of consulting companies in the areas of business analysis, information technology, project management and quality assurance.
In the second quarter of 2016, 131 consultants and 60 other consultants were present on site for the agency.
Since the start of the projects, the agency has therefore been dependent on external expertise in critical areas, but does not have a strategy that regulates the use of consultants.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/151 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Statements by the Court In 2012, the Observatory signed a framework agreement with a maximum amount of EUR 250 000 to sign individual entries.
By the end of 2015, the total amount of payments contracted under this contract amounted to EUR 382 181, i.e. the ceiling was exceeded by 50 %.
For two framework contracts with a maximum value of EUR 135 000 or EUR 650 000, one of the Centre's staff was involved in the establishment of the evaluation committee, the decisions relating to approval and the signature of the contracts as authorised authorising officers.
However, the delegation of powers granted by the authorising officer was limited to 130000 euros, and framework contracts were not expressly recognized in it.
In 2016, payments of €35, 310 were made at H
In its January 2016 audit report, the Commission's Internal Audit Service (IAS) stressed the importance of improving the management of IT projects.
In particular, IAS concluded that a long-term strategic overall vision for the IT systems supporting the Centre's core operational tasks was lacking, that the Centre's IT project management methodology was only partially adapted to its needs, and that the process for managing system requirements was inadequate.
The Observatory and IAS agreed on a plan for corrective measures.
EN C 434/152 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE OBSERVATION CERTIFICATE 3.25.8. The Centre considers that the current organisational structure has not affected the independence of its accountants.
Rather, this independence was consistently ensured in accordance with the relevant rules, in particular by the appointment of the auditors by the Management Board of the Observatory, the functional reporting and accountability of these auditors against the Board of Directors and the careful compliance with the rules on the separation of the tasks of the various financial actors of the Observatory.
In this context, the Centre is ready to comply with the Court's recommendation, ensuring that the appropriate measures are in a proper position to support the body's scope and that the effectiveness and efficiency of its operation are maintained.
3.25.9.
The Centre will also make its job vacancies known on a standard basis through the dissemination of the members of its governing bodies, the national contact points involved in Reitox and the other EU agencies.
In addition, the next selection process of the Observatory will also be published on the agency's cross-cutting portal for job vacancies; the network of EU agencies has developed this common online platform to make the recruitment procedures of the agencies more public.
In this context, the Centre will publish the cost-benefit ratio of an additional publication on the EPSO portal.
The Centre meets the requirements for electronic procurement procedures in accordance with the EU regulatory framework and the timetable established for the introduction of electronic procurement procedures in the EU.
As early as August 2015, the Centre, in cooperation with the relevant services of the European Commission, set up the technical configuration/ICT tool, which is required for electronic invoicing (and provided by DG DIGIT of the European Commission for the implementation of DG DIGIT's framework services).
In addition, in 2017 the Observatory planned the preparatory measures needed to implement the modules of the electronic call for tenders and the electronic submission of offers according to the specification of the aforementioned legal framework from October 2018.
The implementation of this plan is underway and the Observatory expects it to meet this deadline without any major problems.

EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR THE ESTABLISHMENT OF IT GROSS SYSTEMS IN THE AREA OF FREEDOM, SECURITY AND JUSTICE (EU-LISA) INTRODUCTION 3.26.1.
The European Agency for the Management of IT Systems in the Freedom, Security and Justice Area (eu-LISA) (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), based in Tallinn and located in Stra§burg and St. Johann im Pongau, was established by Regulation (EU) No 1077/2011 of the European Parliament and of the Council (201).
The Agency's central task is the operational management of the second generation Schengen Information System (SIS II), the Visa Information System (VIS) and the European System for the reconciliation of Fingerabdrek-ken (Eurodac).

COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY AND SERVICES 3.26.8. In 2017, the Agency had difficulties in reaching a sufficient number of tenderers in several medium-value procurement procedures.
3.26.9.
The Agency is currently managing three dedicated, non-integrated IT systems (SIS II, VIS and Eurodac), all of which process data on the EU's freedom, security and justice policy area.
This approach could prevent the Agency from achieving economies of scale and synergies between the different systems.
The current revisions to extend the agency's mandate in the coming years to the management of several additional IT systems underpins the increasing urgency of this problem.
The Agency should draw up a detailed cost-benefit analysis, in consultation with the Commission and the Member States, to contribute to a discussion on the future development strategy for the systems.
3.26.10.
The project for the construction of a new building at the site in Stra§burg decreased considerably.
Although the Agency had already paid the full price for construction work in 2016, these were still not completed at the end of 2017 and the progress reports on the work that had been done covered only around 70% of the work.
Part of the agency's staff has already moved into the new building, although the work was still ongoing.
The agency and the contractor blame each other for the delays. In December 2017 the contractor made financial demands on the agency and filed a lawsuit.
The Agency has established its own legal claim against the contractor (205).
3.26.11.
3.26.12.
In line with its framework financial regulation, the agencies should establish a single definition for the electronic storage and exchange of data with third parties involved in procurement procedures (206) (207). Since the relevant requirement also applies to the EU institutions, the Commission is currently developing an overall IT system covering all stages of public procurement procedures. It has launched tools for electronic invoicing (2010), the electronic publication of documents on contract notices in the Official Journal of the EU (2011) and the electronic submission of tenders (2015).
Advice 3.26.13.
The Agency uses consulting services mainly in connection with IT projects due to the nature of its activity.
According to the Agency's records, IT projects were implemented in 2017 within the financial and time frame.
For the few developmental maintenance projects that complain somewhat behind the schedule, exceptional reports were prepared.
(205) See also the Agency's 2017 annual accounts, section 2.1.5 ăEvents after the closing date. (206) Commission Delegated Regulation (EU) No 1271/2013, Article 79 Electronic Administration (ăe-Government),
(207) Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012, Article 95(2) Electronic administration (ăe-Government),
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/155 3.26.14.
The Agency uses a outsourcing model for the development and implementation of IT projects, in which around 90% of the corresponding work is carried out by contractors.
There are three main framework agreements with three consortia, one for each system.
The payments made to these framework agreements in 2017 amounted to EUR 3 million for Eurodac, EUR 16 million for SIS II and EUR 13 million for VIS.
Although all phases of IT projects, from the definition of requirements and milestones to the commissioning of new system components, are owned and controlled by the Agency, a model in which the development capabilities for such sensitive IT systems are outsourced to this extent contains considerable risks in terms of abermeinigen Absängigkeit from the contractors.
This is all the more true in view of the limited number of potential contractors from operational and safety-related areas, which can deal with systems of this size and these requirements.
3.26.15.
At the same time, the small number of staff in operational key offices, in particular in the ăReferat for Application Management and Maintenance (AMM), entails a significant risk for the continuity of the operation.
In the second half of 2017, the head of the Unit AMM previously held the position of head of the Operational Department and the post of head of the ăReferat for operations and infrastructure, thus uniting the three highest management positions in the Operational Division, which entails further risks for the continuity.
3.26.26.
The framework agreements concluded with each consortium for the operation of the main IT systems include not only normal maintenance, but also developmental maintenance work, the price of which cannot be calculated on the basis of the cost estimates attached to the framework agreements.
The prices for the individual units are calculated by the Agency on the basis of a combination of fixed price and estimates of the time and resources involved, which is aimed at a sound cost control.
For the VIS contract, the agency also relied on the IFPUG(208) method, a standard method based on the function point analysis to determine prices for developmental abilities.
The agency could also use the IFPUG method for other systems in development.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.26.17.
The Agency made global commitments totalling 69.9 million euros to cover future expenditures for new tasks and IT systems that were originally to be transferred to it in 2017, but for which the legal basis had not yet been adopted by the end of the year (Eurodac recasting and allocation system to Dublin) or only recently (Regulation on the Entry/Exit System of 30 November 2017).
The corresponding appropriations for payments were reduced by two amending budgets amounting to EUR 85.6 million, from EUR 153.3 million in the original budget to EUR 85.6 million in the final budget.

The Agency besties the high participation of external contractors in IT projects (operational and organisational).
This high outsourcing rate is directly linked to the Commission's Communication COM(2013) 519 on financial and human resources planning for decentralised agencies in the period 2014-2020.
In 2012, the establishment plan did not provide sufficient posts for the scope of the tasks entrusted to it.
In addition, the size of the Agency's tasks was considerably increased from 2013 onwards, but its requests for additional staff were rejected and the Agency had to reduce its staff, as requested by the Commission communication (a total of seven posts).
In order to ensure a proper separation of tasks, the contractors involved in quality assurance do not provide external support services for the operational management of IT-Group systems.
The agency embodies the extraordinary situation in which a member of the staff had to carry out temporary additional tasks.
The appointment was forced due to the long absence of the head of the operational department and the ongoing recruitment process for the further free leadership position.
In order to remedy the situation, the Agency appointed another staff member, the head of the ăSecurity Unit, as head of the ăOperation and Infrastructure Unit, until the newly recruited leader began to work on 1 July 2018.

EN C 434/168 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.28.8.
More than 220 liaison officers from EU Member States and third countries and organisations are employed in Europol.
The common working language of Europol is English. Therefore, Europol's internal language rules adopted by the Management Board set out that, unless otherwise agreed, recruitment procedures should be carried out in English.
This is why Europol's job advertisements are published in English.
Europol has implemented an effective and transparent recruitment process with a vacancy rate of 0% at the end of 2017. On average, 58 candidates per selection process were involved in the 89 recruitment procedures carried out in 2017.
For publication on the website of the European Personnel Selection Office (EPSO), the English version requires translation into the EU official languages.
Due to the high number of job vacancies per year, translation into EU official languages would incur high costs and the duration of procedures would be longer.
Europol focuses on operational needs in budgetary expenditure, so that job vacancies are translated into all EU official languages, including EPSO publication, only in certain cases (e.g. the Executive Director or Deputy Executive Directors).

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/173 3.30.
EUROPEAN AGENCY FOR FRONTEX INTRODUCTION 3.30.1.
The European Agency for Border and Coast Guard (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), was established by Regulation (EU) 2016/1624 of the European Parliament and of the Council (228) (the new Regulation on the protection of the environment), repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 2007/2004 (229).
It was expanded by the European Agency for Operational Cooperation at the external borders of the Member States, maintaining the abbreviation "Frontex" and the Warsaw headquarters.
The new establishment regulation extends the agency's mandate, and gives the agency the task of providing for an integrated border management at the external borders at European level in order to manage efficiently the crossing of external borders.
This includes the fight against migratory pressure and potential future threats at these borders, while at the same time contributing to the fight against serious criminality with a cross-border dimension in order to ensure a high level of internal security within the Union, while fully respecting fundamental rights and respect for freedom in this area.

Note 3.30.7.
The Agency's expenditure for financial assistance increased significantly from EUR 123 million (2016) to EUR 167 million (2017).
Unlike in previous years, the Agency did not subject the reimbursement of expenditure related to financial assistance in 2017 to ex-post controls.
It considers that the ex-ante checks carried out prior to reimbursement have been improved and now as soon as they reach a certain date, they provide the necessary security.
However, since 2014, the Court has repeatedly reported that the cooperating States often do not provide adequate evidence of the expenditure they have claimed, which was again the case with this annual exercise (see points 3.30.12-3.30.13).
3.30.8.
In 2016, the Court recommended that the Agency establish the most appropriate financing mechanism in an in-depth analysis (233).
In this context, the Court notes that the Board of Directors decided at the end of 2017 to use reduced unit costs instead of reimbursement of actual costs for operational activities.
At the same time, a pilot project was launched in 2018 to determine unit costs for funds sent by cooperating states.
In addition, in June 2017, the Management Board approved a new organisational structure for the Agency, which will take effect from 2018 and will include the creation of a new inspection and control body, which will report directly to the Executive Director and the Management Board in order to adapt the existing organisation to the new mandate (see point 3.30.9).
3.30.9.
In view of the migration crisis facing the Union, the mandate of the Agency was significantly expanded in 2016.
The Agency's budget was increased by 75% in 2016 and the budget for 2017 was again 21% higher than in the previous year.
Personnel increased by 18% in 2016 and by an additional 43% in comparison with the previous year.
The adaptation of the systems and procedures to the new mandate and the new circumstances is still in progress.
The following remarks do not call into question the Court's judgment and are to be read against the background of the challenges the Agency had to address.
COMMENTS ON LEGAL ACTIVITY AND ORDERAL PROVISION 3.30.10.
Following an open call for proposals, the Agency received four offers on guidance services for the promotion of migrants within Greece.
Following the selection criteria, three offers were retained and one was excluded.
The only criterion for the award was the price.
In April 2017, the Agency signed a framework agreement of EUR 2 million for a three-year period with the car manufacturer, which had offered the lowest price.
However, the contractor's training capacity was limited from season to season and he had problems to complete the order, so that the agency started the order at the end of 2017.
To ensure continuity of services, the Agency signed for the remaining period a new framework agreement of €1.8 million with the second highest bidder in November 2017 who had offered the second lowest price.
It did not negotiate the terms of this replacement contract with the bidders in second and third place, but signed the new contract on the basis of the original bid submitted by the second-placed bidder.
The direct award of the replacement contract was illegal because the original award procedure was completed and a negotiated procedure for agreeing the terms of the contract, which would apply until the conclusion of a new open procedure, did not take place.
No payments were made for this replacement order in 2017.
3.30.11.
The Staff Regulations provide that in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff shall be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (234).
In 2017, the Agency hired two staff (2016: 14) in higher AST grades.

EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/175 COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.30.12.
In 2017, the agency of the Islamic guard obtained financial support in connection with the deployment of an aircraft in Greece.
Before reimbursement of expenditure claimed by Iceland, the Agency requested invoices as proof of a category of expenditure declared.
Although the invoices were never presented, the Agency reimbursed around EUR 440 000.
In this case, the ex ante superlative was therefore ineffective.
3.30.13.
The Agency also co-financed the use of an aircraft used by the Spanish Guardia Civil.
In the absence of documents for the costs claimed for inspection and maintenance work, the Agency reimbursed 430 000 euros on the basis of average costs per flight hour.
These average costs were calculated on the basis of cost ceilings used in exchanges between the Spanish authorities and private contractors for inspection and maintenance work.
There is a risk that higher costs have been reimbursed than actually incurred.
3.30.14.
Although the Agency has already moved into its current accounts in 2014, it has still not drawn up a comprehensive contingency plan approved by the Management Board.
COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The Agency again cancelled a large amount of committed funds transferred from the previous year to cover expenditure incurred by States participating in joint actions, i.e. EUR 7.7 million and 16.5% (2016: EUR 5.6 million and 17.6%).
This shows that the cooperating States had again clearly overestimated the expenditure to be reimbursed by the Agency.
Although funds transferred for joint actions had to be cancelled in two consecutive years, in 2017 the Agency transferred an amount of 9.6 million euros from other budget lines to joint actions, once again transferring an amount of 40.5 million euros to the following financial year.
Joint actions represent 69% of the total amount cancelled in 2017 (EUR 11.1 million) and 46% of the total amount transferred in 2018 (EUR 87.6 million).
3.30.16.
In 2017, 66.5 million euros were made available for return operations. However, fewer actions were carried out than funds were available.
The Agency therefore paid the Commission 13.5 million euros and 20.3% (2016: 23 million euros and 37.5%) back.
In addition, the agency paid EUR 4 million of the budget for Title I of the budget (staff expenditure) to the end of 2017 because it was not possible to hire as many new staff as planned.
3.30.17.
The Agency's original budget for 2017 amounted to 8.8 million euros for the operational financial deficit required for the financing of immediate arrivals for border protection purposes and return operations (235).
However, in September and again in October 2017, the agency transferred 1.9 million euros each (in total 3.8 million euros) from the repo to its operational budget to finance other activities.
3.30.18.
After the implementation of transfers from other budget lines and the establishment of an amending budget, the appropriations allocated to the reduction amounted to 24.7 million euros and 8.1% of the original budget.
However, the Agency used the revision mainly to finance standard operations (8.4 million euros) and to finance a project for remote controlled air surveillance (drones, 7 million euros), for which it had estimated only 1.1 million euros.
The estimates and use of non-mandatory complaints are incompatible with the principle of speciality's budget and undermines the transparency of the budget.

C 434/178 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN Court observations The Internal Security Fund was established for the period 2014-2020.
It includes two instruments: the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, and the instrument for financial support for police cooperation, which provides EUR 2.8 billion (for external borders and visas) and EUR 1 billion (for police cooperation) for funding projects.
Under the instrument for financial support for external borders and visas, the Commission shall reimburse Member States for the cost of equipment such as vehicles or ships, as well as operating costs such as fuel or maintenance costs.
The Agency shall also reimburse the participants in joint actions for such costs.
There is therefore a risk of double financing (4) which is not taken into account.
In border regions participating states, the costs incurred are calculated on the basis of cost specifications, which include ăFix costs (depreciation and maintenance costs), ăvariable expenditures (mainly fuel) and ăEmployment costs (mainly expenses and other expenditures for crew members).
The reported costs are based on actual values and correspond to national standards. The approaches of the participating states therefore differ from one another, which leads to a particularly complex system for all participants.
In its Special Report No 12/2016, the Court recommended that agencies make use of simplified cost options whenever this appears appropriate to avoid such inefficiencies (5).
The Agency's previous certification regulation, which runs until 5 October 2016, provides for the financing of joint implementation operations carried out with participating countries.
However, from January to October 2016, the Agency financed national reverse actions with an amount of EUR 3.6 million.
These payments are non-compliant.
The Staff Regulations provide that, in the case of an external selection procedure, temporary staff shall be recruited only in grades SC 1 to SC 2, AST 1 to AST 4 or AD 5 to AD 8 (6).
In 2016, the Agency hired 14 staff in higher AST grades.

COMMENTS ON INTERNAL CONTROLS 3.30.12.
The costs for inspection/maintenance work are defined as the costs for all inspection/maintenance work during the entire service life of the agent (...).
Rate on the basis of the data provided by the manufacturer or the service point of the holder using the means.
This means that the hourly rate may be expressed in the form of a cost explanation for the eligible persons, either on the basis of the manufacturer's estimates or on a price calculated on the basis of the actual costs incurred in previous years, or on a cost estimate, using reference data for similar means of use, if it is a new means of use and no data are available.
Invoices (or equivalent booking documents due to the amount of data) can only be made available if the hourly price is based on the actual costs incurred during the reference year.
However, the recipient also has the possibility to set an hourly rate on the basis of average reference prices if no invoices were actually issued.
This was the case with the selected payment, although the Icelandic coast guard Frontex presented a bill of the cost of maintenance.
The documents submitted by the Icelandic K Choir Guard include the results of the ex-post controls carried out by an ex-post control team of Frontex in 2015 during a visit to the maintenance centre in Iceland, in which the team had carried out the documents provided by the Icelandic K Timber Guard, which were used as a basis for their calculation methods.
The document submitted by Iceland therefore provides sufficient grounds for approval of the edition in Frontex's view.
The total amount of an hourly rate for all inspection/maintenance work of an aircraft with fixed wing is the result of three operations with special regulations: 拾 Maintenance of the engines 准 The signed contract provided for a maximum amount of 9 010 475.50 EUR; however, the payments are based on the hourly rate for the maintenance of an engine.
The Guardia Civil calculates Frontex according to the contractual requirements the hourly rate for engine maintenance.
If less time is spent on engine maintenance, the overall limit is not reached.
Therefore, in this case, the hourly rate is not relevant to the total value of the contract.

COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY CURRENCY 3.30.15.
The major challenge is related to the ability of commitments during a given year.
To avoid the risk of high cancellations, Frontex also asked the members of the group to submit their submissions in the fourth quarter of 2016, which ended in the first half of this year, and to send forward their comments to the Group for final payment of the total amount of the amount due and to report to the Board of Directors in the course of the operational activities 2016 (December 2016) or planned investments (January 2017) in order to avoid the risk of high cancellations in the fourth quarter of 2016.
The main objective of these calls was to identify possible over-implementations, reduce the corresponding SFD allocations and to re-use the funds in 2016.
Despite some positive results of this action, the transfer of funds was still high.
Consequently, despite a proper estimate of actual financial needs, Frontex required additional resources to ensure the financial coverage of the operations in the autumn of 2016, since the cancelled funds of the ceased and ongoing operations were not available at that time.
The Agency has developed a simplified support scheme, which will be implemented from the 2018 operational cycle, and which will apply significantly higher cost for additions of up to one year; the Agency will not only step up the monitoring of the implementation of grants, but will also strive to reduce the cancellation of transfers.
Reduction In spite of the repayment of funds to the Commission, the main objective of the Agency in relation to the recovery operations was achieved: it provided Member States with technical and operational support for the implementation of recovery operations and implemented specific measures aimed at the pre-return period (to identify returnees, training/training, exchange of knowledge between Member States, etc.).
In 2017, the number of return actions coordinated by Frontex increased significantly: with an increase of 47% over the previous year, the number of migrants increased from 10 700 in 2016 to 14 200 in 2017.
This represents an annual 10% share of the total number of migrants actually repatriated from the EU to third countries (in 2014 the corresponding figure was 2%).
Recruitment Repayments of staff expenditure were mainly due to the difficulties and the associated refusals in the recruitment process: lengthy procedures, long deadlines for application, insufficient number of applicants and a lack of geographical balance due to a low correction coefficient.
Nevertheless, the Agency believes that it is a success that more than 250 new employees have been recruited and trained within one year.
EN 30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/183 3.30.17.
2017 was the first year of implementation of the new EC CFC Regulation for the Agency.
Article 75(13) obliges the Agency to add to its budget an operational financial reduction of 4% of the appropriations earmarked for operational measures in order to finance emergency measures for border management purposes (RABIT) and return operations.
On 1 October each year, at least a quarter of the reduction should remain available, in order to meet any demand that may occur until the end of the year.
The required operational reserve was introduced so that the agency can manage a certain reserve for the implementation of immediate attacks for border security purposes and for the coverage of the appropriate costs of such an emergency operation at any time during the year.
The European Parliament had amended the original text of the ECC Regulation proposed by the Commission to add that by 1 October only a quarter of the revenue for the remaining three months of the year must remain available.
The ECC Regulation remains silent on what is to be done with the remaining three-quarters of the deficit after 1 October; this point is unclear.
The first transfer at the end of September was intended for the financing of strengthened operational measures in the air and at sea and the acquisition of own air monitoring services; the second transfer took place after 1 October.
The Board of Directors was informed in the monthly report on transfers.
The Agency considers that the legislator should provide clarity.
The unrestricted situation had already been envisaged during the preparations for the Single Programming Document (SPD) 2017-2019.
In accordance with Article 75(3)(ff) of the ECC Regulation, the preparation of the SPD and the estimate of revenue and expenditure was started in N-2 and concluded in late autumn of N-1.
The ECC Regulation entered into force in October 2016.
The Agency had to plan the detailed annual work programme 2017 (as part of the SPD 2017-2019) for the whole year 2016 without any final result of the deliberations on the ECC Regulation and thus without a clearly defined legal basis.
Towards the end of 2016, the SPD 2017-2019 was already completed and was ready for approval by the Board of Directors, which fully supported the creation of the unmandated reserve in view of the transition to the European Border and Coast Guard.
The Commission stated in its opinion on the SPD 2017-2019, (C92016)8722, in paragraph 63: ăThe Commission considered that emergency planning has become a guiding principle for the preparation of the annual work programme and that the Agency intends to provide almost 10% of its operational budget for the so-called "operational flexibilitό (...)".
In this context, the Commission calls on the Agency to set up two separate actions within its budget, the first fully in line with Article 75(13) ECC Regulation and the second offers the possibility of maintaining operational flexibility in order to deal with emergency situations which do not involve immediate action.

After the signing of an agreement with the Commission (DG DIGIT), the instrument will be applied for the first time.

C 434/186 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 EN ANNEX Follow-up to comments from previous years Court observations In 2016, an external evaluation of the Foundation was carried out on behalf of the Commission.
This was the first step in a cross-cutting evaluation of the four agencies involved in employment, social affairs and integration(1).
The evaluators concluded that the significant restructuring of the Foundation has not had a significant negative impact since 2011 and that the results of the internal and external stakeholders are primarily positive, in particular with regard to strategy and effectiveness.
The management structure of the Foundation was considered efficient and effective.
The evaluation also stresses that the Foundation has improved its monitoring capacity since 2011 and that it needs to present its achievements and achievements even more clearly.
The harmonisation and simplification of indicators in a single intervention logic and the use of common terminology throughout the Foundation would contribute to an improvement.
The Foundation drew up a plan to implement the recommendations of the evaluators.
In his report on the Foundation's 2011 financial statements, the Court stressed that the situation regarding the Foundation's rhymes is unsatisfactory and that there is a risk that the Foundation will not be able to carry on its activities continuously.
The situation has remained unchanged since the consortium responsible for the management of the building complex, which used some of the rationalities in the complex itself, was completed in 2011 and left the corresponding Rume empty§.
The Member State where the Foundation is based urgently needs to find a solution to this problem.
The Headquarters Agreement guarantees adequate circumstances up to the year 2027.

EURATOM SUPPLY AGENCY INTRODUCTION 3.32.1.
The Euratom Supply Agency (hereinafter referred to as the Agency), based in Luxembourg, was established in 1958(244).
Council Decision 2008/114/EC, Euratom(245) replaced the previously applicable Statute of the Agency.
The main task of the Agency is to ensure regular supply of nuclear materials to EU users, in particular nuclear fuels, in accordance with the principle of equal access to sources of supply through a common supply policy.
3.32.2.
From 2008 to 2011, the Agency was not allocated its own budget to finance its activities.
From 2012 onwards, the Commission has provided the Agency with its own budget, but it covers only a small part of its expenditure.

In 2017, procedures for awarding and awarding grants were not adequately documented.

3.34.7.
In 2017, the Office cancelled EUR 3.2 million and 15.9% of the committed appropriations carried over from the financial year 2016.
The Office continued to use fixed prices for services (258).
The prices used in the different services are based on unit prices (price/person's day, etc.) set out in the framework agreements and the number of units allocated to the service concerned.
The Office will ensure that unit prices are correctly applied in the course of the review of the contractor's price offerings.
3.34.10.
However, the list of services to be provided in connection with the framework agreement was not exhaustive in the case of a framework agreement with a value of 80 million euros on general consultancy, consultancy and project management services as well as studies.
In order to assess the offers, the service descriptions contained two business cases relating to the management of a project and a multi-project programme.
This framework agreement is a mixed multi-framework agreement, partly using a cascade procedure (general advisory and project management services) and partly a renewed call for competition (praction and studies).
The audited units were predetermined by the Office, but bidders were asked to determine the distribution between the different profiles.
The framework agreement and also some of the related individual agreements were therefore advertised on the basis of unit prices, types of profiles and quality, but not the estimated number of benetigte units, which is another essential element in the calculation of a fixed price contract.
3.34.11.
The framework agreement involved a single contract with a fixed price of EUR 145 447.50, which mainly concerns the provision of support services for the execution of a document management project.
The person days required for the provision of these services cannot be derived either from the business cases described in the service descriptions or from the description contained in the individual contract.
A fixed price as defined in this particular order therefore poses a risk that the services will not be provided in the most economical way.
3.34.12.
If not all the conditions for the provision of services for the award of the framework agreement can be established, the individual agreements will be more appropriate to reopen competition among several contractors of the framework agreement.

30.11.2018 Official Journal of the European Union C 434/197 EN Year 2016 Progress of the correction (completed/in progress/outstanding/n.e.) Completed (3) ANNEX Follow-up of comments from previous years Court observations The Office's budget implementation rate was low at 89%, suggesting an inaccurate estimate of its expenditure in the 2016 budget.
As a consequence of the most recent changes to the agency's regulation and financial regulations, it has become more important that the Office, if necessary through an amending budget, draw up an accurate budget, as mechanisms linked to budget estimates, such as the allocation of appropriations to a fund for actions(1) and a corresponding compensation mechanism (2), are now foreseen.
In 2014, the Office launched a call for tenders for a four-year framework agreement on a protected market volume of EUR 30 million to provide advisory services covering a wide range of activities, including expert services, project management, general advisory services and studies.
However, the procurement procedure and the subsequent use of the framework agreement were partly not adequately managed.
The objectives and the ongoing activities had not been set precisely enough to ensure that the volume of the framework contract were accurately estimated.
Therefore, the funding of the framework agreement had been exhausted completely after only two years and six months.
Moreover, despite the diversity of the services to be procured and the very different expenditures of each activity, no lots had been used.
The use of lots would encourage smaller companies to participate in the low value process.
Finally, the price competition was neutralised and the discretion granted by the contractor, since fixed price offers were requested by a single contractor using the framework agreement.
The Office should seek to reach agreements with several suppliers and, if necessary, to reopen competition.
The Office's declaration states that the translations required for the Office's work are made by the Translation Centre for the Bodies of the European Union (CdT), which leads to the fact that the Office is the Centre's principal customer.
The Office is increasingly using internal solutions such as linguistic and translation memory as well as additional software.
These instruments are designed to improve the cost-effectiveness and cost-effectiveness of the Office.
However, from the perspective of the European Union, the current situation could lead to a doubling of expenditure and corresponding costs.

(2) Article 139(4) and (6) of its Decree establishing the Office shall, each year, compensate for the costs incurred by the holders of industrial property rights of the Member States, the Benelux Office of Intellectual Property and any other relevant authority to be designated by a Member State as part of the specific tasks it carries out as functional components of the European Union's trade mark system under various services and procedures; this obligation shall apply only to the extent that no budget deficit arises this year.
