DE C 434/98 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE OFFICE'S COMMENTS ON BUDGETARY SURVEILLANCE 3.34.8.
While the cancellation rate is just over 15%, the amount of cancelled committed transfers is the lowest of the last ten years (since 2008) at EUR 3.2 million.
The Office continues to work with the national authorities to reduce the cancelled transfers by means of interim reports on implementation and half-yearly inspections with reinforced control measures, which are an integral part of each new cooperation agreement.
Further measures were also implemented internally, such as awareness-raising measures through coaching, training, information notes and meetings with financial actors.
Furthermore, before the end of 2017, the Office expected that 15% of the cancelled transfers would be overrun and proactively took additional measures to reduce transfers for the next year.
The Office took note of the Court's observations.
In advance, it should be noted that the scenarios described in the procurement documents for the future use of the contract were aimed at being as vivid and representative as possible and were not expected to be linked in detail to each specific contract.
As regards the appropriateness of the re-opening of the competition mechanisms and as stated in the Office's response to the 2016 audit, this concept has already been introduced in the expert framework agreement on audits and studies.
The Office has compared the added value of this mechanism with the related administrative costs and, given the Office's intensive use of advisory and project management services, has concluded that this is not the most efficient way to manage the latter types of activities.
Taking into account the fact that the current framework contract will be valid until 2020, the extension of this mechanism to advisory and project management services at this time would require a new call for tenders, which the Office does not consider appropriate.
In the existing cascade system for consulting and project management services, the Office repeats the answer to the 2016 audit on the use of fixed price procedures.
The main reason for choosing this option is that proceedings against the Office before the Spanish labour courts are relevant in relation to a misrepresentation of employees, which are inter alia related to the use of the previous ăTime and Means.
The Office has experience in the evaluation of offers during the fixed price process (under the cascade system).
The EUIPO has set up a specific team, which is able to draw up the resources necessary to fulfil the tasks behind the fixed-price performance, on the basis of previous practice and expertise.
However, we believe that the Court's concerns can be addressed by other contractual methods than the ăfixed prize, e.g. by means of the ăQuoted Time and Means [A method] which the Office could use in the future, according to individual cases.
The Office undertakes to provide further information and to document its own estimates of the resources required to carry out the tasks of fixed-price services before issuing the request for information in order to provide proof of the above-mentioned experience of the Office in advance.

Emphasis on a point of view 3.35.9.
Without questioning his judgments in paragraphs 3.35.6-3.35.8, the Court would like to stress that the contributions to the Fund are calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Committee by credit institutions (and some investment firms).
The Court relied on this information when examining the Committee's revenue, but did not exercise its powers.
The SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework to ensure that the information is reliable.
In addition, the Committee cannot provide details of the contributions per credit institution calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, as the calculations are not available and include confidential information about other credit institutions.

EN C 434/204 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE COMMITTEE 3.35.9.
The annual contributions to the Fund, collected in advance, shall be calculated on the basis of the information provided to the Committee by credit institutions and certain investment firms.
Although the SRM Regulation does not provide for a comprehensive and uniform control framework ensuring the accuracy of this information, the SRF pays any attention to this aspect.
The data provided are compiled on the basis of the data transmitted by the institutions in the previous year and the data contained in the ECB database.
Deviations are reported to the national resolution authorities who are asked to clarify the facts. Thus, it was possible for the SRF to improve the quality of the data in the previous cycles.
Furthermore, the Committee cannot disclose any details of pre-institutional contributions calculated on the basis of a risk assessment, since the calculations are not available and therefore confidential information about other institutions would be disclosed.
The SRF has, however, disclosed the calculation method and detailed calibrations to ensure transparency and cooperation.
3.35.12.
In 2017, the financial team's capacity was not sufficient to ensure the efficient handling of all financial resources, including invoices, due to a combination of unexpectedly high workload, unfortunate staff turnover in the financial team and general difficulties in finding experienced employees.
Since the fourth quarter of 2017, the team's capacity has been strengthened and measures have been taken to ensure the timely processing of invoices.
By this date, nearly 98 % of the invoices had been settled within the set deadlines in 2018.
Every case of late payment is now being carefully investigated in order to achieve further improvements in this area.
3.35.14.
The SRB's 2017 procurement plan was adopted in 2016, when the Committee was only in its second full year of existence.
At that time, no resolution cases had been dealt with and the Agency had little experience on the basis of which its procurement plan could be drawn up.
As a new agency, the SRB was able to use various interinstitutional frameworks managed by the European Commission.
This led to the fact that several procurement procedures, which were to be initiated by the SRB in 2017, were ultimately not implemented.
In 2018, the implementation of the procurement plan will be closely monitored and additional efforts will be made to improve the planning of procurement procedures.
In 2017, the SRB spent a total of EUR 20 million on providing legal advice.
Almost all negotiated procedures without prior publication of a contract notice concerned disputes (eight out of ten contracts with a total value of EUR 10.9 million), which did not fall within the scope of Directive 2014/24/EU.
This also includes a large number of disputes brought before the ECJ after the first resolution procedure of the SRB.
The SRB does not therefore consider that it uses such methods ▁denselbenberm快§ig.
As regards the economic and financial assessment of two of the twelve cases in 2017, the re-implementation of a competition proved unsuccessful. Therefore, the SRB was forced to resort to negotiating procedures.
Due to the object of the contract and the necessity of the highest level of confidentiality, the contract notice was not published in accordance with the applicable rules.
3.35.16.
The online access to tender documents has been available to economic operators since the Committee was established on the SRB website and has been fully integrated into the electronic tender platform since the end of 2017.
In June 2017, the SRB requested that it be able to use the electronic submission of offers, but the Commission has not yet gained access.
The SRB has found that such publications on the EPSO website do not raise the quality or the number of applications and are also very expensive because of the mandatory translation of job advertisements.
Therefore, the SRB publishes its job advertisements preferably on its own website as well as on EU_CV online and LinkedIn and informs its stakeholders (central banks, finance ministries, national authorities, other EU agencies and permanent representations).

Note 3.36.7.
The Centre's role is to provide the EU's agencies and bodies with translation services which they require for their service, which it also performs on behalf of the EU institutions which can use the Centre's services.
The basic regulations of most agencies and bodies provide that they use the Centre's translation services.
Some agencies and institutions (which have more than half of the Centre's revenue) are increasingly resorting to in-house opportunities or other alternatives to their own.
This means, however, that the capacity of the Centre will not be used to the maximum, that there will be duplication in the development of systems and the running costs at the European level, and that the business model and the business development of the Centre could be carried out.
In 2017, an external evaluation of the adequacy of the Centre's business model was carried out.
The final evaluation report had not yet been adopted at the time of the Court's examination (268).

EN C 434/220 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.39.8. The electronic submission of tenders is currently limited to open procedures (the threshold is set by Directive 2014/24/EU on public procurement and amounted to EUR 135 000 in 2017).

EN C 434/228 Official Journal of the European Union 30.11.2018 REPLY OF THE AGENCY 3.41.9
The implementation of the targeted recruitment process, which identified weaknesses, was carried out in 2016. A reserve list was then drawn up and adopted in 2016, which was used in 2017 to provide a job offer.
The selection process of the REA for contract staff was revised and implemented later in 2017, taking into account the recommendation of the IAS of 2016.
The revised selection process for contract staff considers the demands with regard to clearly documented search criteria for living and purposeful work, as well as on admission and selection criteria.
The search criteria used by the selection committees for the viewing of living organisms are documented in their meeting minutes.
Thus, the weaknesses raised by the Court in the amended procedure have already been resolved.
In the field of procurement, REA relies on service agreements with the Commission or on Commission framework contracts.
The REA would only initiate a special procurement procedure if there is a special need not covered by these agreements or contracts.
In 2017, REA carried out only a procurement procedure for a low-value contract.
The current tools for electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders are only applicable to public procurement procedures, the size of which is above the 144,000 euro threshold. As the REA has not yet started a procurement procedure, the size of which is above this threshold, it was unable to use the tools for electronic tendering and the electronic submission of tenders in 2017.
Furthermore, the introduction of the electronic tender and the electronic submission of bids in accordance with the Commission's roadmap for all EU institutions and agencies will be mandatory at the end of 2018, and thus the implementation process only started in 2018.
The Agency is already using electronic invoicing and will also use the modules for electronic tendering and submission of tenders when a tendering procedure is launched as soon as these modules also cover medium and low-value devices.

EN 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/7 GENERAL INTRODUCTION 0.1.
The European Court of Auditors is the institution responsible for the audit of the finances of the European Union (EU) in accordance with the Treaty.
As an external auditor of the EU, we contribute to the improvement of EU financial management and at the same time act as independent guardians of the financial interests of EU citizens.
More detailed information on our work can be found in the Annual Activity Report, which is available on our website www.eca.europa.eu, as well as the special reports on EU expenditure programmes and revenue and opinions on new or amended legislation.
This is our 38th annual report on the implementation of the EU budget, which concerns the financial year 2014.
The annual report on the European Development Funds shall be presented separately.
0.3.
The EU's general budget is adopted annually by the Council and the European Parliament.
Our annual report, together with the special reports, forms the basis for the discharge procedure during which the European Parliament, following a Council recommendation, decides whether the Commission has carried out its budgetary implementation tasks satisfactorily.
At the same time as we forward our annual report to the European Parliament and to the Council, we will forward it to the national parliaments.
0.4.
The main element of our annual report is the statement on the reliability of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union and on the legality and regularity of the transactions (hereinafter referred to as ‘the regularity of the transactions').
We complement this Statement of Assurance with specific assessments of all major EU activities.
0.5.
The chapter structure now reflects the headings of the Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), which makes our report even more relevant.
The financial framework entered into force in 2014 and is intended to determine the scope and distribution of EU expenditure for the period up to 2020.
This should make it easier for readers to establish a link between the findings of our report and the relevant budgetary and accounting information.
0.6.
There are no separate annual accounts for each of the MFF headings, and therefore the conclusions presented in the context of specific assessments do not constitute audit opinions.
0.7.
This year's report is structured as follows: — Chapter 1 contains the Statement of Assurance and a summary of the results of our audit on the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of operations. — Chapter 2 presents our findings on budgetary and financial management. — Chapter 3 contributes to our strategic goal of improving the EU's public accountability. The focus is on the extent to which the performance framework enables the Commission to monitor and manage progress towards Europe 2020. — Chapter 4 contains our findings on revenue. — Chapters 5 to 9 (on MFF headings 1a, 1b, 2, 4 and 5)(1) show the results of our audits on the regularity of operations and the audit of selected systems and annual activity reports.
0.8.
The Commission's replies (or, where appropriate, the replies of other EU institutions and bodies) to our comments are contained in the report.
However, as an external auditor, it is our sole responsibility to submit our audit findings, derive conclusions from these findings and thus make an independent and impartial assessment of the reliability of the accounts and the regularity of the transactions.
(1) We do not provide specific assessments of the expenditure of the MFF headings 3 (security and citizenship) and 6 (compensation payments).

DE C 373/10 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 AUTHORISED RELIABILITY DECLARATION OF THE HOFES — REMARK OF THE INDEPENDENT ADJUSTER I. We have (a) audited the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union, the consolidated annual accounts(1) and the aggregated financial statements (2) for the financial year ending 31 December 2014 and approved by the Commission on 23 July 2015, and (b) verified the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying this annual accounts in accordance with Article 287 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (TFEU).
Management II's responsibility. In accordance with Articles 317 and 318 TFEU and the Financial Regulation, the Commission is responsible for the establishment and proper presentation of the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union on the basis of internationally recognised public sector accounting principles and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
This responsibility includes the design, establishment and maintenance of internal control structures necessary for the preparation and presentation of financial statements free of essential misrepresentations, intended or unintended.
The Commission shall bear the ultimate responsibility for the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying the accounts of the European Union (Article 317 TFEU).
Responsibility of the auditor III. Our task is to provide the European Parliament and the Council, on the basis of our examination, with a statement of the reliability of the accounts and the legality and regularity of the transactions underlying them.
We have carried out our audit in accordance with the International Standards on Auditing as well as the professional conduct requirements of IFAC and the International Standards for Supreme Audit Institutions of INTOSAI.
In accordance with these standards, we have to comply with the professional conduct requirements and to plan and carry out the audit in such a way that sufficient certainty is obtained as to whether the consolidated annual accounts of the European Union are free of material misrepresentations and the underlying transactions are lawful and proper.
IV. An audit shall include the conduct of audit proceedings in order to obtain audit evidence of the value estimates and other information contained in the consolidated financial statements and of the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions.
The choice of audit acts shall be at the discretion of the examiner, including the assessment of the risks of material — intentional or unintended — misrepresentation in the consolidated annual accounts and of material — intentional or unintended — non-compliance with European Union legislation in the underlying transactions.
In assessing these risks, the auditor shall take into account all internal controls relevant for the preparation and proper presentation of the consolidated annual accounts and the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions in order to plan audit operations that are appropriate in the circumstances but not with the aim of delivering an audit opinion on the effectiveness of the internal control system.
An audit shall also include an assessment of the adequacy of the accounting methods used, the representativeness of the estimated values in the accounting and the overall presentation of the consolidated annual accounts.
V. In the field of revenue, we use the macroeconomic aggregates relevant for their calculation as the starting point for our assessment of own resources based on VAT and on gross national income, and evaluate the Commission's systems for the processing of these data until the contributions of the Member States are received and until they are declared in the consolidated annual accounts.
In the area of traditional own resources, we look at the accounts of the customs authorities and analyse the tax flows until they are received by the Commission and until the amounts are recorded in the accounts.
1. The consolidated financial statements shall include the balance sheet, the profit and loss account, the cash flow account, the changes in net assets, and a summary of key accounting rules and other explanatory notes (including segment reporting).
DE 10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/11 VI. In the area of expenditure, we will review the payment transactions after the expenditure has been incurred, recorded and accepted.This examination will take place on all types of payments, except advances, (including payments for the acquisition of assets) only after they have been made.
Advance payments shall be examined if the beneficiary provides or has to provide proof of their proper use and if the advance is or can be recovered.
VII. We believe that the audit evidence obtained is sufficient and appropriate to serve as the basis for our audit opinions.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/13 DE NOTES OF THE HOFE INTRODUCTION EU expenditure is an important tool for achieving policy objectives 1.1.
EU expenditure is an important instrument for achieving policy objectives.
Other important instruments include legislation, the free movement of goods, services and capital and the free movement of persons throughout the Union.
On average, EU expenditure amounts to 1.9% of total government expenditure in the EU Member States (see Figure 1.1).
In accordance with the Treaty, our role is, inter alia, to assess whether the use of the EU budget is in line with relevant laws and other legislation; — to give our opinion on the EU's annual accounts; — to report on the economy, efficiency and effectiveness (4) of EU expenditure; — to submit opinions on legislative proposals with financial implications.
With our audit work to support the Statement of Assurance, we are fulfilling the first and second of these objectives.
This audit work allows us to identify risks that are detrimental to economy, efficiency and effectiveness.
It also provides an important input into the opinions we make on proposed financial regulations.
(4) In Article 30(2) of Regulation (EU, Euratom) No 966/2012 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 25 October 2012 on the Financial Regulation applicable to the general budget of the Union (OJ L 288, 17.10.2012, p.
‘The principle of economy requires that the resources used by the institution concerned in its activities are made available at the right time, in sufficient quantity and quality, and at the lowest possible cost.
The principle of economic efficiency concerns the optimal relationship between the resources used and the results achieved.
The principle of effectiveness concerns the achievement of certain set objectives and the desired results.

General government expenditure (Eurostat — General government financial statistics — General government revenue, expenditure and main aggregates — General government expenditure 2014) (http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/web/government-finance-statistics/data/database).
For country codes, see Annex 1.5.

Points affecting the annual accounts 1.8.

OBSERVATIONS OF THE COURT 1.11.
Overall, the audit results have remained relatively stable over the last three years at a level well above our benchmark for materiality (see Figure 1.2).
REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 1.11.
The Commission notes that the error rate reported by the Court is an annual estimate which takes account of the accounting corrections of project expenditure made before the Court's audit is announced.
The Commission notes that it is bound by the Financial Regulation, which lays down in Article 32(2)(e), that its internal control system should ensure, inter alia, ‘a fair treatment of the risks related to the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions taking into account the multi-annual nature of the programmes and the nature of the payments concerned'.
In the 2014 synthesis report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of correction mechanisms to be EUR 2.7 billion, representing 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
The Commission will continue to exercise its monitoring role by making financial corrections and recoveries at a level equivalent to the level of irregularities and shortcomings identified throughout the period and also after the closure of the programmes.

COMMENTS FROM THE COURT 1.12.
Expenditure in the EU consists primarily of two types of expenditure programmes with very different risk patterns (12): — programmes based on payment entitlements, where payment depends on whether certain conditions are met; such programmes include scholarships for students and research grants (Chapter 5), direct aid to farmers (Chapter 7), direct budget support(13) (Chapter 8) and salaries and pensions (Chapter 9); — reimbursement schemes for which the EU reimburses eligible costs for eligible activities, such schemes cover research projects (Chapter 5), schemes for investments in regional and rural development (Chapters 6 and 7), training programmes (Chapter 6) and development projects (Chapter 8).
(12) Paragraphs 1.20-1.22 will cover these different risks in more detail.
(13) Budget support payments are a contribution to the general budget of a State or to the resources allocated by it to a specific policy or objective (see also paragraphs 8.7 and 8.8).
THE HOFE'S COMMENTS A new audit approach...
For 2014, we have redesigned our approach to quantify serious breaches of procurement rules.
This approach clarifies how we assess the impact of these infringements.
In particular, we have introduced a proportional approach to the calculation of errors related to the modification of contracts.
1.14.
In order to ensure comparability of the results presented in this report, we have adjusted the figures for 2012 and 2013 in Table 1.1 and in Figures 1.2, 1.3, 1.4, 1.5 and 1.6 in line with this new approach.
Annex 1.4 provides the unadjusted historical data on the estimated error rates for the period 2009-2013.
As part of this adjustment, the estimated overall error rate was reduced by 0,2 % in 2013 and by 0,3 % in 2012.
The adjustment does not affect the conclusions that we reached with regard to those years, and it remains a clearly significant error rate.
1.15.
In 2015, we will adapt our approach to cross compliance with the revised framework for the common agricultural policy.
While we will continue to report on the information provided by the Commission on cross-compliance, this element will no longer be the subject of our audit proceedings.
This year we found numerous cross-compliance errors with regard to one in four of the farms visited.
The share of these errors in our estimated total error rate is 0.2 percentage points (2013: 0.2)(14) and the error rate for the chapter ‘Natural resources decent 0.6 percentage points (2013: 0.5).
The Commission welcomes the change in the Court's approach from 2015.
For 2014, it reiterates its view that cross-compliance infringements do not affect the eligibility conditions for payments (see the Commission's reply to point 7.7).

C 373/24 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 COMMISSION RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE HOFES Expenditure type and error rates are closely related to 1.20.
We have analysed the relationship between the type of expenditure and the risk of error.
The extent to which the correct calculation of payments to beneficiaries depends on information provided by beneficiaries themselves is characteristic of EU expenditure.
This applies to the largest category of expenditure schemes based on payment entitlements: land-related aid paid to farmers.
This is of particular importance in the area of reimbursement schemes: beneficiaries must provide information in their application to show that they are participating in an eligible action and that they have incurred costs that may be eligible for reimbursement.
All types of management are affected (15).

The size of the circles in this figure represents the respective share of total expenditure, with their respective positioning along the 45-degree line indicating the corresponding estimated error rate; their color indicates whether they are claims-based or reimbursement-based expenditures.

1.20.
The integrated management and control system (InVeKoS), which includes the Land Parcel Identification System (LPIS), contributes significantly to avoiding errors and reducing the error rate (see point 7.32).
LPIS is established and maintained by the national authorities.
Payments to final beneficiaries are only possible after their claim has been compared with the data available in the area identification system.
The error rate for land-related aid is lower than for all other types of aid under shared management, thanks to LPIS.

C 373/26 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES Results in the various areas of expenditure show different patterns of error 1.23. "Competitiveness (Chapter 5): The estimated error rate is 5.6%, higher than the corresponding results for 2013 (4.0%(17). The majority of expenditure is on a reimbursement basis, and the errors in this area mainly reflect the different categories of ineligible costs (mainly personnel costs, other direct costs and indirect costs).
1.24. ‘Cohesion' (Chapter 6): The estimated error rate is 5.7%, exceeding the corresponding results for 2013 (5.3% (17)).
Almost all expenditure in this area is paid in the form of reimbursement.
The main causes of error include serious infringements of procurement rules (around half of the estimated error rate), followed by ineligible costs in declarations of expenditure (more than a quarter of the estimated error rate).
Infringements of State aid rules and ineligible projects constitute the remaining part of the errors.
1.25. ‘Natural resources' (Chapter 7): The estimated error rate is 3.6%, below the corresponding results for 2013 (4.4 % (17).
The European Agricultural Guarantee Fund (EAGF) accounts for more than three quarters of expenditure in this area, and this fund is less prone to error than the rural development sub-sector, for which we have long seen high error rates, especially for expenditure incurred on the basis of reimbursement.
Overall, farmers contributed about one third of the estimated error rate by over-abundance of land or number of animals.
Errors related to non-eligible beneficiaries, activities or expenditure accounted for the second highest proportion (about a quarter of the estimated error rate).
Cross compliance infringements (one sixth) and administrative errors (one sixth) account for the remaining major shares.

C 373/28 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES Box 1.1 — Example of errors in the reimbursement of costs for a project under the MFF heading 3 "Security and citizenship of the Union" The subject of our sample was a payment by the Commission to a beneficiary, who was working as coordinator of a cooperation project under the "Fundamental Rights and Citizenship of the Union" programme.
The beneficiary public body assigned two permanent staff (officials) half-days to the project and charged part of its salaries in the project cost statement.
Deputised staff will only cause additional costs if more staff has to be recruited to replace officials in their usual work, and will actually incur costs.
Since the beneficiary institution has not made provision for the replacement of officials, these costs are not eligible.
Overall, the ineligible costs reported by the beneficiary institution amounted to EUR 58 000 of the total cost invoiced in the amount of EUR 237 000.
We identified ineligible costs reimbursed by the Commission in eight of the 25 projects covered by the sample for the MFF heading 3.
Box 1.1 — Examples of errors in the reimbursement of costs for a project under the MFF heading 3 'Security and Citizenship' The Commission was aware of the difficulties encountered by public bodies in complying with the eligibility rules applicable to staff costs for public bodies (who commission other personnel to replace the official staff in their usual activities).
For this reason, the Commission amended from 2011 the eligibility rules applicable to staff of public bodies, taking advantage of the flexibility provided for in the implementing rules of the Financial Regulation.
Therefore, the ineligible costs identified by the Court in the grant mentioned above (personnel costs for staff in public bodies that do not assign a replacement) would now be considered eligible.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/29 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES There are many forms of corrective action with different effects 1.30.
Our study of "mistakes and corrections" aims to shed light on the complex mechanisms of implementing and recording corrective actions and to explain the various ways in which these mechanisms can enable our audit work to be carried out.
In some areas of expenditure, new instruments will be available to the Commission when expenditure for the new programming period is made available.
Corrective measures 1.31.
We seek to take account of corrective measures taken by the Member States and the Commission in the run-up to payment or our investigation.
We also take note of corrections that take place after our audit announcement. However, we cannot reduce the estimated error rate whenever the audit itself triggers the corrective action (24).
We shall review the application of these corrections (including recovery by beneficiaries and correction at project level) and, where appropriate, adjust the calculation of the error rate.
However, the impact of the corrective measures varies significantly depending on the expenditure area and the corrective action.
1.32.
The Commission and the authorities of the Member States had applied corrective measures for 24 of the transactions examined in a sample in 2014, which had a direct impact on the operation concerned and were relevant to our calculations.
These corrective measures resulted in a reduction of our estimated error rate by 1.1 percentage points (2013: 1.6 percentage points), which is approximately EUR 1.6 billion.
Changes in the number of transactions concerned and the impact on our estimated error rate are no indication that the corrective measures are more or less effective: since these measures apply to a relatively small proportion of our sample, fluctuations are expected from year to year.
1.30.
The Commission considers that the Court's annual representative error rate should be considered in relation to the corrective capacity of the Commission in the various annual activity reports and the synthesis report.
The Financial Regulation requires appropriate consideration of the risks associated with the legality and regularity of the underlying transactions, taking into account the multi-annual nature of the control systems and the nature of the payments.
1.31.
Joint response to paragraphs 1.31 and 1.32: In the 2014 synthesis report (COM(2015) 279 final), the Commission estimated the future impact of correction mechanisms to be EUR 2.7 billion, representing 1.9% of payments from the EU budget.
For a breakdown of the figures by policy area, see Table 1 in the synthesis report.
The Commission underlines that all types of financial corrections and recoveries exclude illegitimate expenditure from the reimbursement from the EU budget (see explanatory note 6 on the financial statements).
(24) See points 1.19-1.37 of the Annual Report for the financial year 2012.
The Commission uses the terms "financial corrections" and "recoveries" to cover a wide range of corrective measures, both before and after the Commission's action (or reimbursement) of expenditure.
1.34.
Note 6.2.2 to the financial statements shows a total amount of EUR 3285 million for corrective actions in 2014.
Figure 1.7 shows how we classify the corrections made at the various stages of the expenditure cycle.

NOTES OF THE HOF 1.35.
The corrective measures discussed in this section of the annual report shall also include the work of Member States' authorities, as well as the recoveries carried out by national authorities and the Commission.
C 373/32 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES The impact of corrective measures on the time when the Commission accepts expenditure is largely tangible 1.36.
All relevant sectoral regulations in the area of shared management shall include rules on primary controls by national authorities or reductions in the amounts claimed by the final beneficiaries before the expenditure is certified.
Sometimes the national authorities also agree to reduce or delete certain costs which appear constantly in the declarations due to errors with long-term implications (such as ongoing payments under a contract where there is an error in the procurement rules).
Such adjustments may have a measurable impact on the amount of refund requested for individual projects or on the aid paid to individual farmers, and the correction will then help to reduce our estimated error rate.
1.37.
In the field of direct and indirect management, the ‘recoveries' covered by the Commission include the deduction of ineligible amounts from cost applications before the payment is authorised.
The eligibility of the amounts is determined by examination of the file of the available documents or by the results of the checks carried out (see also Figure 1.7).
This also allows us to reduce our estimated error rate.
Conformity decisions ("financial corrections" in the agricultural sector) are often taken on a flat-rate basis.
In general, they relate more to system deficiencies than to errors at the level of the final beneficiaries.
In the rarest cases, they result in the recovery of the farmers concerned.
Such corrective measures are an incentive for Member States to improve their management and control systems.
They contribute to the legality and regularity of operations at the level of the final beneficiaries if they lead to constant improvements in the cost statements accepted by the paying agencies (see boxes 1.2 and 1.3).
The Commission services also carry out recovery ‘at source' by deducting non-eligible expenditure (as determined in previous or current cost statements) from payments made.
1.38.
Financial corrections made by the Commission on agricultural expenditure are designed to protect the EU budget and are imposed on the Member States.
They do not directly result in the recovery of farmers, since the Commission does not pay the final beneficiaries directly but reimbursement of payments made by Member States to farmers.
However, if these incorrect payments are identifiable as a result of the conformity clearance procedure, the Commission would expect Member States to pursue them by means of recovery measures against the beneficiaries.
See answer to Box 1.3.
Payers implement conformity decisions by reducing future requests for reimbursement by the Commission for payments to farmers.
The Commission shall keep the full amount paid out to farmers as expenditure, i.e. the adjustment shall not entail a reduction in the amount of the payments recorded.
Instead, the difference between payments to farmers and refunds to the paying agencies is recorded as assigned revenue available to finance agricultural expenditure (26).
More than two thirds of the ‘financial corrections' covered in the cohesion area in 2014 are to replace new expenditure,...
1.40.
In the cohesion field, ‘financial corrections' are cases where more than two-thirds of the total amount covered is spent by the authorities in the Member States and is replaced by new expenditure.
In some cases, ‘takebacks' do not recognise any concrete projects as being withdrawn.
Instead, Member States report additional projects and thus receive a de facto lower co-financing rate.
1.40. The Commission considers that any financial corrections, including those allowing Member States to contribute new projects and new expenditure to re-use the corrected amounts, protect the EU budget from unlawful expenditure and encourage Member States to recover from beneficiaries (and thus contribute to improving management and control systems).
However, the deterrent effect of net financial corrections, where Member States are unable to reuse the corrected and recovered amounts and thus lose funds, is certainly higher.
(26) For example, if an agricultural paying agency is subject to a 5% financial correction and makes payments of EUR 100 million to farmers, the Commission will reimburse it EUR 95 million, but the Commission will record expenditure of EUR 100 million which will be offset by assigned revenue of EUR 5 million.
C 373/34 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS OF THE COURT... while net corrections are less frequent 1.41.
If replacement is not possible, the corrections for the Member State concerned will result in a loss of EU funds(27), which, although relatively rare, may occur if Member States are unable to submit sufficient eligible expenditure and if a replacement is no longer possible (28) or permitted (29).
The Commission expects that, as a result of amendments to the legislation, net corrections will be applied more widely in the future.
Following the example of agriculture, the legislator has decided to apply a similar mechanism of net financial corrections for the 2014-2020 programming period to cohesion policy.
This will give Member States an additional incentive to prevent or detect and remedy serious deficiencies in the management and control systems before the financial statements are sent to the Commission.
Otherwise, and if serious deficiencies continue to be identified by the Commission or the Court after the financial statements have been sent, the Commission must make net financial corrections under the conditions laid down in the relevant regulations, which means that the resources for the Member State are lost.
The Commission also considers that, under shared management, all financial corrections and recoveries have a negative impact on national budgets irrespective of the method of implementation.
In order to avoid a loss of EU funding, the Member State must replace non-eligible expenditure with additional eligible operations.
This means that the Member State with its national budget must bear the financial consequences of the loss of EU co-financing of expenditure deemed to be ineligible, unless it recovers the amounts from each beneficiary.
(27) Either as a reduction in payments or as a return to the EU budget leading to assigned revenue (see Figure 2.2).
(28) After completion of the programmes.
(29) In the event of disagreement between Member States and the Commission (see point 1.25(b) of the 2012 annual report).
10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION C 373/35 DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES In 2014, the Commission and Member States applied all these forms of corrective measures 1.42.
Box 1.2-1.4 illustrates different types and impacts of corrective measures. Box 1.2 — Example of improvement of management and control systems — Greece: adjustment of the area identification system The Commission has taken measures to ensure the improvement of the system for identifying agricultural parcels (LPIS) serving as a basis for payments to agricultural holdings, such as under the single payment scheme (the largest single EU expenditure scheme).
This process took place at different stages and resulted in the ‘Eligible permanent pasture' covered by the Greek LPIS, falling from 3.6 million hectares in 2012 to 1.5 million hectares in October 2014.
Non-legislative applications for "permanent grassland" that are not eligible for EU aid have been a key factor in our estimated error rate for "natural resources" for several years.
We took into account the impact of adjustments in respect of individual payments made to final beneficiaries, which were the subject of our sample of operations of the EAGF and the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development (EAFRD).
A further effect is that the paying agency rejected a large number of non-eligible applications, which resulted in the corresponding expenditure falling out of our sample.
Box 1.2 — Example of improving management and control systems — Greece: cleaning up the area identification system Other examples of the positive impact of action plans are given by the Court in Chapter 7.
Action plans are implemented whenever deemed necessary and the Commission closely monitors their implementation and reports on the corrective actions taken in the annual activity report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development.
The area identification system shall prevent beneficiaries from claiming claims for non-existent land or non-compliance with the eligibility conditions, or for land for which claims have already been made by another beneficiary.
If properly implemented, it is a very effective tool to reduce the error rate.
It covers 75% of CAP expenditure.
The 2014 Annual Activity Report of the Directorate-General for Agriculture and Rural Development shows that the error rates for area-related payments are lower than for other measures.
C 373/36 The Official Journal of the European Union REPLY OF THE COMMISSION 10.11.2015 DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES Box 1.3 — Example of corrections arising from conformity clearance procedures (30) — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers In 2014, France accepted an adjustment of EUR 1.1 billion (984 million for the EAGF and EUR 94 million for the EAFRD)(31).
The national authorities stated that this would have no impact on farmers and that the amount would be denied from the national budget.
In previous annual reports, we pointed out that such an approach would not encourage beneficiaries to correct errors (32).
The main reasons for the correction were deficiencies in LPIS/GIS (695 million euros) and the overshoot of the ceiling for payment entitlements, resulting in excessive payments to farmers (141 million euros).
Another reason was, albeit to a lesser extent, violations of the cross compliance obligation of timely notification of movements of animals (123 million euros).
All these reasons are linked to payments made between 2009 and 2013.
No adjustment was made for 2014, and the non-compliance with the ceiling for payment entitlements and the non-eligible areas covered by the LPIS of France contributed 0.3 percentage points to our estimated error rate for "Natural Resources" this year.
Box 1.3 — Example of adjustments resulting from conformity clearance procedures — Conformity Decision 47 and its consequences for French farmers Under shared management, Member States are responsible for ensuring that the control systems function properly.
The EUR 1.1 billion financial correction will be repaid to the EU budget in three annual instalments (2015, 2016 and 2017).
The Commission notes that the nature of the conformity clearance procedure, which applies ex-post, after the clearance of the accounts of the year and after a counter-dicatory phase in which the Member State concerned can present its own reasoning and calculation, has made it very rare that a financial correction is already decided in the following year of the expenditure in question.
An ongoing conformity clearance procedure will protect the EU budget for 2014.
Box 1.4 — Example of corrections resulting in additional expenditure: ESF — Romania In our annual reports on the financial years 2012 and 2013, we pointed out corrective measures in Romania.
In 2013, we were able to reduce our estimated error rate in relation to a number of Romanian projects of the European Social Fund (ESF), as national authorities had identified the impact of the corrections at project level.
This was also the case in 2014.
In some of the projects we study, there are still errors due to problems not covered by the corrections.
In its Annual Activity Report for 2014, the Directorate-General for Employment, Social Affairs and Inclusion (DG EMPL) points out that it continues to follow the implementation of the agreed action plan.
The financial corrections that have been made do not necessarily mean that Romania will receive less EU funding, since Member States can make use of the possibility of claiming a larger amount of expenditure (33).
(30) A multi-year procedure allowing for the recovery of amounts paid to Member States where such payments have been in breach of EU rules or where there are deficiencies in the Member State's management and control systems.

10.11.2015 Official Journal of the European Union C 373/37 REPLY OF THE COMMISSION OF THE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES In its reporting on corrective measures, the Commission does not always quantify their different impacts,...
1.43.
Note 6 on the financial statements is to a large extent a voluntary disclosure of information not required under the accounting rules.
A significant part of this information does not originate from accounting systems.
The explanatory note gives a description of the different effects of the different corrective adjustments on the EU budget, but not always in quantified form.... and further improvements would allow a better analysis 1.44.
The Commission's capacity to improve the quality of expenditure is linked not only to the amounts concerned but also to their impact.
A rigorous assessment of the effects of corrective measures requires better information on the nature of the corrected error and on the way in which corrections are made (34).
When assessing the impact of their corrective action, the relevant Directorates-General of the Commission shall make the necessary adjustments to the figures set out in Explanatory Note 6 (see point 1.55).
The Commission's synthesis report confirms major errors in operations 1.45.
Each Directorate-General of the Commission shall draw up an annual activity report.
This report shall include — a report on the achievement of the main policy objectives (revealed in Chapter 3), — a management report from the Director-General to the College of Commissioners and — a statement by the Director-General to ensure that the financial information contained in the report is properly presented and that the transactions falling within his/her area of responsibility are lawful and proper.
1.43.
The legislator has provided the Commission with the instrument of financial corrections to ensure that illegitimate expenditure is not financed from the EU budget.
These financial corrections relate mainly to system deficiencies which lead to a risk of error.
It is the responsibility of the Member States and not of the Commission to identify incorrect amounts and recover them from the beneficiaries.
If this does not happen, EU funds will be replaced by national funds, as national budgets will have to bear the burden of financial corrections.
1.44.
Several services have properly adjusted their figures on the protection of the EU budget included in Note 6 in order to provide an estimate of future corrections with regard to their specific circumstances.
(34) See points 1.13-1.15 of the Annual Report for the financial year 2013.
C 373/38 Official Journal of the European Union 10.11.2015 DE COMMENTS FROM THE HOFES 1.46. The synthesis report contains a summary of this information and a statement that, with the adoption of the synthesis report, the Commission assumes overall political responsibility for the management of the EU budget.
1.47.
This section of the chapter contains the results of our analysis of the Annual Activity Reports of the Directorates-General and of the Commission's Synthesis Report(35).
The focus is on the consistency and appropriateness of the Commission's estimates in relation to — the error rate at the time of the Commission's reimbursement or payment of own expenditure (the Commission refers here to ‘risk amount'), — the extent to which errors are remedied by subsequent corrections (the Commission refers here to its ‘correction capacity' or ‘estimated future corrections' (36)).
The Directors-General shall report on regularity 1.48 annually.
If the Directors-General are unable to guarantee a significant part of expenditure, they have a reservation (see Box 1.5).
The Director-Generals should proceed in such a way when — an event which has a serious impact on the reputation of the Commission has occurred or — the impact of the estimated error rates, less financial corrections already made and recoveries, is still essential.
(35) The Commission's synthesis report and annual activity reports can be found on the Commission's website: Synthesis report: http://ec.europa.eu/atwork/planning-and-preparing/synthesis-report/index_en.htm, Annual activity reports: http://ec.europa.eu/atwork/synthesis/aar/index_en.htm.
(36) See synthesis report, footnotes 10 and 13, pages 14 and 15.

THE COMMENTS OF THE COURT 1.50.
In accordance with the request of the discharge authority, the Commission further developed in 2014 its internal guidance (45) on the presentation of information in Annual Activity Reports.
The Directors-General are now expected to present an "average detected error rate" (46).
The application of this error rate to the total payments of the year leads to the calculation of the ‘risk amount'(47).
The synthesis report shows this amount together with the estimation of the future correction capacity of ex post controls carried out by the Commission.
1.51.
In the 2014 synthesis report, the Commission reports the ‘risk amount' as a range of EUR 3.7 to 5 billion.
This represents between 2,6 % and 3,5 % of the payments for 2014(48) covered by the synthesis report.
These figures show that total expenditure is substantially affected by errors.... but points to the estimated impact of future corrections 1.52.
The 2014 synthesis report provides an estimated total amount of estimated future corrections (correction capacity).
Based on the corrections recorded over the last six years(49), the Commission estimates that in the coming years it will be able to "identify and correct errors of around EUR 2700 million in total" (50).
(45) Standing Instructions for the 2014 Annual Activity Reports (SEC(2014) 553).
(46) This is the detected or estimated error rate at the time of payment (not the residual error rate), i.e. without adjustment due to errors corrected afterwards.
